description:
Wow, the Venezuelan arepa I had was not only delicious but surprisingly filling despite its' small stature. 

I chose the yellow arepa and it was perfectly crisp on the outside with a soft warm interior. To fill the amazing maize pocket I selected the pulled pork,, aioli, avocado trio. I could eat it again and again it was that incredibly edible. And the yucca fries were a godsend to my mouth! I'm a sauce girl and they had several amazing ones to drench all your tasty morsels with. Great vegetarian friendly options as well. You've gotta check this spot out!
author: Lo R.

description:
We had an arepa trio which included a beef, pork and chicken arepa. They were...good.  You could taste that this was real food and it had a home-cooked feeling of quality to it.

But in terms of flavor nothing was really great. I mean for all the yummy noises and flavor-town faces Guy Fieri makes on their episode of Diners, Drive-ins, and Dives, my expectations were much MUCH higher.

We didn't add any of the sauces to our arepas because the squeeze bottles were crusted over and looked like they might give us food poisoning. That was a great shame because I'm guessing those sauces were probably pretty damn tasty and would have elevated the arepas.
author: Amy B.

description:
Oh my god. I wish there was a location in SoCal! The sauces were amazing and the meat was tender and flavorful. I love the idea of the corn pocket. The plantains were cooked perfectly. The yuca fries were so unique. It was nice and crispy on the outside and the texture inside was nice and smooth like a potato. 

I really have nothing to complain about.
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
Decided to try Pica Pica Arepa as part two of our weekly office lunch. Our delivery order arrived via Caviar last Friday, June 29th around 12:30pm.

*Tres Empanadas:Served with guasacaca sauce (avocado dipping sauce), Queso ($7.50)
*Shrimp Ceviche: With plantain chips ($9.50)

Our orders were a little confusing as I don't think anything was labeled. Also, a coworker ordered a side of plantain chips so we figured the side that showed up was hers. After recapping the food above, I discovered my ceviche came with chips, so they actually forgot hers. At least I'm assuming the chips were mine and not the side she ordered. I wouldn't have ate them anyways, but they got our order wrong. It was also not packed well as the liquid from my ceviche got everywhere. If someone had a seafood allergy, they would not have been able to eat their dish.  Moving on to the food...

The ceviche was a good size. A nice amount of shrimp, avocado, etc. It was heavy on the tomato which I didn't prefer. And it was missing some acidity to balance it all out. I tried one of the empanadas my coworker ordered and they were not the normal empanadas I'm used to. There was no crust. It was basically like eating a smushed mozzarella stick. I didn't mind as I adore mozzerella sticks, but if you want that pie like crust, you will not find it here.

The food overall was average, but subtracting a star for the delivery situation. Maybe everything is better in house, but I found myself wanting more.
author: Elena N.

description:
I tried Pica Pica Arepa Kitchen on the recommendation of a friend who I was meeting in Mission. I've had arepa's only a couple of times before so I was excited to try this place. It is located on Valencia & 15th and I was able to find parking on 15th a couple of blocks down. After going through the menu, I decided to get the Sweet Yellow Arepa with the shredded beef Pabellon filling ($11.50) to-go. After ordering it was a quick 10-minute wait and I was on my way.

I got a small desert/snack size container with the arepa. It was a decent sized corn pocket which had become soggy. It had a nice sweet tinge which balanced the taste of the shredded beef perfectly. Unfortunately, the beef was a little chewy. It also two fried plantains that were way too oily for my taste. Overall, I thought this was passable. My memories of Arepas is that they are crispy/crunchy on the outside and juicy on the inside. Maybe the drive home messed all this up.

Price wise it was pretty high for the quality and service size. If you are a light eater a single Arepa may be enough but most would need either the combo or a side of fries for a complete meal. If I'm in the area I'll give them another try but given what I got I'm not in a hurry to do that.
author: Ahmad J.

description:
3.5/5
Gawd I love arepas and I've been dying to give this spot a try. Finally had a chance and came by on a Sunday around noon for lunch with a group of friends. The line wasn't too long but the space is very cramped and we had a fight for about 15 minutes (after we got our food) to snag one of the few larger tables near the door. I definitely say this is an easier place to go to alone for a quick takeout meal. There's some bar seating but it runs parallel to the line and can get really cramped and uncomfortable. Because of how long the lines were there weren't any employees cleaning the tables which was unpleasant since the table before us left a mess but we didn't want to bother the employee who looked completely swamped at the register.

Otherwise service was fine and the food came out fairly quickly and I appreciate how clean and straightforward their menu is. Between our group we ordered a variety of arepas with both white and yellow corn and a variety of meats. We also got a side of garlic Yuca fries and their nachos pica pica. 

1) Arepas: For my meal I got the blackened beef asado in a sweet yellow arepa. It came with a pleasantly light slaw on the side that pairs well with the meat. The arepa itself was really dry for the most part. I had a hard time chewing through it and it had very little flavor. The meat had juices flowing but texture-wise was stringy and slightly dry as well. The cheese and slaw were the main saviors. A bit pricy at over $10 (2.75/5)

2) Garlic Yucca Fries: The garlic yucca fries were decent at first but once they weren't piping hot they revert to a stale-ish sawdusty texture. They had a thick crunch and a fluffy but dry starchy texture inside. I love the garlic on top and wish there was more. The fries became more of an aioli delivery vehicle for me after a while. (3.25/5)

3) Pica Pica Nachos: The best part of the meal were definitely the nachos. Not exactly the most traditional dish but they're delicious and I don't care. I love taro chips and these were done very well. Large, evenly cooked, thin crisp chips stacked high with toppings. The only downfall of the dish was the pork which was flavorful but once again dry. (4.25/5)

Overall, this wasn't the arepa heaven I was looking for. I may give the arepas another shot while I get more nachos though.
author: Vivian C.

description:
Pica Pica has a pica my heart... hahaahah

I've walked past this place on countless treks to the Mission, and I was so excited when my boyfriend said he was in the mood for tortillas. Forget tortillas - how about arepas??? 

It wasn't too busy inside around 3pm on a Sunday, and we took our time assessing our options from the menu before settling on the 3 small arepas sample platter. There are a variety of fillings, but we chose the Spicy Chicken, Asado Negro, and vegan options.

Even before our arepas arrived, I was already so excited by the number of sauces that this place offered. There were three types of aioli-type sauces, as well as a hot (?) sauce in big glass bottles. After lusting over other people's arepas, which were gaping open and showing the treasures within, we finally got our order. The arepas came looking adorably small but stuffed with fat plantains and meat, along with a side of slaw. 

Pro tip: try everything separately before you have it all together! Only then will you get that crumbliness of the cornmeal wrap, the sweet juiciness of the plantain, and the smokiness of the meat... And there are so many more fillings and sides to try, along with the sweet corn tortillas that they also offer!

I have now made it my mission to get this place to cater at our next work event.
author: Sophie W.

description:
I would recommend the sweet yellow Vegetarian Arepa and Crispy Chicken Arepa

The Food is sweet, and really flavorful. The chicken in crispy chicken Arepa was  well cooked and tender, and so was the grilled tofu in the vegetarian Arepa

I also tried the coconut lime drink, and loved it
author: Amar P.

description: My first time trying arepas and Yuca fries they were decent a little overprice for what it really is. The yuca fries come with a green sauce that was really good the sauces at  the table are very bland.Also come in here at 5:50 and asked for the happy hour special with my friend the cashier asked the person in charge how to key it in then she told me that there was no such a thing. Then  I told her about the adverstiment on Yelp that it was until six she then proceed to tell me it lock it five minutes before six but it was 5:52. Anyways this place is something to try is unique in SF since we don't have many Venezuelan food options.
author: Julia D.

description:
When I'm in the mission, I have to stop here. In fact, I prefer this over the many other delicious food options the mission offers (tacos, burritos). 

If you have never had an arepa, it's basically like a giant taco, but instead of a thin tortilla, it's in a deliciously sweet and thick corn tortilla. The pulled pork pernil is my favorite- it's chock-full of tender pulled pork, their delicious spicy sauces, and a large helping of avocado. One was enough for me, they're very large and surprisingly filing!
author: Josephine M.

description:
Ambiance and wait staff: this place is tiny, you order at the counter, pay, take a number and then find a seat, it is pretty tricky to go with a large group, since there's not a lot of seats.. somehow the group of 10 that I went with ended up being able to sit together! This place was on food network and is gluten free, and is really good! The employees are nice and the decor is very eclectic and bright! 

Food: I ordered an arepa, the vegetarian... it was really tasty! I chose the sweet corn arepa. It was a little crumbly and kinda fell apart, which was messy, but I used a fork and knife to eat the rest!! We also ordered an arepa with fried chicken, which was really good too ! We got yucca fries and nachos to share, both were great! There are 2 sauces on the tables, which are both awesome! One is more mayo based which I loved ! And the other one was a little spicy ! The empanadas were delicious as well! 

I would definitely come back here if and when I head back to San Fran! 

Happy Eating 
Nicole
author: Nicole S.

description:
Solid arepas. 

First time trying this arepas location. My friend had really good arepas in the past but he was a little hesitant at first. In the end, he thought they were really good. My friends and I got a couple of tasters to try a variety of options. The beef, pork and crispy chicken, and a shrimp one. All of them easily met our expectations! They had a couple of different sauces that were so enjoyable. The two creamy sauces were the best! The service was good. We came in on Saturday for lunch and it wasn't busy. I highly recommend for anyone in the area!
author: Katrine U.

description:
Came in on a Saturday afternoon, and it was busy but not so busy you couldn't get a seat. This being our first visit here, we wanted to try a bit of all the meats they had to offer so we opted for:

Arepa Trio Taster:
- Shredded beef pabellon was tasty, good amount of meat and the 
   plantain added a nice sweetness to it
- Crispy chicken was by far my favorite, it was a lighter flavor I think from 
   the aoili and jicama
- Pulled pork was my least favorite, it was a bit dry and just meh in flavor

Ceviche: served with plantain chips and taro chips; came with two types, a classic Peruvian ceviche and a Mexican? style ceviche. I'm not really sure if I classified that right, but I did appreciate the variety given. I liked the classic one more, it was super acidic (the way I like it). The bf liked the tomato-y Mexican one more because the flavors were more mild. Overall, I really enjoyed this!

Garlic Yuca Fries: good, but not great. 

Sangria: Mmm so good! It was refreshing, yet also packs a punch! Loved it.

Overall, would come back again.
author: Evee N.

description:
Yes, 11$ sounds like a lot for one arepa. But wait til you try it...it's delicious! That price is fair for the freshness, flavor, and size. It's so filling. I almost couldn't finish the yuca fries after eating the whole arepa. The pulled pork was my meat of choice. The meat was very tender. The avocado was a nice refreshing addition. The arepa was nice and crisp on the outside. The sauces on the table were also great. Loved the orange one, had a spicy kick.

The yuca fries were perfectly crisp and the green sauce it's paired with mmmm... I'm at a loss for words...
author: Mary R.

description:
I was really looking forward to trying them a third time but first time in a different location while in San Francisco.   

I would always order their Pavellon, sorry not sure of the spelling and remember it completely different from what I was served here.  First it was twice as much as I have ever paid for this previously and it was smaller skimpier and the taste was so not there. 

Service was also not great, and it wasn't busy but apparently it may have been a short while ago as there was nowhere to sit as the few table that exist were not bused.  Never again!
author: Sylvia Q.

description:
I've had home made arepas before and the intricate layers of flavor, textures and colors of these Arepas will not disappoint! 

I had the vegetarian arepa with pickled jicama added on. It was a little messy to eat, BUT it was amazing!!! 

This place is a must and their versatile menu can accommodate to a variety of palates and dietary restrictions.
author: Jackie Z.

description:
The veggie Arepa I had was good, not the best I've had, but nothing to complain about.  I was thinking at that point "this is a place I'll know about but not put on my list of 'must eats' when I visit SF."  (yes, I really thought that)

But then I tried my Yuca fries!
WOW - can these really be the same stuff as all other Yuca fries that I've had before?  Can I ever go back to those other fries again?

I'm sold!

The portion of fries were a good value: not large but inexpensive enough that you can buy more, which I did.  I wished that the hotel I was going to had a microwave so that I could bring more with me, but that was just an excuse to pass by again at the end of my trip!
author: Raymond B.

description: Even though the arepa seems small, I was full after finishing it! I loved the taste of the sweet yellow corn arepa, as well as the plantains! The coleslaw was also flavorful, and not too wet. The only complaint I have is that the asada negro was a little dry/tough.
author: Alice Z.

description: This place is amazing for vegans! There are three different vegan filling choices. I tried the Shuli Arepa which was delicious! My vegetarian boyfriend had the Vegetariana Arepa and loved it too! We split a garlic yuca fries which were good as well. We will definitely be back when we are in the area!
author: Katie S.

description: Have been curious to try this place ever since I saw that it was feature on Triple D. Everything we tried was delicious! Good job Pica Pica! I have to come back with my friends and try more of their delicious food!
author: Frisco N.

description:
I come here for my arepa fix (vegetarian style). 

They sub with tofu and it's perfectly made! 

The price is totally gentrified prices but otherwise very delicious.
author: Gregory F.

description: First tried pica pica up in Napa at the Oxbow. That location has since closed, but this is my third visit to the SF spot. The food has always been delicious and the service has been prompt and friendly. It's always a treat to come here. Arepas and salads are bomb. Everything is Gluten-free, and tastes amazing. Fresh ingredients call for amazing flavor. And yuca fries are always a must when I come to pica pica.
author: Brenna C.

description: This was a really tasty place. First time and it was really delicious. We wanted to share the nachos (there were for of us) so we each got 1 arepa but if you're really hungry, 2 is a good amount. I ordered the spicy chicken arepa and was very happy with my order. I also ordered the coconut lime agua fresca and it was bomb.com! This is a place to check out!
author: Leilani C.

description: Good food but a restaurant is more than just about the food! For that $25 I paid I could have had way more authentic and delicious food with great customer service! the cashier could barely speak English, the yelp page says free WiFi, which they denied to me so I had to make my food to go. Then when my food was ready they give me only the food stapled in a paper bag, I opened it to find out there were no napkins, utensils, sauces or the Perrier I had paid for! Then she was like "oh yea here"  then walking the food to my car all the grease dripped on my white sweatshirt cuz she'd placed the boxes on the wrong sides in the bag I will never go back regardless of the food. Proceed at your own risk!!! Shame
author: Celine B.

description:
Get the Pica Pica Taro Chip Nachos! Do it. 

I saw Pica Pica featured on Triple D years ago with Guy Fieri and walked passed the restaurant on many occasions as I strolled down Valencia. But only this year have I finally made an effort to stop by for dinner and boy was it worth it! I am disappointed that I didn't go sooner.

Order your food at the counter and grab a number. Three types of sauces are on the table and made in house. You can go for zesty, Herby, or spicy. The arepas are all delicious and the meats are juicy and flavorful - you can't go wrong. There are two different types of "breads". The original is made of white corn while the sweet is a yellow sweet corn. For the latter, I found the flavor subtle but my coworker found it too sweet for her - I think it's just personal preference. The sizes of the dishes are pretty substantial but definitely try out the fried plantains and yuca fries. The yuca fries are cut much thicker and have a denser texture than a typical french fry so you definitely can't eat as many. Make sure you eat them while hot though as that's when they taste best. 

So... back to the nachos. If you think you've had taro chips and haven't liked them, you still need to try these. The chips are sliced super thin so that every bite is paired with a crisp base. Unlike tortilla chips, the taro chips have a very satisfying snap when you bite into one and are lightly salted. The chips are then loaded with savory meats, beans, fresh cheese and other toppings. It's a great dish to share if you're not too hungry but could also be a large meal for one if you really wanted.

I'll need to come back a few more times but for now, it's certainly on my list of quick bites.
author: Liza X.

description:
I first had a taste of Pica Pica's arepas back when they had a small booth at Off The Grid Fort Mason.  Their arepas were smaller but they were portioned to the masses at OTG then (http://bit.ly/2xxL2qq).  I finally had a chance to visit their restaurant and I was really impressed!

Although the prices are much higher than when I last had them at OTG, the prices are justified by the bigger portion size.  Their arepas are huge!  More full-sized than the ones I had at OTG back then.  And they had a pretty wide selection to choose from.  I went with the Pulled Pork Pernil and the Spicy Chicken Catira, both with their classic white corn pockets.

Pulled Pork Pernil Arepa -- http://bit.ly/2A0lTqe
Tomato, avocado, pica'pun, aioli

Spicy Chicken Catira Arepa -- http://bit.ly/2zXqsS2
mozzarella cheese, greens, tomato, pica'pun

I really underestimated the portion sizes for these Arepas.  Luckily, I came in hungry, but I could not finish both of them.  Between these two, I'd say my favorite was the Pulled Pork Pernil.  The pork was really tender, juicy, and flavorful.  The Spicy Chicken Catira was still good though and definitely had a good spicy kick. 

Pica Pica really surprised me and I do want to come back to try their other Arepas because they all look good and also everything else on their expansive menu which includes cachapas which are like crepes, soups, salads, platters, and desserts.  It's a great spot for lunch, dinner, or an afternoon snack.  So expect more visits from me in the near future.
author: Rodney H.

description:
What can I say about this place it's our second time here and they never disappoint the AREPAS are so delicious you have to try it with the grilled chicken that's the best one I think the crispy chicken is pretty good as well make sure that you get the coleslaw and the coconut rice as well you won't be disappointed
Got to give these guys five stars they rock
author: Paul P.

description:
Oh my goodness, this was the best thing I've eaten in a while. This was my first time having an arepa, so I can't really compare with other places/ judge the authenticity. 

The crispy chicken arepa was definitely the best decision I made yesterday. I got it in the sweet corn, and I loved the balance of the sweetness and savoriness of the dish as a whole (although it was definitely a bit on the sweeter side). The tender yet firm chicken, wrapped up in a fluffy corn pouch, makes my stomach growl as I'm typing this. 

I also got the yuca garlic fries, and they were super t h i c c, which I wasn't a big fan of. 

Overall, the restaurant feels super home-y, and the staff is super friendly. 10/10 would come again if I lived closer.
author: Tiffany H.

description: I'd bookmarked this after watching someone rave about it on a show on the Food Network. I had the blackened beef in sweet corn arepa. Perfect portion and the different sauces and vinegary slaw complimented the sweet corn cake and chunks of tender savory beef perfectly.  The plantains perfectly punctuated the dish and they were a surprise because it was hard to tell the dark chunks of plantain from the beef, similar texture but the beef so savory and the plantain pieces bright and sweet.i wish I could have tried others. Yummy!!
author: E H.

description: Just got the empanadas and they were too oily and not too much filling. I'll have to update the review after having arepas. Also make sure your meter parking has enough time bc you will get a ticket!
author: Diana L.

description:
This place is a fast casual type of restaurant, which also means less tips! The ingredients that go into each arepa was a fantastic combination, great balance. Protein, acid, savory, sweet, they thought of everything. And they've really made what goes into their arepas more complex, more creative, so that it all comes together nicely and balances out. The sauces they have really bring the arepas to another level, especially the hot sauce that had a perfect tanginess to it, and their cream sauces that had a great balance of herbs to it. But the arepa themselves, the part that should matter, what this place is named after, the corn cakes, were dry and tough, so it took away from the whole experience. Maybe if we had gotten the large individual sized ones vs the mini sizes it would've been less dry. 

Yuca fries were pretty good, but the dipping sauce wasn't strong enough. It needed more flavor, more acid, more everything. We also got a grilled chicken plato, which was pretty good, the winner on the plate was the coconut rice. It even had some flakes of rice in it that plumped up the rice and gave the rest of the dish a good flavor when you ate it all together.
author: Ellen C.

description:
For all the gluten free peeps out there, this place is for you!  

I love my gluten but still love a corn based, delicious arepa every now and then.  Last time I went, I had the grilled chicken while my partner in crime had the crispy chicken.  It was moist, flavorful, and one was definitely enough for me.  

What I didn't like:  the yuca fries.  Unfortunately, they were pretty dry even with the sauce.  I'd pass on those and maybe go for the plantains instead.  

Everything is made in house.  There are only a few Venezuelan restaurants in the city that I know of but this seems to be a fan fave for a lot of peeps I know.
author: Jen W.

description:
I already miss this place.

If you haven't had an arepa, GET THIS ON YOUR BUCKET LIST. Honestly, I was one of those people who would rely on tacos and burritos when going to Mission, but then I had pupusas (life changing), and now, arepas are the newest best thing.

I got the sweet corn arepa with shredded beef pabellon and the portion was bigger than expected! It came with a side of some pickled veggies that frankly didn't taste great. But the plantains were so well cooked and soft and sweet *drools.* There was no shortage of meat either, it was stacked on top of a smooth layer of black bean purée. The cheese was a nice touch of sharp flavor as well.

Only thing is that it's kind of messy, it's hard to eat with your hands and get all the flavors in one bite. regardless, it all tasted so good apart or together. My favorite thing is the arepa, the sweet corn shell was just so crispy on the outside, yet fluffy inside. (Aren't the best things this way??) It prevented it from getting too soggy too.

Guys, you've got to have this arepa. $11 seems pricey, but it fills you up the same as a $16 salad elsewhere would.
author: Lilian K.

description:
A little pricey, but delicious!

I ordered the spicy chicken sweet corn arepas and a passionfruit drink. The spicy chicken arepas was filling and tasty! I enjoyed mixing it with all of the sauces on the table. The arepas itself was also super sweet and dense, and exactly what I needed after a long Monday at work. The passionfruit juice was tart, sweet, spicy - definitely worth the $3!

I'll for sure be back, but next time I'll probably try something else!
author: Hannah H.

description:
Ever since I went to The Arepa Lady in New York, my life hasn't been the same. I've been searching for a place to satisfy my arepa cravings since. 

Service was alright and seating is limited. Plan your visit accordingly. 

Love the salad that was paired with the food. The dressings complimented it very well. Both arepa ordered was made with sweet yellow corn pockets. 

Shredded beef pabellon (3/5): usually I love my arepa with beef, but something didn't work here. The meat itself was ok but something about the heaviness/thickness of the cheese and the after taste left me disappointed. 

Fried chicken (4/5): really good! Chicken was fried to perfection and was very juicy. 


This doesn't compare to The Arepa Lady but it does fill a certain craving. Will come back though.
author: Ida H.

description:
Came here with a group for dinner on the suggestion of one of our party.  Really good stuff here, in general.

First, the yuca fries are great.  I was skeptical beforehand, but was converted with the first bite.  The arepas I sampled were all good, and some were very good.  The crispy chicken is also great.  Our party was generally satisfied with their food.

This place isn't very big and seating is limited so be aware going in.  Prices are pretty typical SF prices - that is to say, I don't think you'll eat here for less than $15 at the minimum, but it's not bad.

I would happily return for the yuca fries alone.
author: Brent T.

description: Overpriced at first glance but after ordering the arepa with plantain and beef, I found 1 made me plenty full. DELICIOUS!
author: Bryanna W.

description:
Incredibly tasty fast and healthy! 

Impressed with how they kept up service even only with 3 staff on site.

The cachaca is my favorite bc the crepe style is nice and thin and it's not too sweet. I also really loved the spicy beans and coconut rice as sides. 

The desserts were not great, but I'd go for coconut flan.
author: So N.

description: Very bad this is not real Venezuelan food, this taste like Mexican food or something like that. If you want to eat a cachapa with cheese this is not the place they have just cachapa with pabellón that taste spicy and and the beans is beans cream like Mexican food and nothing of cheese. They come with salad and the flour doesn't taste corn. I don't know how this place have good reviews probably the clients are Mexican or American, they don't know the real Venezuelan food thats why I think this place have good reviews. I Don't want to come back to this place anymore. Also is very expensive
author: Jessica F.

description: This is a no-frills, fast casual sit down restaurant. I ordered the sweet yellow vegetariana arepas (delicious) and a sangria (decent for $5). My whole meal was less than $20. When I received my arepa I was a little worried that it wasn't enough food. However, after getting started on it I realized it was really filling. Had I had more of an appetite I would have given one of their numerous sides or desserts a try as they all sounded good (and are vegetarian-friendly).
author: Tarah P.

description:
Food: excellent. This was the best gluten free meal I've had in a long time. I ordered the Arepa Trio Taster with Asado Negro, Pulled Pork Pernil, and Spicy Chicken Carita filling. My favorite was the Pork. Oh, did I mention they have GF beer? 

Service: no complaints 

Location: right in the mission! 

Will I come back: yes
author: Zack D.

description:
What Pica Pica lacks in environment, it doesn't make up for in flavor or spice. I found the meats to be rather bland and the sauces didn't help the cause of boosting the flavor. 

If you are gluten free, this place should be on your "I need something quick and I had vegetables" radar. 

I will say: sweet corn arepa over the white arepa.
author: Anna S.

description: I didn't like the food. We went there because someone in my group was gluten free. I thought the food was tasteless
author: Tanya M.

description: Amazing arepas!! The sweet corn arepa with pulled pork was delicious. The vinegar coleslaw was a perfect addition as well. I also go a side of yuca fries with a avocado sauce. They were crispy and so tasty! Highly suggest this place. It is small, so you may have to wait!
author: Meg D.

description:
Food tastes outstanding. 

Where I was turned off is the pricing of the Cachapa is much more expensive than the Arepa. The Arepa was way more food with the same ingredients! It said salad I got a dink coleslaw. My friend got a full on salad. I basically paid $18 for a homemade tortilla taco. He got a full on platter for less.
author: Stu S.

description: This is my favorite place to eat in the city hands down. I will never tire of the sweet corn dough sandwiched around tofu, decadent sauces and plantains. What a powerfully delicious experience for the taste buds!!! You must must must learn for yourself!
author: Njambi G.

description: Amazing! And everything is gluten free!! The food was very delicious. And the customer service is awesome. Definitely one of the best meals we have had so far while visiting San Francisco. And the desserts are delicious. The Dulce de Leche sauce is so good! This place definitely does not disappoint
author: Melissa T.

description:
I've only had Venezuelan food once before. It was in Miami, and boy they were the bomb, so I was very excited to find this spot. I ordered nachos, pulled pork arepas, and shredded beef arepas via the yelp Eat24 app. 

The nachos had amazing flavor. The cheese, beans, tomatoes, and onions were fresh and juicy. They missed putting pork on our orders, but we were refunded so thank you for that. It is made with taro chips, which are healthy and delicious. However, they were unevenly cooked, so I tasted a lot of bitterness. If I burnt some chips at home I'd eat them, but was expecting a restaurant to toss the burnt pieces. 

The arepas were also decent, especially with the 3 sauces they have. I'm not a fan of the original white shell, they were not as crispy as I had hoped for, but it could be caused by being in delivery containers. The side slaw were way too sweet for me. To be fair I've only had Venezuela food once before, maybe that's authentic and just how they like it. 

Overall it seems like the flavor is there, just lacking in execution a little bit. So I would like to give it another shot, try the sweet corn shell, in the restaurant instead of ordering delivery.
author: Tata X.

description: My boyfriend and I are currently visiting San Francisco, and after a long day sight seeing, I, as a Venezuelan, was craving arepas and my boyfriend has come to really like Venezuelan food too. I try to look for Venezuelan places everywhere I visit. Sadly, I must say we were a bit disappointed. I ordered a chupe soup, a Venezuelan soup that's supposed to be made with milk and squares of cheese and corn. There was no milk or cheese squares in it, and little corn. We also ordered arepas and those were good and had good flavor. We got our food delivered via Caviar, the service they have on their website. It arrived fairly on time, but without utensils or napkins. I had to sip my soup from the container and pick the chicken out with my hands. I hate that I have to leave a poor review, but our experience this time was not good. Maybe check the order better before handing the bag to the delivery person. Good luck Pica Pica.
author: Romina M.

description:
Very disappointed. I'm Venezuelan and this type of food was far away from Venezuelan typical food. Besides, too expensive.
We order cachapas and arepas. The cachapas were too dried and I didn't taste the corn flavor. The arepas were crunchy outside but inside they seemed to be raw. It seems like they fired them too much without allowing too much time for cooking. The yuca frita was good but they should offer a non spicy guasacaca for kids.
author: Ricardo M.

description: Food does not taste as good as it used to be. Specially the cachapa with cheese was very sad.
author: Alberto W.

description: I've had this place bookmarked for a while now and finally I had the opportunity to check this off the list. I was a fan of the spicy chicken. My favorite part of the meal was the array sauces that you can try to go along with the arepa. They also had a nice selection of bottled beers for the limited menu. Service wise the food came out pretty quick.
author: Marcus M.

description: The arepas looked delish but we actually got empanadas which were a total hit. The food came out quickly and was nice and hot and the condiments on the each table were fun to try. I loved the veggie filling option. This was a the perfect place to grab a snack while checking out Valencia.
author: Marissa E.

description: Still good, but the white and yellow corn arepa shell was soggier than before and the coleslaw had a little too much vinegar. The sweet plantains were good (very sweet). The food came out very fast.
author: Mel L.

description:
I fell in love with arepas in another city and this is only place I've found them in the bay so far. So, they get a base star or two just for existing.

I had been to eat in twice, and remember it being pretty good both times, but ordered pickup this time and it was rather a disappointment. Dry meat, soggy/greasy corn bread, almost no flavor to speak of even after dousing it in sauce. Maybe I'll give them another chance, but I'll also be researching other places to get my fix instead.
author: Maddie R.

description: If you are venezuelan or Colombian this place is not the right for you. The taste is Mexican . This doesn't taste any of Latin American taste. Cachapa doesn't taste corn. Seems like they try to imitate a recipe but they do not know how to do it. Also very expensive for the quality
author: Daniel P.

description: ABSOLUTELY AMAZING FOOD!! I'm am gluten intolerant and this places makes you feel like a normal person- you can order anything on their menu! The flavors are so rich and amazing, and the service is excellent. I'm visiting from LA and this made my trip!  Every single thing is amazing. Now, back to scarfing down my dinner!
author: Ashley B.

description:
Three things are certain in life: death, taxes, and the arepa filling dripping all over and making a mess. It's worth it. Pica Pica does a yummy and satisfying take on Venezuelan food.

Vegans can eat well here with the "vegetariana" (vegan without aioli), "shuli" (vegan) and generically named "vegan" filling options. My fave is the "vegan." With plantains, avocado, black beans and jicama, it's a great combination.

Service is friendly and, other than at crowded peak times, quick.
author: Scott F.

description:
Arepa was delicious and it held up very well with all the fillings inside.

Arepas aren't THAT big, so it's somewhat hard to justify paying ~$14 (which includes tax) for what's essentially a small sandwich.
author: J. A.

description: Visited here on a Saturday afternoon and it was surprisingly empty. I didn't really have much expectations going in considering this was the first arepa that I have ever tried before. I ordered the shredded beef arepa on the traditional white corn arepa. Visually, it looked like it would be a great dish. However, the overall flavor was lackluster. I didnt get much flavor from the actual arepa. It was also more dense then I thought that it was going to be. The black bean puree was flavorless and the shredded beef was actually pretty dry. With all this being said, I did like the all of the sauces that you could pair with the food though. The best thing that they had was their coconut lime drink, it was delicious. I would probably come back and try something different, but my experience was just okay.
author: Steven K.

description:
Had to try the arepas here. Came on a weekday and was glad that they actually had seating inside as some places are so tight inside. You order at the counter and they bring the food to your table.

Got the pabellon arepa with the sweet corn shell? I guess you can get original or the sweet corn. Was kind of surprised that items were so pricey, but they are big portions. So the pabellon comes with shredded beef and plantains. There are a variety of arepas available with different kinds of meat. The sweet corn was good, but I think I would try the original flavor next time, so it wouldn't be so sweet since it also came with sweet plantains. Got the lime coconut drink and it tasted like a non-alcoholic pina colada, so good. 

The garlic yuca fries...wow, just wow.   The perfect combo of crispiness on the outside and creamy texture on the inside. The aioli sauce complimented the fries perfectly. They also didn't skimp on the garlic. Husband got the nachos, but he thought they were ok. Just different than he was used to since they weren't spicy and had no cheese. They did have some hot sauces on the table though. Bonus points for having self serve water on the side. Also loved that the food came out very fast and hot. 

Would love to come back and try different items on the menu.
author: Sherille S.

description: My best friend and I spent a little time on the Colombian coast, going from Capurganá to Cartagena. The food was as wonderful as the people. I was so excited to try this place, and it did not disappoint! The flavors, the quality, the artful taste combos take me back! Even more amazing, my Midwestern fiance- a boring meat and potato kinda guy- also loved it!
author: Chelsea T.

description: The flavors were interesting. I liked all the individual ingredients but together they weren't so great. I got a beef arepa with the sweet corn and garlic yucca fries that ended up totaling $20 (tip and tax). The sweet corn outer portion was so dry that it was difficult to eat. The sweeter plantains with the sweet shell paired with the savory cheese didn't work for me at all. The best thing was the yucca fries but it's $5 for a small side of just 5 fries. Overall, I'd recommend the pupusaria near 16th and mission over this in regards to the flavors and pricing for similar food.
author: Kalani R.

description:
Cool, but not super impressive.

Came via groupon for some grub--good thing too because it's quite expensive!! This is a cashier, table tag, seat yourself, and clean yourself kind of establishment. They have a bunch of appetizer options, and arepas or plates for their mains. Pretty limited menu overall but it's a small and new-ish establishment with a solid focus so, fair.

Ordered the shrimp ceviche and 2 of the arepas. The food came out pretty fast and seemed simple enough. The ceviche was quite watery, and very sweet with almost a ketchup-y sort of taste and a couple of shrimps, plus a small bit of taro chips. It wasn't terrible but definitely wasn't anything special. The pulled pork arepa with tomato, avocado and aioli was pretty good, especially on the yellow arepa. The filling has a very minuscule kick but the creamy avocado/aioli balances everything out pretty nicely. Meanwhile, the shredded beef pabellón was a less complimentary mesh of flavors, with the thick and super sweet plaintain and the beef. While they were okay, it was very expensive for 2 rather small arepas for $10 and a very small cup of cole slaw. Plus, the meat barely filled into half the arepa.

Overall, I probably wouldn't go again but I'm glad I tried it. Somewhat good but not worth the price and value for the experience.
author: Nerissa C.

description:
Good food but the portions are small for the price relative to other nearby options.

Finding seating can be a bit of a challenge.
author: Nick H.

description:
I'm not a person that regularly leave less than 4 stars reviews, but in this case is necessary. I'm from Venezuela, I come here from San Jose with my boyfriend with the hope that we finally find a Venezuelan restaurant in California. 

1. The lady on the register tell us they were out of the White Corn Arepa, and she offer us the yellow corn arepa, we say that is ok we just need to eat our regular flour corn arepa, it does not matter the color, but the surprise is that we receive a Flour Cachapa in an Arepa's shape. If you know this food you can recognize this is totally wrong, yes the flavor for this Cachapa is AMAZING! (That is why I leave the 3 stars) is a real CACHAPA, but the thing is that we don't ask for a Cachapa we ask for 2 arepas, if you are out of the original flour of the arepa (white or yellow), please sell the correct name, $11 for a really small Cachapa, sorry I'm not agree with that. 

2. I ask for a Malta, and the personal does not know what is a Malta, then I ask for a frescolita and they does not know what is a frescolita, then we really expect our famous garlic or green sauce and we receive ketchup. Yes the regular tomatoes sauce. I think you really need to offer more Venezuelan sauce options. 

3. I completely understand that you have to adjust this to the San Francisco environment. But it was so hard to get a table to eat our food, yes your place is busy and congrats for that I mean it and the decoration is great. But in my opinion, I understand that the 85% of your customer are North Americans, but keep in mind that probably the other 15% are Latins and they were expecting for an authentic Venezuelan food and I'm sorry but this is not what I received. 

I feel bad because I'm from Venezuela and I really was hoping to leave this place with a 5 star reviews and expecting to come back soon.
author: Alejandra G.

description:
I was walking around the Mission craving for papusas. This popped up on Yelp and I walked down Valencia street to find this cute, colorful and cozy place. I've never tried Arepas  which 
are corn pockets stuffed with savory fillings. Venezuelan street fare is the forte of Pica Pica and it's all gluten-free. They also have Cachapas,  sweet and savory corn pancake with delicious savory fillings. I tried the:
~ Shredded Beed Arepas - amazing, meat is juicy and full of flavor
~ Pulled pork arepas who doesn't love pork - with sliced tomatoes, avocado, pica pun, garlic aioli was WOW
~ Garlic yuca fries, very filling but must try

Be sure to try the three sauces smoky(almost like a bbq sauce), the aioli and the hot orange sauce all three complemented the dishes. They have empanadas, soups and salads, plates and desserts. So much to choose from. The guava aqua fresca is so refeshing. Good staff. Food is served VERY quickly! Cheap and fast food! The place is tiny but the food is pretty amazing. In summary - good food, great prices. All gluten free menu. Very filling and super delicious! Four stars!
author: Maria M.

description: This place is always really good. I started going there when I was gluten free for a time and it was a lifesaver. Now that I'm not gluten free, I still go and introduce friends who are always surprised about how delicious it is!
author: Dasher K.

description: This place is small, but serves up big flavor!! The arepas are amazing, I personally recommend the crispy chicken. Very casual, they serve beer, perfect for dinner with a friend or take out. Two of us shared garlic yucca fries and each ordered one arepa. That was more than enough to fill us up!
author: Melissa H.

description:
I finally ate here after wanting to go for some time. It's a quaint restaurant off of Valencia which turns out to have some pretty good arepas. Full disclosure I've never had an arepa before stopping by, but I was pleasantly surprised. 
We got an ok deal of two arepas (which are actually pretty filling) an order of fried plantains (which I recommend) and a coke for under $20. My girlfriend and I were looking for something quick and something light and this hit the spot! 
The place isn't very big and was reasonably busy when we went, but we fortunately had no problem snagging a table. The service was ok and everyone was polite.
I probably wouldn't consider it if I were especially hungry, but if you're in the area and looking for a snack or something light it's worth stopping by. I'll be back!
author: Lyndon G.

description:
4.5 stars
Amazing hole-in-the-wall Venezuelan place on Valencia. Order at the cashier and hope a table opens up. Its a tiny place. But the food is amazing. I got the arepas with spicy chicken catira. Was impressed, but the Cachapas were the best thing on the menu by a fair margin. Will definitely get that the next time, I can have the stuffed corn crepe just by itself, its that good. The trio of sauces on the table are great as well, especially the aioli. I think the Mission will be my destination for food in the city!
author: Sudipto G.

description: Had to visit this spot while in San Francisco since I LOVE arepas, and I have to see these were amazing! I am vegetarian and the veggie option was fantastic. I even cancelled other plans to come here a second time for dinner since it was so fantastic. The service wasn't great, but what you'd expect for a order and sit type spot in the mission. Only drawback was I didn't find the dessert nearly as good as the food. Worth a visit if your in the area!
author: K M.

description: Dry meat, not the best quality. I wouldn't mind that if it wasn't so expensive. But for $15 for one wish and a drink, I'd expect a better quality. Stil, I like the corn bread and the sauces.
author: Dan S.

description: If you like cilantro, the slaw with the sweet yellow Shredded Beef Pabellón Arepa is bomb!
author: Andrew H.

description: Little did I know with all the mission taco and burrito spots this would be far and away the best hispanic food id have in the city. I had a sweet corn arepa with shredded marinated beef, sweet plaintains, and cheese inside. I also had an order of garlic yucca fries. It all tasted amazing tho a bit messy from the meat juice and yucca oil. The meat was super tender and juicy and the sweet arepa and plaintains complemented it perfectly. Im Peruvian and this fried yucca was bomb and fried perfectly golden. The garlic and garlic dip while not authentic were a perfect addition to the flavor similar to garlic on french fries. Prices are good and the art filled atmosphere are good as well. Definitly go here!
author: Sean G.

description:
My wife and I have been here a few times now.

I have gotten their arepa with crispy chicken.  Fabulous!  Crispy chicken is flavored perfect.  The salsa can be hot at times but well worth it.

Nice tiny place to grab something to eat and go.
author: Sam V.

description: This place is a disgrace to the great reputation of arepas and cachapas. Anybody who has tried the real thing will be appalled by Pica Pica's rendition. Soggy, greasy, with little flavor or texture. The place is dirty and tables are greasy and sticky. Yuk! Avoid!
author: Emanuele O.

description: The service and food were TERRIBLE. The lady at the cashier was rude and didn't bother to greet us. We were asked our order 3 times and they still got it wrong. We asked for cheese, they came over after we paid to double check if we wanted cheese, we said yes, they brought out arepas with NO cheese. We ordered one with just cheese, we got one with shredded beef instead. The arepas broke apart just by holding. Very UNHAPPY with this service, took one bite and left. The quality was extremely bad.
author: Valentina G.

description: The best gluten-free restaurant in the Mission! Highly recommend....everything. Seriously, you could eat and enjoy every single item on the menu. The arepa trio taster is good for first-time arepa eaters. The sweet yellow corn pockets are the best! Highly recommend the garlic yuca fries with guasacaca (avocado dipping sauce), nachos PICA PICA (with taro chips), asado negro cachapa, pulled pork pernil arepa.
author: Sarah N.

description: I've never eaten here before but this was a great experience. The food was awesome and I'll probably want to come back here again next time here in the city.
author: Jeff C.

description: I was so excited to try Venezuelan food and found this place on yelp. I have to say I was thoroughly disappointed.  The menu was confusing and the people at the counter were't any help as we were trying to get  through the ordering process.  When our order came we didn't get a shrimp arepa as we ordered- it was beef instead.  We spoke to the girl at the counter about it and she brought us over two shrimp in a small bowl and said we could add it to the beef one we had?!  The caribbean arepa had different ingredients, only one of which was shrimp.  We made a fuss about it and then she wanted to take my plate.  We told her we were still eating and asked that she just bring a caribbean arepa with the shrimp to us instead.  So after much fussing- we got it.  But 64$ for lack luster food and sangria was a complete disappointment.  I wouldn't go back and would tell anyone wanting to try this place to go somewhere else.
author: Melissa P.

description: Had my very first arepa from Pica Pica, and I was AMAZED with how yummy this was! An arepa = fried masa (corn) patty that's stuffed with an assortment of meats, veggies, and cheeses. Pica Pica offered an amazing menu of options, but I stuck with the spicy chicken cotija (sans the cheese). The arepa was crunchy on the outside yet soft on the inside. Also, the simple vinegar-based slaw that came with my meal balanced the spiciness of my chicken perfectly! Don't forget to try the sauces that are offered on the tables: a spicy-tangy ketchup, pica'pun (which is slightly reminiscent of mustard), and aioli.
author: Connie X.

description:
I'm giving a 4 star strictly for the food. The food is delicious and would go back for sure. The service however I would give maybe a 2 star. Completely messed up our whole order. I ordered vegan arepas and got pork arepas. My friend asked for two arepas and only got one. She made us pay for his second one. I would think at that point after messing up the whole order we would get a discount or his second one free. 
The environment there is a hole in the wall feel. One bathroom and not much seating. 
Thank god the food was amazing or else this would of maybe received 2 stars.
author: Jen D.

description:
Fast and good gluten-free food that is healthy enough for me.. what's not to like 
Have been here 4 times the last 10 days after moving to the area, and will be back for sure
author: Håkon K.

description:
Delicious hole-in-the-wall joint in the Mission--Pica Pica is a casual, counter-service restaurant with some really simple but tasty arepas, which are basically corn pockets stuffed with braised meats and other fillings. I came here for lunch on a Sunday, and though the setting of the restaurant wasn't particularly nice, the food is what really matters!

I ordered the pork pernil (pulled pork) on a white arepa, and it was juicy and delicious--so juicy that a lot of liquid leaked out of the arepa! The arepa also came with a good amount of aioli-like sauce and a green chile sauce, and there was even more on the table for squirting. My favorite sauce was the spicy aioli, as it was just so complex in flavor! Each arepa also comes with cole slaw on the side, which was very sour, but a good refreshing contrast to the meats. I also got to try the sweet yellow arepa pocket and found it sickeningly sweet--definitely stick with the classic white. 

On the side, we also got an order of the garlic yucca fries, which I was absolutely crazy about. The texture of the yucca was so smooth without being the least bit dry or gritty--the garlic flavor was so aromatic, and they went perfectly with the aioli sauce for dipping! 

Overall, this was a fantastic little restaurant with delicious, simple food. The portions were not too heavy and were fair for the price, and the service was fast and no frills. I'd definitely recommend this place for anyone looking to try out this classic Venezuelan street food!
author: David K.

description: Very good !!! I highly recommend the arepas , it's delicious - it's food from Venezuela
author: Maria V.

description:
TLDR - Tasty meat but portions are a little small for a meal and a little expensive for a snack

Small little spot in the Mission. Not a lot of seating so it's not great for a large group of people. Expect to have to wait for a table if it's busy or plan to take your food to go. They're known for their arepas, or corn pockets, but they also have other things like rice plates, cachapas (sweet corn crepes) and salads.

I've been back twice now and tried the cachapas and the arepas, both of which you can choose the meat filling (beef, pork, chicken, veggie). The CACHAPAS ($14.50) are served with a side salad and bigger in portion size. The AREPAS ($10) are served with a small cup of cole slaw (light and sweet/tangy rather than mayo based) and are honestly pretty tiny and feel more like a pricey snack rather than a meal. I've had both the white corn arepa and yellow corn, and definitely prefer the sweet yellow corn. The white corn was flavorless, but I did like the crisp, grilled exterior.

* SPICY CHICKEN CATIRA - 4.5/5
[mozzarella cheese, greens, tomato, pica'pun]
I got my spicy chicken without cheese in the cachapa and thought it was delicious! The chicken was soft and moist. The flavor honestly just tasted like a less sweet, less thick version of BBQ sauce mixed with thousand island, but I enjoyed it. Not very spicy. I loved the sweet corn crepe! Soft and chewy with some slightly crispier parts. I only wish the sauce didn't make the crepe soggy at the bottom.

* GRILLED CHICKEN - 3.5/5
[black bean puree, tomato, queso fresco, guasacaca]
I got the grilled chicken on the white corn arepa and thought it was lacking flavor overall. The grilled chicken was tender but simple in flavor, and probably would have paired better with the sweet corn. I'm not a fan of beans so I was a little hesitant about the black bean puree, but it was a great consistency and not overpowering. Probably the healthiest meat option.

* CRISPY CHICKEN - 3/5
[spicy pickled mojo, lettuce, jicama, tomato, aioli, guasacaca]
Not particularly crispy, kind of dry and also lacking flavor. Between this and the grilled chicken, I thought the grilled chicken was better since it was at least tender.

* YUCA FRIES ($5.25) - 3/5
Meh. If you like thick cut potato fries, you'd probably like these. I prefer thin, crisp fries, so I wasn't as fond of these. Very thick cut, drier than normal fries and pretty bland unless you douse them in sauce. At least they weren't super greasy and had some crispness on the outside.

Overall, solid food, but depends on the meat you get. I wouldn't mind coming back to try their other meat options or even their nachos or salads (yes, those looked good too), but might pass on the arepas since they're rather small.
author: Jessie L.

description:
I gave up bread for lent and I thought Pica Pica would be the best replacement. Lucky for me, I did some research and found Pica Pica's arepa, and they're made of corn and it's gluten-free! Dream come true!

We came in on a Thursday night and it was super busy. People were coming in and out, people left their garbage on the table, the line didn't stop and the cashier was in charge of taking your order, dealing with take-out, refilling condiments and utensils on the table, and cleaning up after you! Whoo! She deserves a raise!

We ordered the Nachos Pica Pica ($14) which included pulled pork, taro chips, black beans, cheese, tomatoes and guasacaca sauce. Have you ever had taro chips? It's very interesting and new to us! The boyfriend said it tasted like chlorine? Hmm... I don't know if that's good or bad, but I'm just happy we tried it! The pulled pork was pretty chunky and cold but moisted up when dunked in the sauce! 

Secondly we had the shredded beef arepa ($10) with sweet plantains, black bean puree, queso fresco sauce in a yellow arepa pocket. I thought the yellow corn pocket was sweet and chewy and when combined with the plantain made it even sweeter. The shredded beef became a bit invisible to me because of the overpower of sweetness. I ended up picking out the beef and eating that first before eating the sweet yellow pocket with the plantains like a "dessert".

Lastly, we had the pulled pork pernil arepa ($10) that had tomatoes, half of an avocado, pica'pun, aioli sauce in a white arepa pocket. The pulled pork had a kick to it and it was really good on it's own. Unfortunately, I wasn't super wow'd by the white pocket. I thought that they were two separate things that didn't mold well together. But I loved them separately and enjoyed them separately!

Overall I felt like Pica Pica has a good background and theme. The price was a bit shocking but it is very filling for such a small pocket. I like that it is gluten-free and that it satisfied my cravings!
author: Linda K.

description: The arepas were great. But giving it only 3 stars because both the website and the menu board stated that the arepa trio taster was $15 but I was charged $16. When I asked the cashier about it and commented that both the website and menu board said it was $15, she only said the price went up and shrugged.
author: Neil H.

description: YUM! I ordered the arepa and was worried it was $14 for one and I won't be full, but it was stuffed after 3/4 of the sandwich. The ingredients are fatty and fresh. I was very pleased.
author: Tina L.

description: This is street food. We tried an arepa and their savory crape. That savory crape thing was seriously outstanding. The ingredients were fresh and full of flavor. The chicken empanadas were very good. The portion was small for the price but very delicious. Anytime you have an option to go with sweet corn in a dish I recommend you take it. The place was busy but the staff turned people at a good rate.  If I lived closer I would be back for sure.
author: Josh Z.

description:
This is a small place with big heart, I went here for the first time many years ago to get my husband gluten free yuca fries after my swim at the YMCA pool not too far away.
Even though I am not gluten free I really enjoyed my healthy lunch there and the fries Wow,Wow! 
Mouthwatering and light but crispy not the heavy yuca fries like I have had back home in N.Y.  Definitely a must!
Every visit I made for yrs I had to bring back to hubby an order of Yuca fries to have as a snack in our hotel, and he loved it but he never went before.
This year he was going there without me and I reminded him of this place right near one of his fav tea places and he could not stop raving over the fries, I was only sorry I was not there to have an order or two myself-next trip for sure!
author: Eva B.

description:
Food has good taste but it is NOT authentic Venezuelan food. I am born and raised Venezuelan and was horrified when the lady explained to me that cachapas were "like crepes" and I knew I wasn't gonna have real Venezuelan cachapas. Not a single employee in this place who really knows tradicional and authentic Venezuelan food. The only authentic thing about this place could be the decoration and all the pictures of beauty queens in the restroom. 

Ps. Cachapas don't taste like real cachapas.
author: Mayliss G.

description:
It was my first  time trying an arepa, and it was actually pretty delicious. I like the pay first then seat yourself thing they got going on since it gets packed. 

I got the shredded beef and my friend got the pulled pork. Both were so flavorful, and filling! I thought I was going to have to order another one when I first saw it, but don't let that small looking thing fool you. I also had the garlic yucca fries which I shared. The aioli that came with it was good on the arepas! I've never tried yucca fries, and I was surprised on how fluffy they were inside. Personally I didn't like it that much since I like my fries crispy. 

Service was good, ordering was not hard at all after looking thru yelp LOL. The sangria here is ok for what you pay for $5 a glass I believe, except there aren't pieces of fruit bits which I would have appreciated.

I'll probably come back if any of my friends want to try Venezuelan food or are gluten-free since the arepas themselves are made of corn, not flour!
author: Jamila W.

description: I'd never had an arepa and was pleasantly surprised. The bread is wonderful, which is not true of most gluten-free foods. I've tried all of the fillings. I like the pulled pork and grilled chicken the best. I love fried plantains. Theirs are like Belgian fries -- crisp outsides and creamy insides. The black bean soup is another standout dish.
author: Therese M.

description:
I feel bad about giving a bad review because Pica Pica is my people ..kind of. I am Colombian and grew up on arepas. and thanks to Diners and Drive Ins (the tv show) I know that PicaPica is owned by Latinos. but truthfully I wasn't super impressed with the food :/ 
I have gone here twice and both times I felt like it was a lot of arepa and not a lot of stuffing and arepas aren't super flavorful. Even their sangria was wine and fruit juice. There was no fruit. 

I would come here again bc at least they have arepas, they have good service and relatively affordable but I just need to set an expectation for the food. (Also I think it's all pretty healthy which probably plays a factor in taste)
author: Julianna I.

description:
I FINALLY got to try this gem - and regret not coming here sooner. I had the shredded beef arepa with yellow corn, with a side of yucca fries (must get!!). The beef was tender & flavorful, while the yellow corn added some sweetness. It came with plantains, bean puree, and queso fresco. 

I literally have nothing but positive things to say about this place. I definitely want to try their classic white arepa next time, but will be back VERY soon!
author: Carrie L.

description:
I have been wanting to try this place ever since I saw it on Diners, Driveins and Dives and finally had the chance to sample some delicious venezuelan food last month. I ordered the yellow corn arepa with pulled pork and the flavours were deliciously fresh. The meal was complemented well with a side of fresh slaw. The coconut lime fresca was refreshingly cooling and perfect for a summer day. The menu is fair priced, staff is very friendly and great options for vegetarian. 

The arepa is super filling and I found it difficult to finish the entire thing. If the size could have been smaller, i could have tried somethibg else. If you dnt like sweet in your food, stick to the white corn arepa.

Small spot that should be a must try!!!
author: Mrunal K.

description: Excellent arepa! I tried the sweet yellow arepa, with the crispy chicken filling. And it was SO yummy! I'm going to be back soon :)
author: Trisharti G.

description: Holy crap! My girlfriend is from Venezuela and I've had her cooking many times (which is delicious). We saw this place on triple D a few times and luckily remembered about it as we were passing the SF. We decided to stop in. I ordered the cachapas pabellon and it was literally incredible. That flavor with the plantains was out of this world. First ever cachapa for me. She had the Arepa black steak pabellon style and it was amazing as well. Got to try legit passion fruit juice for the first time. WOW so good. The ceviche was top notch, only got crumbs for chips tho and the 2 shrimp was a bit disappointing but overall a 10/10.  Oh and on our way back north we went out of our way to come back and I had the arepa negra and she had the pabellon plate. I just wish I didn't live so far away! Thank you so much!
author: Trent L.

description:
We saw this place on Diner, Drive ins and Dives and we bookmarked it on the spot. We got the arepa and one is actually pretty filling. Upon recommendation, we got the pulled pork arepa in yellow corn pocket and a shredded beef in a classic white pocket. The pulled pork was super tender, flavorful and spicy and went well with the sweetness of the yellow corn pocked. The beef was really good as well and got some sweetness from the plantains. I'm not usually a fan of slaw but the slaw was really good here with a vinegar dressing.

Overall, good and filling meal. There was a great combination of flavors that the staff recommended.
author: Sophia Y.

description:
Crispy chicken with yellow sweet arepa was soooooooo delicious!!! The chicken is spiced and crispy. 
My friend had pulled pork. Sweet and salty. Amazingly sweet plantain. Yummm~~
author: Tina K.

description: Servers were friendly, food came out pretty quick, and it was delicious. I'll go back next time I'm back in San Francisco to get some more arepas.
author: Josh S.

description:
I really enjoyed when this place had a small storefront in Napa's Oxbow Market. When I finally had the chance to check their new & only location in SF, I was excited. I have only ever had their yuca fries but this time, I decided to try their nachos and their fresh juice (they have i think about 5 different flavors). I enjoy the fact that the ingredients are fresh. The nachos are so good. I am not sure what they use for their chips but it is mouthwatering. Honestly I can eat those chips on their own. 
Hopefully I can be back soon.
author: Janine C.

description: We busted a mission to get here! 30 minutes on Bart and a 10-minute walk through some sketchy streets and we made it! First impression: this is a tiny little place with even less seating. Unfortunately, we showed up during lunch time and there wasn't any available seating so we took our order to go and we ate at one of the local parks. Of course, we ordered arepas, that's what they're known for! Fast forward to my first bite. I fell in love, I tasted so many new flavors that were new to me. I literally loved everything they put in it to achieve this flavor. Everything tasted fo fresh! Will be back if i find myself in the area.
author: Jermaine C.

description: My daughter and I love this place! I have Celiac Disease and my daughter is Vegetarian. Every time we are in SF we have to hit Pica Pica. I am never ever worried about getting Glutened. Great food, nice people and clean.
author: Barbara B.

description: First timer at Pica Pica and had Arepa de Pernil y yucca frita....DELICIOUS! Pork meat was tender and perfectly flavored, corn arepa was toasty on outside... just how I like 'em.  Please open a small restaurant in Southern California!
author: Christine Faye D.

description:
I've tried Pica Pica many times over the years, both at the former SF Street Food Festival and at their bricks-and-mortar location, and have definitely enjoyed the freshness of the corn pockets as well as savory flavors like the pulled pork pernil and the crispy chicken. It's all certifiably good stuff.

I do understand that costs are super high here in the Bay Area - whether it's getting fresh ingredients, paying your workers fair wages, or dealing with spiraling rent costs - but my rating of Pica Pica is somewhat tempered by price vs. value considerations. At $10, the arepas are no longer a cheap eat given that they are portioned in a way that won't bust calorie-counters' waistlines. Nevertheless, Pica Pica definitely won't let you down if price isn't a concern.
author: Vincent L.

description: As a severe celiac, this place is a life saver! Everything on the menu is 100% gluten free, not to mention AMAZING! In my short stay in SF, I made it a point to go there twice. Also, the staff is extremely nice and knowledgeable about celiac.
author: Kate D.

description: Came in on a Tuesday afternoon for a bite. Cute little restaurant and very sweet staff! I loooooved the empanadas (I got chicken and cheese). Perfectly crispy and soft. Really quick service. It's small so I wouldn't recommend groups or going in with the expectation you'll get to sit. Crispy chicken filling for arepas was delicious. Perfect spot for Venezuelan food. Friend is gluten free and had no issues!
author: Casey L.

description:
I came here with high expectations given the rave reviews and it just didn't compare to three authentic arepa place in east village NYC where I frequented while living there. 

The arepas here are much bigger (twice as big), making it difficult to eat while the meat and plantain start to drop out of the corn shells. 

The meat in the shredded beef arepa is tasty. The plantain is moist and sweet. The cole slaw side was a bit acidic on its own - you may want to consider adding it to the arepa. My disappointment was around the corn shell where it's very starchy and a bit hard.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
I've been wanting to eat at Pica Pica ever since I first saw them featured on a TV show a few years ago. I've never had an arepa before - and I already scolded my Colombian friend for not introducing me to them sooner :P - because it was delicious!

Their menu is 100% gluten-free and the arepas are made with either white corn or sweet yellow corn. I like flavor combos, so I paired the sweet yellow arepa with their spicy chicken filling. The arepa comes with a side of coleslaw and I ordered the yuca fries. My entire meal was perfect. The arepa was so delicious, the sweet arepa with the chunks of spicy chicken that were mixed with tomatoes and onions. I added some spicy sauce and an herbal sauce on top of my arepa for some extra zing. I added the sauces on top of yuca fries as well, which were crunchy on the outside and tender on the inside. So good! I was happy to see that they have maracuya on the menu - a passion fruit beverage. If you like tart drinks, try it. It's great. 

I can't wait to go back so I can try the other arepas, and especially the platanos fritos - which are a must-have for me.
author: Jonnathan B.

description:
Delicious! I ordered the shredded beef and plantain on a sweet yellow arepa. It comes with a side salad of shredded cabbage (lightly dressed slaw).  

Compared to the other ones I've previously ordered at other locations, these were light and not greasy. Beef was moist and not overly seasoned. 

My dining neighbor ordered the pork and avocado on a white arepa and she noted it was light and clean, again meat was not overly seasoned or dressed. 

She also ordered the yuca fries - thick and crispy but not greasy. Goes nicely with a side of mayo. 

Overall: 
Food - 5/5 - see comments above
Ambience - 5/5 - lots of large sharable tables as well as bar stools, food salsa music that's not too loud
Service - friendly and super fast
Wifi- YES AND FREE. Great for travellers needing service. 
Eat here!
author: Janice K.

description: This was a great place to eat. The girls are very attentive, so service is great. It's always good to find different flavors and options beyond the usual. A Venezuelan dish definitely sounded good today, and it was. I would just say that the pork was a bit flavorless, and $11 for an arepa is a bit too much, but I did enjoy their soup, and their coleslaw. Their coleslaw is the best!
author: Trisha T.

description: GOOD FOOD. Being a foodie, I can say Venezuelan food is on my top 5 list of favorites. Being from Tampa makes the competition extra difficult. But this place passed the test! I ordered the blackened pork arepa (I think thats what it's called) and it did not disappoint. The meat paired well with the plantains and what seemed to be feta cheese. You get a side of pickled cabbage which goes perfectly worth the flavors and textures in the arepa. I added their aioli which is in your table and after that, there weren't many words exchanged between me and my date. The food was on the table in minutes and the customer service was cordial and welcoming. I only wish there was more seating!
author: Elizabeth G.

description: The beef arepa overall was very good, but my experience eating here was awful. It's not a place that I'll be coming back too. First, it was really difficult finding table because it was so crowded and the place is really small. Second, my girlfriend made a mistake ordering one arepa with queso fresco, and kindly asked if she could get another one without queso fresco because she's very sensitive to it. The staff hesitated at first, but decided that it was okay to make a new arepa which she and I was glad about, but one of the staff was especially and unnecessarily rude to her saying if she can read next time. She was being very passively aggressive about the whole situation. We're very disappointed, and sorry but there won't be a next time.
author: Jorge S.

description: Love this place! Been here twice, It's a bit expensive- but its totally worth it at the same time! It's like comfort food but its healthy, and totally great for those eating healthy and who have allergies.
author: Daniel I.

description: What a difference a year makes :( it's been about that long since we've been here. It was Emily's favorite place in the city because it's all gluten free. But this visit was different. We were excited for the meal since we had spent the day in SF with our daughter. First thing I noticed, not very busy. It was around 6ish maybe a bit earlier. She ordered the crunchy chicken arepa and I went with my go to pernil arepa. The pernil was very bland, most and juicy as it should be but no flavor for the first time of the maybe 5 times I've had it. The other very obvious difference, the employees just don't seem to care. All of our previous visits the employees were happy, helpful, listened to the customers, joked with them. They seemed genuine ya know? This time the young lady that was cashiering was gazing out into the street while a customer was in front of her looking at the menu. I mean cmon, engage, look at him at least, smile, offer a suggestion! None of the above. I dunno maybe it was a bad day but when I see a place that has tanked like this compared to how I loved coming here in the past, it kinda makes me think the owner maybe doesn't spend much time there or possibly has put too much trust in someone else to run this location? I do believe there is another establishment somewhere else in the city. Oh well, I'm not saying I won't come back, maybe I'll try the chicken or as for a taste of the pernil first. I hope our next visit turns out better.
author: Frank R.

description:
We came in for a quick bite while waiting to see a movie. We were recommended to try the vegetaria arepa and it was so good! The "shell" was so soft and flavorful. They did great putting together all the flavors + greens mix.

However, I think the value was not there. $10 for a vegetarian Arepa is a little too much.
author: Katia K.

description:
Finally made it to Pica Pica, and my friend and I absolutely loved it!!!  I ordered a vegetarian arepa and a side of yuca fries, total came out to $15.  Didn't feel like ordering the plate, because I was focused on the fries.  My friend on the other hand did order the plate and let me sample some of his food, which had beans, coconut rice and plantains.  Prices are somewhat high, but the flavors that were going on in my mouth were so worth the price.  It is a special treat to eat here, wish that I could more often.  

First time I heard about this place was on the Food Networks, Guy Fieri's "Diner's, Drive-Ins, Dives."  Place is legit and worth a try.
author: Michelle M.

description: This place is a little over priced I mean I know it's San Fran but even so for what it is it's a bit much, but the food was super tasty I love that they have two types of arepas as far as yellow corn and regular white arepa. The drinks were very refreshing and delicious. The garlic yuca fries were also very good.
author: Ari Y.

description:
AREPAS! I really liked this place, just wish it wasn't so expensive! The serving portions are not that big and the order easily comes out to $10+. The food itself was good. Not the best arepas I've had, but no major complaints.

Make sure you choose your meat first (despite the order of the menu) and ask them which "bun" goes better with it. You have a choice between classic white and sweet yellow (plantain/cornmeal). Pulled pork is good, but needs added sauce!

I recommend this place to try at least once, but personally will choose the go elsewhere 9/10 times.
author: Vasiliy M.

description:
Delicious and unique! Arepas are just great. I had the vegetariana arepa and man the flavors were spot on and so interesting.

Lovely service also

Try the yuca benigets too. A little dry but such a cool take on benigets.
author: Jaclyn B.

description: Good food I just wish the place was a little bigger it's a bit cramped. It's a bit pricey as well for what it is but with the Bay Area rent being ridiculous not surprised pricing is high. Arepas are delicious and definitely recommend for people to try them out.
author: Cindy L.

description: Discovered this place and love the food quality. Been twice just this week. Thankful for GF restaurants that allow those of us who have to eat a certain way the flexibility to choose from the menu. Small things in life. Thank you!
author: Kalin K.

description: Empanadas were delicious!!  Must try.  Catira arepa was good and the crispy chicken arepa was so-so.  4 stars for being a safe hearty place to eat for those with gluten sensitivity.  Also great for those who are dairy free!!
author: F. J.

description: The white corn arepas are so good. I especially liked the beef one with plantains. The sauces are the best. I appreciated that  they put them in separate containers as I got deliver and it helped to not get the arepas soggy when it arrived. Delivery was earlier than expected.
author: Tara K.

description:
Not your typical "Mexican" cuisine! They specialize in Arepas. The concept is similar to a Mediterranean shawarma, but the "pita" bread is made with corn (white or sweet yellow) & the meat is marinated with mexican/latin inspired spices & ingredients. 

FOOD:  
We ordered 2 arepas and yuca garlic fries.
