description: I'm saddened by the fact that I came to visit San Francisco with this restaurant in mind, I'm Venezuelan and I was looking forward to have food from my country, what I found a very dirty place, the food wasn't what I was expecting at all, lousy service and on top of that food poisoning, yes food poisoning! Our vacations are officially ruined. Not cool.
author: Lorene O.

description:
I love Pica Pica! I came here cause I saw it on some food show on Netflix (I forgot the name) but it looked great and wanted to try it out!

I had the Shredded Beef Pabellon! It was great and tasty! It came with a small side of cole slaw. 

The place was packed and it was hard to find a seat but overall a great place! I definitely want to come back and try other items they offer in the future!!
author: Daniel S.

description:
My boyfriend & I are completely obsessed with this place. I'm a celiac and it's great knowing I can walk in here and order whatever I want. 
PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE order the Pica Pica nachos and the fried plantains if your come here! Completely orgasmic while also being super healthy. Great vibes and music playing too!
author: Jessica U.

description: Very small a bit cramped. Quite slow service, took us about 39 minutes to get two arepas. Decent effort but still not as good as homemade.
author: Sanaa H.

description:
Oh man! Pica Pica has easily become one of my favorite restaurants in the Mission. At Pica pica, you order at the counter, grab a number, and after you are finished with your delicious food, you are expected to bus your own tables.

For 4 people, we ordered:
- Pork Nachos w/Taro Chips
- Garlic yucca Fries
- Pork cachapas
- chicken arepas
- Mango fresca 
- passionfruit fresca 

One order of pork Nachos can easily fill 4 people if you order other things.  The bed of taro chips were topped with pulled pork, tomatoes, guac, cheese, and what they call the Guasacaca sauce.  Not too sure how to describe the sauce, but the combination of everything was magic! The taro chips are a bit thicker so there is a crunch to every bite.  And even until the very last bite, the taro chips did not get soggy. The garlic yucca fries were also amazing!! Very Garlicky!! I prefer the cachapas over the arepas, but both were good. The arepas itself was a bit more bland compared to the cachapas, which is a sweet corn crepe.  The mango and passionfruit frescas were both too sweet. But I prefer the passionfruit over the mango.  

Next time I would love to try their plantains, and ceviche. And of course get everything I ordered again ^_^ (minus the frescas)
author: Janel L.

description:
LOVE THIS PLACE!

Came here b/c the hubs saw this joint on TV and wanted to check it out. We were not disappointed and will be coming back again. We don't go back to a lot of places twice b/c we try to eat somewhere different every time we go out, however, for this place, we'll be back! 

We ordered:

** Tres Empanadas and opted for all beef. Good but if I have a choice, I'd order a 3rd Arepa instead of this.
** Shredded Beef Pabellón Arepa w/ sweet plantains, black bean spread, queso fresco. This was good w/ the Sweet Yellow corn pocket! 
** Pulled Pork Pernil Arepa w/ sliced tomatoes, avocado, pica'pun, garlic aioli. My husband liked this with the Classic White corn pocket.
** Yuca Beignets - Buñuelos de yuca with Dulce de Leche dipping sauce. AMAAZING w/ coconut taste! It was a nice surprise. 

There are condiments on the table. 3 different choices in squeeze bottles and the Mojo spicy pickled sauce. My fav was the creamy ranch tasting one and the Mojo!

Oh yes... and this place is GLUTEN FREE!!! Love love love.
author: Michelle T.

description:
This was my first foray into Venezuelan food and it was delicious! 

Me and the boyfriend got two arepas to share! Arepas are the Venezuelan version of Colombian pupusas or Mexican tortas. I could be totally mixing up all these Latin American foods. Fail. I apologize! But pika pika is definitely the culturally appropriated version. Come on. Only white people would advertise gluten free as a health benefit. 

My favorite was the pulled pork with the sweet yellow corn tortilla/bread/shell. It's a bit pricey at around 10 bucks for just the sandwich but it's meaty enough to be worth it, imho. I also enjoyed the garlic yuca fries! Imagine thick steak cut fries covered in garlic :3
author: Xinxin W.

description: Stopping in here was a terrific find on our walk through the Mission District in San Francisco. The smell of fresh ground corn wafted through the little place and we were delighted with our arepas. I chose the sweet yellow corn filled veggie style with tofu, avocado, and plantains. Hubby chose the white corn filled with spicy pulled pork. Both were uber-delicious. The yucca fries were just starchy enough and there's a few choices for bottled beer as well. Service was friendly and quick. Yum - stop in and give 'em a go.
author: Deb S.

description:
Amazing. I wish they had more locations! First of all - the entire restaurant is gluten free!! Huge sigh of relief for any Celiac person like me. If it's your first time here, you have to try an arepa! Their specialty is the beef pabellon. It's delicious and super filling. I got one of those, and I was full. I've tried other arepas on the menu as well as the nachos on different occasions, and they were all delicious. You really can't go wrong with anything you order here. For a side, the yucca fries or plantain chips are solid choices. 

A little small inside, but we went during the week so it wasn't crowded. Service has always been great, and our food came out super fast!! Come hungry, leave happy for sure.
author: Christina C.

description:
Finally writing a review for this place. Came here to have lunch with a friend who suggested this place and It was one of those places that i had been bookmark for quite some time. 

Its in the heart of the Mission district. Its one of those restaurant where you pay at the cashier for your food and drinks and seat wherever you want and they'll bring out your food. This place is very small so it can get pack fast during rush hours. 

I got the arepa white corn with pull pork. It comes with side vegetables. The pork was very tender and moist and has that sweetness from the flatbread. They do have a few special sauces that can either give the extra tangy, spiciness, or sweetness to go with your food. The vegetable has the sweet and sour favor. It cost $7.99. Although the food is good, but its quite pricy for a small meal. The price was not worth it. Thats the only reason i didn't it a 5 stars.
author: Julie N.

description:
Things I'm really into: the garlic yuca fries. Hello--you taste like potatoes, but somehow, dare I say it, better than potatoes. Crispy on the outside, that mealiness on the inside, and somehow they taste healthier than french fries even though I know they're probably just as terrible for me.

Things I'm pretty into: the pulled pork arepa. It was great, and pretty flavorful, but it didn't adequately hold the juices so it kept leaking in the container. I drank it, and it was delicious, but it made the pork in the arepa a little dry. It's okay, I'm clumsy already, especially with food, so I'm sure I just need to finesse my skills to be a graceful lady eater.
author: Rosy H.

description:
I'm surprised I haven't reviewed this place before. 

One of my favorites meals in SF. Venezuelan style arepas (I've tried most of them and you can't go wrong) and the most delicious sauce - pica pun. I wish they sold that sauce because I would have a fridge full of it. 

Oh and the fruit juices are bomb. Passion fruit and coconut lemonade. 

Yummmmmm
author: Laura D.

description:
Food: 5
Service: 5
Atmosphere: 5
Cleanliness: 4

Warning: You might need a siesta after eating here. I am worthless when it comes to telling you what to order. I walked in like a cave woman and/or tapped into my American roots, while throwing all my manners out the door on the way in and loudly asking and pointing at some one plates " I want that please!"

I had no idea what it was called, nor did I care, I was so grief stricken with the food that had left my body to what felt like ions prior. I impatiently waited for my food after I placed my order and paid at the counter, by slurping down a fresh made coconut and lime 8oz drink I purchased, faster than the blink of an eye. It tasted like candy in liquid form and wet my appetite even more. 

My cave woman tendencies dissipated as my blood sugar levels raised. As soon as my corn cakes (again I don't know their proper name) , grilled plantains, beans, tofu and cole slaw arrived and whatever else was smothered inside the corn cakes; I quickly chatted with my classmate and devoured everything that was served on my small plate. I knew it was probably a little more than I would normally consume, so I ate fast before the remorse sunk in. It was decadent and fulfilling and all the other things that would make me want more.

I know I could not dine here on a regular basis, but for a treat every now and then, I would highly recommend! 

Enjoy !
author: Cassandra E.

description:
DELICIOUS!!! Just go. My boyfriend and I ordered:

-Garlic yuca fries -delicious
-Empanadas - we got both beef and cheese which were just ok, I'd pass next time
-Pulled pork arepa (sweet corn) - "Simply exquisite." - Tha Hound Dawg 
-Beef paballon arepa (sweet corn) - the plantains were so good and sweet and it was a great combo with   the meat
-Guava fruit fresca- super fresh
-Coconut lime fruit fresca- we were hesitant on this but the guy highly recommended it and gave it to us for free, omg it was delicious!

They also had three delicious sauces on the table, the white one was my favorite! My only qualm was that it is a bit pricey, $10 for one arepa, but I'll attribute that hopefully to better quality ingredients which I'm always willing to pay more for. Will most definitely become one of our go to spots!
author: Bernadette R.

description:
Don't go here.... I want all the Arepas to myself. 

Love love love love love!!!!!!!!!!

The wait can sometimes be a bit painful, but after the first mouthful of delicious pork and cottony corn arepa.... all worth it. 

I also really like their sangria
author: Greg F.

description: It took me a few tries to find what I like, but I must say that the pulled pork sandwich is amazing combined with tasty puffy yuca fries. I like that they have no gluten at all, as I have had no celiac symptoms when eating here.
author: Zack K.

description:
Food: ordered a Suli arepa, Mango juice, and garlic yucca fries. 

Mango juice was good, a little watered down.

Fries: needed more garlic.

Arepa: oily. 

I went with a Venezuelan friend who told me the food wasn't as authentic. He had recommended the place but said the food was also oily. 

Decor: cute, lots of reds and vibrant colors.
author: Chhaya N.

description: Awesome food, very tasty, and very, very yummy! You will not be disappointed! First time here today and will come back.
author: Scott W.

description: What a delight! It's been years since I've had arepas but I don't remember them being this delicious! Every aspect of our meal was filled with complex flavors. Eating gluten-free often involves giving up a lot of taste but Pica Pica is gluten free flavor heaven!
author: Kara R.

description: I've only had Colombian arepas so my expectation was of something similar. The arepa came out quick and was lukewarm and the stuffing was the same. I had the spicy chicken which was under seasoned and not spicy. The slaw was too sweet. I tried the various sauces on the table to see if they added good flavor but was disappointed.
author: Wildeflower M.

description: I ordered food from here and it was a dreadful experience. We've had a long day and ordered food to our hotel from this place based on the reviews. I'm guessing the service inside is much different. I ordered the nachos and received chips in a damn box. I called them and told them what I received, she said "sorry what would you like me to do?"  I said, well I'm hungry and paid for nachos and received chips, she replied with "there's nothing I can do. Sorry. Bye." Worst experience ever. I wouldn't even go here to eat in person because of how rude the woman was on the phone. This is a BUSINESS, if you can't provide what is on the menu, then don't have me pay and deliver me this crap. See photo.
author: Kathleen S.

description:
Pica Pica! No it's not Pokemon's cousin or the newest Power Ranger character, it's my new favorite pick for food under $10 in San Francisco! I came here with co-workers one night and walked in with low expectations. It looks like a chain, but it eats like a Mom n' Pop shop. 

We don't have Venezuelan food where I live (Honolulu) so I really didn't know what to expect. Thankfully I was more than overjoyed with my meal! I had the sweet yellow corn arepas stuffed with grilled chicken for $8.95. The arepa itself was so tasty I could have eaten that by itself. It's like someone took my Grandma's cornbread and compressed it into a perfect flat bread. The arepa was stuffed to the brim with a very well seasoned chicken and an assortment of veggies. AH-MAZING! I washed it all down with a passion fruit fresca for $3.50 that was the perfect pairing to my delicious arepa. 

It's a gluten-free if that's important to you but I found the price to be much more enticing! Service is welcoming and the restaurant is clean. Under $10 and I left feeling stuffed but not like I needed to curl up into a ball and go to sleep.
author: Emi H.

description:
If you're in the Mission District or visiting Clarion Alley Graffiti, make your way to Pica Pica Arepa. We came here because the arepas are gluten-free. You get a choice of white corn or yellow sweet corn for your arepa. I would recommend white corn if your choice of filling is heavy. The yellow sweet corn is delicious but it's oily and heavier. 

Highly recommend the white corn Arepa crispy chicken - this is all gluten-free! The chicken paired well with the tangy sauce.
author: Ellen Z.

description:
I'm not an arepa expert by any means. I am however, a lover of food and CORN.

Why anyone would ever order white maize arepa is beyond me. Sweet yellow corn is the best corn there is. Do yourself a favor and go with the yellow corn. Don't be a fool.

Arepas are deceiving. I've always been told by the mister that Pica Pica is a heavy meal and we have to be reeeeaaal hungry to eat there. I've passed on Pica on a number of occasions because he declared I wasn't hungry enough. Glad I listened. Seriously, if you're not famished don't bother. Save it for another day.

I went with the vegetarian on yellow corn and it is soooo heavy. Grilled tofu, grilled plantains, black beans, avocado, MMMmMmMMmM. I could probably live off black beans, yellow corn and plantains alone. Okay I lie, I need bacon too. The outside of the arepa is crispy and semi crunchy.  We also split a small side order of yucca fries. The yucca fries are amazing and totally worth the order, but hard to finish if you kill your entire arepa. 

Come here if you're starving! 

I need to hit this place up again with room for yucca beignets. Yes, you read that right - YUCCA BEIGNETS!
author: Susy C.

description:
I am neutral about this place. It is not a place I would go back to if craving Mexican food but not one I would definitely reject if someone wanted to go. 

A friend and I shared the nachos Pica Pica after hearing that this place served taro chips. We were intrigued and figured we would give them a shot. Although they were covered with enough toppings, they just tasted okay. The shredded beef was kinda dry and the sauces were just... okay. The white sauce did not add as much flavor as creaminess to the chips. Meh, what good is adding some creaminess if the flavor is lacking? We kept adding spicy sauce to our individual bites to add flavor. At least the tomatoes and avocado were fresh *thumbs up
author: Liana F.

description:
Love this place but it's hit or miss with takeaway or delivery. Tonight, I waited 25 minutes for a takeaway order. I ordered three beignets, three orders of sweet plantains, and one order of chicken. By the time the order should have been ready, the cashier comes out to ask what I ordered because he just realized he only put in an order for 1/3 beignets and I need to pay for the other two. Then I'm asked to wait again for the other two as if it's a new order and not something they need to accelerate because I've already been waiting. Everyone else who ordered just after me is now gone. People who came in well after me are eating. Finally the order is ready and I run out. I jet off the my friend's place to deliver snacks for game night and find there are only six boxes. One order of plantains is missing. 
I call. I explain. After explaining what I ordered and when I was there, the response is "you were here?" Yes. "When were you here?" Just now. "Oh...can you call back tomorrow?" You're asking me to take time when I'm supposed to be at work to call back tomorrow. "Yes, call back at 11." No. When you are either the person who took my order or standing next to the person who took my order, I am not calling back tomorrow, to give more of my time. I paid. I tipped. I deserve to receive the food I paid for. Simple.
author: R B.

description:
A friend and I were looking for lunch and we happened to walk by Pica Pica at the perfect time! There is a really good arepa place in our college town and I am obsessed with arepas and they are usually pretty hard to find, so the minute I saw this place we quick looked them up on yelp and decided to go in.  I ordered the blackened beef asado (which was a dollar more than the other arepas) and my friend ordered the pulled pork pernil. 

The style of the place is you order at the counter and they bring out your food with a number. The inside of the place is pretty small and when I went it was busy, but there are enough places to sit if you wait around for a minute or two. There seemed to be a lot of people taking food to go as well. 

When the arepas came out, the portion was pretty small, but I was happy with it. It seemed like $10 was a little expensive for what you get, but I am also not from California and find a lot of the pricing to be shocking out here. It comes with "Pica Slaw" which is basically cole slaw. I thought the meat on my beef asado was a little strange, but the plaintains were delicious and so were all of the sauces! I had the yellow corn arepa which was great! 

If you like arepas or want to try a new food, I would recommend trying it!
author: Hanna K.

description: As a Venezuelan, I can vouch for the authenticity of the food at Pica Pica. I've had the Arepas and the Cachapas and they taste like the ones at home. The Asado is excellent. I also really enjoy the Yuca Fries and the Empanadas... bringing the tastes of long ago.
author: Wolfgang F.

description:
Came here with a group after happy hour on a Friday night. It was crowded, yet with good reason. 

Pica Pica uses fresh ingredients and has a variety of sauces (I always enjoy having lots of sauce options). I had a pulled pork pernil arepa- great combo of pork, sliced tomatoes, avocado, pica'pun, and garlic aioli. It came with a small side of slaw. In addition to their arepas, the yucca fries are also well known. All my friends were satisfied with their dishes. Good for people who are gluten-free, as well. 

You wait in a line to order, and there's limited table and counter seating. Prices are reasonable for SF, at $8.95 for an arepa. Sides are $2.50 each, platters are $10.95- $12.95.
author: Joanna L.

description: So the grilled arepas are good. They don't have cheese as the original recipe but nevertheless they're tasty. Only thing that was disappointing was the lack of fresh ingredients. You could taste the fake guacamole and "ketchup" used in the recipes. If they make everything fresh, I would have give them 5 stars undoubtedly.
author: Juliana A.

description: I literally had a dream about the Crispy Chicken Arepa the other day. It could be because I am running a fever, or because I am on my period and could eat anything in sight, but I don't think so. Will definitely come here whenever humanly possible.
author: Lauren G.

description: The food is good overall, but their prices are just outrageous. Came in over the weekend to get my arepa fix and they have raised the prices of a single arepa up to $10. If you want a few yucca fries on the side, make that $13. Must be because they were recently featured on DD&D or something, so let's make it even more expensive! The place is small, so it's a good stop for a quick bite. They also do their food to-go, which is good given the size. Now, for all the talk about the price, I do have to say that the arepa was delicious. The vegetarian one comes with plantains, tofu, avocado, and black beans ... Everything worked really well together. The garlic yuca fries however were nasty, the garlic oil they throw on top was not good at all -- stick with regular yuca fries and use the sauces on the table. I would come in more regularly (for the arepa) if the prices weren't so gosh darn high.
author: Cara R.

description:
Crispy chicken - gluten free fried chicken, that actually tastes like fried chicken, it is Da Bomb!
Arpea's are delicious as well as the sweet plantains.  It's a small cafe kinda place - very cozy.  Friendly service and really good food, fast.  I will be trying everything else on their menu!!!
author: Sherese J.

description: Wonderful Mexican Food, real taste. On vacation, was told to try it. Try it you will love it.
author: Gerald C.

description:
So my friend is gluten free, so I suggested this place.

Then he gets mad because it's $9 for one small pita pocket thing.
I got the shredded beef arepa, which was about the size of my palm.
My buddy got the pulled pork arepa.

Guess I'm going on a diet, I thought.

I also ordered the coconut lime drink and Coconut Quesillo because I was hungry. 
But, I'm always hungry.

Here's the thing, the arepa seemed like it was more corn pocket than actual meat. It wasn't filling, and I didn't think the meat tasted all that great.

My buddy didn't like his pulled pork one, but was happy it was gluten-free, then unhappy again when he realized it was $10 with tax and he was still hungry.

The dessert was good though, but pricey. $4 for 2 bites of what tasted like a small caramel flan. The coconut lime drink was standard size at $3. Not very limey though. And more watery than coco-nutty if you know what I mean.

$20 bucks later and I'm still looking around the Mission for something to eat...
author: Jack R.

description:
It's not so easy to find good arepas in the U.S., so I was really excited to discover this place right around my apartment. It's really conveniently located at 15th & Valencia, and when I stopped by on Sunday at 7, there was a decently sized line of people waiting to order.

I had the shredded beef arepa in a sweet yellow pocket, and the incredibly kind and adorable lady at the counter added aioli to my arepa (after I mentioned that I was torn between the shredded beef and the pork because the pork had aioli). While I will admit that this is not the best arepa I've ever had, it was good, and it was filling, so I'm pretty satisfied. Given that I live so close, I'll definitely be back. :)
author: Kelly R.

description:
One day I was sitting around with the bf and suddenly he brought up Pica Pica and asked if I had been there before. Just a few seconds later, my coworker texted me and asked about Pica Pica also! I guess ever since their appearance on Diners, Drive-Ins, and Dives, everyone knows this place! I had walked by this  restaurant all the time, but always thought it was just another taqueria in the Mission.

Finally, after making our way down the street on the 4th of July, we wandered inside and gave it a try for dinner. I went by the Yelp suggestions and ordered an arepa with the sweet yellow corn. Here's the breakdown:

Food: I ordered the pulled pork pernil and sweet yellow corn arepa (once I saw pulled pork, sweet yellow corn, and avocado, I was sold!). My bf ordered the shredded beef pabellon and sweet yellow corn arepa. I tried a bite of his and it was pretty good, but mine was definitely better! We also got an order of yucca fries to share. They were pretty good, but nothing amazing. They also have several sauces to try and were good complements to the already amazing arepas.

Service: There were two employees working behind the counter (the cook and the lady that took our order). They weren't particularly efficient, but they were really nice! We ended up changing our eat-in order to take-out just because we couldn't find anywhere to sit (luckily, my bf lives super close)!

Location: In the Mission - perfect place for hole-in-the-wall delicious grub. Also super close to my bf's place, so double bonus!

Ambiance: Almost feels like a fast food joint, but there's nothing mediocre about their food. I don't even know where I would get anything like this besides Pica Pica, so really, ambiance almost doesn't even matter when it comes to their tasty offerings!

Would I return? I think this might be one of my new favorite finds!
author: Leana L.

description:
Pics pica! You're the maize of my dreams. your shredded beef pabellon sweet corn arepa is the perfect mash up of sweet, savory and saucy. I bow to your corn majesty. 

I do wish you had metal/reusable utensils. That being said - props for ensuring using compostable forks & knives
author: christen V.

description:
Love this place.... def a must go to when in sf. 
Im a fan of the sweet arepa but all taste amazing. Yuca garlic fries are beyond bomb! !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Mariapaz J.

description: Hard to find parking but worth circling around the blocks a couple of times. Had the beef arepa with white corn and it was delicious! Definitely need to go back to try more!
author: Alma G.

description:
This place is delicious! We had the pulled pork arepa with sweet yellow corn and the blackened beef asado arepa with the sweet yellow corn 

- The Pulled Pork was good, a little dry....it comes with avocado and tomato
- The Blackened Beef was really good, the beef was in a BBQ-like sauce with plantains and queso. The combination of the beef with the sweet arepa was amazing 

For $10 each, they're well served. Will be back to try other dishes!
author: Bonnie R.

description:
I was going through a super old Food and Wine Magazine from a few years back and ran across a mention of Pica Pica in their corn issue.  I love corn and I love arepas but unfortunately it can be hard to find.  So I immediately bookmarked it and actually got around to trying it a couple of days ago.  

Sweet Yellow Corn Pulled Pork Pernil Arepas.  It was a bit spicier than I would've liked it (is that what pica pun is?) so next time I will request that they leave the spicy sauce out as the pork itself was flavorful enough on its own.

White Corn Vegetariana Arepas - I absolutely love the black beans and the sweet plantains in it.  Who knew that vegetarian can taste so good!!  

Drinks:  Passion fruit fresca - not as sweet as many passion fruit drinks so it has a nice tartness to it but I actually liked the coconut lime fresca my friend got even more!!
author: Joyce Z.

description: (This is a review from a few months ago...) We came here for the first time and tried an arepa and the pork nachos.  The staff was great, very helpful and the food came out in good time.  We really liked the flavors of the fried chicken arepa and thought the nachos plate looked fantastic.  We couldn't wait to try the taro chips because that is a favorite and not often on most menus.  After a few bites, however, we were disappointed -  The chips had no distinguishable taro flavor (not sure why), the pork was dry, hard to chew and also did not have any flavor, the small amount of guacamole was watery and the overall dish was bland.  We would usually welcome a mountain of taro chips, but given that the chips had no taro flavor, a suggestion is to perhaps have a few less chips and add some toppings that have some contrast?  We may go back to try more arepas and other items, but not the nachos.
author: Mary D.

description:
There are few restaurants that I choose to regularly frequent and recommend on Valencia, but Pica Pica makes the cut. While at times the service is slow (they do orders through some apps now, which could be the reason), the food never, ever disappoints.

To order your arepa, you have your choice of corn. I go with yellow because I feel like it's a little sweeter, but the white is just as good! You then have your choice of meats (chicken or beef) and as a carnivore, I've found that I really love the tofu! If you're grabbing your food to go, make sure you grab sauce cups!!!

But in complete seriousness you will regret eating it without the sauces. It's slightly bland without them.

I will come again and again and again. And maybe still again.
author: Colleen M.

description: Ok food but very small servings, the yuca fries had 4 fries in the basket that's correct only 4, considering the prices the value is poor.
author: Rob M.

description: Definite mixed feels. The food is good (barring the beans, which are a bit too al dente for my taste, and the meat, which I found a bit hard rather than delightfully tender?), but quite overpriced, especially the plates! Glad I had a Groupon. May come back just for an arepa sometime.
author: Shendi X.

description:
I came here two days in a row because fat. But you probably want a more detailed explanation of why I, queen of variety and trying new things (particularly in a part of San Francisco where I actually can), decided to opt for the same type of lunch at the same restaurant, both days this weekend.

I tagged along with some of my classmates and even though I have a natural predilection towards nachos whenever i see them on the menu, I decided to hold off and instead order what Pica Pica is known for... aka arepas. It is basically a grilled corn pancake that is filled with some type of protein. I got Crispy Chicken on Saturday and Grilled Chicken on Sunday. They also have two types of arepa, classic white and sweet yellow. The yellow seems to go better with chicken, but I'm interested in trying the classic white next time around. I also got the garlic yuca fries. Don't worry about the fact that each order only has like five fries. These are like steak fries on steroids and they will fill you up. 

The chicken was perfectly cooked both times but something about the arepa keeps me coming back. So good. 

Now that I've had my arepa fill, I've got my eye on the nachos for next time.

Shout out to my homie E (known as Ivan F. on yelp), I was scrolling through yelp finding out what other people liked and came across his review. Miss you.
author: Aivy C.

description:
Love this place. If you are eating gluten free this is a great place.

My husband and I have eaten there a few times and have enjoyed every meal. come hungry. The meals are very filling. I don't think I've ever finished my plate and I'm a not a petite girl. The prices are reasonable especially for the amount of food you get. 

The service is fine. It's a pretty low key atmosphere. If you want a quick, tasty, satisfying, affordable meal this is your place. If you want something fancy or romantic or on the lighter side find another place.
author: Hope A.

description: I have a lot of food allergies and this place was perfect for me. The food was super delicious and different from any other restaurant I've been to.
author: Anna C.

description:
Over priced and very small portions. They don't cut the small corn biscuit all the way through and then the call it a pocket.  I think they just do this so they can get away with giving you less in it.  
The classic white version is bland as can be and the yellow one is just sweet.  The yellow one tastes like a can of sweet corn. 

The meat is great but not worth the price with how much you get. If it was half the price and they called it an appetizer it would totally be worth it.
author: Harrison S.

description: Guy Fieri featured this restaurant on his show. I finally made it and wasn't disappointed. I am planing to go back few more times to try the other items. It worthwhile big time.
author: The Food L.

description: As a venezuelan I feel so disappointed!!! "VENEZUELAN" food? I don't think so, our food is so much better than this. I gave 2 opportunities to this restaurant and it was awful. I definitely not going again. Adriana, tu eres venezolana y me imagino que haz probado mejores arepas que estas en nuestro pais, el queso que usan nisiquiera tiene un pequeño parecido al queso de nuestro pais, la masa esta pobremente cocinada y de verdad que como venezolana deberias saber que nuestra comida es mil veces mejor que lo que ofrecen en Pica Pica.
author: Adriana F.

description: Oh my Pica Pica, you just blew me away.  The sauces are all amazing. The mustard seed cole slaw side is out of this world, and I actually feel justified paying the price for this arepa.  Oh the flavors.  THANK YOU!
author: Amanda J.

description:
Food =  3.5  ( pulled pork 4.5 stars; shredded beef 2.5

Value = 2.0 -$10 for an Arepa, Really?!

Atmosphere = 2.5

We know and love Venezuelan and South American food. Ordered 2 Arepas on a Thursday evening. For $10 each I was expecting something fantastic after all the Yelp reviews. The shredded beef on white corn was a bit tasteless and dry and definitely needed the excellent plantains and black bean purée to bring forth any flavor. Perhaps it was overcooked. The pulled pork on sweet corn was excellent, bursting with flavor and juice and loaded both with pork and avocado. Delicious! Atmosphere was nothing special, a bit small and cramped seating. The staff is helpful and polite. I'll be back for the pulled pork and maybe the spicy chicken.
author: Scott S.

description: Disappointed. I was expecting a larger portion for the amount they charge for their arepas. I was also expecting fresher ingredients. The meat in the arepa had too much condiment and did not taste fresh at all! The seating area was also small and did not have a clean appearance. The tables were sticky. One star for the yucca frita. That was the only OK item.
author: Ramon P.

description:
Wanted to check this place out after seeing it on Triple D (That's Diners, Drive-ins, and Dives for the uninitiated). My only previous experiences with arepas was a little place in Aptos, CA...that was in business well over a decade ago. I forget the name of the place, but frequented it often.

GF and I arrived around 3:30 for a late lunch, and decided to order 3 different arepas so that we could try the flavors. We got the Grilled Chicken, Shredded Beef Pabellón, and the Blackened Beef Asado. All were made to order, and took about 12 minutes to be served. 

The place is very small, and we sat at a table in the corner near the door, and large picture window that opened to the street. It was very cold today, and it was a bit of a surprise that the window was wide open, and both of the fans in the restaurant were on. We had jackets, and didn't make a fuss about it, but seems like a bit of an oversight. 

Anyway, on to the arepas. They had extremely generous portions of the protein, and were served with a slide of simple cabbage slaw. For me, the plaintains in both of the beef arepas were just too sweet, and so I ended up pulling them out. 

The grilled chicken was my favorite, and it had a nice smoky flavor to it, the Shredded Beef Pabellón was #2, and the Blackend Beef Asado pulled in at #3 out of three. 

My main nitpick is that due to the generous amount of protein, there was no easy way to get a perfect bite of all the flavors other than to fork and knife it (perhaps by design). Fortunately they offer plastic forks and knives at each table. I also felt that to get a completely satisfying bite, the sauces really needed to be included, and I would definitely recommend including the slaw in every bite.

The Mojo (vinegar + heat) is definitely the right stuff. They had three other sauces at the table, one that was kind of spicy chipotle mayo, another that tasted like it had cilantro and lime, and the bright red one was basically ketchup + red pepper, and I wouldn't recommend it (unless you like ketchup). 

Bottom line after a single visit: Pica Pica seems like a great place for folks seeking a decent gluten free meal. It didn't knock my socks off, but it's a cool spot with some interesting combinations of flavors, and very good protein to dollar ratio.
author: Forrest F.

description:
A woman with a determined look on her face was sitting alone at a table for four. We asked her if the other seats were free, not even waiting for her answer before we started sitting down. 
"No."
And then we understood why, because the food started arriving and it kept on coming. Pretty soon the whole table was covered with plates of arepas, cachapas, empanadas, fries, tajadas, a soup or two and maybe even a quesillo. I don't know. It got blurry fast. 
And she started digging in. 

The food's great here.
author: Patrick S.

description:
On my recent visit to San Francisco, two of my friends separately decided that I should visit Pica Pica.  I do not often get to read a menu for much beyond finding the one or two things I can eat and hoping they're good, but here I was overwhelmed with choices and everything was amazing.  Everything is gluten-free, most of the menu has no soy, there are many vegetarian and vegan options (with the vegan options marked), and other allergens were easy to avoid.  

The supergrain is corn, but there are also a lot of beans, plantains, yuca, and avocado.  The black bean and plantain empanadas are wonderful.  I also enjoyed the yuca fries, tajadas, garlic coconut rice, and black beans.  I am in love with the yuca beignets with dulce de leche.  

When you go in, you read the menu, order at the counter, get a number, and if you've come during dinner you try to find a table and hope for the best.  You can order in English or Spanish, and if you're like me and trying to learn Spanish they will be patient with you about that.  Water is to your left as you face the counter.  The bathroom is down the hall in pretty much the only place it could be, and is a single unit bathroom which means it's friendly to people of all genders.
author: Penelope B.

description:
The sangrias were strong, and the Arepas were filling. I couldn't ask for better meal. Especially as someone who is always on the hunt for a gluten-free accommodating restaurant.

I will echo the comments made by other people regarding the arepas. They are much thicker than I am used to. This makes them very difficult to eat. However, if you have a knife and fork and you don't might embarrassing yourself a little I guess it works out!
author: Nicole V.

description:
I have to eat my words (and more pica pica). went back a few times and decided that the veggie arepa was just the right amount of food - you don't leave feeling overly stuffed and guilty.

I heartily recommend the vegetarian nacho plate. The flavors are bright and the taro chips are a refreshing change from tortilla chips- thin and light.
author: Marianna M.

description: The plato with the crispy chicken is everything! love this place it has a diner type feel and it a good local. The mead can be a little spicy at times. Arepas good also. Love this place!
author: Morgan S.

description:
Original one-star review: I am super-sensitive to gluten and get blisters (dyshidrotic eczema) and arthritis and general inflammation from it. My friend and I got delivery from here (ceviche, taro chips and yuca fries; all very tasty) and next day ... bad blisters. I couldn't believe it was from this place, since it's supposed to be 100% gluten-free and so a couple of days later, I ate the leftover yuca fries I had kept as part of a late dinner and, the next day, more bad blisters. Of course we don't eat anything with gluten at my house and I never went out, so I can't point to any other source than those yuca fries.

I can't prove anything of course, but I wonder if they are perhaps cooking gluten-free, but not sourcing gluten free (there is cross contamination in factories that process many foods such as herbs, nuts, pulses and seeds along with wheat products).

Update 1: I have updated my review to a 3-stars, based on their exemplary response to my original review above. We're going to test the suspect yuca fries. I will update again later.

Update 2: Pica Pica folk were as good as their word and tested the fries. They came back negative for gluten down to 2 or 3 parts per million. So it may be sheer coincidence that I somehow encountered gluten both times another way, or it may be that I am one of the few that are so extreme in sensitivity that even 1ppm is a problem (as the FDA suggested in a 2011 report). Whatever the case, I appreciate Pica Pica taking me very seriously and being extremely nice about it throughout. It's great to be understood and respected, even if one's reaction is hard to track down. Many people would have lost their temper or at least been resentful about all this.
author: Victoria B.

description:
Thier pulled pork with the mojo will change your life. Everything is fresh, natural and full of flavor. 

Bottom line.....DAMN GOOD! 

This is a must try.
author: Roc P.

description: Four of us ordered various items from the menu and had it delivered to eat family style. I preferred the yellow corn Arepas and Cachapas over the white ones. The slight sweetness complemented the savory meats. The Arepas are dense and filling so don't let the "small" size fool you. We all enjoyed the plantains, garlic yuca fries are a must, pork, beef and veg options. The chicken was my least favorite, nothing bad but nothing standout either. The sweet yuca beignets were a disappointment because I don't think the texture and starchiness (not a real word) of yuca can be easily manipulated to be a dessert item. Overall we enjoyed eating their food and would definitely recommend and return to eat from here.
author: Ashany S.

description: Nachos pica pica!! Definitely one of my favs here! The taro chips are so tasty and compliment the flavors well! It also comes with pulled pork, black beans, tomatoes, and guasacaca sauce. Oh, and their arepas are good too!
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Amazing. We came back again, just one day later. Place is still cash only for the time being- their card machine is broken. This led to some discrepancies on our as well as our friend's check, but they were quick to rectify it and give us back the extra money they had accidentally taken. Poor things were using a calculator trying to add up menu items and subtotal in tax. 

Anyways, we got the pork nachos again, which are SO crazy out of this world good! We also tried the empanadas- beef and cheese, as well as plantain and black bean. They came with a side of guacamole to dip. I wasn't crazy about them but my husband liked them. 

We got another three orders of the yucca beignets for the table to share..... Wow. As well as a coconut quesillo, which to me was grainy, but everyone else loved it. 

Love the fact that the place is 100% gluten free, so we don't have to worry about cross contamination. They even have gluten free beers and ciders! Incredible! 

Everything is fresh, and sizes in general are huge. The taste is unbeatable. 

Can't wait for my next trip to San Fran to try more of their menu items.
author: Matt D.

description: We were very excited to try Pica. Read generally good reviews. I'm sorry to report our experience was quite disappointing. The cashier/server couldn't have been more unpleasant. She genuinely seemed put out by our presence. She was unhelpful and sour. We asked for suggestions and info. She just referred us to the menu. When she delivered the food, the plate barely made it on the table as she couldn't be bothered by us. As we ate, we observed the same behavior with the other customers. Now to the food. The arepa arrived stone cold, mushy. The empanadas were over cooked and flavorless. The yuca fries were awesome as well as the various sauces. I'm sorry to report we can't recommend Pica nor will we return.
author: Jennifer B.

description: Not impressed. Nachos I had weren't great at all. Toppings were scarce and literally only on top of the store bought, tasting chips. I tasted the food my friends bought. Wasn't impressed. Mediocre seasoning. The seating is awful. It's not a great place to take a group of people. We had 4 people and had to wait to sit to eat. At least I can say I tried something different, but I'm not pressed to go back.
author: Ana S.

description: Completely worth the über ride from Union Square!  Authentic, unique and absolutely delicious!  Loved the refreshing coconut line fruit Fresca to go along with my shredded beef  pabellón arepa!  Go right away!
author: Laura S.

description: After seeing this place on TV my mom had to come try it the minute we landed! Very small place of course I feel like every spot is much smaller than usual in SF.. Nice people and the food was delicious. I could live without the garlic yucca fries though and I wish their empanadas had more flavor! My favorite was probably the nachos, loved how the chips were made of taro! It's a bit on the pricey end but it was worth trying.
author: Elejina L.

description:
Came here after hearing about a place in San Francisco where to get Cachapas. We ended up ordering a cachapa, an arepa and some Yucca fries.

Food was great, not as good as the Venezuelan food that you can find in Miami but hey its San Francisco and finding Venezuelan food in California is very rare.

Service was good, they let me and our friends sit down even though they were closing shop in 10 minutes.
author: Giovanni F.

description:
Man, when I first came to the city I found this little place and thought it was amazing. I still do love the food but they recently put chalk paint on their menu board so they can change the prices anytime they want. $9.50 for an arepa? Really? That just baffles me as I know how easy an arepa is to make. 

I almost feel as if they have the "oh, we're in the big city, so we should have big city prices" attitude. WRONG! Pics Pica may have just lost a customer based on this, although my recipe may not be as good, I will have easily made 5 arepas with $10 rather than paying for one. 

bring the price back down.
author: Cory S.

description:
Got to visit for the first time Pica Pica Arepa Kitchen in San Francisco, CA and I was sure excited for this! They are 100% GLUTEN FREE and feature as their main dish a Venezulan Arepa which is a corn pocket that is filled with your choice of their signature family recipes. They offer vegan, vegetarian, and dairy free options as well. My date and I both came here in between lunch and dinner time. I ended up with a yellow corn arepa filled with the Blackened Beef Asado, sweet plantains, and queso fresco. Since I have a dairy allergy I got it with no queso fresco. My date ended up with a yellow corn arepa as well but filled with Grilled Chicken, black bean purée, tomato, queso fresco, and guasacaca. We both really enjoyed our arepas and they even came with a side of coleslaw which wasn't even mayo based, which we really enjoyed. We also split a basket of yuca fries which is usually fried in the same fryer as dairy but they were able to fry them in the meat fryer for me to avoid cross contamination. Very accommodating!

They make their own spicy hot sauce that was really good and even mixed it into the ketchup available on the table giving it a nice kick. Would definitely come back here again and would classify it as one of my new favorite places.
author: Diana W.

description: SO SO good!  A healthy Latin cuisine, that serves comfort and delicious food that will satisfy anyone's palate.  I had the Sweet Corn Arepa with Grilled Chicken!  Full of flavor, meat was juicy and the corn arepa, WOW!  Highly recommend this place!!
author: Jackie L.

description:
Great place! Got the Crispy Chicken Cachapas - portion was huge (definitely enough to split). The Cachapa itself was just sweet enough to balance out the spices and savory flavors.  Yuca Garlic Fries were also amazing. Food came out quickly and was definitely reasonably priced given the portions you walk away with.
Will definitely be returning!
author: Tanya M.

description: Was hoping/expecting more from this place. The arepas are indeed tasty. The yellow corn one is much sweeter than the white, which I enjoyed. I think the meat and other fillings could have been better seasoned. Also, $10 for an arepa?
author: Ron G.

description:
i would have given 1 star, but the service was good.

i just spent $22 on two arepas, one crispy chicken, one beef.

got home to find hardly anything inside of the sandwiches. the chicken was dry, clearly old, and barely present. the beef was less pathetic than the chicken, but not by much.

don't waste your money here.
author: meeks b.

description: Delicious delicious delicious!  This tiny restaurant brings traditional Venezuelan cooking to San Francisco! Not only does it take gluten free to an amazing level, but the unique flavors are a real delight. I had the, yellow corn arepa with shredded beef and the sweet plantains. My husband and son had the pulled pork on white corn arepas.  The little vinaigrette salad with mustard seeds added just the right accent. They have three sauces on the table- which are each unique and so savory! We shared the yucca fries which came with a cilantro sauce. They were tender on the inside and crispy on the outside - wonderful. Folks are friendly, it is totally casual-bus your own table style. Visit Pica Pica Arepa Kitchen Kitchen and give your taste buds a treat!
author: Janis T.

description:
On hold for almost 25 min. Chick just forgot about me then never picked up the phone. I counted at least 9 other people she served instead ... aaaaaaaand I'm pretty sure that she burped at some point during a lull in the customer flow.

It's too bad, those nachos looked rather tasty.
author: Ian M.

description: Pica Pica is a great little place in the northern part of Mission to grab a quick lunch. We were able to cobble together several tables to seat our group of 7, but ideally, you should not come here in larger than a group of 4. You could either order an individual arepa (which comes with some slaw), or a plato. I was surprised the plato means the beef comes as a pile rather than an arepa. Regardless, the arepa is the best part (homemade sides are a hit / miss meh, -2 stars for that).
author: Shang S.

description: Love it. I agree, as a vegetarian I'm going nuts for this place. Pica Pica is Venezuelan fair, similar in ingredients to Mexican, Central or South American flavors with its own distinct style. Toasted handmade, tortillas (mmmm mmmmm good). The veggie arepa is amazing, go with the regular tortilla - the plantains make it sweet enough. Add a side of garlic coconut rice. Solid!
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
All the way from Ventura to "visit a traditional Venezuelan place to eat". Not so much!! If you are Venezuelan, don't waste your money, it is not authentic Venezuelan food. The pabellon not even taste like on, black beans taste that came out of a can, rice from a rice cooker that not even was seasoned. The arepa not even is tasty. "Guasacaca" is guacamole, get it straight people! Very disappointed!!!
 Oh and forget to find Malta or Colita, they only have regular sodas. U r better off going somewhere else!!!
author: Alejandra L.

description:
Gluten free? Eat here! I also the Plato with the fried plantains and grilled chicken. 

Everything on their menu is gluten free and most dishes can be done without dairy. 

They can get pretty busy and the spot isn't huge so not the best for big groups.
author: Daina L.

description: Had the spicy chicken sweet yellow arepa, delicious. Garlic zuca fries also great, w great sauces. Took my friends here a few times and they all enjoyed it. It's pretty different so great option for when you and your friends can't think of what to eat but don't want the usual cousines.
author: Khanh N.

description: Gluten free deliciousness. Standard order is pulled pork pernil on sweet yellow corn arepa. Bring floss.
author: Mandy H.

description: Great food and friendly service.  The guy taking our order made recommendations after finding out it was our first time visit.  We tried the pulled pork and shedded beef aprepas- both were excellent - very flavorable and juicy
author: C C.

description: Delicious arepas! We first dined at their place in Napa, which has sadly closed. So when were back in SF and heard this was the same place, we knew we had to come! I had the pulled pork on the sweet corn arepa which came with avocado and a side of spicy coleslaw. Was a little too spicy for my taste. The sangria was a little too sweet. Plantains are a must. The empanadas (beef and then the plantain with black bean) were okay. Smaller than I expected as we eat Colombian empanadas which are much larger. It's a small place. Order at the counter and then sit down if you can grab a table or counted seat. Their dessert looked amazing but didn't have room.
author: Michelle S.

description: We were there last Friday evening, before six. Everything sounded so good on the website we wanted to try a variety of new dishes. The counter person was no help in ordering. I thought of asking some of the other diners what they liked best. And then noticed several had left almost full plates un-eaten. That was also what we ended up doing. Very disappointing.
author: Darryla G.

description: Take out review. I had the chicapas meal. You guys have a gift when it comes to making plantain fit with the beef. I am definitely going to stop by soon. Love the texture of the meat, the arepa, and the overall taste.
author: Jean L.

description:
I ordered a beef and plantain arepa through ubereats so this review is only for the arepa. I've never had one before so it was great to try something new. I wasn't sure what to expect but it looked a bit like a soft taco! 

The yellow corn pocket is soft and sweet with little corn bits. The filling had sweet plantains balanced out with salty shredded beef, both of which were delicious. I didn't like the black bean mix but because it was not spread throughout the arepa, I was able to scoop that aside. The arepa looked small in pictures so I was afraid it would not be filling, but the portion size was just enough for one person. 

Ubereats had a deal on this for $5. If I had to pay full price though (more than double the price!), I don't think it would have been worth it.
author: Vio C.

description:
*3.5 stars*

Never having tried Venezuelan food or even hearing about arepas, my friend and I decided to venture to this place to give it a shot. I had no expectations coming in, but I'm glad to say that Pica Pica proved to be a very pleasant surprise. 

I ordered the pulled pork arepa in the sweet yellow corn pocket. You have the choice of ordering either their classic white or the sweet yellow. I'm glad I chose the sweet yellow because the sweetness of it perfectly balanced out the savory meat. The pulled pork (or pernil) was tender, very flavorful, and even had hints of citrus and sweet aromas. If that's typical of Venezuelan food, then consider me a fan! The arepa was stuffed with the pulled pork, sliced tomatoes, avocados, a great garlic aioli sauce, and their pica'pun sauce. Their pica'pun sauce added the perfect hint of spice to the arepa. There's more of it on the tables that you can use to add to each bite if you'd like (I definitely did). The arepa also came with a side of slaw - nothing special about the slaw but it was a nice addition to the meal. 

The price you pay for an arepa is very reasonable considering how much they stuff the arepas with your choice of meat or tofu if you're a vegetarian. I left very content and would love to come back to try some of their yuca fries!
author: Christine V.

description:
First time having Venezuelan food & having this place bookmarked for awhile, I was excited to try out their food. 

I ordered the Plato (black beans,coconut rice, sweet plantains) w/ Spicy Chicken Catira (mozzarella, greens, tomato, pica'pun). I didn't know how I would feel w/ the coconut rice b/c in Asian food it's used as a dessert, but it surprisingly tasted really good esp w/the black beans. Unfortunately, I wasn't a big fan of the spicy chicken catira. It wasn't spicy,& I wasn't a fan of how it tasted. I was going to order the shredded beef pabellon(black beans&plantains), but my plato already had black beans&plantains; so it would be too much.

Overall, really delicious food! I would def like to come back here again & try out their arepas since it's obviously their signature dish here
author: Trina N.

description: Yuca yuca yuca. Get the yuca fries. Great place for vegans. Fast service at lunch. Food is hearty, unique and delish.
author: Trisha D.

description: Came here cause hubby saw it on  triple D. A very small place in the Mission.  I had Nachos Pica Pica, very good, large portion,  enough for two people.  Hubby had pulled pork arepa, rice and sangria. All good. We bought a bottle of the mojo spicy pickled sauce. It's too hot for me ( I'm wimpy) but, everyone else loved it. Very good. We'll be back.
author: Bobbie R.

description: The food was ok but I was expecting more. The Cachapas were dry and not fresh, the pork was not as flavorful as I want it. My husband ordered pabellón and he said it was ok, the cheese was regular mozzarella or cotija.
author: Rina H.

description:
VERY disappointed with my visit this past Tuesday. 

After watching Diners, Drive-ins & Dives feature for this place, confirmed days and hours of operation and then traveled from Oakland in search of Arepas.

1 hour later we arrived to find the place shuttered with no notice of extraordinary event / closure. ( See pics)

Is it out of business or just inconsiderate?
author: J S.

description:
I seriously get so excited every time I eat here cause the braised beef arepa is so delicious. The "bun" is always perfectly toasted and crispy outside and soft inside. Beef is always tender and the plantains are soft and sweet with the beans that add another layer of texture. So. Goood. They have this white sauce I drown my arepa in. 

Overall, the food comes out quickly and staff is nice but you don't interact much since you order and sit. Great for a quick lunch or part of your tour in the Mission!
author: Melanie L.

description:
This was basically a snack for us before our dinner so we came in hungry and were initially surprised by the $14 price tag since the picture from less than a year ago stated that the nachos were only $9. Nacho inflation?! That's a pretty huge jump.. 

Anyhow, I'm a sucker for mouthwatering presentation and the pictures of the nachos had me drooling and I came running but it was a bit of a let-down to be honest. The taro chips made the whole dish a little heavier as was expected, but I felt that in order to offset the heaviness of the chips there needs to be an incorporation of some really fresh ingredients to balance that out. 

Really great concept with the whole gluten free thing, but the dish as a whole felt a little flat to me. I mean, I tried everything in order to make this thing right. I tried a dab of all the sauce containers they had on each table and nothing really hit the spot. Maybe some jalapeños would have done the trick? Next time, we will try the arepas!
author: Ann K.

description:
Location:
It's a couple blocks away from the main Mission area so easy to park. Nice place to walk around after you eat.

Food:
Tastes GREAT. I got the arepa shredded beef. Quantity, quality of food was prime. Not too saucy, not bland at all. I recommend you get this dish. 

Service:
Excellent. Cashier was extremely welcoming and helpful. The server gave us a free set of fries because we were nice. Very cheerful vibes.

Price:
Great budget meal. Paid $10.88 and am pretty stuffed. My friend, a girl, are half and took hers to-go. 

Overall, definitely coming back
author: Joon J.

description: I was referred to this restaurant by my boss who had came on his honeymoon with his wife told us that the food was really great and we had to try it turns out we made it all the way down here to San Francisco on our own vacation so I made it a point to stop by with my family the service was amazing very helpfully food was great the fresh drinks were really good salsas were so spicy but good wt the food but the fried banana was so on point I I will b returning to eat here before I head bk home to Pomona thank u so much for the service and the great tasting food
author: Adriana G.

description:
Went here because I was craving arepas ever since moving here, and haven't found a good place yet in San Francisco. Their arepas were pretty good, but the portion size is somewhat small if you get one, so we had to get an extra dish for enough food. I did like their coconut rice and plantains, so definitely get those if you're there!

The restaurant is pretty small, and you order at the counter first before sitting down. We had a big-ish group and went in around 7pm on a Saturday, and had to wait for some groups to finish before we could sit.

Overall an OK experience with good food, but pricy for the portion size and not much sitting room.
author: Tony C.

description:
I really don't know what the big deal is, sadly. Saw this on Triple D and have had it on my to-do list for a while. The last time I was here, I stopped by for dinner and got whatever vegetarian arepa option there was. So unmemorable I can't really tell you much else.

With about twenty minutes to spare before our Armory tour, we went back and forth between Pica Pica and Samovar, which were a short walk from the Armory. I was hesitant given my last visit here, but was feeling something a little more substantial than sweet pastries from Samovar next door.  I decided on the mango/passionfruit agua fresca and the taro and plaintain chips. Agua fresca was nice, but the chips were just alright. They weren't even warm. Taro chips were just okay, and I love taro chips. They just weren't that flavorful and didn't have much of a sweet finish. Plaintain chips were worse - like starchy cardboard. Even though I drowned them in the four sauces found at every table, they're still not anything I think I need to sample again. Someone told me I needed to have their taro chip nachos. Nope.

K, Pica Pica, I'm done. Bye.
author: Christina K.

description:
I happened to be in the Mission during Sunday Streets, and when the festivities were over, I was on the prowl for some good grub.  I saw Pica Pica ended my hunting here.  I ordered the vegetarian arepa, and it delicious!  If you haven't had an arepa (or don't know what it is), you have to go to Pica Pica and try it out for yourself.

The vegetarian arepa came with plantains, black beans, tofu and avocado.  It also came with a side of cole slaw.  I'm not a big fan of cole slaw, but this was delicious and a great addition to the dish. And if you haven't read my review of Cha Cha Cha, I'm in love with plantains together with black beans!  So this dish was right up my alley.  I downed the meal with refreshing mango juice.

I need to come back here!
author: Vira P.

description:
Love it, crave it like a pregnant lady. Never fails to make my day. Food is fresh, clean and always delicious. 

My only complaint would be the drink variety or lack there of and the drink prices.
author: Heather G.

description: So happy to find this place! My wife and I had arepa's for the first time in New Zealand (of all places) and have been craving them ever since. They offer a sweet corn and classic white arepa stuffed with 8 different options. We tried the spicy chicken and shredded beef and they were both delicious! We also ordered a side of yuca fries which were also great.
author: Corby D.

description:
Solid dining option on the Valencia corridor!  I particularly like their vegetarian arepa, and people rave about the pulled pork arepa.  Tasty and easy.

Minus one star for service (e.g.,  On one occasion, I've ordered at the counter for takeout and they forgot to serve me.  On multiple instances, they've also forgotten to include items in my take out order.)
author: Rina V.

description:
Good place, very quick service, arepas are larger than what they normally are here in the US. Pabellon arepa was very good, the plantain was awesome. We ordered empanadas and they were good, crispier than normal on the outside but still good. I liked the beef empanada better. Definitely try the salsas on the table, every bite should be accompanied by some salsa on your arepa, it is the Venezuelan way!
Passion fruit juice was oK.
author: Ricardo M.

description: Shredded beef, plantains, yuca fries, and both the  mango and passion fruit juices on point!!! We will definitely return.
author: C S.

description:
My favorite meal in a long weekend in San Francisco. I had a sweet corn pork arepa and a veggie dish with avocado over tofu and black beans. We also shared Yuca fries.

Holy moly cannoli. The arepa was so good. I have never had one before. And it may now be one of my favorite foods. The sweetness of the corn mixed so well with the salty pork and hot sauce. And the avocado.... oh the avocado. I will get back to that in a sec.

And the Yuca fries were so good. They have such a smooth texture inside. Potato fries cannot compare. 

The tofu was sliced thin and so flavorful. And the avocado atop was creamy and melted in my tongue. Avocado is so good in California. I do not think they can compare on the east coast or deep south.

Wow. Just wow. I will definitely come back here.
author: Biff W.

description:
Came here for a quick casual dinner on Saturday.  It is an order at the counter, then sit and eat your meal (which I am a fan of when I want something quick but good).  The place is small, but it seemed that there were not really people waiting for tables long, or hovering without a place to eat.  The food was really tasty, though my one friend thought it was a bit sweet.  I got the shredded beef arepa and it had a lot of flavor!  

We have been here a few times and will be back.
author: Sarah F.

description:
I came into Pica Pica starving. I have never had Venezuelan food but it looked like a Mexican gordita of sorts so I knew I would probably like it. 

I asked for the Plato but the gal who took my order must have not heard me and just gave me the Crispy Chicken Arepa that she recommended. It took a while to get it but it was hot and really good def crispy and with a bit of spice. Came with cabbage salad on the side that compliments well. 

I liked their sauces on the table. I wasn't as impressed with the maize pocket itself though. I suspect I got the sweet corn but I'm not sure. I will try to go again to make sure I have tried the classic Arepa. Even though I didn't get the Plato, I was full at the end of my meal so that made me feel better.
author: Judith G.

description: Great food but not so great customer service. I ordered a few items to go, waited 25 mins before finally asking about my food. Turns out they prepared half of the items, set my to go bag aside and forgot to notify me. I had to remind them about including the rest of the order.
author: Ivana M.

description:
Wonderful to know everything is gluten free!  Had the grilled chicken arepa and plaintains. Yummy 
Very casual, order at the counter. Wish there was a Pica Pica in Philly!
author: Tough C.

description:
Casual interpretation of Venezuelan traditional arepas.  Arepas are semi-sweet corn pouches or crepes that are filled with savory and traditional fillings such as meats, beans, and/or soft plantains.  

Pica Pica is a small casual restaurant where you order from the counter up front, and they bring your order to your table.  They serve extremely quickly!  I had enough time to self-fill my glass of water, check my phone, and my order was here.

I ordered an arepa (a grilled corn pocket), a cachapa (corn crepe). plantains on the side, and taro/plantain chips with guacamole.  I got the vegetariana filling (grilled tofu, avocados, pureed beans, and plantains).  All were vegan!  This place is definitely vegan friendly and completely gluten-free.  I would suggest the cachapa over the arepa, portions are almost twice as large, and only $12 as oppose to $10 for the arepa.  Also the arepa is pretty hard to eat, since it's hard to stuff all that into the small pouch.
author: Matt T.

description:
This review is also a few months behind, but the food is so memorable I must review.

My boyfriend saw this place on the Food Network with Guy Fieri Diners, Drive ins and dives when we were watching T.V at the BNB we were staying at (shout out to Gough Hayes). So the next day we decided to check it out.

Upon arrival this place looks pretty cookie cutter. I thought it would look a bit more run down like the other restaurants in the district...and that isn't a bad thing. I was almost afraid we were walking in to another fast food restaurant by the décor...which was nice by the way. We decide to order a variation of Arepas and a side, coconut rice I believe. It was pretty awkward because my boyfriend kept speaking to the owner in Spanish and she kind of would brush it off. He noticed it also but we chalked it up to her maybe not being comfortable speaking it or she just didn't want to.

So back to the food, it was extremely delicious. Any place that gives me a heaping portion of cheese on my food gets my vote., but it wasn't just the cheesiness...I'm telling you the items we ordered were delicious. The only sour taste in my mouth was due to the fact that Arizona doesn't have a Pica Pica ! We'll definitely be back on our next go round in the Bay.
author: Chelsea W.

description:
Pica Pica has been a regular in my TotMW rotation since at least 2013.  I won't lie; the main reason I first came here was the name.  I also wanted to see what an all-corn-based menu looked (and tasted!) like.  I may have bought something from their booth at the 2009 San Mateo County Maker Faire, but if I did, I don't remember what I got or whether I liked it.

Like a lot of Latin American and Caribbean fare, Pica Pica's food can be a little bit heavy.  It's mainly the plantains, but there's also a way in which the flavors and textures aren't quite different enough to make you feel like you're eating more than one thing.  OK, that doesn't make any sense, but try Pica Pica and tell me that you don't understand that sentence after you've eaten the food.

I've tried everything vegetarian on the menu, but I can't tell you what's best, because it all tastes the same to me.  And I really really really want to eat that giant non-taco as a taco, but the non-taco isn't sturdy enough to keep from falling apart in my hands, so I end up eating it carefully with a fork and knife like some dandy eating a banana in Vienna.

The food comes up quick, and all the people who work here are nice.  The location adds to the place's charm.  Back in the day, I don't think I would have spent too much time on this block, but I'm fascinated by it as well.  Remember when they ground down the projects into gravel?  That was just crazy.  Pica Pica also made me realize that I can pretty easily walk to the beginning of Haight Street from the Mission.  I had never even considered this until I tried Pica Pica for the first time during a previous TotMW.

It's a tiny place that isn't good for groups, so if you're trying it for the first time, you should come alone or with an intrepid partner.
author: John S.

description: I died and went to food heaven! The shredded beef arepa with the sweet corn masa was amazing. I can't wait to go back here!
author: Lily L.

description:
This was my first time having Venezuelan food, in particular, arepas. These corn pockets are filled with your choice of deliciousness. You have the option of white or sweet yellow corn and your choice of protein. 

We started off our meal with plantain and taro chips, only because they ran out of yuca fries. The chips weren't greasy, but they were just ok. I had the spicy chicken catira arepa with sweet yellow corn. My bf had the shredded beef pabellon on white corn. I love spicy foods and unfortunately there wasn't anything spicy about the chicken. For dessert we shared a side of sweet tajadas (ripe plantains). 

Overall, we enjoyed our meal and would definitely come back and try other items on the menu. Left feeling satisfied but not stuffed!
author: Sammie B.

description: I ordered a large order with caviar delivery service. Food was good. Only suggestion is that they label the boxes so I know what is what as I had to open every box to figure out who to give what ( a little operational advice). Thank you for the great food
author: Crystal M.

description:
If you have Latin friends, do not bring them here. They will laugh at you for thinking this was authentic Venezuelan cuisine. My friends came all the way from Tennessee wanting to check this place out, because they saw it on DDD.  

I ordered the Pulled pork plate, Tres empanadas and the Plantain & Yucca chips. You all know my favorite word when it comes to food lacking flavor. Bland, bland, bland! The only portion of my pork plate that was good was the cabbage salad and only because the vinaigrette was refreshing. The pork was dry and the beans were more akin to puffed air. 

The plantain & yuca chips starter is deceiving. I thought I would get yucca chips and regular plantains, but instead I received a basket of yucca chips AND plantain chips.
What a bummer, because I sure was looking forward to some soft chewy sweet plantain. 

We took the tres emapanadas home for a late snack. They were not terrible, but they were so fried I ended up cutting away the breading and eating only what was inside. The beef ones are actually pretty good. 

Although there is outdoor seating available, you can not have alcoholic beverages outside. No sangria in the sun for you! All this disappointment for $32.00, makes me want to fly to Venezuela just to try actual authentic cuisine.
author: Jaylena P.

description:
Pica pica yum! 

Arepas are grilled corn pockets with meats, vegetables, sauce etc inside.  In addition you can get sides like sweet plantains, garlic yuca fries and coconut lime juice. 

For two you should order a couple arepas, a side and a drink or some beers. It will set you back about $35-$40 with tip and you'll be quite pleased.
author: Mike G.

description: SWEET CORN AREPAS!!!!! ALL THE WAY!!!! Love this place! They never seem to fail me and the food is just great! It is a small place I suggest getting the food to go and chill at your favorite bar down Valencia instead of eating there if you were a group of 4 people. I can get pretty crowded on Fridays and weekends. Also try the empanadas, they're pretty tasty.
author: Giselle J.

description: Walked into the cashier saying they were closed. There were quite a few of people still inside. I asked what time they closed she they said ten. It was 9:45. Still refused my to go order. Won't be back
author: Jesse M.

description: I finally made it into this place! I have salivating about Arepas after watching food network show. The food was off the hook! We decided to split a dinner which came with one arepa rice and beans and ordered another arepa al la carte. The price was def on the higher end for what you get.
author: Kyle W.

description:
My husband and I had seen Pica Pica on DDD a while back, and I'd filed it away in my brain as a must-visit. Of course, none of my trips into the city have taken me in its vicinity...until yesterday. My friend recommended it, luckily, since I had spaced on even wanting to go there. So off to Pica Pica we went! 

Im severely gluten intolerant, so you can guess my excitement at trying a 100% gluten free place. The rest of the group (there were 5 of us) were game, especially because they know how hard it is for me to eat out sometimes. Well, this place did not disappoint on options, or flavor! 

I knew I wanted to try an arepa, and everything on the plato sounded amazing, so I ordered a beef plato. Of course, I misunderstood the menu, and didn't realize that the platos don't come with the meat in an arepa. Oops! Luckily, they let you buy them separately, too. So I got one, and stuffed my own! Soooooo good! Our table orders consisted of a pulled pork plato (with arepa on the side, oops, again!), a grilled chicken plato, a tofu arepa, a chicken arepa (I think), and an order of plantain and taro chips. All of the arepas were the yellow sweet corn. The platos all came with black beans, coconut rice, sweet plantains, and your choice of entree. The chips were crispy and not at all greasy. I only had the beef, didn't taste anyone else's, but everyone loved it, and we were all stuffed afterwards! We seriously considered finding a park nearby to stretch out for naps! 

I am giving Pica Pica 4 stars, because, while the menu could have been clearer, and the seating is a bit cramped, everything else was A+! I look forward to visiting again and again. Any thoughts/plans on opening a Sacramento location? I'd be there all the time!
author: Carla M.

description:
Absolutely Delicious!!! I have been waiting to try this restaurant for quite awhile now..The reviews here, well, some were so bad, it almost made me wanna go elsewhere as there are a million yummy places to eat here in San Fran..But....We did it ,we came in last night aroung 5 ish......We had a hard time ordering the Arepa...
We finally chose the Pulled Pork with avacado and a sweet yellow arepa...and the Taro chip nachos with pulled pork..We shared as usual, every bite was so good i was saying ummmm this is so good..The sauces are so good but i like the yellower one..spicy and delicious i put it on every bite..I liked the red one too..Besiides that we had ordered two Coconut lime drinks. OMG very good and refreshing..seating was limited but we managed to find a spot on the wall and fully enjoyed every bite...We will be back sometime in the future for sure..BTW we didnt see the Tofu Arepa on the menu..Finally we left satisfied and happy that we came in ,thankfully didnt listen to the bad reviews..Thankyou from Kat and Pete
author: Kat S.

description:
Have I not reviewed this place yet? It's gotten better and better. The kitchen is 100% gluten-free, so every fried item on the menu is safe for celiacs (a.k.a. "heaven").

My favorite meal is the pulled pork pernil, but with chicken instead of pork, on the white arepa. The white arepa is a thing of beauty: made only from corn, it mimics the crispy chewiness of an English muffin. The yellow arepa is closer in consistency to a pancake.

Packed with meat, and together with a side of yuca fries and chipotle catsup, one arepa sandwich makes for a highly satisfying and flavorful meal. The "fruit frescas" are a bit on the sweet side, but they do help tame the spice of the meal.

For dessert (if you have room) you'll want to check out the coconut quesillo, a Venezuelan version of crème caramel, and the yuca beignets (need I say more?).
author: Omar Y.

description: This was disappointing. I had this place marked and was super excited to try and the arepas were sooo not good.
