The sweet yellow arepa is too sweet, and the texture is so consistent and thick. The crispy chicken was over fried and oily.... I am somewhat optimistic and do think maybe some of the other arepas might be better. Also friend got the nachos, which were huge and fresh looking. She loved that. But with the experience I had here, I doubt I will be back to try other things on the menu unfortunately. Not memorable :(
author: Lisa K.

description:
I had Pica Pica bookmarked for quite some time, but never found myself in the neighborhood unless I had another destination in mind. 

Just yesterday, the stars finally aligned in just the perfect way; I was wandering around the Mission District, killing time, waiting for a friend. I was feeling a little hungry, but mostly trying to be proactive, as our plans involved heavy drinking to properly start Pride Weekend off with a bang.

I ordered the Vegetariano arepa, which is described as having "grilled tofu, avocado, sweet plantains, black beans, garlic aioli". I asked the cashier if omitting the aioli would make it vegan, and she said yes. I also opted for a side of the yuca fries. Total bill was around $14 bucks (including tip). A little on the pricey side, but I was willing to pay a few dollars extra for something exotic. 

You are given a choice of classic white or sweet corn for your arepa, and I'm a stickler for the classics, so I chose the former. There was a lot of flavor in that bad boy. I especially loved the contrast between the savory ingredients and the sweetness of the plantains. I would order extra plantains, if anything, because if you accidentally eat all of them before you finish the rest of your arepa, it loses a lot of the flavor. 

Plus plantains are fan-freaking-tastic, and you should always order extra, regardless. 

I've only had one other arepa in my life, and Pica Pica's version was much more flavorful. Then again, I smothered mine with the red chili sauce on the table, which also gave it a nice kick. I love how plentiful the avocado was, as well. 

I'm not a gluten-free gal by any means, but this is a terrific option for any of those who are, as nothing in their restaurant contains any gluten. Yes, that's right. It's 100% gluten free! 

I appreciate that they offer a few vegetarian options, although I wish there was a vegan arepa listed on the menu, just to even it out and give us cruelty-free folks peace of mind when we order our food.
author: Brandi W.

description:
(UberEATS)

These things are freaking delicious! I wish I could buy arepas and keep them at home and just like reheat them, but doesn't seem to be an option. The bread is so corny and delicious. I lurv corn.
author: B H.

description:
I came here as part of the San Francisco culinary mission district food marathon (follow the link and you can make a vote) and was pleasantly surprised with the offerings they had have to make it good for me. First thing, you walk in and you can tell the care. The front counter offers a friendly yellow and how can I help you.

Next up? I got the pork and arepa. The slow cooked flavorful and excellent pork expertly placed in the delicately glavored corn she'll, well let's jus say I was glad I picked this place. It come with plantains too, inside them, which is a great addition to complement the flavor a of the pork and corn. I added a sauce to it, which you will have to try and see which you enjoyed (they had 3, 1 ketchup).

Aguas fresca to drink and everything on the menu seemed it'd be pretty top notch. Great little place and definitely what I d recommend if you're in the area and look for a bite.
author: Brinson D.

description:
Had this place bookmarked from Guy Feiri and since all the Nicaraguan restaurants we tried were closed, why Not. 
Had to start with a sangria and the shredded beef white corn Arepa, the bf chose chicken frito plate and we both shared sides of black beans and coconut garlic rice along with platanos.
Everything we had was very tasty and filling, the chile on the tables to give our meal a Lil kick was even better. 
Definitely will stop by again and hopefully not get to full
author: M A.

description:
The food itself has an alright flavor. Not bad at all but it is pretty expensive. The portions aren't that big but for an arepa and some nachos, I paid nearly 30$! 

Also, we came in at a very busy time so there weren't any seats available and it was pretty hard to walk around. 

I saw this place on an episode of diners drive ins and dives and I'm happy I came in but I don't think I'll be coming in again.
author: Carol C.

description: I love this place! It reminds so much of my culture. They're always playing great music and have awesome customer service.
author: Tatiana R.

description: This food is amazing!!!!! A MUST try for anyone in the Bay Area. It was great to start with a groupon, but I definitely went back even without one. YUM IN MY TUM!!!!
author: Danae D.

description:
I had a great arepa here.  The cornmeal pocket was sturdy and the meat contents were flavorful.  The best part was that Pica Pica is so fast with its service.  I only waited about five minutes before getting my order.  This is a kid-friendly restaurant, too!

1 star off: My agua fresca was on the super-sweet side...almost artificial tasting.  After a cornmeal arepa, I did not need more artificial carbs.
author: Ally W.

description:
This is a review based on an dine-in and to go experience. 

Dine-in: 
My best friend and I love latin food so we decided to catch up here one night. The service was good. It was a Thursday evening and there weren't too many people dining in. I chose to order the vegetarian arepa and got a fresh coconut lime juice. We also ordered vegetarian nachos that came with taro chips. 

The nachos are heavenly. They're are incredibly delicious, authentic, and absolutely flavorful. All of the ingredients were fresh and the taro chips definitely were a good twist in comparison to traditional nachos chips. 

The vegetarian arepa was a bit mediocre. The tofu was not flavorful at all. It was poorly cooked and not marinated.  The arepa wrap dominated most of the dish. It was sweet, but I expected something savory. 

The coconut lime juice wasn't as potent in sweetness or tangy-ness as I'd like it to be. 

For $40? You can go somewhere else better. 

To-Go: 
If you ever order it on the yelp app-it works great. 

I ordered the vegetarian nachos and the vegetariana ceviche. Once I got to open the container for the ceviche- there was shrimp. 

The total for the nachos and the ceviche? $30. 

I'd only come back for the vegetarian nachos.
author: Rachel C.

description: I have been going here every Sunday after church for a year! This ENTIRE restaurant is gluten free and is wonderful is you're craving Latin food! My favorite is the Enselada Verde and yuca fries! The platanos are incredible as well!
author: Laura L.

description:
I've got a new favorite place when I'm in San Francisco!  In a city with so many great restaurants to choose from, I shamelessly keep ordering take out from this place.  

Pica Pica Arepa Kitchen is 100% gluten-free.  

Those of us that are allergic to gluten appreciate the value of knowing that whatever you order, it won't make you sick - the food, the sauce, etc.  This is one of those restaurants that "get it".  

The food is amazing!  The beef in the shredded beef arepa has been slow cooked and marinated in tangy bbq sauce.  Slap a big portion of that with sweet plantains on an arepa (sort of a sweet corn pocket) and you have a solid comfort food combination.  The garlic yucca fries and beef empanadas are a must try.

They sent a sampling of their delicious sauces on the side along with our order.  They ranged from sweet/vinegar to a spicy aioli.  You can tell by their attention to detail, they love food at this place and have a passion for preparing it for their customers.
author: Larry D.

description: Meh. First of all, $10 for an arepa is pretty steep. If you're getting the shredded beef/plantains as your filling, don't get the sweet corn arepa. I have a huge sweet tooth and that was way too sweet for me. My bf got the pulled pork/avocado and that one was a little better. I've always wanted to try this place whenever I walked by and I had high hopes, but it didn't meet my expectations.
author: Stephanie G.

description: It may be that the arepas here are good, but I just may not be a fan of arepas themselves as they are quite thick and a bit too filling.  I had mine with pork, avocado and other vegetables, plus I had some yuca fries.  The pork flavor and juiciness were great, but maybe I should not have ordered the yuca fries as my meal was a bit too starchy and heavy.  The mango fresco was a good balance, but I left feeling heavily full.  I will give it another try and order differently,
author: Maile N.

description:
Oh how i Dream of a Pica Pica opening in Los Angeles! I got to try them this past weekend when I was up in SF. I went there twice over a three day weekend, so that should say something.
I tried both the chicken and pulled pork arepa as well as the fried banana side (Yucca?).
Everything was delicious. I have the worst intestines ever and have celiacs disease, so the arepas here are a godsend. They fulfilled a long lasting craving I've had for a good solid sandwich. Very Yummy!! I lathered their hot ketchup sauce over my sandwich too, its amaze!!
author: Amala S.

description: By far it's a hearty meal!!! I order arepas the first time I came here... And I wasn't disappointed it was good... This time I went with "cachapa" and wow!!! It was sooooo good by far I think I am sticking with cachapas from now on can't go wrong!!!
author: Abby E.

description:
I don't remember a lot from my three years of middle school/high school Spanish class.  Oh sure, I remember a little bit here and there.  But, three things actually stand-out.  1.  The Chupacabra.  Creepy.  2.  In Spanish, a rooster doesn't say Cock-a-doodle-doo.  It says:  Qui-qui-ri-qui.  3.  We saw a commercial for a packaged Arepa mix.  Dona Arepa!  That was the first I'd heard of Arepas.

There's a part of me that isn't quite sure if I love this place because of the food, or because every time I think of it, I think Dona Arepa!  As this is Yelp, and not a therapy session, we'll go with the fact that I love this place because it is delicious.

This was my first experience eating Arepas.  The menu is pretty extensive, ranging from starters to arepas to full-size entrees.  I've yet to have anything that wasn't good.  That said, I'm a creature of habit, so I go with the Arepas.  There are two that totally stand out to me:  The Beef Pabellon (with sweet plantains, black bean spread, queso fresco) and the Pulled Pork Pernil (with sliced tomatoes, avocado, pica'pun, garlic aioli).  Take the above, and serve it on a Sweet Yellow Corn Arepa (I've never tried the White Arepa, and I'm not sure I will because the Yellow Corn is SO good).  The mix of flavors is incredible and well balanced.  Truly one of the most tasty places I've come across.  The Arepas are about $9 and come with a nice slaw.  It's plenty of food - although it is tempting to get the Yucca Fries too.  Why - because the killer-star of the place is their side sauces.  Garlic Aioli.  Spicy Jalapeno Mustard.  Some sort of souped-up Ketchup.  Wow.  I'm wondering when they are going to start selling this stuff on its own.

My one and only conundrum with this joint is that I'm wont to stick with the same thing I've already had because it was just so good.  The platters and the Cachapas (sweet corn crepes) all look great.  But, how to pass-up what I already know is amazing.  ...  These are high-class problems.
author: Adam S.

description:
My first time trying Venezuelan food and it was aMAIZing.

Ordered the lunch special with pabellon arepa and their bululu salad. Arepa looked small but was actually very filling and yummy. WIsh there were more plantains because I'm all about the plantains. Salad was light and refreshing. Perfect complement to the arepa.

Wish there was more seating available. Would like to come back to try their cachapa and maize'wiches. AND their pitchers of sangria.
author: Jennifer C.

description: I was there today to pick up UberEats orders. Employees were so mean to me for no reason. Lol I don't even look like trump
author: Ariel Nashiro C.

description:
We had lunch here and the mix of food was very good. 
Arepa stuffed with seasoned beef, black beans and queso fresco. All of the food was fresh and very tasty. The soup, shredded chicken with corn, once again all fresh and tasted great. You must try the yuca fries with garlic.
author: John B.

description: In the 10 minutes between my 1st bite of my arepa with pulled pork and me throwing up, this was a 4 star review. I thought the $10 was a bit much for an arepa and a side of slaw. But after that 1st bite I thought the price was well worth it. That was until I started to throw up while eating it. To be fair I think it was the slaw that did it and not the arepa. But alas only my stomach knows.
author: Natasha R.

description:
We came a long distance to eat here tonight, and we were very pleased.  Food was great. The sangria was the best ever.  It's too bad there isn't a restaurant closer to me.  Well done, Pica Pica!

Returned on May 7th with my family.  The food was delicious.  My youngest, who is gluten free, loved everything.
author: Ken R.

description: This place will likely disappoint you if you have spent time in Venezuela or Colombia - the arepas here simply aren't the same as they are on the streets of Caracas, Maracaibo, Bogota, etc. (even though they are probably a bit healthier here, if you can believe that). This is not to say that the food isn't tasty here - it just seems quite overpriced and isn't quite the authentic cuisine that you would expect in the heart of the Mission.
author: Andy L.

description: Excellent GF menu. Arrows are a go to as are the yucca fries, garlic sauce in the side.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
Please...stop with the cheesy loud 90's music. Also, the service has been lacking. 

We came here tonight and wines are no longer available even though it is on the menu. 

I asked for grilled chicken and got sloppy shredded chicken instead...

With all the amazing spots nearby not sure I'd go back.
author: Mimi T.

description:
This place was a total bummer. :(  There's a big disconnect between the cashier (where you order) and the kitchen. Also, the kitchen staff doesn't seem to understand what vegan means.

I walked by one day and stopped to see if there were vegan options.  The cashier was really friendly and told me a few things that were vegan or could be made vegan.  On the menu, there is a "V" symbol, meaning it can be vegan.  

I came back a few days later with a friend to try it out.  We ordered/requested the vegan nachos and some black bean and plantain empanadas.  

The empanadas they brought out were beef, cheese and black bean/plantain.  It was not what we ordered, but my omnivore friend went ahead and ate the beef and cheese empanadas.  The black bean and plantain empanadas were pretty good.  All were incredibly greasy, tho.

Then the nachos came out and they were sprinkled with cheese.  I asked the server if that was cheese and she said yes.  I told her that I had requested vegan nachos.  She took the plate back to the cashier who kind-of sighed and said that, yes, it was supposed to be vegan.  Then the server came back with what was obviously the same plate, but some of the cheese had been picked off.  I didn't want to make a fuss, as I was there with my friend but it totally grossed me out.  Every few chips I picked up, there was some cheese on it.  I can't believe they gave me back the same plate!!

I'm really disappointed in this place.  It seems unprofessional, unsanitary and all-around GROSS that they picked off some the cheese and gave me the same dish!  They didn't even succeed in taking off most of the cheese.  They should have made a new order when they messed up the first one, especially when the cashier confirmed it.
author: Miss W.

description:
A few years ago I met a gentleman on Bart, who told me about this place. I can't remember how we got to talking about food. Maybe he heard my stomach growl, like it always does, and thought maybe this tiny young lass was passing gas. I can't remember if it was gas... I digress.

We all got Arepa's. I got the Pulled Pork Pernil on Sweet Yellow. I chose to take out the tomato, avocado and have the sauce on the side. The rest of my family got: the Shredded Beef Pabellion on Classic white, and the Spicy Chicken Catia on Sweet Yellow. We all were quiet while we were eating. I really enjoyed the pork. It wasn't fatty and it was seasoned well. The taste of the sweet yellow paired with the seasoned pork, was an orgasm of tastes bursting together in my mouth. 

We also can't forgot to mention that we got the Yuca Garlic Fries basket for all four of us to share, the coconut rice side, the plantains side and a side of black beans for myself. Hopefully I won't see that same man on Bart...#ohyummyfood  

I can't forgot to include that everything here is Gluten Free!!! I'm excited to enjoy tasty delicious GF food with the ones I love. 
I gave it 4 stars because the seating inside was minimal. I noticed upon leaving there was a large patio where more seating was, but saw no one brave enough to sit out in the cold. Maybe close up the patio and have heaters. If you do choose to come here, I would order to go. They do have bar seating but it's best if it's just a party of two. 

Pica Pica, please build one across the Bay and one down south in San Diego.
author: Lara R.

description: Delicious arepas! The pulled pork is cooked perfectly - and the arepa is positively stuffed with it. Delicious sauces: spicy, sweet, smoky. i appreciated the very subtle integration of mint in their cole slaw and their white sauce. Very fast & friendly service.
author: David W.

description:
Visited Pica Pica last week. I am Venezuelan and I want to be as fair as possible on my review. 

We headed to Pica Pica after getting our passports at the consulate. It is a short drive. 

The area is very dirty lots of trash and dog poop. Sorry but San Francisco is getting worse...mayor's fault.my guess.

PicaPica has a very nice decor and feeling. Menu is precise and not overwhelming. We ordered the empanadas. Arepa reina pepiada, cheese and pernil. To drink coke.... of course..arepa and.refresco....priceless

The cashier was very nice helpful and friendly. It is an open kitchen so you can watch them make u arepas. The arepas are big and made in the grill. Like areperas in Venezuela. 

My wife got the yellow corn arepas. Venezolanos be aware.... Yellow arepas are made w cachapa mixture not arepa yellow flour. So be aware my wife who is also Venezuelan was dissapointed when she ordered the yellow arepa w reina...cachapa with reina mixture...not what she expected!! It was good flavor..

I ordered the pernil arepa was very good. I was looking forward to get guasacaca but they offer a guacamole type mixture.it was good..

My kids got arepas with cheese.
Butter would be nice to have available. They love them. Queso y mantequilla..the perfect pair

Well Empanadas...3 for $5.50 sounds like a good deal. Flavor...not good. The empanadas were not up to par. The real secret for a good empanada is to make them very thin so cook faster and suck less aceite.  The empanadas were in a pool of oil...let it drip a few sec before plating..just a recomendation....

It was about 2pm and the place had a lot of business. The salads looked good. Fresh parchita juice being made.
.People in and out. It seems it is a very popular spot. Plus they promote that Guy Fieri filmed there..nice big fan!!!

Kuddos to the manager and The staff was very nice and friendly. 

I wish the spot was at a nicer area of San Francisco.  Thank you for bringing arepas to SF. LOTS OF SUCCESS...
author: Daniel P.

description: Very filling for its size. I ordered this from Uber Eats and it still arrived to my house crispy and warm.
author: Jeselle O.

description: Go spend your money somewhere else! The service was terrible and the food was just meh.
author: Frank D.

description: Amazing food! Every bite I was in love. I shared the Pica Pica nachos with my friend and we each got our own Arepa. The vegetarian Arepa was completely FILLED and delicious with tofu, avocado, beans, plantanos and the most delicious aioli I've ever had! Cannot wait to go back!
author: Jackie S.

description:
Everyone is right... I had a gone a few months back and had the best experience. This time was a bit different but I still enjoyed my time there. The soup was solid with warm corn on the cob, cool sliced avocados, shredded chicken and cheese.  My arepa was huge and the spicy chicken which was recommended by the lady at the cash register was delicious in my warm sweet corn arepa. My passionfruit agua fresca like drink was tart and slightly sweet like it was supposed to but the rest of my food wasn't made like I'd had it in the past. 

My beef empanadas to go were great but the cheese "tres empanadas" were totally over fried and almost too crispy and soggy with oil. The cheese inside had dried out and when I took a bite the whole thing was like a big fat fried cracker. It crumbed and got grease all over my pants and of course hands. The pot de chocolat with shredded coconut flakes was a nice break from the oil, it was thick and rich and I was good after two bites. My sister enjoyed the rest in the car. 

Besides the soup, the highlight was the kid's chicken strips... I don't usually order from the kid's menu but due to my leaky gut and severe sensitivity (actually react immediately) to gluten, I order anything fried if it's gluten free no matter where I go. With their fine and fun sauces I was stoked for the fried chicken. The only problem was that it was an accordion cut. You know when you pick something up and it is one long stip because it is not cut all the way through?!? Still very edible but just with a little more care it would have been a little better. 

I don't mind that the prices went up (so it seems) as I just read they closed their Oxbow location which makes me very sad but I think they should bring it back to the level it was a few months back and put that pep back in their step. It can be done. 

3 stars but an extra one for being so gluten free friendly!
author: Shiho F.

description:
If you're living la vida gluten-free, you'll love Pica Pica.

If you're not gluten-free, you'll find yourself wondering: 'Just how did they get everything to taste so [expletive] good?'

It's a mystery... or the Venezuelans are gods.

But I digress. We arrived not even realizing Pica Pica is a 100% gluten-free restaurant; our appetites especially healthy after binging on gluten, err, Belgian craft beers at the Monk's Kettle. We ordered a couple of arepas which are basically sweet corn pockets filled with everything from tofu, avocado and plantains to pulled pork, sliced tomatoes, and garlic aioli.

Because I used to eat quite a bit Venezuelan food when I lived in Chicago, I know that their version of chicken salad usually reigns supreme... and at Pica Pica, it also delivers! The salad is comprised of shredded chicken mashed up with creamed avocado, and then stuffed into the warm, sweet corn pocket. It's a Venezuelan specialty that I'll continue to order if a menu features it.

Also worth an honorable mention are the yuca beignets served with Dulce de Leche dipping sauce (I almost didn't believe these are gluten-free!) along with the garlic coconut rice. Next time, we'll be sure to give the pulled pork nachos a go!
author: Jelena Z.

description:
The most fantastic and interesting take on nachos I've seen.

Flavorful pulled pork, black beans, cheese, tomato, Guasacaca sauce piled high on... TARO CHIPS!  A massive serving for just under ten bucks?!  Blew my mind.  It's a must try.  And actually, it's pretty brilliant since taro chips seem to stay crispy longer than corn or tortilla chips.  So even the ones that have soaked up the tastiness piled on top, still have a crunch.

That's all I got.  What a mistake.  All their other food looked so good, but I was on a mission to try a bunch of places that day.

It's a chill little spot that I will definitely be back to.
author: Nimai W.

description: The arepas are great but my favorite is the vegetariano platos. The nachos are good too!
author: Aashay M.

description:
Outrageously huge portions of nachos. 

A coworker and I stopped in after a client meeting nearby -- we were drawn in by the smell of course. Have to say, we were not disappointed. 

Arepas: Wow. Amazing. Semi sweet corn bread thing. Pork was on point. These people know what's up. --- Also looks like a small portion, trust me: it's enough for a meal. You'll be super full. 

Nachos: Overwhelming. Didn't even finish half. flavorful, chips at the bottom (by beans) were super soggy so that was sad, but cest la vie.

Passion Fruit Fresca: Delicious. Super sweet. Would be better mixed with rum, but alas, this is not a bar. 

We ordered takeout - it took them a solid 10-15 min to get our food ready, so this is not the fastest of 'fast foods' out there. that said, I'd go there again to try something new. 

Fun vibes, nice people, funny shirts.
author: Andrea D.

description:
I have a tendency to follow Mr. Guy Fieri around, so had to hit up Pica Pica since it was on his list.

First of all, this place is TINY and PACKED on weekends. Come prepared to wait, squeeze in, and perhaps even share a table. Don't worry, it's a friendly neighborhood. :)

I was hoping to find authentic arepas like I've tasted in some other hole-in-the-wall Argentinian and Venezuelan places. The result was good, but was still missing something.

I opted for the Spicy Chicken Catira arepa. No joke on the spice, my mouth was on FIREEEE. The filling was good, but the classic white corn arepa was quite doughy and lacked flavor. 

There are a variety of sauces at the table, which I dabbled with. Some better than others, but a nice way to accent the flavor of the arepa.

I'm actually surprised at the quantity of food they dish out from the tiny kitchen, but it definitely seems to work! I may return to check out the sweet corn arepa flavor, as well, and also some of the side items that looked tasty - empanadas, yuca fries, and plantain chips!

Bottom Line: Don't expect completely authentic, and you'll appreciate the Pica Pica flavors.
author: Mansi A.

description:
Normally I'm pretty happy after getting food from this place but this time was unfortunately different. I placed my order on Eat24 through the yelp app, got my confirmation that my order would be ready in 20-30 minutes. I got there 30 minutes after my order was confirmed and they told me that I had to wait an additional 15 minutes. I was patient and waited. After another 30 minutes of waiting I finally got my food. No apology for the wait or anything. 

So I take my food home and expected some nice and tender shredded pork but the meat was dry and lacked the aioli sauce. This was quite strange since the bottom of the container had a puddle of juice. My husband had the shredded beef arepa and he was disappointed to say the least. They had forgot the plantains and had what look like a rather big inedible bay leaf in it.

I guess I would be more forgiving if this place were a bit more apologetic as I let but there was no remorse. There is no point in ordering online if I still have to wait. I get that it was busy but the extreme wait is not something I would want to waste my time with only to be provided with food less then mediocre. And I will never provide tip beforehand. This experience pretty much turned me off to this place. It's a shame because I really used to like it.
author: Kathleen T.

description:
Great food, terrible service. No apology for forgetting to make my order until I asked (after 20 minutes) if it was on its way. Even if you weren't the one responsible for making it, honey, you still could have apologized for the kitchen's oversight. A simple "I'm sorry" would have sufficed. 

Note: A line of 6 people formed after I ordered and all were served before me. That's what prompted me to ask when the server came past my table. She went to check on it, came back with more food for the table next to me, then asked for my receipt to bring back to the kitchen. Another couple of trips to the table next to me, and no comment from her. So I had to ask again if my order was on its way. And all I got in response was "I'm not the one making it."

(I didn't realize the post wasn't actually posted... This incident happened a couple of years ago. After that, I never went back.)
author: J. K.

description:
The pulled pork arapas is the most delicious thing I have ever put in my mouth. Seriously, it was like a mouth orgasm. The sweet corn mixed with pulled pork, avocado and the sauce was like nothing I have ever experienced. 
The fried plantains were good and the cole slaw average. But holy shit! The arapas was transcendent! Did I mention I liked it?
author: I M.

description: Welcoming vibe with vibrant music. The staff is always friendly. I ordered the vegetarian empanadas and they come with what appears to be guacamole but more like seasoned mashed avocado. Still really good! They're quick and the food I ordered was not greasy which is great! I want to go back and try something else now
author: Eliza B.

description: Visiting San Fran and had to try this place. Food is very good and fresh, definitely would go back.
author: Kyle R.

description:
I had been wanting to try this place for so long. Yes, I saw them on Diners, Drive-Ins and Dives...and they have such great reviews. Years ago I had actually tried the Pica Pica food truck at the Treasure Island flea market. Back then I ordered the vegetarian sweet corn arepa and thought it was super! My first time at the actual restaurant, though, was greatly disappointing. I actually left the place feeling sad.

I ordered the beef pabellon white corn arepa with a side of yuca fries. The portion size and price I thought seemed normal for the area, so no complaints there, however the taste and quality of the arepa was pretty subpar--almost bad even. After I ordered, my food came out super fast. I was hungry so I picked it up right away and I was not able to even hold it because the whole thing was wet and mushy. So I had to eat it with a knife and fork. The arepa pocket itself was not cooked all the way through and was a little raw inside. The masa was wet and clumpy. The inside was quite lackluster and had just a one-note sweet flavor running through it. Like, sweetness was the only flavor I could taste at all. The beef was not very tasty either--even the meat had absorbed all the sweet flavor. The ratio of meat to plantains was strange too: there was very little meat but 3 big pieces of plantains (it was like a plantain sandwich). I did order the yuca fries and those were delicious though! But the avocado dipping sauce that came with it was super sour...like maybe they had put too much citrus without tasting it. The slaw accompaniment was also overly sour--I know it's supposed to be tart, but it was an unbalanced sour. My first Pica Pica experience at their food truck was great--I liked everything very much...but this experience at their Valencia St restaurant was disappointing. It seriously bummed me out and I was sad for the rest of the day because I had actually planned my day around going to lunch there. They only thing good I can say is that the yuca fries were really good and just like how it was from their food truck.
author: Sam C.

description:
3.5 Stars

I first had Pica Pica in Napa at the Oxbow Market and it was amazing! The Yuca fries and the arepa were a standout. So when I found out that Pica Pica had opened another location in the Mission district in SF, I wanted to try it out. The place is very cute and I love how they have sample dishes laid out in a cabinet so you know how their food looks like. I had ordered the shredded pork arepa and the yuca fries with the spiced ketchup. My total bill came out to $13 without tax. Really expensive for a fast-casual establishment.

My food came out pretty quick and I was excited to eat, mainly the yuca fries. The yuca fries were not like I remembered. They were more dense than the last time I had it but still had a nice crunch to it. The arepa too was very dense and wasn't light and airy like I had it in Napa. I don't know if it is this location or the quality slipped a little but I would definitely come back to see if it wasn't just an ok day. Overall, a simple lunch but quite pricey when there are other takeout places nearby for half the price.
author: Danster L.

description: Great gluten free options at this arepa place, but varying quality of food. Sometimes my food is piping hot and tastes super fresh, other times its just good. Love the sweet corn arepas, and the maduros they put into the shredded beef are excellent. Fast casual style restaurant with 5-6 small tables and bar seating.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Latin American food is my absolute favorite and so I was thrilled when friends of ours suggested we try this place.  Pica Pica specializes in Venezuelan street food.  Fond memories of tangy and wholesome fare from prior Latin dining experiences filled my mind and whet my appetite.  Sadly, Pica Pica did not satisfy and fell far short of my expectations.  Frankly, the food was not that tasty and the service was typical of a fast-food joint.

We tried several of their Arepas, which could be described as a corn flatbread sandwich with your choice of barbecued meat filling and a slice of plantain.  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/pica-pica-maize-kitchen-san-francisco?select=fD81tF8tALBFtid4cJCk_g#xn9fSd7LoPVXsSFj8esj7Q   They also offered a vegetarian version with marinated tofu patties instead of meat which was fantastic tasting, better than the meat filling!    http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/pica-pica-maize-kitchen-san-francisco?select=fD81tF8tALBFtid4cJCk_g#lPxfsuo3e74-_Y9i3X_8tw  For starters we shared an order of yucca fries, these were super crispy and pretty good when combined with any of their potent sauces.  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/pica-pica-maize-kitchen-san-francisco?select=fD81tF8tALBFtid4cJCk_g#z9iY4LjpZMNbRZn_dXgJew

Overall the food was decent and filling but relatively tasteless when compared with my favorite Latin restaurants, Sol Food in San Rafael or Brazil Cafe in Berkeley.  I think I would even prefer an order of humble papusas to Pica Pica's food.  Overall I would rate the dining experience a 3.5 and I doubt I will be back anytime soon.
author: Ethan Z.

description: Ventured into the mission today and discovered Arepa, which is a corn pocket filled with meat. I split a sweet corn crispy chicken Arepa with my friend. It came with a side of slaw and we also ordered a side of coconut rice. The sweet corn was good. It was probably my favorite part of the arepa. The crispy chicken was good too-not oily but I couldn't taste the seasoning. The coconut rice was just ok. I will def come back to try the other arepas.
author: Tommy L.

description: Good food, large portions at reasonable prices. Three of us shared the crispy chicken Plato, a salad that had hearts of palm, grilled chicken & lettuce greens, chicken & corn soup, and the yuca beignets for dessert. The crispy chicken Plato came with rice, black beans and fried plantain. It was very good. The chicken was a little over fried, causing it to be a bit dry but otherwise it was forgivable and tasty. The salad was tossed with a tasty vinaigrette that complimented the ingredients which were fresh. I actually liked the grilled chicken in the salad more, with the smoky flavor. It was also a bit dry but with the dressing, that helps give moisture. I cut the corn off the cob into the soup, which was flavorable and the chicken in it was shredded and tender. The yuca beignets were moist but also kind of doughy in the center. Maybe it was the yuca. The caramel dipping sauce was alright. Nice decor with cheerful colors and native decorations. The restaurant is located on the corner and it's very pleasant to dine there, with the large window open and to watch people and cars go by.
author: Lucy L.

description:
I fell into the same "Diners, Drive-Inns, and Dives" trap that maybe other customers did. I saw it on the TV show and decided I wanted to try it.

I tried to place an order via Yelp's app with Eat24, but it was not a seamless experience. It was not user friendly and the prices were higher on the app than on the actual restaurant menu.

I called to place an order to-go, and after a series of being put on hold and forgotten about, managed to place my order.

My friends and I ordered:

1 - Grilled chicken arepa with yellow tortilla: I thought the arepa's fillings complemented the sweetness of the yellow tortilla well. 

2 - Blackend beef arepa with yellow tortilla: my boyfriend did not like his. He found the meat dry.

3 - Crispy chicken arepa with yellow tortilla

All of the arepas were $9.50 each- very pricey considering the size!

4 - Pica pica nachos ($12~): I think this was the best item that we ordered. I love that the nachos came with taro chips, and the pulled pork was juicy and tender. I wish they gave more fillings though, as we ran out of toppings and had bare chips at the end.

I might return for the nachos, but the arepas are very expensive for what you get.
author: Mina K.

description:
VEGETARIAN AND GLUTEN FREE AND BOMBNESS (meat options too).

Don't get the huge plate, get the Aerpa (ask which tortilla to serve it on, white or yellow, they usually know the best pairing) and a side of the coconut garlic rice.
author: Dede C.

description:
Came here for a late dinner on a Wednesday night.

Considering this is supposed to be a dine-in restaurant, it definitely doesn't feel that way. There's not a whole lot of decorations (or even tables to sit at really) and the utensils and plates are all cheap looking and plastic.

The food was just okay. The portions are decent, but the flavoring was too salty for my taste. I had some kind of carne asada plate. It came with a hunk of meat and some fried plantains. The plantains were delicious but not the best I've ever had. The meat was, in my humble and not particularly attuned to any sort of Mexican/Spanish/Latin American food tastes, worse than something I could get from say Taqueria Los Coyotes a few blocks away or even Chipotle.

To drink I had a lime coconut beverage, which tasted weird at first (lime and creamy coconut milk? lime and any kind of milk???) but it got better the more you drank.

Overall I probably wouldn't come here again. For two dollars signs, I'd rather just go to a Chipotle. The food is cheaper with equal (maybe slightly less) portions and the ambiance is about the same anyways.
author: Whitney L.

description: I have celiac disease, and it's very difficult for me to find delicious gluten free food. This place is 100% GF - so we knew we had to try it. The result? The most DELICIOUS LUNCH I've had so far in San Francisco. Absolutely delicious! I had the vegetarian arepa and yuca fries.
author: Bethany F.

description: One word: Delicioso!   I went to Pica Pica because it was Gluten free.  My friend and I had no idea about the culinary adventure we were about to embark upon.  Indeed we decided to get a "smaller" order and split it.  Yeah... the portion sizes are suuuuuper generous.  We got the nachos and one of the arepas (traditional white) with some type of beef ( its the last meat option on the menu  I think its blackened?).  As I am half Colombian, I have a special place in my heart specifically reserved for arepitas!  This place did not disappoint.  Defs give it a try and really explore the menu.  As an aside, their sangria was also pretty good!
author: Candice B.

description:
Thanks to Lorrie M, my local Yelp Elite friend who brought me for lunch on the start of the personal tour of the Mission that she organised for me

I'm not a connoisseur of Mexican food and I gather that Pica Pica do a nice variation of the usual tex mex fare available. The main difference is that they use maize rather than flour to make their wrappers, making them gluten friendly and lending a sweetness not present in flour

The meat fillings was nicely flavoured and moist though needing a little hot sauce to really bring them to life. The plantain and yuca fries provided some interesting starch and were quite filling

It was a good solid start to my tour of the Mission with Lorrie
author: Yee Gan O.

description: Very disappointing. I ordered food here through grubhub and it was a bad experience. Cold food. Rude girl answering the phone at The restaurant hung up on me. I called back and told her I didn't appreciate that and she laughed. The grubhub driver called me at my hotel and asked me to meet her downstairs because she was illegally parked. I told her the point of delivery was delivery. She was in the lobby when I went down. I got my food cold. Disgusting cold cheese empanadas. I'll think twice before ordering there again.
author: Beautiful D.

description:
One of my favorite spots in the city. 

Their arepas are amazing (sweet corn with shredded beef!) as are the nachos. The only thing I was disappointed with were the empanadas.

I love this place and it is at the top of my list when I come into the city to eat. We take visitors here and they always love it too! It's a small space but we have always been able to find a place to sit and parking isn't too bad. 

This prices have gone up since we started going which is unfortunate but again it is definitely worth it!
author: Morgan O.

description: Updating my review! I've recently tried Pica Pica again, and it seems that perhaps I just ordered something that didn't quite suit my tastes. I tried some of their food again after my sister brought some home from her visit. The size must've been very generous for one dish to feed two people lol. I believe it was the Shredded Beef Pabellón Cachapas with plantains. I'm already looking forward to my next visit to try something new :)
author: Bianca C.

description:
Brought me back to the streets of Bogota.

I am completely biased against white arepas, as they are not my favorite, but give me a arepa de choclo and I am extremely happy. Though its not quite as good as the lady on the street who made fresh arepas to order on the streets of Colombia, there is some added flavor and variety with the fillings at Pica Pica. The pork and steak were both delicious and flavorful, strong taste which complements the sweet arepa perfectly. I will definitely be back.
author: John A.

description: The food gets a 5!  The only problem with this place is it is kind of small and parking sucks.  But you MUST go to try the food.  Their homemade sauces were delicious and they had vegetarian options that would make a meat eater want.  Love this place and cannot wait to go back.  I wish they had a place in the East Bay so I could go more!
author: Megan M.

description:
So bright and colorful, intimate and comfortable. 

The shredded beef Arepa that I had was fantastic and for the price, I was surprised by how much taste and thought was put into the dish. If there weren't so many delicious places to eat in SF, I would have to come back.
author: Jolie D.

description:
Thrilled to have found Pica Pica's tasty arepas! 

It would have been five stars, but the customer service was lack luster. On a positive note, they were willing to make substitutions (remove onions), which is appreciated, and helpful for food-challenged folks like me.
author: Cecilia C.

description:
Grilled Plantain & Taro Chips - At first I got trolled... I thought the plantains were potatos =[ The plantains weren't bad. Kind of sweet. Not mushy or hard. The Taro chips were good. Not salty but very crispy and fresh.

Pica Slaw - This was a nice and refreshing salad. Ingredients were definitely fresh. The dressing wasn't heavy.

Pulled Pork Pernil with Sweet Yellow - I did not know what I was getting myself into upon biting into this. It was SUPER SPICY!! It was like some sweet chili sauce; I think it's called Pica' pun. Though the arepa was really flavorful. Pork was lean and tender. The yellow corn wrap was nice and sweet, definitely something different. The avocado on mine was all mashed like guacamole but I'm not complaining. It's really big too so it will fill you up!

All in all, good food experience!
author: Benita M.

description: Loved the chipotle ketchup! If you're in the mood for something fast, healthy and delicious, that is different from the tacos you eat all the time, go here.
author: Sheviche R.

description: This place is so dirty n food is cold I had grilled chicken plato it's too bad n the server the girl is so rude I don't recommend to my family or friends in this place better go to McDonald's the girl very rude
author: Darjeelinga N.

description:
I've been meaning to stop in here for quite a time. I just had to get that magic combination of being hungry, in the area, and finding parking....

So....., I finally made it. The girl at the register was very friendly and helpful as I navigated the menu. I originally went for the Cachapas but, sadly, they were out. So, I got the Arepa with the Beef Pabellón and a side of Yuca Garlic Fries. She was even very patient of my awful Spanish accent.

I originally took at seat at the long bar-like table but, every time the door opened, a FREEZING-cold draft came in so, I moved to one of the tables.

The food came out all together (nice surprise), the Yuca fries were nice and fresh and hot. I tried all of the various toppings but, found the cilantro-lime thing seemed to fit them best.

The Arepa was overflowing with meat (and came with a side of slaw), so the only way to attack it was with the chinsy plastic fork. The meat was tender and delicious, the corn from the arepa was crispy on the outside and nice and chewy on the inside. Can't complain about the food. A good solid tasty meal.

My only complaint: the crappy plastic forks. Some real silverware would have made the meal much more enjoyable. The crappy plastic fork made eating the slaw near impossible. Try to take a bite, and 90% falls off the fork before you can do anything. It's use in the arepa was marginal at best. A real fork could have changed the whole meal.

All in all, I'll come back when I get that magic 3.
author: Paul D.

description:
pretty good food, super (uncharacteristically?) fast service. 
Interesting flavors, but needed a little piquant zing, like the slaw they were serving on the side. Dumped that on my arepa and it was delish.
author: Amani Ellen L.

description: Sooo good, I've ordered here a few times and eaten in once.  The spicy chicken arepa is indeed spicy and the pork arepa is delicious and flavorful.  I recommend both.  The arepa cheese bites were a bit bland...
author: Dave R.

description:
I was reuniting with my San Diego buddy after nearly two years and we wanted to find a yummy place in the city for some gluten-free grub.  Even in San Francisco it can be a tall order, but we managed to find what turned out to be a great place for delicious lunch.

I ordered a Pabellon Arepa (skirt steak, plantains, beans, and cheese) and shared an order of empanadas (guiso, queso fresco, and chorizo and potato) and yucca fries with my buddy.  I found all of the food delicious, though I question how healthy it was since much of it was quite fried.  There wasn't anything I didn't like and the meal was nice and hearty, perfect for a Friday.

Service was pretty quick and everything was made fresh to order.  The restaurant gets pretty busy during lunch so it's good to get in early.  Prices were reasonable but can get pretty expensive once you start adding sides.  My sandwich and side came out to almost $14, so it's definitely not cheap.  Still, it's definitely worth trying and is a gem in the gluten-free scene.

Food: 9/10

Service: 8/10

Price: $$

Atmosphere: 7/10
author: Joe M.

description:
Delicious, TOTALLY over priced. Writing this as I stand in line and see that they've raised their prices.

For $9.50, you get a corn pocket with your choice of meat. I recommend the sweet corn with the pulled pork pernil.

I really like their food but it's just not really worth the price. I plan on coming back once in a blue moon if I'm really craving something. You'll get a lot more bang for your buck at many other places along Valencia. Go to El Buen Sabor.
author: Frances W.

description: Everything looked so good, we got plates, arepas and the nachos with carnitas ! The plates are my favorite because of the coconut rice.
author: Mariah S.

description: Tres empanadas is definitely for the kids, my 2 year old enjoyed the cheese empanadas, however the guacamole wasn't their best it was lacking on seasoning. The shredded beef pabellon was really good, a little bit sweet for my palette but it was worth trying it. The pulled pork pernil was definitely my favorite arepa, the taste wasn't sweet or spicy. The place is clean and the staff is nice. I do recommend this place.
author: Suzy R.

description: Great spot for the Gluten Free person and every one else... it is Venezuelan so everything is naturally corn based not wheat.
author: Alan R.

description:
Sought this place out for an arepa and was not disappointed. As a vegetarian, I've sometimes felt left out of the arepa game in some restaurants, but the vegetariana at Pica Pica was delicious. 

I went in during the odd time after lunch and before dinner, so nobody else was there. The cashier came out with fresh yucca fries for me just to snack on - delicious and a nice surprise! Excellent with the Pica'pun sauce.

My order was ready shortly thereafter and, like a good arepa should be, it was a tasty mouthful. I got mine without the tofu, and it was loaded with beans, avocado, and plantain. The arepa itself was cooked perfectly - crispy outside, soft and warm inside. It also came with a nice little slaw on the side to balance it out with some acidity. It was so much food! I didn't have to eat again the rest of the day and didn't want to cause nothing was going to be as tasty as my arepa!
author: Nicole H.

description: Friendly staff, great flavors, fresh tasting ingredients, fast service and good prices (9,50$ for the Arepa plate that gets you full). The yuca fries were so amazing too. Will come back to try their desserts which sound delicious too: yuca with dulce de Leche. Yum!
author: Leslie S.

description: Come in wAs my first time there. I walked up looked at the menu, was not greeted. So when It came time for me to order. She asked what I would like I ordered two pork with sweet yellow corn and yuka frys with garlic. Came out to $37. She brought our food out and then brought out something else we didn't order and told me she was out of the yuka and had that instead so I kindly asked her for a refund that I didn't want what she had brought. Don't get me wrong the food is good but it's so damn expensive for a small portion to boot the cashier with black hair doesn't seem to care at all about service or smiling. I understand you don't want to be at work or don't like people but you shouldn't be in customer service if it's like pulling teeth for you to be nice. Att General manager train your people on customer service cause what they think is customer service is not. The guys in the kitchen rock so two stars for them!!!
author: Brandee D.

description:
This place is pretty small, so I wouldn't recommend bringing a big group here during rush hour unless you guys are planning to eat elsewhere. Our group was pretty big (7 people), but some people got there early so we got really lucky and snagged the largest table in the place. Also for this reason they don't take reservations.

The arepa ($8.95) and the cachapas ($10.95) are almost the same thing except cachapas are bigger. So the cashier looks at me and recommends the arepa but obviously I get the beef cachapa ... and eat the whole thing ^___^. Yum. It was very filling. It also came with a side salad, and there are cool sauces on the table.

My apartment is so close by I can literally see it while I'm eating in this place. I'm feeling it.
author: Cynthia W.

description: I love Pica Pica. I go there often. I pretty much restrict myself to the plato dishes. The arepas are good but too spicy for my taste. Gluten free so there's nothing to worry about there.
author: Paul M.

description: The food was exorbitant. $10 for a meager sized arepa. With $10 I can buy a burrito at la piñata and it would be way more filling. I did like my food though. I had the vegetariana and I think that the yellow, which is sweeter, masa for arepa is the real game changer in a good way. Absolutely loved it
author: Kaitlyn N.

description:
Great take on street food that's healthy, tasty and casual. We popped in for a late lunch and really enjoyed the food. The space was a bit cramped though. 

We had empanadas, the beef are great, the cheese I would skip.
Then we had the yellow corn wraps with chicken and pulled pork. Both great, the meat was tender and lean the quality of the meat was good. The corn gave it a nice sweet taste and great take on a comfort food, for those that don't like gluten this was a treat. 
The salad was kinda wilted and not worth it.
I had the house wine that was ok for what it was. 
Our tab was $40 not bad for lunch but given we ordered at the counter not the cheapest either. Ambiance could be better even though this is not a place for sitting around.
author: Inga W.

description:
I was having a meh experience but then the crispy fried chicken hit my mouth- whoa, outrageously good. The arepas themselves are great-crispy on the outside, moist on the inside. They have white savory and a sweet yellow corn one (I recommend the latter with the fried chicken). The pork filling was too dry for me, the plantains overcooked and with a cheese that resembles mozzarella, the yuca fries were ok (use the red sauce with those). I kept comparing to Limon's rotisserie place which has similar (but better) sauces and better yuca fries but they certainly don't have arepas. 

As far as atmosphere, you order and your food is brought to you, you bus your table.
author: Marina N.

description: I am Venezuelan so this is my kind of place, since I moved to San Francisco I was always looking for a place that had Venezuelan food, when I found this place I was so happy. I really like it. This is my type of food of course "AREPAS" !
author: Natalia M.

description: 5 stars ! Omg this place is sooo good ! Amazing ! I found out about it while watching food network ! Best lunch I had . The shredded beef , cheese and plantaines was amazing ! So flavorful . Ive recommended this place already to 5 people I know . I def will be coming back here very soon .
author: Sasha F.

description: We had the food ordered. My missus received the vegetarian pica pica nachos. There was about 5 chips with food on, the rest had NOTHING on. Plain chips. Useless! I hope there food in the restaurant is better. DO NOT ORDER FROM HERE!
author: Matt W.

description:
After we made our rounds at Off the Grid @ Fort Mason, Pica Pica was one of the stands that appealed to us. The line was long, but once we got to the front we placed our order. 

We got four arepas:
- Pernil (pulled pork, avocado, tomatoes): lots of meat! It was good in taste, but the corn pocket was a little... blah. It seemed like they cooked it hours before, and it was a little dry.
- Caribe (bean, cheese, plantains): I think we all liked this one the best (& the pepeada). Of course the corn pocket has the same issues as the previous one.
- Pabellon (skirt steak, bean, cheese, plantains): I thought skirt steak is like a steak...? This was pulled beef. It was good. There weren't enough plantains though. It was two tiny itty bitty pieces.
- Pepeada (chicken guacamole salad): this was very avocado-y, but pretty good! The chicken salad was nice and moist, so it helped the corn pocket. 

Overall, it was okay. I didn't regret getting this, but next time I would get something else.
author: Leslie P.

description:
Delicious food, huge portions, and the service was great! It's always nice to have cashiers with great attitudes and a sense of humor. It gets a bit busy at times, but the turn over is pretty fast so even if there is a line, it won't take long to get a seat or to take it to go.

They also serve some beers which go well with the food!
author: Rob P.

description: The food was delicious...until I found a fully cooked cockroach in my Shuli Arepa. Unfortunately, I don't eat meat so this was unacceptable. And oh yeah - did I mention it was a fucking cockroach?
author: Alison A.

description: This is my second visit to Pica Pica in a week!  Tried the Fried Chicken Sweet Yellow Corn Arepa with the Plaintains on the side.  It was cheap and hit the spot.  They make everything fresh.  And its ALL gluten free.  Cool little spot!
author: William P.

description:
had Pica Pica delivered and was just content. I think if they invested in different to go boxes I would be a much happier camper. our meal arrived half spilled out in a torn up brown bad from the "juices" and pretty cold :( 
the taste of the food was pretty good but just needed top warmed up.
author: John C.

description:
Decided to try this place out because we were in the area and saw it featured on "Dines, Drive-Ins and Dives" on the food network channel. Loved it!! First time trying Venezuelan food and I will definitely try again. I had the grilled chicken chachapas which is a taco like dish but the tortilla is made out of corn.  OMG...BOMB! The chicken was flavorful and the portion was huge! They have these dipping sauces on the table and I would put some on each bite and it added even more flavor. We had the cooked plantains as well which is topped with feta cheese. I wasn't really feeling the cheese on that one though, but the plantains were extra sweet and melted in my mouth.  

Dessert we tried the coconut quesillo for dessert which reminded me of flawn, it was OK...nothing too special. But the food is great here, and I didn't feel guilty after eating here because things were fresh and healthy.  Definitely would return and now I can say I've tried Venezuelan food.
author: Myrna Y.

description: By far the best Venezuelan food I've ever had, everything on the menu is delicious. I definitely recommend getting the Arepas. This is an extremely gluten free friendly restaurant because the entire kitchen is 100% gluten free! They also have fresh juice which is one of my favorite parts about it. Super cozy and cute interior, I'll definitely be coming back.
author: Megan M.

description: I have been waiting for a restaurant like Pica Pica. My family is from Venezuela and it is nearly impossible to get arepas like these in Los Angeles. If only I lived in SF so I could eat there every day! The Asado negro was AMAZING. You have to get it.
author: Steph S.

description:
Tried the Empanadas (appetizer, the beef one was def the best), a little on the small side but very delish and served with generous amounts of guacamole
and we got the dulce leche yucca beignets dessert (perfect for a cool day, warm and crunchy)
We just came in for a snack but we definitely want to go back for lunch another day.

Love that the entire menu is GF!!!
author: Win H.

description: Loved this place. Portions are filling, flavors are developed and well paired, price is right. Limited seating, so maybe plan to get take-out if you have a decent sized group. Coconut rice, yum! Pulled pork plato came with fried plantains that were a perfectly sweet end to a delicious meal! We also tried the garlic yuca fries which are heavy on the garlic and absolutely delicious!
author: Megan K.

description: I was not impressed at all!  Placing an order was difficult enough, the waitress had horrible customer service.  She should not be working there..didn't know what pabellon was,,,every time I would ask her a question she seemed to know nothing.  I wouldn't go there again even if it was for free.
author: kristy U.

description:
Nice atmosphere to wind down on a busy day with nice music and open windows for a good breeze. 

The food was excellent, I had an grilled chicken Arepa (which is a kind of a corn sandwich) stuffed with chicken, sauce, salad and tomatoes. Very far away from average food and exotic. 
Also worth to mention are the plantain chips. Very great. 

Definitely a place to come back!
author: Martin Z.

description:
Environment: uncomfortable chairs and wobbly table super annoying

Service: no issues

Food: ordered arepas one original white corn with crispy chicken and one sweet corn with pork and side of yucca fries . Both arepas tasted ok and came with a side of slaw. Yucca fries ok tasted kinda powdery. Food was pre frozen you can see the cooks taking food from freezer and cooking as orders came in. Sauces on the table were both good.

Price: kinda high around $10/arepa and fries $4 for 5 yucca sticks

The place is just ok like all other restaurants I've visited that have been on DDD.
author: ROXY G.

description:
I felt dissapointed when I tried the food in this place. As a venezuelan I think this food doesn't have any of the flavors of traditional venezuelan food at all.

I tried the  cheese empanadas which were ok. The arepa however felt far from a traditional one. The dough wasn't coocked properly and the mix of a traditional beef pabellon which is just all the ingredients mixed poorly and almost no cheese. 

I came here with four other Venezuelans and it generated the same reaction with everyone. In general I would not pay this price for the quality of the food.
author: Ricardo S.

description:
This place is amazing. I always love south american food and this place serves venezuela food. 

yucca frieds: only 5 fries, so it's pricey. but it is just so good. 
pull pork arepa: the corn bread is crispy, but i feel there isn't much pulled pork inside. it's $9 so it's quite pricey. pretty small. the cole slaw is just normal, but they have all types of homemade spicy sauces for you to add on - all are tasty! 

i would love to try their black bean and chacapa next time!
author: Ashley C.

description: The shredded beef arepa was pretty good, but I was expecting better since this place was featured on the Food Network. It was maybe a 7/10 for me.
author: Nicole F.

description: I came here because I was on the search for Colombian food in the Bay Area. I have struck out. However, Venezuelan and Colombian have some similarities. The arepa are hug and the corn was sweet with the the perfect texture. They did not skimp on the fillings. It is messy and can get a bit soggy. Still delicious! The staff was super friendly and the food came out quickly. I also enjoyed a glass of sangria. Not too sweet, light and refreshing and I felt the booze later.
author: becky G.

description:
From the reviews I expected  more. Not impressed.
Extremely confusing menu, girl at the front was not much help.
tried the yuca fries that everyone seems to like, our's were barely warm, fried maybe a half hour before, and only 4 or 5 pieces.
Same with the sweet corn arepa, Luke warm, a mess to try and eat, and a bit soggy. Don't need to do that again......
author: K. K.

description:
My friend and I came here yesterday after she read the ROTD, and announced, I like corn, so let's try it.  Since I had been to the Napa Pica Pica, I told her that this place was going to be THE BOMB, but unfortunately, the Mission location does not compare with the original Pica Pica in Napa, CA.

My friend and I ordered:
- a Pabellon arepa
- a Pabellon Maizewich
- garlic Yuca fries with aioli
- Tajadas (stir fried plantains)

Things tasted pretty similar between the Pica Pica in Napa and here, with the EXCEPTION of their plantains (in their tajadas and the plantains that they use to fill their arepas/Maizewiches/cachapas).  The plantains here tasted quite disgusting, almost like a deep fried, wet banana chips sopping with oil, barely even cooked--almost raw and too chewy, and definitely sweet.  Similarly, they smelled rancid, thus enhacing their unpalatable and disgusting taste.  The plantains over in Napa's Pica Pica has truly stirfried plantains, cooked in the Central American/Caribbean style whcih are wet, moist, soggy, and sweet due to the caramelization process from extensive stir-frying that brings out the sweetness.  

Because plantains are extensively used in Latin American cuisine, I had expected that the Mission's Pica Pica plantains would be cooked as I had like in the Pica Pica in Napa as well as what I've had in Latin American cuisine in general.  But no...and my friend was even more disappointed because she had expected that the plantains would be cooked the way we're used to... and truly the way to bring out the true flavor and sweetness of plantains.  As you could imagine, we could not finish the side of plantains because they just were not agreeable.

The one redeeming dish that Pica Pica does quite well is their yuca fries, which were as good as the Napa branch's.  Adding the garlic was an excellent touch, but costed an additional 50 cents.

The arepa and maizewich were so-so, and were a little too burnt.  They grill the arepa and maizewich (flat)breads, almost like a panini...but they overgrilled them that they were a bit on the charred side, imparting bitterness to the food.  It tasted like I was scarfing down carcinogenic charcoal down my throat.  Not very tasty and not pleasing to the palate either.

Overall, I was disappointed with Pica Pica in the Mission as it did not compare with Napa's branch.  I would have thought that the Pica Pica in SF would be better due to the sheer fact that there are more Hispanics here, so the quality and freshness of the food would be better.  But my expectations were not met.  I don't think I'd come to this Pica Pica branch again due to my poor experiences here.  However, if I am in Napa, I'd definitely go to that Pica Pica since the quality and taste far surpasses the averageness I experienced here in the Mission.

My overall rating for the restaurant is a 2 *star*.  Breakdown is as follows:  *3* stars for good quality yuca fries, but minus *1* star due to the poor quality of their plantains.
author: Matthew L.

description:
Just had an early dinner here. Spent $12.45 on a vegetarian arepa and yuca fries. 

Arepa- it was nice, creamy on the inside. The yellow corn bread was perfect. Good flavor. 

Yuca Fries- Meh. Kinda lacked in the flavor department. Too thick of a cut for me so with each bite you could really taste how bland and dry yuca can be. 

Table Sauces- the white sauce was so delicious, worked well with the arepa. 

Service- the guy who rang me up was just as bland as the yuca fries-- I think he was stoned? A woman quickly replaced him and she was super friendly and attentive. 

Overall, an okay experience. I'm not vegetarian or gluten free so maybe that's why it wasn't very exciting.
author: Mona E.

description: The garlic yuca fries were good, but the arepa itself was oily, one-note in taste, and nothing to write home to mom about. Had it not been for the fries, it would have been a sad, and uneventful evening for my tastebuds. :(
author: Chase B.

description:
I've had Pica Pica several times now and everyone I've eaten it with loves it. 

But I haven't come around to it. Well, it's really just the corn version of the arepas and capachas I don't like (they so crumbly). The empanadas are decent.

I seem to keep ending up here somehow though, so perhaps I'll give the Shredded Beef Pabellón flour arepa a shot next time.

I do like the design of the place. Just not much seating.
author: An Y.

description: Awesome Latin food in the mission. I have had my fair share of arepas due to coming from Ecuadorian decent and I will say that these were great! The restaurant is right on the corner and offers indoor and outdoor seating which was convenient since it gets pretty busy during lunch. They offer a great variety of meats with the arepas from fried chicken to pulled pork. I decided along with my gf to get the plate, which consisted of the arepa and black beans+coconut rice. I am not to big of a fan of the coconut rice the consistency just didn't do it for me, the beans and plantains were great however, very home-cooked taste which I enjoyed. I got the pork option, it was savory and had no fat in it, just juicy meat which I loved! The tomato was an interesting touch, but I'm a fan for sure. I recommend this place!
author: Josue V.

description: The food here was soooo delicious! I am still missing this place...well worth a trip back to SF!! Just go!! :)
author: Kare B.

description: I tried my first arepa in NYC and fell in love. Coming back from my trip I have been on a hunt to find some here in SF, so I had high hopes for this place. Sad to say it was an expensive disappointment. My family and I shared two orders of white arepa with shredded beef, one with corn arepa, a side of plantains and pica pica nachos. The arepa was overstuffed with lackluster dry beef, beans and plantains that had an odd taste. The arepa itself was crumbling and tasted stale. The only thing I liked was the guava juice. This place is overpriced and not worth the quality. I guess I'll keep searching for some good arepas or fly back to NYC.
author: Alexa D.

description: Pica pica is a small hole in the wall. The arepas are always fresh and made to order. The sauces are delicious.
author: H K.

description: The food is here delicious, authentic, and a great value. This is one of our favorite LATAM places in the city. We usually get the grilled chicken arepa on sweet corn, a side of yuca fries, and an agua fresca. The food is great and the service is great as well.
author: Dani P.

description: Excellent food! Discovered this place from Diners, Drive-ins and Dives. It did not disappoint. Can't wait to come back here!
author: Nick S.

description: So flavorful and yummy. I got empanadas and yucca fries with crispy chicken on yellow arepa so good just sweet enough.
author: Marlene T.

description: I haven't been to the restaurant itself, but I've ordered delivery several times now and I can't get enough arepas! Portion-wise they are a good size and very hearty. I have a big appetite so I can easily eat two. My favorites are the blackened beef asado and the shredded beef.   The pernil is a little too spicy for me. The empanadas are so good too! I've been impressed with everything I have tried so far.
author: Gabriela P.

description:
Pica Pica was a great way for my girls and I to wrap up a day in San Francisco. Even though I'm a native San Franciscan, I can always rely on my friend Elise T. to find great eats in SF. She first heard about it in Napa and was stoked to find it here too. I've never tried Venezuelan food prior to this food and now, I'm wondering what other foods I'm missing out on! 

I ordered the Pulled Pork Yellow Corn Arepa ($9.50) and includes avocado, tomato, alioli (which contributes to a sloppy wet mess!), and pic a'pun. Initially, the portion seemed small for $9.50, but after taking a few bites, you realize the corn maize pocket will suffice. I loved the juicy, tenderness of the pulled pork. The alioli paired perfectly with the creaminess of the avocado. I squirted a lot of the orange sauce available on the table and though my mouth was burning, it burned too good to stop! 

My friends all order different meats for their arepas, including steak skirt, fried chicken, and grilled chicken. We all sat in silence as we ate, unless we were making "mmmmmmmmmm" sounds, if that's not an indicator of how good it is, I'm not sure what is. 

My friend also ordered Nachos ($10.25) and its not your average salsa, meat, cheese, and tortilla chips. Taro chips are used and its thinly sliced, crispy enough to withhold the toppings but still thin enough for a great, light crunch. The pulled pork meat, cheese, black beans, guacamole, and, oh excuse me while I wipe away my drool..... okay okay and Guausacaca sauce (white creamy sauce). IT WAS DELICIOUS! It wasn't really until towards the end that it got a bit soggy, but for the most part, the chips stayed crispy, paired perfectly well with the toppings, and I just want more!

Its a very casual setting but offers high quality, fresh food. Quick service is also a plus!
author: Connie C.

description:
I've never had an arepa so didn't really know what to expect other than dat yelp hype, but everything was still pretty good! You order at the counter when you get there, and they bring the food to your table. 

We got the shredded beef in the sweet yellow corn pocket and the shredded chicken in the white corn. If you're gonna go for an arepa, definitely get the yellow corn pocket! The white corn was sort of dry and flavorless while the yellow corn was sweet and definitely packed a bunch more flavor and wasn't as dry. I did see someone else get a yellow corn crepe thing that looked really good - I may have to get one of those next time. Also got the yucca fries! Yucca fries were good, super crispy on the outside like they should be.
author: D.J. N.

description: Great food. Yuca frita is definitely a must try. Not a lot of space thou but great food. Like really good. Definitely have to try their chachapas or their arepas on yellow corn. Beef Pabelion Cachapa is really good.
author: Xavier M.

description:
I went in to Pica Pica for lunch today and fell in love with the flavors so much that I had to order it for dinner again. Yes, that's how good it was. I'm waiting for my food to be delivered and I cannot wait. 

What I tried: the arepas (spicy chicken and minced beef), platanos, and garlic yucca fries. The sauces on their tables are to die for.
author: Peeta B.

description:
This place is alright. It was my first time eating Arepas. The place is quite small, so if you are going in as a large group, you will have a difficult time finding where to sit. 

I had one problem with the food. I ordered Empanadas and when I received them, they seemed to be very greasy and a bit over cooked. I told the staff about the overcooked empanadas and they willingly took the empanadas and made new ones. 

The Mojo is quite delicious and it adds a bit of spice and flavor to your food.
author: Ismael G.

description: I love this place. I always order the sweet yellow arepa with grilled chicken as the main course and the yuca fries and garlic coconut rice as the appetizers. It's like nothing I've ever had and so I can't really compare it or describe it for you guys. But please, you must try this place. It's really inexpensive for how delicious their food is.
author: Christina C.

description:
While walking one night we noticed this restaurant was quite popular.  We decided to try out this restaurant.  Menu as mentioned is simple :  pick one of three (arepa, crepe, or plate- rice.  Then select the meat you want.  Simple enough.  We opted for the arepa - this was not toasted as well as it should have been.  The Plate option provides coconut rice (which was tasteless and mushy).  The meats we had were tasty - spicy chicken, pulled pork and beef.

Not bad and not great
author: Bill L.

description: I ate here with my friend and it was delicious. The food had flavor, the steak was tender and juicy, and the arepas were very tasty. The coconut lime drink is very refreshing. I can't wait to go back!
author: Chev B.

description: It is a Venezuelan concept, however I do not considered Venezuelan food at all, also too expensive for the quality of the food, in my opinion an overrated place for sure.
author: Jonathan H.

description:
Some of the dishes are OK -- the salads in particular are good. Some of the other dishes, like the arepas can be dry and starchy, with a poor ratio of filling to corn.

I'm surprised this place is so popular, though, because of how expensive it is, given how casual the place is (counter service) and the relatively small portion sizes. The prices were just raised up to 25% more, making this place a really poor value. The arepas are now $10 each, and they are really more of a snack than a meal. Even the "platos" aren't filling on their own, and cost $14 each. So it's easy to spend $25+ per person on a full meal, which is a fortune for this type of meal.
author: David C.

description:
4.5

After hearing about this gluten-free paradise for months, I was excited to finally check it out. Sometimes, after building something up in your head for so long, the actual experience can't possibly compete. I'm glad to say that isn't the situation at all at Pica Pica. If you've heard good things, expect to experience good things. 

In all my years of gorging on comida latina (I hope I said that correctly, otherwise it looks REALLY pervy), I don't think I'd ever had Venezuelan fare. Because of some cuties from Caracas, it had been on my radar, but I hadn't had the chance to try it. I was missing out. To start with, I ordered a passion fruit fresca. By now, readers should be well aware of my addiction to fruit (juice). I was in fresca overload. Every sip made me want to be in South America. I could have consumed a gallon of the good stuff. Definitely order it. Also? Pace yourself. One arepa might not sound like a lot but it and a couple of sides will be enough to satisfy without turning you in to a fattyfatfatfat. I opted for the sweet yellow corn arepa topped with grilled chicken, black beans, tomato, queso fresco, and Guasacaca sauce (which is magically delicious and a ton of fun to say). To the main course, I added sides of coconut garlic rice and taro chips. AND, to the arepa, I added a variety of the delectable sauces that were on the table (try 'em all).

The meal... delicious. Absolutely delicious. I'm a voracious eater and between everything I had set before me, I was more than satisfied. I knew I was a fan of arepas but between the yellow corn base and fantastic toppings, I was in culinary heaven. Truly, every bite was a blend of wonderfully satisfying flavor. But, there was more; there was dessert. Before that night, I probably would have passed on yuca beignets and that would have been a mistake. Not only were these beignets reminiscent of donut holes, they were served with a dulce de leche dipping sauce. Done. Done! How can you not be fatkid happy with that kind of sweet treat to close out the meal? Despite Pica Pica having nothing to do with a diner, dive or drive-in (seriously, does NO one in that production have a dictionary), this is a SF haunt to make a destination, be you resident or tourist.
author: Johnny T.

description: I would really give this place a 3.5 stars. My boyfriend got the Pull Pork Arepa and it was delicious! I got a salad and that was also really good. The issue we had was with the yuca fries and the Taro and Plantain chips. The Yucca fries were not seasoned at all and the Taro/plantain chips needed some sort of dipping sauce. Also at 10 dollars an Arepa it feels a little pricey but still definitely worth a try!
author: Eileen H.

description: Really good. I order the spicy chicken arepa and the shredded beef and platano . In love with them although a little pricey ($10 for 1 arepa) is well worth it .
author: Victoria T.
