description: Pretty unique food. I haven't had much like that before. I liked it, it's great for lunch. Nothing amazing but fast high quality food. It's in an insane Ingress/Pokestop location if you're into that sort of thing.
author: Geoff G.

description:
The yellow corn pork pica pica is the way to go.

Food Quality - Excellent
Food Taste - Excellent
Food Originality - Excellent
Price - Excellent
Customer Service - Excellent
Ambiance - Average
author: Vibhor C.

description: Food was OK.  The tables were not cleaned so we just moved the plates so we could seat ourselves.  Later the lady came and cleared the table.  Overall it was a meh experience.  I love their name pica pica but that is the only thing I loved about this place.
author: V V.

description: Walked from the office all the way to the Mission and saw this place on the way. Hopped in to order an arepa and got my boyfriend one too. The arepa's are SO EXPENSIVE! It's like $10 for small one and a side of coleslaw-ish stuff. Definitely not worth it and I'm sure these are like $1 in Venezuela. Totally price gauging us! I was going to share mine with my bf until I realized how small it was so I had to go back up and order one for him. Definitely not worth $20 when we could've easily gone to any taqueria and gotten twice as much food for the price. It was fun to try one for the first time but never again.
author: Tiffany V.

description:
Ordered dinner delivery through uber eats and had a great experience! We ordered the shredded beef and pulled pork arepas, bululu salad, and beef tres empanadas. 

Our favorites were the shredded beef arepa and bululu salad. Both had a lot of flavor and were seasoned well. The pork arepa was tasty, but the pork was not seasoned as much as we would have liked. 

Overall we really enjoyed that the food was fresh and not as heavy as you'd expect for this type of food. We will order again soon!
author: Hayley N.

description: Delicious, interesting and healthy food! Loved the baked bananas. Great for vegans! Cool atmosphere.
author: Lihi Z.

description:
Take into consideration I am Venezuelan, know the food and have come here since it opened. And this is written with some loyalty to the only Venezuelan spot in the city. 

With that out of the way, it pains me to do this but we stopped by today for Easter and it was so mediocre. We had two cachapas de pabellón and one arepa de pabellón, an order of empanadas and one of yuca fries, good for $55, not the cheapest by my standards. The cachapas were reheated, rubbery and thick, cracked when bent, obviously dry, not fresh by any stretch which is key for a cachapa. The yellow arepa mix was not even right, it was like they mixed cachapa mix with arepa and the texture was off. Real yellow mix is soft and delicious, this was not it. The beef empanada was ice cold on the inside and could not be eaten, my daughter put it down and quit eating. The bean and platano empanada tasted like the bean was a bit spoiled, they should check their product better. The cheese empanada was great as were the yucca fries. So mediocre minus. You get a star for the yucca fries and one because I love Venezuela. So sad, this place used to be great with the sweetest owners.

Ps. At least play Venezuelan music at your Venezuelan restaurant. Nothing wrong with regional Mexican Banda music, but you'd think they'd know the difference being in the Mission and selling Venezuelan food.
author: Ed P.

description:
I've been to Pica Pica twice and the first time was great. I went again with my friend after telling her about this awesome arepa place, but sadly we left feeling very disappointed. Our white arepa was greasy, semi hard/stale and appeared to have been cooked too long or sitting too long. The filling was OK but I was just so sad that they would serve a sad arepa. When we arrived there weren't many folks inside and I wonder if we got some left over pieces. While we were eating several people came in and their arepas looked fresh and delicious. In retrospect, I should have said something but I think I was just too disappointed to bother. 

I appreciate a place that is consistently good and unfortunately Pica Pica was not. I'm also from a latino background and have had many tasty arepas in my day.
author: Marcia M.

description: This place was on Diners, Drive-ins and Dives so obviously that's very attractive, but unfortunately I think that Pica Pica is just ok. The arepas are $10 and are not very big, so the value isn't really there and the arepa itself is dry and not super satisfying.
author: Amy Y.

description:
Born and raised in Venezuela, I'm always craving those flavors that bring me back home. When I moved to San Francisco, from Miami, the first thing I did was to search for a place where I could eat Arepas. When I found out that they had Cachapas I was beyond happy, so one day I decided to go and give it a try. 

The Arepas were delicious, but kinda small. However the cachapas were just ok, plus they don't have the "Queso de Mano" which is what complements the flavor. I also enjoyed the "Jugo de Parchita" (Passion Fruit juice) which you never found anywhere.

But the biggest disappointment was the prices. I understand it might be hard getting the ingredients, but for the simplicity of the food and the size of the portions, I thought it was overpriced and I was still hungry. That's the main reason why I haven't been back, since I could get more and interesting food in this town for the same or less money.
author: Jose S.

description:
I came back to the Mission location and was happy to find the place much better than the first time I went. I brought with me some friends from Venezuela and they were very happy as well. The food was tasty, the staff was knowledgeable and the music was beyond cool. 

Thank you Adriana for listening to your loyal followers and making this place kick butt as it should be. We had arepas here on a Saturday and Sunday we were at your Napa location eating Cachapas.
author: Del M.

description:
I'm a big fan of this place and so happy that I was finally able to try it out. However, I must warm you, the empanadas ... are sort of a joke. I have no idea how they can call these empanadas ... maybe they're from a different country but I've had empanadas before and these are NOT empanadas!

Regardless, their maize "sandwiches" or maize cakes are awesome. The corn is delicious whether sweet or otherwise. It's gluten free, which is cool for most people who are gluten intolerant, and their juices are super yummy.

We got a sweet and a regular maize item with pulled pork and some kind of grilled beef? The plantains were yummy and the portions were pretty large. I guess since we shared, I can't attest to how they might fare if you just got one little sandwich with meat stuffed in it. 

We also got the yuca fries. They're definitely different, I don't know, it's an experience but it's not something I'd crave ... unless you really like super fried starchy things! Towards the end of my meal, I don't know why I didn't ask earlier, but I requested some hot sauce. Holy tamales! These were AWESOME. They have a habanero mustard, a MUST ... it's so spicy, and oh so good.
author: Lorrie M.

description:
It's OK. Not jumping up and down awesome, but OK. 

In a popular hipster neighborhood of a dense urban city, you expect good food in small shops served by people who bring the style of their original country to their new home. Pica Pica does that. I'll assume it's authentic, I really have no way of knowing, but enough other people have said it's authentic I'm going with it.

It's SF. It's busy. The whole city's busy. Know what makes eating nice in small busy cities? Sitting down. Pica Pica could use some better seating. And Pica Pica's customers could use some better manners (not trying to hold 4 seats along the wall when there's only 3 people, and maybe shift your asses down a seat so there's 2 empty seats on one side instead of 1 empty seat on either side of you).

The food is good. It's solid. I enjoyed it. Went with shredded beef with sweet corn arepa, and I was happy with it. The yuca fries had good flavor - little starchy, especially near the center, but they were good. 

In an area filled with decent food, it was decent food. It's not the best food on earth, but it's cheap, quick, easy.
author: Jeff J.

description: Went here twice while staying in the Mission. The food is delicious! We had yuca fries, the pulled pork and pulled beef sweet corn arepas and the yucca beignets. Everything was amazing! I am gluten free and it is so nice being able to eat at a restaurant without fear of cross contamination. Absolutely will come here again on another trip to SF!
author: Lauren G.

description:
Delicious!  Arepa with pulled pork was very a nice blend.  We chose the yellow corn which had a slight sweetness that paired well with the aioli and pork.  Slaw on the side was a great contrast.  I like food more spicy, so added some of their hot sauce.  Tangy and very mild but a good heat level for the mild Peruvian dish.  

Shrimp ceviche was a hit too.  Served with taro chips.   Only con is that it was served in a tumbler rather than a small bowl.  Makes it tough to fish out of the copious juice. Seemed like the intent was to bulk up the look rather than present the dish.  Still very good and I do recommend it.
author: Eric H.

description: This place was awful, filthy, and smelled like vomit and rancid food. All the tables were full of leftovers and there wasn't a single clean place to sit down. The food is sitting in my stomach like a rock.
author: Eater S.

description:
Adriana,
Thanks for your response. We ate there Wednesday 27 July at around 5pm. Again if it wasn't for that experience I would rate it all higher. I enjoyed my first Arepa and went back for a second one. Thanks for your attention.
author: David T.

description:
the girls who work here are super sweet and my food was deeeelish.
BUT.
but but but...

$9.50 for ONE arepa? dude... I seriously thought I was too dyslexican to understand this menu properly because there's just NO WAY it could really be... really...? REALLY? hypoglycemia, you win this time... -1 star.

NO reina pepiada? you are an arepa joint that sells nothing but arepas! explain to me how this is even remotely possible? no. just no. - 1 star.

but otherwise, great! ahem.
author: Vanessa L.

description: Food was good but the service was pretty off the mark. Our food was served at different times so we had to wait on one another to begin eating, pretty frustrating for a party of four. My arepa was beyond soggy, seemed as if it had been already made and waiting for someone to order it. The quesillo was definitely the best part but $4.35 for that small of portion seems like a lot. I was really excited to come to the place but kinda disappointed in the end. Maybe it was just an off day.
author: Sharon S.

description:
I ordered the vegetarian arepa on sweet corn and it was delicious.   But way too pricey at over $9.50

My daughter had the fried chicken and she loved it.  She does like super crispy skin.  It comes with a generous portion of coconut rice and beans, and sweet plantains..  So this may be a better deal.

I'm glad i went.  It's been on my mind since I saw a Guy Fieri episode; but, I probably won't go back until they lower the price.
author: Foodlover B.

description:
I've been to the Pica Pica up in downtown Napa where it resides in the semi-snooty Oxbow Public Market. This was a couple of years ago, but it really slipped from my memory. No offense to the owners, but I had an arepa with Pepeada - shredded chicken mixed with avocado and onions. It was Venezuelan chicken salad in one of their signature corn flour cakes shaped a bit like a Hot Pocket. My most vivid memory is waiting quite a while to get it since Pica Pica was easily the most popular eatery in the market. 

Now Pica Pica has come to the Mission where it competes with more rustic pupuserias as well as the full ethnic variety of food to be found here. Taking over for the more friendly and beloved Mi Lindo Yucatan, Pica Pica feels a bit too slick and manufactured to be in this 'hood, yet the audience appears ready-made for the hand-held creations they serve here. Jamie W. and I came to give it a try after having a couple of libations at the Casanova Lounge. We were peckish, not starving, so the tapas-size food was just the ticket. What to order, what to order, hmmmm... 

This time, I avoided the Pepeada and went for the $7.99 Pelu'a Arepa, which has the grilled corn flour cake wrapped around a hefty mound of shredded skirt steak with equally shredded cheddar on top. Pretty good, a tad too salty for my taste (see photo). Jamie ordered the $7.99 Pabellon Arepa, apparently the national dish of Venezuela (stand up please), with shredded skirt steak, black beans and plantain slices (see photo). Heartier than mine but frankly not as tasty to me.

We shared a $3.99 order of Yucca Fries (Pasapalos) which were just too greasy for me to enjoy guilt-free although Jamie loved them (see photo). I thought the seating set-up was rather awkward with a narrow counter to the right and tables too close together to the left. If a large group comes in just before you, you may find yourself eating standing up. All in all, Pica Pica offers a reasonable dining option in the Mission but definitely not my first choice. 

FOOD - 3 stars...decent arepas seem a bit pre-packaged to me 
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...slick, commercial air about the place, none of the rustic charm of its predecessor (Mi Lindo Yucatan) 
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...somewhat indifferent 
TOTAL - 3 stars...I think it made me want a handmade pupusa more
author: Ed U.

description: I never heard of arepas before randomly trying Pica Pica, but they are heavenly. Thick grilled corn pockets stuffed with meat and veggies. This is now my go-to for takeout or a quick sit down dinner. Side bonus: this place also happens to be 100% gluten free (arepas are surprising naturally GF), so safe if you are celiac.
author: Lori R.

description:
Overhyped. 

The arepas were underwhelming and messy. We tried the fried chicken and the shredded chicken versions. Lacked seasoning, depth of flavor, and were wet/soggy messes. We didn't get any layering of flavors or textures. My husband did enjoy the yucca fries, which I thought lacked salt (and he's the salt fiend! ).

Save your money and get your Latin food hankering somewhere else in the Mission.
author: K. S.

description:
I'm not sure if I've ever been so purely delighted in one little food establishment.

Not even having Guy Fieri's greasy countenance emblazoned on the door could change my mind!

I'm gluten-free.  I have celiac disease.  So if I get a trace amount of gluten in my food by mistake, I will end up sick for days to weeks.  I'm not one of the fad dieters who can't even tell you what gluten is (short answer: it's a protein!)

So going out to eat can be tricky!  Exhausting!  Unrewarding!  Daunting!  But when I'm in the Bay Area, there are suddenly all these options - my current favorite of which is Pica Pica!  I can eat ANYTHING on their menu!  THIS NEVER HAPPENS TO ME.

So I legitimately try, every time I come in, to do so.  They have an enormous trough of taro nachos with pulled pork - very, very good.  Their yucca fries are amazing.  Their cheese empanadas are also delicious.  Everything is so good.  And I always drink like 3 coconut lime aqua frescas.  

The employees are super-friendly and nice.  I love them all!  They don't know how happy they make me!

Writing about this place is making me hungry and sad to be back in Chicago.  I miss you, Pica Pica.  Promise to wait for me.
author: Jen H.

description: We ordered the food for online delivery for our Christmas gathering! It was a hit! Everything we ordered was gluten free. We had lots of options to choose from: vegetarian, chicken, meats like pork and beef. The plantains were the bomb! Others were in love with the spicy orange sauce - it's got a kick!! All of the guests were in love with the food. Everyone went back for seconds and thirds! Seriously everything we ordered was delicious, even the salad!
author: Jenn R.

description: ordered for the first time using uber eats. Got the chicken plate. I was literally a cut up fried half of chicken breast cutlet. So disappointed not at all what I was expecting. Came with no utensils. Portion and presentation were a let down.
author: Admin A.

description: I was excited since I am colombian and arepas are really important in our country. I ordered a white corn arepa . I waited for about 30 minutes. I started noticing that they were serving people that came after me. I told the girl about it and she said sorry she didn't put my order. Finally i got my arepa with yellow corn. Good but not what I expected.
author: Alejandra N.

description: Made the trip to San Francisco after seeing this place on Diners Drive-ins and Dives. I have some mixed feelings about this place. As usual it's in San Francisco, so parking for this place is hard to find. I've had Arepas in Las Vegas and now here. If I had to choose between the two, I'd have to say Vegas rules. Vegas Arepas were something I could take to go and eat without making a mess and it tasted like authentic street food. Pica Picas were a little sloppy and wet. Something you probably have to eat with a knife and a fork. Filling flavor wasn't bad. For $10 each I'd have to say it was a little bit over priced. If you haven't tried Arepas before I'd say surely come here to get introduced and so you have a comparison to make when you try them elsewhere.
author: Christian E.

description:
Pica Pica! I came across this place while watching some food network show on Netflix and thought of giving it a try and I was so happy I did! Very flavorful food and moderate prices, I just wish the place was a little bigger as it can get challenging to bring bigger parties. But I would come back again :)

5 stars from me.

Veggie Tip: Order Kattchapa and Veggie Arepa!
author: Rohini M.

description: Very casual and fun. Friendly personnel. Fast service and delicious -very authentic- food. I have tried arepas made by my Venezuelan friend's family, and these are as good. The spicy sauces are very good too if you are into that.
author: Andres O.

description:
I can't believe this place doesn't have more reviews, it is a gem of the Mission!

I went here for the first time with a friend who had heard about it on the show Diners, Drive-ins, and Dives. Our high expectations were met as the food was absolutely delicious. 

You order at the front of this restaurant, which seats ~20 people. I would recommend avoiding major rush hours if you don't want to have to wait for seating. 

The setting is very casual but has a colorful vibrant ambiance. I would not call Pica Pica a fast food restaurant but it is definitely a place I would recommend when you want to have a nice meal but don't want to wait a long time.

Food recommendations:
- Pulled pork arepas (a must for first-timers)
- Yucca fries
- Homemade sangria (probably not Venezuelan but still a good drink)

My one complaint would be that at times they are understaffed with one person taking orders, serving, and busing tables. You can't help feeling sympathetic when a big group comes in and the employee is running around frantically to take care of everyone.
author: Amanda G.

description:
Pica Pica could be 5 star worthy just because in all the diverse Bay Area glory there isn't another joint serving up authentic Venezuelan food. Yeah, they have Coupa Cafe in Palo Alto but the owner has only lived in Caracas and isn't a Native like this family run business here.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/_Iupdt0IslH_jU8zkKcWLA?select=BoZ66sqdIIwNirbAxTQtTA)

The item to get is the Cachapa ($9). Yeah you can get the Arepa or Maize'wich, but they're snack size. You get more bang for the buck with the Cachapa. It's a dollar more but more of a meal. Solid for a budget bite. 

Ordered the Cachapa #3, Pabellon. Sweet from the plantains, savory from the tender shredded skirt steak but also a little greasy and heavy. I think they are still working out some cooking kinks! With the addition of fresh herbs (cilantro/mint?) and maybe a side salsa it could be even be more awesome.   (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/_Iupdt0IslH_jU8zkKcWLA?select=fD81tF8tALBFtid4cJCk_g)

The yucca fries are a must try -  the texture remind me of cheetos! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/_Iupdt0IslH_jU8zkKcWLA?select=YOz5IXR4HFZjBHLPlDkCRQ)
author: Earl G.

description: I think it's a bit pricey, especially for a mostly take out place. But the food was good, and everything's gluten free. So that made me happy.
author: Tamar K.

description: Omg! This food was absolutely delicious!  You would never know it was gluten free. Yum!
author: Julia A.

description:
Delicious Arepas!
The yellow are my favorite as they are made of sweet corn. Maduros served with queso fresco, genius.
author: Anthony M.

description: This was the fist time to come to this place.  I was meaning to come for so long. Although it's so hard to find a parking space in the area.   But it was worth the hustle. I don't know what to order so the girl taking my order suggested a nice arepa which was amazing.    I will come back!
author: Marcos R.

description:
I came all the way from the East Bay to enjoy these wonderful arepas. Unfortunately, we walked in at about 1210 pm, and to our surprise, the service was not splendid, to say the least. 
We came in in a very good mood, but the cashier Maria, was not very patient. We took 3 minutes to order, and she was worried about a shipping order, that she had to excuse herself, when all she had to do was swipe my card, instead of attending to a male delivery man, who didn't seem to mind at all. He wasn't in a rush and wasn't illegally parked, so I thought that was a bit rude. Guests want to feel welcomed and feel like they're appreciated, but that wasn't the case.
Maria lacked genuinity and does not know how to make a guest feel welcomed. I ordered 2 pabellon arepas, and really wanted to try the passion fruit drink, but I was told, they did not have any. I would have put a sign and indicate "sold out" or "not available at this time".
I go to the bathroom, and the door is locked. But I see a key hanging on a ladel and so I proceed to unlock the door. With a hard tug and a slam in my face, to my utter shock, I almost walked in on someone. I then told Maria that I almost walked in on a guest, and she said, "She forgot to get the key". Hmmm, so it's the customers fault? Well, my argument is, why lock the door and provide a key, when easily a tourist, a guest, a child, an elderly, may not have known the rules to the Pica Pica bathroom. 
I then told Maria, that I will be yelping this because I stated, "it is not nice to have a guest wait, while you insisted on finishing a shipping order, when all you had to do was swipe my card. Plus, I almost walked in on someone". Maria then retorted, "My bad". 
Furthermore, there were no guests behind me waiting. I was ready, with my card out. I knew what to order since I've been there before. I would take my friends there!
Once we received our food, I noticed a line. Maria brought us our arepas which was accompanied by a nice tangy slaw salad. "If you have any questions, let me know", if what she told us add she walked away. I said, "Thank you".
There were 3 small bottles of  mystery sauces. I would have labeled them. What's the name of these sauces? Which one is sweet, spicy, or would it be great to put on the yucca fries, arepas, or salad?
I was so hungry and excited to eat here again today. Out of all great restaurants in SF, we chose this place. But after such disappointment with the service, the delectable arepa ended up tasting ok and mediocre. A person can really change the taste of a meal, by just the way they look at you, present themselves, out how they make you feel when entering. 
Also, I asked her why the Castro one closed and she responded with, "They were more of a sit down place. I really don't know why they closed. Maybe they didn't do so well over there. I've never been to that location". And I responded, "I can see why".
Nonetheless, I miss the Castro location because it had pizazz. When you walk into the bathroom, I noticed all the different framed photos of Venezuelan beauty pageant contestants. It had culture and a great vibe. This one on Valencia seems dark and if they don't change the customer service, it could harm the restaurant successes. 
I would love to go back, so that my mind will change about this once favorite restaurant of mine. 
I left feeling disappointed and upset and a bit sad:(
author: Shirley M.

description:
DISCLAIMER: this review is based on Pica Pica's food stand at OTG Fort Mason.

My friends and I were lucky enough to be able to try Pica Pica's stand at OTG Fort Mason and it was literally the first place we went to get food from.

I had never heard of arepas until they were featured on Throwdown with Bobby Flay and after seeing how delicious they looked on TV, I was hoping there was a good Venezuelan place to get them in the city. *Drum roll* Pica Pica!

Sure enough, once we were looking at the menu, it was apparent that we wanted to try all 4 arepas that were being offered. So, for our first visit my friends chose the Pabellon (skirt steak, black beans, plantains) and I had the Pepeada (chicken salad w/ avocado). They were each $5. 

My friends shared the Pabellon since I don't eat beef. But anyway, they both really liked it and thought it was good. We all shared my chicken one and we all agreed that it was HELLA good! There was just something about the creaminess of the avocado that went really well with the chicken. 

We came back for a second round and this time my friends had the Pernil (pulled pork, sliced tomatoes, avocado) and I had the Caribe (black beans, cheese, plantains). We also got a side order of plantains and it came out to $15. 

By this time, we were already stuffed after making a few pit-stops at the other food trucks but we just had to get more arepas. My friends thought that the pork one was ok. They liked the steak one better. My vegetarian one was pretty good. I loved the black beans! The plantains were alright.

Overall, this was by far our favorite food stand amongst the others we tried. Hopefully, we can make it out to the Mission to visit the actual restaurant and indulge in the full size arepas!
author: Fallon P.

description:
I.LOVE.THIS.PLACE.

Arepa's are really the perfect meal; they are quick, fun, satisfying & completely delicious. & the slaw they come with is such a great, refreshing and acidic side that just bursts in your mouth! 

But to complete the whole experience to get the house sangria is NECESSARY! Pica Pica's sangrias taste so good that at first try my friends & I weren't sure if they even alcoholic, they taste like juice!! But by the time we finished them...we sure did know the were alcoholic & Wow literally the perfect buzz!

This place just keeps me coming back.
author: Zhenya S.

description: Probably one of the worst value buys in the Mission for its class. $10 for a tiny arepa smaller than a Taco?! Honestly, the vegetarian options looked exciting but didn't live up to the description. Do yourself a favor and eat literally anywhere else.
author: Kartik S.

description:
Que rico! I read about Pica Pica in Daily Candy and had to show up on opening week. SO glad I did.  This is actually my first time having Venezuelan Arepas.  

Everything I had was good. 

I started with the sweet plaintains with tamarind sauce. 

See: http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3351/4631306914_442d47431a_b.jpg

The platanos themselves weren't that great but the tamarind sauce they were damn tasty. That was a new touch for me. The platanos were about $4. 

I also had the arepa. I chose to go with the area with scrambled eggs and chorizo. I was definitely a fan. 

See: http://farm5.static.flickr.com/4026/4631308276_f1dc81d988_b.jpg

I tried their queso fresco empanadas and also enjoyed them. 

See: http://farm5.static.flickr.com/4033/4631308040_a6c9ae394e_b.jpg

As far as drink I had three of their drinks. 

I really enjoyed their granitas which is like a shaved ice / slurpee drink that tastes like coconut. 

See: http://farm5.static.flickr.com/4055/4631306576_01a7c105bc_b.jpg

We went on a pretty busy night. It's not a huge space so I wouldn't try going on a busy night with a party of 6 or more. If you're a small group it's a great space. 

I'm very excited about going back as it is a pretty cheap meal with arepas being $8.
author: Carlos A.

description: I ordered the vegetarian cachapa through GrubHub.  I've never had Venezuelan food, so the uniqueness of the menu was super intriguing. I place a high bar on SF dining (how can you not!) and Pica Pica did not disappoint. I loved the boldness and the blend of flavors that came together, even in a vegetarian dish.  I also instantly thought of those who needed to visit this little gem with me in person next time and what meat dish I wanted to try (the beef looked amazing).  Thanks Pica team for sharing your Venezuelan culture with us! Great job!
author: Deanna S.

description:
One of the first restaurants in Mission that is finally GLUTEN FREE!!!! Yehey!!! I'm savor type of girl so I went ahead an ordered Arepa with pork, avocadoes and tomatoes. DAMNNN!!! it was super delish!!! I also tried the Sweet Corn pancake which was good but too sweet for me. 
I also tried the Yucca Fries and their red Sangria. Both items I will definitely order again. I want to try their empanadas as well which looks really good.

Cute little place, quick, affordable, clean and food is DELISH and GLUTEN FREE!!
I'm definitely coming back and would recommend for everyone to try..
author: Claudine V.

description: I was hungry one night and Pica Pica happened to be open. I wasn't familiar with their menu  so I selected 3 things without having them before. I was not let down. Everything was incredible, especially their Pulled Pork Pernil.
author: Philip D.

description:
I decided to choose a healthy option that my friends and I could come eat for my birthday dinner. I didn't realize the place was super small as I brought a party of 20. I felt bad for having to take over the restaurant. 

Everyone of us ordered a arepas and one friend ordered a salad. All my friends raved about how the food is super yummy and reasonable.

This is another place I would like to visit again if I'm ever in the city.
author: Huong N.

description:
We were looking forward to eating here based on the reviews, but the food was disappointing. 

Our order: 

-Garlic Yuca Fries. It was cold in the middle.

-Plain Yuca Fries. It was served lukewarm like it had been sitting there. 

-Grilled Chicken Arepa (white corn). It was cold and crumbly, and certainly not "crunchy on the outside, moist on the inside", as described on their website. 

-Spicy Chicken Arepa (sweet yellow corn). This was the only item that was served warm. 

The yellow corn was too sweet for my liking, but that's a matter of preference. The fact that 3 out of 4 items were cold, was unacceptable. It wasn't even busy. We barely touched our food and just left. We didn't have the time, or the appetite anymore to ask for a redo. 

The only positive experience we had was with the gentleman who took our order. He was very courteous and friendly. Both stars are for him.
author: F D.

description: I was missing out! The price is high, but the quality is amazing!  One filled me up,without having a guilt trip about it, and still being able to walk around the mission district!  I posted this on one of my other medias and my friends were going crazy about it! I will be coming back!
author: Jose Manuel C.

description: First time trying Latin American food. I ordered the arepa. The bread is nice and soft with some sweetness. The grilled chicken is a little too dry for me. But over all it's decent. Portion is kind of small, so if you are supper hungry, you might want to order some side dishes or order the cachapa ( not sure if I spelt it right lol) which is something I want to try next time. The place is a little small. You might have to wait a little bit for the tables.
author: Pauline W.

description: Vegetarian nachos to end all vegetarian nacho comparisons and experiences - so flavorful and the yuca chips are perfect. Note - plenty to share!!!
author: Jeanette R.

description:
I had the pulled pork Cachapas, which is served in a sweet corn crepe.   Cover it in their hot sauce and the sweet and hot make a great combo.   You can also order your protein on a grilled corn pocket, more like a sandwich or you can get it over rice.   They offer chicken, pork, beef, or grilled tofu vegetarian style.  

My wife had the Ensalada Verde Caracas with no meat and covered it in the home made hot sauce. 

Yuca Garlic fries are not to be enjoyed if you will be in a crowd as they are covered in big chunks of garlic.   As a side you get about 4 large, square cut fries that are lightly fried.   My wife and I both shared them so we would be equally offensive. 

As a dessert I had the best dish of coconut Quesillo ever.  It is crème Carmel with a light sauce.

The place has a small fast food layout; They give you a number and they bring you your order.  So no need to dress up here.   

It is a easy 3 block walk from the 18th street Bart station.     Not too scary of a neighborhood, but not Beverly Hills either.
author: Martin L.

description:
Thoroughly enjoyed my first visit to this restaurant.  A friend brought me here after seeing it on Diners Drive-ins and Dives. And I was maybe a bit skeptical based on that fact. However I loved the food I got a Pulled Pork Arepa. The pork was tasty, but the corn pocket they put in is absolutely delicious. Crispy on the outside moist on the inside it makes for a perfect little sandwich.  We also got the Yuca fries. I'm not sure what I was expecting, but whatever it  was they exceeded those expectations. Big thick fries with an almost tempura like texture. And served with Guacamole. 
My only criticism was that the place was a bit cramped we ate along a small counter along one wall. While chatting with people sitting next to us and the communal vibe was nice, it wasn't a very relaxing place to eat.
author: Gary B.

description:
First, don't order their special! They sold it hard to me, but the asado negro special was this cold overcooked beef thing that looked like last night's leftover with some even colder burned sauce. I've never had this at Venezuela but I surely hope the real asado negro isn't leftover overcooked beef with colder burned sauce.

Then the staff completely forgot our friends' order. They nicely waited for 15 minutes, walked up to the counter to ask for their orders, and was told they didn't know what they were talking about. Even after telling them what was the order, the staff didn't put a rush on the missed order. Several other tables' food came out before the missed order was out.

So 0 star for service, and 2 stars for the food. Good: yucca fries and plantain and drinks. Bad: taro chips (like cardboard), asado negro (aforementioned), ceviche (unimpressive).
author: Dorothy M.

description:
The coconut & lime drink was beyond words in the best way possible. I came here early with a group on a cold evening and I was glad I didn't wait until later. We arrived in time to snag great seats and the place was jam-packed within the hour. Every thing I tried here was delicious and well worth the prices, which seemed reasonable. 

Gluten-free options abound and Vegans will not be hard-pressed to find delicious choices!
author: Janna S.

description:
Never had an arepa before - if this is how they are supposed to taste (dry, lacking a bit in flavor) then Venezuela has some explaining to do. I liked the crispy corn flour shell very much - I just wish they had added some more sauce to the arepa. It was as dry as Oprah Winfrey's snatch. 

As for the Yuca fries - these were amazing. There was a nice thick batter on them - almost like the batter on British Fish n Chips. I'm sure they were just as unhealthy.. but when your only choice is Oprah Winfrey's snatch or deep fried Yuca - you always go Yuca.
author: Henry W.

description: I love Pica Pica! I always recommend it to people going to the city. The Yucca fries are the best and every time I take people here they enjoy it. Arepas are delicious and a nice alternative to other hispanic/latin food.
author: Liam P.

description:
Pica Pica was a major let-down for me. We tried the place after getting a Gilt City deal that provided us with a pitcher of Sangria and what seemed like half the menu. No complaints there.

You order your food at the counter and somebody brings it to you at your table. We were there around 8pm and the place was a mess. The woman who appeared to be the owner was also really rude. The floor was dirty and most of the tables were out of silverware. I had to interrupt a family next to us to get my hands on a metal fork. Same for the sauces. 

The place was hyped up and we were excited to check it out, but Pica Pica appears to be a poorly run operation that stumbled upon some good luck in the form of a TV appearance with Guy Ferrari. The food wasn't bad, but I would recommend 20 places in the Mission before Pica Pica and I'll probably never go back.
author: Marcus C.

description:
Gluten free and amazing!
Love this place. The fresh juices are so delicious also. Use the big bottle of hot sweet/ sour spicy sauce on the empanadas.
author: Anne C.

description:
Stopped by the other night, and OMG, it was good!!!  There was a line and no seating available when we entered, which was about 8:30PM on a Sunday.  The line moved along slowly but that let lots of the people sitting finish and work their way out.  By the time we ordered, we had no problem finding a seat. 

I ordered a side of the yucca fries...more like yummie fries.  And also Arepas sweet corn style with pulled pork.  Let me tell you what... I think I'll stop by every time I'm near to get a plane sweet corn arepas. This little corn pocket thing is amazing.  It's so delicious and of course gluten free.  These things are great.  You can probably stash a couple in backpack or purse to chomp away on while commuting to work or riding muni.  Or even keep some on your night stand in case you get hungry in the middle of the night.  Man I'm getting hungry now, ok heading there to order a dozen arepas.
 
I also want to go back and try the Nachos Pica Pica and the Sweet Tajados (fried plantains)
author: Dominic P.

description:
Is there a blog/tumblr/wtfsite named Fuck yeah, arepas!  If not, there should be, and Pica Pica should be front & center.  Pabellón es la palabra, and it's interesting how palabra is considered feminine.  Also, they carry local (non-GF) brews.  The combo of a heaping arepa with a local beer is astoundingly filling.  Great fuel for cruising the book stores down the way.

Also, fuck yeah, salsas!  Not the dance.  That's a different f... er...  The salsas available are in a wonderful range of flavors and spice.  Ahem.  Affect of having book stores near by, sorry.

And this is the Mission.  On one side of us were a couple arguing about which band was the most ironic (I'm not joking).  On the other was a group of construction workers relaxing with a pitcher of sangria.  FTW, SF.  FTW.
author: Jason R.

description:
I've been to Pica Pica a few times before. The price is a little high but the food has been pretty good. Today was an awful experience.

When I went to order I asked for Lemonade but they said they're out of the regular sugar so it might not be very good, I said ok how about the passion fruit? Well it's very sour. Ok how about the Mango? Apparently she thought there was nothing wrong with the mango so I was allowed to order that. Then I ordered the Empanadas. Got my table number and found a seat.

Then I waited. And waited. The table next to me gets their food but when it's delivered they say "we ordered empanadas too, are they coming?" The waitress says oh yes I'll get them. I think to myself, "uh-oh, wonder why there are delays for empanadas". More waiting. The people who were directly ahead of me in line get their food. 10 minutes go by. I'm still waiting. 

Finally my food is delivered. And what is in the top of the little container of guacamole? Right in the center like its a garnish? A hair! Gross!!! I say excuse me but the waitress was already gone. Seriously? Ok so I walk back up to counter and very nicely and quietly say to her "there's a hair in the guacamole". I said it quietly because I didn't want to ruin anyone else's appetite, mistakes happen, right? So she hands the plate to the cook and again walks off. The cook is standing there looking like he doesn't know what to do. So for 5 more minutes I'm standing there, politely, waiting for her to explain to him what's wrong. Did I mention that no one has apologized to me for the hair in my food? For the long wait? For the fact that I had to bring the hairy guacamole back up to them since she couldn't wait one second after delivering my food to hear me immediately say there was something wrong? Finally she speaks to the cook and then she starts asking me if I want a different kind of sauce? I say "I just want some guacamole without any hair in it" and then she gives me attitude "Well, I'm just asking" like she's the one who should be offended. Finally they give me a new container of guacamole and hand the original plate back to me. So, finally I have my food and I go to sit back at my table where my Mango juice was and there are 2 guys sitting at my table and my juice is gone? What the heck. Ok all my patience and politeness and willingness to put up with disappointment is used up. And did I mention that I'm 7 months pregnant. That waiting a long time to eat when I'm hungry is very hard on me? That squeezing in and out of tight spaces and waddling up to the counter multiple times is uncomfortable for me? The guys at the table were mildly apologetic and offered to buy me another juice but I was just so upset. If the waitress had paid attention to the plate before she delivered me hair garnished guacamole, if she had waited one second before she dropped the plate on my table and ran away, if she had told the cook what was wrong immediately instead of dropping the plate in front of him and walking away, the guys wouldn't have assumed the table was free. 

I made it known that I was not happy but still no apology, no service, not even an inquiry as to what was wrong. I've never been treated so rudely before. You lost a customer today Pica Pica. I gave you many chances to make it right. I forgave you multiple transgressions. But enough was enough. I hope you stop pay attention to the food you serve before sending it out of the kitchen with hair perched on top. I hope you stop serving hairy guacamole and I hope you at least learn the lesson that when you do serve hair to your customers and the customer calmly lets you know that there's a problem that you should at least apologize and deal with it right away.
author: Kelly S.

description:
I really love arepas and this place absolutely delivered! 
I've been here about 3 times now and every single time I come, it's always tasty and fresh. 
How the heck to do they braise the beef so tender? 
It's was juicy, salty and fresh that I am in love with it. 
I always get it with the yellow corn arepas but one of these days I gotta go with the plain white. 
The stewed pork is also amazing and is highly recommended. 
I was thinking about giving them a 5 and might change it later but I wish they had the garlic shrimp (camarones al ajillo) like the arepas place in Vegas.

More options please Pica Pica!  Gracias
author: Chris L.

description:
walking into Pica Pica was arguably the most exciting thing i did all year.  "why? what the hell is wrong with you?" one might ask...well, its because after a late night of watching food network i happened to come across THE AREPA sando for the first time in my life.  immediately i went to Yelp to find an arepa place in the east bay...none...how could this be? the following day i called around to different restaurants not wanting to believe that they didn't have it on their menu's...even going as far as to google translate "can you refer me to a restaurant that sells arepas please..." 

Pica Pica kinda sets the bar for Arepa's in the bay area...the reason why is because there seems to be only 2 or 3 places that actually sell Arepa's (of course all in SF and all in the Mission)  The arepa is a flat, round, unleavened patty made of soaked, ground kernels of maize, or--more frequently nowadays--maizemeal or maize flour which can be grilled, baked, fried, boiled or steamed, etc. The characteristics vary by color, flavor, size, and the food with which it may be stuffed, depending on the region. Arepa is a native sort of bread made of ground maize (or flour), water, and salt which is fried or grilled into a thick bread. It can be topped or filled with meat, eggs, tomatoes, salad, cheese, shrimp, or fish depending on the meal. 

the selection of the Arepa's at Pica Pica is pretty simple...6 different Arepa's to choose from with either white corn or yellow corn (the yellow corn is sweeter and tastes EXACTLY LIKE the sweet corn ball they make at Chevy's with every entree) all the Arepa's are priced at 8.95...small enough where you could easily eat two, but still big enough that you will feel guilty and full after.

the best way to describe biting into an Arepa is like eating a sandwich stuffed into a tamale...not exactly the life changing experience i was dreaming of or hoping for, but still good enough for me to drive over the bay bridge and look 30 minutes for parking to come get my Arepa fix next time around.
author: Kyu L.

description: Picked my gluten free daughter up from SFO after many months in New York & we immediately headed to Pica Pica (both of us were STARVED & even though it was NY, she hadn't had a good GF meal the entire 3 months she was there). We had a little bit of everything and it was beyond fabulous.   Remember that kids cartoon- "I'm gonna eat & eat & eat & eat until I die). That was us- But what stood out the most- my daughter had her service dog with her, she was tired after the long flight & hungry.  The girls let me order a special plate for the puppy of chicken & rice & brought her a water bowl.  If I lived I. SF I'd be at this place weekly if not more.
author: Robin R.

description:
The place caught my eye because of the DDD Guy Fieri thing on the window. My husband reluctantly agreed. 

I ordered the shredded beef arepa and was pleasantly surprised by the sweet flavor of the yellow corn. I was not-so-pleasantly surprised by the fact that there was just one in a $9 order. It was good, but the slaw that accompanied it was not worthy of the price. 

The husband ordered the crispy chicken and it turns out they take crispy to heart because that poor chicken was pretty burnt. It was meh. 

It was a really basic dining experience. The best part was the Latin music playing.
author: Brisa D.

description:
We drove two hours to try this place and it was very disappointing. 

The price to portion ratio is ridiculous. My coconut price had glob of white stuff on it, which I assume and hope to God that it was coconut milk mix. Needless to say, I did not finish the tiny portion of rice. 

The place is filthy, they just wipe the leftover food on the tables on to the floor. Be prepared to walk all over other people's leftovers.

I wanted to try the coconut lime drink. I can't have diary so I asked the cashier if this drink had diary in it, she keeps telling me what it is made of but won't say if it had diary. I just wanted to know if it had any diary!! By the time she got another person to tell me there's no diary, I already don't trust them. 

Never again.
author: helen l.

description:
I think this is the first restaurant I've purposely been to because it was on Diners, Drive-Ins, and Dives. It's a tiny place with some tables on the left side and a small shelf-like bar with stools on the right. When we got there, the place was packed, but we were able to get seating pretty quickly at the bar. You order up front, take a number, and then the food is brought out to you. 

Both me an my buddy ordered the pulled pork platter which is pork, coconut rice, black beans, slaw, and a couple of fried plantain chips. Everything tasted really fresh and the flavors were nice. I'm more of a spicy fan, so I appreciated the big bottle of vinegary hot sauce as well as a couple of smaller bottles of sauces. I ended up dousing everything in the hot sauce and then mixed up a spicy mustard-like sauce with the slaw. Yum!

The owner of the restaurant is a real sweetheart and very friendly. She was happy to answer our questions about the menu and seem genuinely happy to have us in her restaurant. The place is clean and stylish and even though it's small, the ceilings are high which creates an airy space. I'm looking forward to returning to try some of the arepas!
author: Jason W.

description:
I was down in LA one weekend, and my friend introduced me to Arepas. It tasted like pupusas with meat in them, and it was amazing! He bought them from some place in Santa Ana that was known for their arepas, and I instantly fell in love with them.

Well, I get back to SF and find out that Pica Pica has some arepas. Awesome! I jetted down there one Sunday morning, and went on full fatty mode, over-ordering as usual. I had me an arepa and a maize sandwich.

Unfortunately, the food here just did not blow me away. The arepa shell was just not as good. The meats were just excessively salty. All I tasted was salt! The maize shell was just crumbling and falling apart. and it ended up being a fork-and-knife dish instead of a sandwich.

My search for a great NorCal arepa will have to continue..
author: Kazu O.

description:
Disclaimer: I understand that sometimes restaurants do not have all of the ingredients mentioned on their menus because they 1) ran out of them or 2) is just not the season. This negative review is about customer service, not about lacking the ingredients to complete an order.

Today I walked to Pica Pica Maize Kitchen in the Mission and ordered the "Pulled Pork Pernil" platter that comes with "Tostones." I saw the plate come in without the tostones but waited hoping that the lady helping me today would bring them later. After a few minutes with no sight of tostones coming my way, I asked the lady about the tostones. She looked at my plate and pointing at two plantain chips said, "Those are your tostones." I explained that those were in fact "plantain chips" and that I knew that tostones were different because I had them before. (They're thick fried discs of smash plantains).

She laughed and said, "No, these are real tostones. I know what you think tostones are but these are what we call tostones." I then explained that this could not be true because "Plantain Chips" were already mentioned/listed as "Plantain Chips" in another part of their menu. She then laughed again and said: "These are what we call 'tostones' is just that where you are from, they are called different. What we called plantain chips are these 'Taro Chips,' I'll bring you some for you to see." A minute later, she produced a plate of - what do you know? - "Taro Chips." At these point, I was feeling a bit insulted by her attempt to fool me with this poor customer service strategy of deceit and just said: "No, I think that those are Taro Chips, from the Taro Root, which are also listed on you menu as 'Taro Chips.'"

Somewhere in the list of customer service rules, there has to be a bullet point that says: Do not lie to customers to cover shortcomings on your services. Just stick to the truth and apologize when appropriate.
author: Oscar V.

description:
Wow this food is heavy. I had the sweet corn spicy chicken Arepa. One was more than enough. 

The food was pretty tasty. Try the salsa sparingly at first - very spicy. I also had the mango agua fresca, which was delicious. 

If you're in the area and need something quick, without it being fast food, this is a pretty neat little place.
author: Breylan D.

description:
Pica Pica is for surely one of those restaurant where I gotta try a little bit of everything.  Gluten free lure aside - I freakin' LOVE corn based ANYTHING.  Texture and taste of it wins my stomach over.  I was all for trying out this restaurant with my friends who suggested it!  And, I'm so happy I went with great company that treats eating out as an experience rather than a necessity, 'cause you know we DID get a little bit of (almost!) everything!

I've never heard of an arepa before!  It was a lovely, light corn flavor with a good portion of undressed mixed greens to balance out the sandwich-like dish.  The aioli really enhanced the essence of it.  Had it with the #7 Pernil pulled pork, and I'm still smitten!  Reading other reviews from native Venezuelans left me curious to try an authentic, legit Venezuelan spot somewhere in the Mission to see and compare.  

What I loved even more than the arepa were my amigas' cachapas!  Man, oh, man, was that corn flavor more evident!  The word "pancake" does not properly describe what I had chomped on, in my opinion.  The taste of this crunch-tastic dish was to die for.  I would definitely come back for this!

We also shared their hefty-sized chupe soup - really good for the rainy weather that raged on outside of this small, cozy restaurant.  The empanadas and yucca fries were great, as well.  For the empanadas, it was all about the sauces for me.  Slash ya gotta get at those plantains y queso fresco!  We had it with the tamarind sauce, but I'm sure the black bean one would have suited it more.

Anyway, I shall be returning, and am very sad that my home in the Sunset is not eligible for delivery for this lovely place.  I'm always munching around in the Mission, but always for get there are some sweet spots on the other side of 16th, going towards 15th!  If you're around there, check it out.  It gets really crazy up in there, though.  So, if you don't want to wait for a spot, go during non-meal hours.
author: Nadia D.

description: Great  food great music cool place , I had the blackened beef arepa on the yellow corn And the pulled Pork pernil and the yuca fries sooooo good loved it can't wait To go back try more things
author: Catalina D.

description: I had three different arepas from here and they were all amazing...flavor, texture...so good!  The yucca fries are awesome, the sauces were delicious too.  I wish I lived closer to this arepas eatery, yum!
author: Brianna W.

description: I had been to the Pica Pica location in Napa so I decided to give this one a try.  Overall, it was an ok experience.  I ordered the Crispy Chicken Platter and it was ok.  The Chicken has a nice crispiness and was rather moist but I thought that that the batter got a little burned.  It was a darker color than I expected and had a bitterness to it.  After dousing it with the sauce on the table, it was hardly noticeable...but not ideal.
author: Rob P.

description:
We had just watched the Triple D episode featuring Pica Pica the night before and just so happened to be in the area so naturally, we had to stop by.

After waiting awkwardly to be helped for a few seconds too long (seemed like everyone was too busy prepping the to-go orders that the in-store customers were slightly neglected), we posted up by the wall (it's a small space) to eagerly anticipate our food. I got the Beef Pabellon Cachapas and it was AMAZING. The thick corn crepe with plantains and beef worked extremely well together and bonus: there was a hefty portion of salad that accompanied the cachapa. 

I'm not one for repeating dishes at restaurants but even I have been enticed to repeat this unforgettable meal.
author: Furai X.

description:
Had the pulled pork plate. It came with white rice, black beans, 2 plaintains, their version of cole slaw and the pulled pork. At first I was eating the items separately one at a time, big mistake! Mix up the slaw with the pork and mix the beans in with the rice and use the PICA PICA sauce and the little bottle of Pica Something Sauce, ultimately delicious!!! 

Don't forget the coconut lime juice, straight JUICEGASM!!! 

My girl had a chicken arepa with a side of yucca fries which she ate with the aoli sauce and the pica pica sauce. 

Orders come quick, place is small, biggest table I saw can hold up to 6 ppl. Hope you give it a tester! YUMMY!
author: Miss V.

description:
Where else can you get yuca fries, much less ones so perfectly fried (hot and soft on the inside and crispy on the outside)?  

One arepa is very rich and filling, and though they may seem small, try eating one first.  I got the pulled pork with garlic aioli and avocado, and it was tasty!  They had three sauces out for you to put on top, and I had the hardest time figuring out which one was my fave, haha.  The pocket does get a little soggy, but I still enjoyed it regardless.
author: Lily N.

description: Very unique and filling. I ordered way too much food. It was well made and fast. I loved the yucca fries. The nachos were too busy. Next time I would get the yucca fries to share and an Arepa
author: Matt W.

description:
Food was tasty and great for the price! Lots of gluten free options.

I had the chicken with avocado with garlic yuca fries.
author: Pam S.

description:
Hella good.

My boyfriend and I had our first arepa at Outside Lands and knew we needed to give the restaurant a visit. And we were not disappointed! We got there early so it wasn't crowded and our food came out quick! He had a beef arepa and I tried the beef cachapa. Accompanied with their signature sauces which we didn't get at OL. Everything was delicious and can't wait to go back for more! Definitely a new favorite spot for the New Year.
author: Valerie E.

description:
This. Place. Is. The. Shit.  

First and foremost: Their kitchen is 100% gluten free.  No concerns about cross contamination.  It's like a dream come true. 

Second, and equally important: The food is perfect and delicious and amazing.  I ordered the shredded beef pabellon, and it was perfect.  It's a good balance of sweet and savory.  I liked the sweet yellow corn a little more than the white corn because it added a little extra moisture and sweetness, but both were really good.  My hubbs got the pulled pork pernil with sweet yellow corn, and it was also really amazing.  

We obviously had to try the Nachos Pica Pica, because.. Nachos.  They were good, but perhaps a little bit dry once you eat all the toppings off.  I love that they use taro chips though. 

The yuca fries were So. Bomb.  Especially with all the sauces they have on the table.  They were hot and crispy and starchy and perfect.  

I was dying to try the yuca beignets for dessert, but after stuffing myself with all that amazingness, there was no way I could fit anything else in my stomach. Next time, pica pica.
author: Christa M.

description:
Cheap, quick and every bite was better than the last. I've never eaten an arepa prior so I have nothing to compare it to, but this was a delicious introduction. 

I'm not vegetarian, but went with the vegetarian arepa on sweet yellow corn and found it to be both filling and flavorful.
author: Lauren H.

description:
Came in with my GF, who thought this would be a great Colombian choice. Definitely not, Colombian but Venezuelan. 

Food was pretty good, not what I expected. I did have difficulty with cutting into my arepa with the provided plastic fork and knife, so I eventually ended up picking the thing up. I was pretty bummed that they did not have all of the options available on the menu at the time, really bummed they did not have their spicy chicken!

Sangria was amazing!
author: Chris B.

description: Food is good. I have never had a sweet Arepa It was fresh. Price is OK . Confusing menu. Both the cashier and the looks like a shift manager touch there hair meanwhile I was there. They should keep it in a bun.
author: Carolyne R.

description: Hip, compostable, and delicious. Wonderfully authentic yet modern take on the best flavors and great vegetarian options and all gluten-free. It's a delicious mouthful, basically.
author: Matt J.

description:
LOVE this place. 

Beef Cachapa was the bomb. Love the juicy beef and sweet plantain in those corn crepe!

The grilled chicken salad was great! I can drink the whole pitcher of Sangria on my own. Yuca fries and taro chips are the best snacks with their homemade sauces!

To skip: the platter (too starchy for me: rice+beans), the coconut quesillo were not that great.
author: Yuchi C.

description: A friend and I split a spicy chicken arepa, yuca garlic fries, beef and cheese empanadas and finished with the yuca beignets. Everything was amazing and the sauces at the table took it to the next level. The yuca garlic fries were the highlight for me, especially with the white sauce! They are a must try!
author: Becky M.

description: If you get the Arepa, I definitely recommend going with the sweet corn to enhance the flavor. Also, the Vegetariana and Shuli platos are so good! I love the coconut rice, plantains, and spicy black beans. If your like me, what makes this restaurant so great is their dedication to serve local, sustainable food as well as their eco-friendly business practices.
author: Kaitlyn M.

description:
After stuffing my face at a nearby restaurant in an i-haven't-eaten-breakfast-yet frenzy, I remembered seeing this place on the corner where my friend was commissioned to complete a grafitti mural. 

I asked myself, "Pica pica?" in a pikachu voice. Why, yes. I think I will. 

I walked in, and was greeted enthusiastically. The guy was happy to explain any of the items to me, and I chose to do the lunch special, which comes with an arepa and a side. I had the arepa Pernil (pulled pork, avocado) and the yucca fries (which comes with one of a variety of sauces). 

I received my to-go order, carefully wrapped and stapled in a brown paper bag. I carefully contained my excitement (which is unusual) and walked to Dolores park. 

I opened the bag like a gleaming Christmas present, and went to town. Because I had already eaten a meal, I promised myself I'd only eat a portion. The corn of the arepa was thick and tender, so wonderful. I thought the pork could have had a little more flavor, but I was happy with the amount of avocado stuffed in there. 

but..the best part... wait for it... the yucca fries!! crunchy in a light, fluffy way, I just had never had anything like it. they crunched a little and then melted in my mouth. I used the aioli dipping sauce from my sandwich and I was in heaven. needless to say, i didn't end up saving any for later. 

The lunch special was a good deal, but otherwise they may be a little pricey for such a small portion.

P.S.- the place also has empanadas and i REALLY wanted to try a chorizo and potato one. they look excellent, so, make a note to leave room in your belly :)
author: Rose K.

description: The food was good. I'd like it more if the portion was bigger. Its a healthy alternative to the junk food you get everywhere else. Waiting for the good took a really long time and they don't have an order on how the food goes out when its ready. It should've been first come first served, but not always the case. I'd come back again when its not too crowded
author: Suryo H.

description:
Great STAFF!
Super FRIENDLY employees, very helpful and attentive. 

Delicious! I tried one with avocado, it was pretty big and super delicious. 
The bread they use is amazing. Very tasty and with a unique sweet flavor.
author: Sara J.

description: YUM!  The sweet corn Arepas are DELISH!  The yukka fries are good too, but one arepa is more than enough food.  I don't know what else to say other than TRY THIS PLACE OUT!
author: Brooke M.

description:
Pica Pica was always the joke in our apartment. We kept meaning to go there and for 6 months avoided it. Yesterday, the other shoe dropped. 

The wait was SUPER LONG. It was unreal! Seriously waited 30 minutes and there weren't that many people there. I was so ready to give it one star... and then my pernil arepa came... 

Holygoddamnomfg ONE OF THE BEST THINGS I HAVE EATEN IN A LONG TIME. The pulled pork - OH-  THE PULLED pork! Glorious.

Get take out. And spicy creme instead of aioli.
author: Emily D.

description: Gluten free.Quick.Innovative.My fav Guy Fieri been here.We had corn veg maize and coconut lime.Great creamy spicy stuff.Loved their 3 sauces.
author: Priyanka L.

description: Really good, unique food. It was nice being able to choose anything off the menu and not having to worry because the entire place is dedicated gluten free.  We had 3 different dishes, chicken, pork, and beef, and tried 2 sides, the yucca fries and plantain and taro chips.  Yucca fries according to my sister are "better than regular fries" and they are thick and a bit more bready.  The sauces are all unique and interesting, and taste good with the fries.  Both type of arepa, white and yellow are good, and we loved the seamless combination of sweet and savory.  If it wasn't such a trek to SF we'd probably visit way more often.  The only downside is there is limited seating, and although service is quick and the staff is helpful, we encountered some rude customers because of the limited seating and others who had a loud and crying baby--still couldn't make the food taste less good :)
author: Casey N.

description:
This place has enough reviews here's the lowdown:

White Pica Suck, Stick with the Sweet Yellow. The white doesn't have that strong a flavor. 

Spicy chicken is actually spicy, man that stuff burns. 

The salad that comes with Cachapas is the most delicious salad with their crispy things. I would just come back for that. 

Yuca Fries are good, no sauces though. The sauces on the table at ketchup, spicy mustardy, and something else that I couldn't recognize. 

This is the breakdown. 

Basically this is Venezuelan fast food restaurant. Expect clean tables and decent service, but a order and clean your own plate place.
author: Rohan D.

description:
Tried this restaurant based off a suggestion from a friend.  

Ordered the pulled pork arepa,  the pork was delicious.  Had great seasoning and a great kick of heat at the end.  Also ordered the shrimp ceviche. Was great. Fresh, good flavor and love the chips served with it. Also ordered the fries.  Not my favorite.  Maybe I was missing something. 

Only gave 4 stars because I was not thrilled with the service.  Service with a smile is pretty key in the service industry.  

Loved the food. But the people who worked there not so friendly. Maybe it was an off day for them.
author: Lis M.

description:
So I was really really excited go try this place out finally. However, it left a sour taste in my mouth because it took almost 1/2 hr to make my small order. It was NOT busy. First the guy on the register didn't seem like he could speak English well. 2nd they called out my name for my empanadas but I had clearly informed them it was all too go. Finally when my food was ready I had to double check. They didn't include any sauce for the Yucca fries which I had stated to the cashier what I wanted. Also, I asked for a Mango Fresca. When I asked the guy for my drink he said it's not on the order. 

Good thing I checked my receipt because I knew I wasn't going crazy that I didn't order it and he took it down. So, I showed him the receipt. He looked at the front where the drinks were and he said that he "THINKS" the mango is the one to my right. I was in a rush and didn't bother to try because of his skeptical tone.  Just trying the food now and it was NOT mango. :| My bf liked his food a lot which is good. The fried chicken wasn't bad. However, the yucca fries are not memorable at all. It's only good with the dipping sauce. 

When I left the guy handing me my food asked "if everything was ok" because he could tell I was annoyed. No, everything was not ok on my first trip there. Sadly disappointed. Should have stuck to the first place I was going to try, Gracias Madre.  Not sure if I have the heart to come back again. Really disappointing. 2 thumbs down.

A waste of $28.....that food was NOT worth that much.
author: Sheena C.

description:
I am in LOVE with this place - my mouth is watering writing this review! I've been here twice now on visits to San Francisco and can't say enough good things about the food (quality, taste, presentation - you name it) and the service. The place also happens to be gluten free! 

Grab arepas and a drink (preferably the to-die-for coconut one - no idea what it's called) to-go and eat at Dolores Park.
author: Dominique M.

description: I wrote the review as soon as i finished eating because i was so disappointed. Im sorry to say nothing about the quality of the food indicated that it was just an off day at the kitchen.
author: Marjon K.

description: This place is NOT gluten Free. Celiac's BEWARE! They use Harina Pan which is cross contaminated with gluten. So if you have celiac don't eat here! I don't understand why people label things gluten free  when they are not!
author: John D.

description: Get the sweet yellow corn arepas, they are better than their original white corn ones.  I might have liked them more if I hadn't had much better arepas in SoCal.  The highlights were the cheese cachapas and passion fruit sangria.
author: Lisbeth B.

description: The food is absolutely delicious. They really have the flavor and the service is good and fast as well. The only thing I wasn't absolutely happy with was the price. I think is overpriced for the size, not the flavor, but the price. 1.50 less would be more effective for you guys. Keep it up guys.
author: Francisco Javier B.

description:
As a newly minted glutard, I am so grateful for restaurants like Pica Pica, which is 100% gluten-free AND has gluten-free beer, too. I actually came here a few years ago, back when I was stuffing myself with bread and pizza crust, and liked it a lot then, too. I love arepas, in general (corn cakes are my weakness!), and this place has some very flavorful options. 

This time around, I tried the sweet corn crepes, which were really delicious. They probably would've been more so if I had had them with the mozzarella cheese they come with (I miss the ubiquitous mozz-arepas at NYC street festivals), but alas I am also now dairy-free.

It's a family establishment, the staff are super friendly and nice. The owner's grandma was also a glutard, which is why the place is gluten-free friendly. Yum! and Thank you!
author: Nami S.

description: Yummy, wished there were more variety. After a few times there, didn't feel like returning again
author: Hua W.

description:
I really liked this place the first two times I went there. I liked it enough to choose it amongst the plethora of amazing eateries in the city to bring my mom to for lunch today. The previous times a young, enthusiastic girl worked at the counter and was more than pleasant. But today we received awful service from the woman who was working the counter/cash register. She was not particularly friendly to begin with, but that was neither here nor there. After a REALLY long wait, at least 20 minutes or more, we got SOME of our food. She placed my and my husbands plates in front of us and then walked away, didn't even mention the other plate. I wondered if she forgot we had a third entree. My mom likes to eat lunch by like 12 noon latest and at this point is was going on 1PM. I felt so sorry for her being hungry. To make matters worse, we all now had to stare at 2 plates of food for the next 5 minutes while we waited. I finally got up and approached the desk, where i was ignored by the woman for several minutes, then I finally just addressed her and said "my mom drove an hour to come here with us for lunch today" and she said "your other plate is coming" and walked away. She and the men working in the kitchen talked and laughed and flirted with each other for several minutes after that, nobody seemed to really be working. I observed them cook my mom's arepa start to finish during that time, they had either forgotten it or didn't care about serving us our plates on time. One man grabbed hands full of lettuce (with bare hands) and stood there, waving them around in gesture while talking to the woman before tossing them on plates, haphazardly. It was beyond insulting. All of the men in the kitchen were staring at me with critical looks on their faces, obviously dismayed at my impatience. Finally she came back and handed me a plate, which I had now stood there waiting for for several minutes. I told her "you shouldn't serve two plates and leave one diner with no food" in a non-confrontational manner. She responded callously "the arepa takes longer to make that's why but I can get a manager if you want a discount or something". COMPLETELY added insult to injury. I told her "no, I don't need a discount, I just wish you had acted a little more graciously". When I got back to my table she was blatantly bad-mouthing me to the guys in the kitchen, they were all looking at me, scoffing and visibly making negative remarks about me. There was absolutely not a drop of professionalism in that place today. FURTHERMORE if "the arepa takes longer to cook" (crock of BS) then you start cooking it first Einstein. There was about a 10 minute lapse between the first 2 plates and the 3rd. Unacceptable! Our food was completely cold and soggy by the time we ate it. I will never return. There are so many hard-working great people in this city looking for work, why employ these kinds of lazy, unintelligent, rude people at an otherwise great restaurant?
For the owner's reference: Our bill says "Lucero H" at the top.
author: Emma H.

description:
Came here before seeing a show at the Chapel, and it was such a good decision. I'm not too familiar with Venezuelan food, but after eating here, I definitely want to discover more. I'm all about plaintains now. Savory bananas. The business.

We split the shrimp ceviche and vegetarian cachapa--a sweet corn crepe filled with black beans, plaintains, and garlic aioli. The cachapa was so delicious, especially with the not-as-spicy green salsa that comes in a bottle. The shrimp ceviche was also great--wish there was a bit more shrimp (who doesn't?), but it had a really nice tomato-y flavor. And the taro chips were so addictive! 

Next time I want to try the yucca fries and one of the arepas. Also, this restaurant is entirely gluten-free for all the allergic Yelpers out there.
author: Rachel F.

description: Yum! The arepas are delicious! The portion is kind of small though for the price, but it taste so good! The yuca beignets are good too although their coconut lime fresca is wayyyy too sweet.
author: Claire S.

description:
Was in the area and decided to check this out and perhaps relive a bit of Venezuela... Not that wowed by the cachapas, unfortunately! There was a gd amt of sweet corn but it was a bit chewier than I'd have liked. Also a bit on the sweet side. Definitely a huge amount of meat, and the plantains were yummy! Was a bit disappointed with the 'queso fresco' - I expected more cheese. Or maybe something more chunky instead of shreds. 

Sauces on the table were a pretty gd foil though. I guess nothing compares to a hot fresh cachapas off the grill in a Venezuelan market, but this was not bad in an effort to relive that memory.
author: Clarissa L.

description:
I looked up the Yelp review before purchasing the coupon from Groupon. The 4 stars was impressive so I must've ordered all the wrong stuff or they had a bad day. There are really 3 different entrees on the menu.
1. Arepas: Grilled Corn Pockets - Choose one: Classic White OR Sweet Yellow
2. Cachapas: Sweet corn crepes made with fresh yellow corn, filled with savory fillings and folded over
3. Plato: Coconut rice, black beans & sweet plantains ccompanied by one of our family recipes
We ordered two different Plato, one with spicy chicken and one with shredded pork. The rice was ok in flavor but mushy because it was cooked with way too much water, both the plantains & beans were ok, nothing great. The spicy chicken was decent but the shredded pork had no flavor whatsoever. None of the sauces on the table made it any better b/c they were crappy too. What a disappointment. We didn't even order drinks and it was over $30. I would not go back even if it was free.
author: May G.

description:
So we were meant to take the kids to the pizza place across the road from here. But I was bored of pizza and saw this place. And we thought why not?

Firstly, it's great for kids! Welcoming, a good selection for them and art on the wall to keep them occupied. 

The owner was lovely. Very welcoming and cheerful. And this place felt comfortable. 

We had the spicy chicken arepa, pulled pork nachos and yucca fries 

The arepa was everything they promised. Moist corn arepa stuffed with spices chicken. It was more filling than I expected. Loved it!

Nachos were huge. The pork was moist and flavorful. And the taro chips tastes fresh. 

The yucca fries were awesome. Soft, slightly sweet yucca. 

This has to be on your must try list!!
author: Jay S.

description: Small so I'm not sure how it will be while busy. Great food though! Most authentic arepas I have had since I moved to the US.
author: A D.

description:
Pica Pica is a gluten-free haven! The Valencia location has more of a casual atmosphere compared to the Pica Pica on 17th. 

We ordered:
- Shredded Beef Pabelln: One of the sweeter arepas, a decent size to split with another person. 
- Crispy Chicken Platter: Absolutely delicious! However it spent too much time in the fryer leaving the chicken dry and tough.
- Yuca Beignets: (4 pieces, 2 per skewer) It was just divine! I loved the creamy center and it paired well with the caramel dipping sauce. 

I would definitely return, but I would forego the arepa next time. The Yuca Beignets are a must!
author: Juliette R.

description:
YUMMY! We went here because there a gluten allergy in our group and it was a great way for all of us to dine without anyone suffering from lack of GF food on the menu. 

What to expect: Walk in. Take a look at the menu. Take a look at the pictures. Let your stomach decide. Order at the cash register. Take the number. Sit down and it will be brought out to you.

Service: It is counter service. Regardless, it was friendly service.

Food: YUMMY! This is Venezuelan food. It's all naturally GF. I had the pulled pork pernil arepa with a sweet corn pock. It was it served with a few sides. Pretty much, I gobbled it up! Perfect portions. Super delicious. And perfect for anyone with a gluten allergy that wants to eat something a little different. They also cater to vegan/vegetarian as well. 

Atmosphere: Casual. Not stuffy at all (some little places in SF tend to feel a little hostile from the locals, or maybe that's just me?). Come here with friends and get something yummy to eat.

Overall: I don't have a gluten intolerance, however, I do love this food. Will definitetly come back if ever I need a quick lunch spot to hit up.
author: Alexandra R.

description: Coming from a huge Venezuelan family I had high expectations for good arepas and I'm glad to say that Pica lived up to it!
