I had the classic white arepas with shredded beef and it was good as any arepa I've had (except my mothers ;) ) I was there this past Sunday and haven't had time to post anything but everyone in my group was satisfied. Next time I'm in the Bay Area I will definitely be looking forward to this place again!
author: Kevin S.

description: Loved the food! The cashier helped me order something, I got the pulled pork with avocado on sweet corn bun. It's about $9-10 for one of them so it's pretty pricey but I think it's worth the price! There's plenty of seating inside and lots of sauces to try!
author: Jane H.

description:
Ready for a bad pun... Yucca to be kidding me, this place is awesome!

Seriously, it's pretty darn good.  Filling, healthy, gluten-free with massive flavor.  Arepa with a side of Yucca fries is an excellent meal.  I'll be back soon.
author: E L.

description:
5 stars for this amazing 100% gluten free restaurant! 

My boyfriend and I each had an arepa, and we shared the yuca fries and yuca beignets. 

I have some additional dietary restrictions and they accommodated per my requests painlessly and accurately. 

My boyfriend is not GF and he said it was some of the best food he has ever had. I am GF and it was some of the best food I ever had. 

I cannot begin to explain the delicious warm gooey-ness that are the yuca beignets. Perfectly crispy on the outside and magically molten on the inside. 

Whether or not you are gluten free you should try it!
author: Kalila K.

description: If I lived in San Fran I would be here all the time. So good! I had the pulled pork arepa and my friend got the vegetarian. The yuca fries were somehow better than any others I've had. I will definitely come back next time I'm in town!
author: Ani S.

description: So, after the owner reached out to me and I replied with the order info and details she requested, I never heard from her again, never got a credit for the hockey pucks. She sounded so sincere in her note but because she never did follow up as promised in her public! reply to me, don't take the caring service to heart - it's just not there.
author: Chanel B.

description:
Ok, the food at Pica Pica is ok. I usually order from here for my work, about 3 times a month. We spend about $200 per visit for the 10-15 of us.

Tonight I was super lazy and wanted something quick and this place is right by my house.  I call the order in and ask them to sub rice for my salad.  When I get there I pay, and then I check my order and they've given me a small bit of rice with an empty spot where the salad (or extra rice is suppose to be). No big deal.  I kindly tell them the mistake and they inform me that rice is extra... I literally see these people every week and always order my food the same way and it's never been a problem.  Anyways, they straight up fought me on not giving me rice instead of my salad and I walked out for what will be the last time I ever eat there or order it for my company.  Apparently they don't know how much rice costs... Will for the 5cents it would have cost them (probably less then the cost of salad) to give me the rice the way I ordered it they've lost my buisness. They can kiss there $7200 a year I spend there for our company lunches there goodbye.  The worst part is they read the order back to me the way I ordered it over the phone. Hell I would have even paid for the extra rice if they really wanted me to... Just charge me for it when I'm paying for the rest of my food. Average food, horrible buisness with no idea what customer service is.



Not sure how to respond to the buisness owner... But if you're seeing this it happened around 8pm or so last night 10/13.
author: Matt S.

description: Have loved this place for awhile now, though the quality may have slightly declined since they opened up - it's still great. The vegetarian cachapa is my favorite, and the coconut-lime juice is a nice treat. Can get pretty busy around lunchtime, but the food is really good and its hard to find arepas around SF, so that makes sense.
author: Gabrielle M.

description:
This place is awesome! Have to recommend the crispy chicken cachapa. Everything is great, but anytime I get something other than that crispy chicken deliciousness, I wish that's what I had bought. Always, though, get the cachapas instead of the areaps...almost the same price, but at least twice as big.

The yuca begniets are a super tasty dessert too.
author: Troy A.

description:
We found our way here via Gilt City. The sangria is delicious although slightly sweet. Still didn't stop us from drinking a pitcher.

If you have the chance to grab anything with taro chips - do. it.  I think the nachos may give me a heart attack later.  

Speaking of Jerry from Parks and Rec,  the arepas. They look small. They pack a punch. That's what she said. As my boyfriend said of the pulled pork: "You could club an elephant to death with this thing".

We don't actually condone the clubbing of any animal but you get the picture.
author: Kelsey G.

description: Thank you for commenting on my review! My favorite sauce on the table...hmmm...its a toss up between the ketchup and garlic aioli.  I'm a ketchup girl and I love the blend that you have (ketchup/bbq)! My BF prbly ate 1/2 bottle of your garlic aioli! He liked it so much he recommended it to his coworker who went a few days later and she was not disappointed! I look forward to trying the slaw again.
author: Thuy N.

description:
Honestly, I'm not sure what the rave is all about here. Perhaps the food is better at the actual location than at the stand in Outside Lands. However, that's definitely no excuse for a mediocre delivery. 

I had both the pulled pork arepas and the yuca fries. The arepas were really chewy and sticky in texture and the corn was a bit too grainy. The meat was definitely flavorful but did not go well with how sweet the corn exterior was. And the yuca fries were a bit too sweet and grainy as well. I'm one of the biggest fans of any kind of fries but these ones just didn't please.

If you're coming here for the arepas and yuca fries, don't. Save yourself some time and head elsewhere.
author: Priya S.

description:
Everytime I go here it's amazing. If every selection being delicious in its own right wasn't enough, the sides and sauces are out of this world as well. Get the yucca fries and dip them in every sauce possible, you won't regret it.

Everything is gluten free - super bonus, no need to be selective if you can't have gluten. The cachapas and arepas are all delicious. Haven't had the salads or pulled pork + extras item, but they looked delicious too.

Take some sauces to go if you can!
author: Cody J.

description:
Saw this place on the Food Network (Diners, Drive-Ins, and Dives) and had to try it out.  The arepa is the star item here, so I had to get that and the nachos looked pretty bomb in the pictures, so we ordered that as well.  

I had the shredded beef arepa on white corn and the girlfriend had the spicy chicken on yellow corn.  The yellow corn dough is definitely much more flavorful and I will likely get my next arepa on that the next time I visit.  Both the chicken and beef were quite flavorful and you can't really go wrong with either option.  Be careful as these little sandwiches are deceivingly filling.

The nachos are a definite pass next time.  They are definitely Pica Pica's take on nachos and taste nothing like normal nachos.  They come with pulled pork, beans, guacamole, and cheese.  All served over taro chips.  Now the taro chips on their own are delicious, but making them into nachos is a mistake in my opinion.  I would rather just have them plain and served with the guacamole or some other dip instead.

We also tried the yucca fries.  These were crisp and delicious.  They come with a side of guacamole, which could use some salt.  But the fries themselves were cooked perfectly.  

Overall a good experience and I would likely come back if I was in the area.  The place is small so don't come here with a big group.
author: JP T.

description: I can't think of another place in the city like Pica Pica. It's Venezuelan exotic cuisine that melts delicately in your mouth. Yuummmm
author: Vien T.

description:
It was ok.
I'm gluten/wheat sensitive, so I'm always on the lookout for stuff I can actually have when out for lunch...the nice thing is that the whole place is gluten free.

The food was ok, the fries were good, the dipping sauces were good...the only thing I didn't like is the price/portion sizes.  Seemed a bit expensive for how much food we actually got.

Still, this place is jam-packed on weekends so either come 4 hours early and get ready to be squished like a sardine, or forget it altogether.

I came on a weekday just after lunchtime so it wasn't bad, but the hardscape everywhere make it loud--there was only one group of 6 there besides us and it felt like they were really loud-talking, but maybe it's just that the sound was bouncing off every surface.

I'd probably try it again, but I won't go out of my way to go there.  The service was good and they were nice, so I had to give it at least a 3 (better than half) score.
author: Lisa B.

description:
Apparently this restaurant has been featured on Diners, Drive-Ins, and Dives, but I've never really allowed bleach-blonde Fieri's opinion to sway me, so I walked into Pica Pica without any expectations. I used to work at Scuderia, which is walking distance, so out of convenience I figured I'd give it a shot.

I ordered the sweet yellow arepa with pulled pork, which comes with coleslaw (not a fan). I was delighted to find avocado in the arepa, because I am obsessed with avo. The pulled pork meshed well with the sweet yellow and the spiciness of the sauces they use. They also have a variety of different sauces on the tables for you to try, which included a spicy chipotle and some others.

My only complaint is that the corn pocket became very soggy as it soaked up all the ingredients, which made it mushy at the bottom. It was so soggy it ruptured, causing the ingredients to fall out. Pica Picas wants you to eat its arepas with your hands, but it can get really messy. Also, the price ($8.95) is pretty steep for such a small pocket, and at this location, the free fountain water tasted foul. 

Overall, I'm glad I tried it once, but it's just not worth the price, and I've since found a new job, which is not in the Mission. I don't think I'll be going out of my way to eat at Pica Pica.
author: Annette C.

description:
best place in tha world™ 
the arepas are to Die for. 
the alfajores are also to Die for.
author: Mysterious O.

description:
Caribbean food isn't as ubiquitous as, say, Mexican in the SF Bay Area. So I was delighted to learn about the Venezuelan fare offered at Pica Pica. Although I am not blown away by it, I am glad to say that their arepas did not disappoint! Both the pabellon and pernil are tender and flavorful (although I would have liked the pernil to be a tad fattier/juicier). The traditional arepas (made with white corn) is on point too. Yuca fries and taro chips are both quite nice.

They also offer yellow corn arepas which are sweeter and softer than the traditional ones. I tried it but it wasn't for me. I think they are made from the same batter as their cachapas. The sweet corn arepas and cachapas are yummy on their own, but as a canvas, their sweetness somehow drowns the flavor of whatever is inside.

The place is a little messy. Prices are decent. Staff seems friendly. These all add up to an apropos setting for the enjoyment of street food.
author: A. W.

description:
We've been a few times, and the taste of the arepas is satisfactory to both of us, but at home later, we always develop an uneasy, full feeling.   The amount of plated servings actually seems small, so I guess those fat, corn-based arepas are just too filling for us.  

Will have to try something else on the menu.  Gluten free is only the beginning of my selection hurdles.
author: Liana R.

description:
This is a must if you're in the Mission District and looking for some amazing food!  An arepa you say?  What the heck is that?  Well, it's a bite of total deliciousness, stuffed with dreaminess, accompanied by delightfulness...too vague? 

Okay, so the arepa is made with corn maize, mixed with a little vegetable shortening and water, rolled into flattened balls and thrown on the grill.  These are then stuffed with slow-cooked pork, chicken, or beef and sometimes accompanied by fried veggies.  They have the option of a spicy or sweet sauce (although the arepa is already dripping with the stew juices) I had the pork, and it was one of the best "sandwiches" I've ever eaten.  I tried a little of the spicy and sweet sauce and I honestly couldn't choose between them - and I LOVE spicy food - so that's saying a lot!

It's all accompanied with the most amazing vinegar based, fresh coleslaw that I could make a meal of on its own if necessary!  So what are you doing...put down the phone and get yourself to Pica Pica!
author: Catherine H.

description:
Finding a good gluten-free plate at some restaurants is pretty common now a days but, finding a gluten-free plate  without risking cross contamination, now that's hard.. Well this place can stop your search! All ingredients are 100% gluten-free! using corn flour, pica pica offers an amazing variety of venezuelan food!
My favorite dish is the spicy chicken cachapa. A cachapa is a sweet corn crepe folded in half holding the savory goods inside. This plate has the perfect spice to it. Once you take you first bite you will not put ur fork back down. I really recommend this location. whether you have celiacs disease, eating healthy or are just plain hungry and are looking for a satisfying dish this is the place to go!
author: Leli C.

description:
Good choice for a quick, great tasting meal in the Mission. I ordered the Chicken Arepa on a whim and was surprised at how delicious it was. It was almost like a giant omelette with a corn cake exterior and chicken, beans and cheese on the inside. The table has a selection of sauces, which I always enjoy so you don't have to beg for more. 

The shrimp ceviche appetizer was a little lacking, and was pretty much served in a large shot glass. I had to navigate through the watery sauce to spear the lone shrimp and it was kind of a waste of time and money. Also the sangria was worthless, so sugary sweet (and I'm from the South so I can hang with sugary beverages) that both me and my friend left it on the table. Unprecedented.
author: Janette W.

description:
Tried this place out after my sister saw it on Diners, Drive-ins, and Dives. Paid around $10 for a shredded beef pabellon arepa and waited in line for nearly a half hour before getting my food....

It was all worth it! I've never tried arepas prior to Pica Pica, so I don't have any of those to compare it to. But it was amazing!
author: Fiana L.

description:
I watch food network all the time so after seeing pica pica on triple D i had to stop and try the place.

I am from Venezuela and this place was very disappointing. The though wasn't cook properly and it was thick too. We ordered beef pabellon (was okay probably because of the sweet plantain) and the catira had dill pickle which i didn't like. We also had the garlic yucca and a side of the sweet plantain and that was okay. The bill was about $36 dollars including drinks.

I go to the place in L.A call Coupa Cafe 100% better. And i think they have another location in San Francisco. . If you are in SF try Coupa Cafe.
author: Venezuela M.

description: This place is ok only. Sticky tables that need much more than just wiping down. Portions that are fair, but rice and beans cost nothing. More Pulled Pork on a 14 dollar item please. The Nachos Pica Pica.. are great. Super yummy. The soft yellow pockets are good, but not for 12 dollars.. You'll probably leave still  hungry unless you do the nachos..
author: Brian W.

description: I hate to give a local business 2 stars but this was not a good experience... Soggy corn bun with a stale fried chicken arepa... Fried chicken has to be hot hot! But it was pretty sad.. Sangria was way too sweet... And cole slow was way too sour... I don't understand why this place has gotten four stars...
author: C MH L.

description: This restaurant is one of my biggest regrets that I left San Francisco. I had dreams about how amazing the vegetarian arepa was. The bigger plate was pretty good too, but that arepa was just so good that I always gravitated back to that. The combination of flavors was just plain amazing and if you love your tastebuds at all you will take them here.
author: Zoe H.

description: The Best! Great food! Every time I'm in San Francisco I have to go back there and eat. They need to open a franchise in Las Vegas.
author: William S.

description:
YUMS!! Gluten free Venezuelan food! 

Was in the city this past weekend to support my cousin's art instillation at the icTus gallery. We got hungry halfway through the grand opening and the cheese and wines they served at the gallery was not enough. So my cousin suggested Pica Pica down the block for a quick and cheap bite. I'm glad we listened =)

We ordered the pulled pork maizewiches, shredded beef maizewich, the garlic yuca fries, the sweet plantains, and the sampler (not on the menu) also got the empenadas which i didn't get to try. 

i loved the pulled pork maizewich. the pork itself was really soft and the maizewich (sweet yellow corn) was delicious!!! i think i could have eaten that alone! it wasn't too sweet, but soft and melts in your mouth esp when you add their "spiciest" sauce. Mmmm. I also really like the garlic yuca fries- it's a must try! not your ordinary fries. The sweet plantains reminded me of my childhood snack- i like that it's not too sweet and the cheese added a salty taste to it. This was a definitely good recommendation and I'm so glad we went! I don't think it was that expensive either ($7.99 for the maizewich?) The sampler looked interesting so that's why I decided to try it, but I thought it was just alright. Pretty reasonable priced tho for $5.99. The guava drink was also SUPERB!
author: Natalia H.

description:
Despite the weird reviews about this place, I loved it! First time there, tried a little bit of everything. 
Got the pulled pork arepa and the grilled chicken arepa. However the pulled pork was   Way better in my opinion ! Also got the coconut lime drink! Which was really really good but kind of small for $3. Then we got some yuca fries and taro chips plus the banana chip things. In my opinion the yuca fries and taro chips are pretty plain, just something to snack on. Then we had the coconut flan and that was so good! Pretty pricey but worth it if you want something delicious and sweet. Hands down though the pulled pork arepa was amazing! Would def come back. One tip I could give is to have more staff available, and I wish there was more seating? Possibly outside as well. Luckily we got a seat b/c somebody left and  we swooped right away! Oh and the sweet yellow corn is the best! Haven't tried the white corn yet however but I like sweet
author: Janessa H.

description:
Need dinner in a flash? Call in your order and get it within 10 minutes. Bam.

The other night I ordered the Bululu salad with a Chicken Pepeada - cubes of chicken surrounded by avocado in a hefty arepa. While certainly filling, the ratio seemed totally off and not at all what I remember from my last visit. Avocado/sauce was delicious but the chicken was a little skimpy. We picked out some of the chicken and were left with a dense corn frisbee. Tasty but I'm rethinking the value. Mind you, the Bululu salad is awesome - fresh veggies and fruit with passion fruit dressing. Win.

Dessert? The owner/wife makes mini alfajores at home and packages them in threes for you to take with.

I'm wavering on the fence with this one but for now, still a good call.
author: Alissa A.

description: Take-out said it would take 10-30 minutes and it took 35minutes, but it was hot and good. I especially liked the bean/cheese epanadas. Not too heavy and the dipping sauces were tangy and spicy.
author: Lozzy W.

description:
Everyone loved the food. Even tho it was pricey, you get a lot of meaty goodness.

Minus one star cause there was no alcohol in the sangria. Like i have no tolerance and i didnt get a buzz.
author: Jackie C.

description: Amazing. Sweet corn arepas are awesome. Perfectly arranged and delicious. Got plantains and was very pleased. Crispy not gooey. People at the local were also very relaxed and only increased the ambiance. Loved it and will done again!!
author: Patrick S.

description: Had the pull pork yellow corn arepa, a little pricey for what it is $9. but taste and the the picked side was good. Would come again.
author: Iede M.

description: I would give it 5 but the service was a little slow seeings though a group of 9 and 6 came before us so it is understandable. The dips are SO GOOD and the salad was fresh. I liked the "facebook wall" they had and also the vibe from the inside. It is only a block from work so I will be coming back soon to pork out on the chips =P.
author: Jess C.

description:
This place is great.  It's a small little kitchen and space but it serves it's community well.  Offering all wheat and gluten free foods let's you know that Pica Pica can provide quality taste with a better quality of life.

I've had a couple things on their menu and so far everything's been great, but it gets pricey for the amount of food you get.  I wish items were a bit cheaper but I guess you can't complain when you're spending money on quality not quantity.  The Yuca fries are a must.
author: Kevin J.

description:
Love the pabellon arepa!

This Venezuelan spot is delicious. I'm always satisfied and never disappointed after dining here. My Colombian roommates also love this place.

Perfect for a quick and cheap dinner. Casual atmosphere great for eating alone or with friends. Communal, bar, and two-person seating.
author: Erin C.

description:
While vacationing in San Francisco my wife (who is gluten intolerant) and I had this restaurant high on our list of places to eat. 

We were not disappointed. The dining room is not large and we almost had to take our food to go. We would have happily eaten our meal on a nearby bench or even the curb but two seats opened up shortly after we paid. 

I love pupusas and it seemed to me that arepas would be similar enough that it would be a safe bet that I would love them too. I was right! 

My wife and I shared a beef arepa, a chicken cachapa and an order of taro/plantain chips. So delicious. 

The restaurant was not far off the beaten path but far enough away from the tourist areas that we were able to get away from the crowds that seemed to be in every other part of the city we visited. The atmosphere is very casual and local.
author: John M.

description:
The texture of the crepes is delightful - thicker and chewier. The sweetness also complements the savory filling. Get them with the vegetarian filling and you've got a salty-sweet-creamy trifecta of goodness starring plantains and avocados.

The Yuca fries were such carby treats. They didn't quite work as beignets though. The crunchy, cinnamony exterior of the beignets was perfect, but not enough to offset they all too bland interior.
author: Aiko S.

description: The arepas here are amazing!!! The corn "buns" were great, actual pieces of corn and it was the right amount of salty and sweet. The pork was super tender, definitely slow cooked for a long time. Anything topped with avocado is pretty much the savory cherry on top!
author: Hilary S.

description:
Yum, I loved it! I hadn't had arepas forever! The food was simple, but good.
Very close to Bart, I'd come back!
author: Yoko S.

description:
The website has a delivery order form, but because we were planning a special lunch I wanted to make sure.  I called and was told by the man who answered the phone to put in my order at 11:30 the day we needed it, which was the next day. So we planned the lunch and when I called at 11am to place the order, a woman told me that they only deliver catering and that requires two days notice. She said, several times in a combative way, that there was no way a man answered the phone the day before- only she answers the phone?- but then remembered that they had a new staff person who had been taking calls and had given me incorrect info. She told me they could still bring lunch to my office, which is 3/4 of a mile away from their store, if I ordered from Eat24 or Try Caviar or GrubHub. I tried Eat24 and the app said I could only order pick up from them. And then I was out of time to spend on this that day. 

Miscommunications are bound to happen, but at every turn they gave bad info.

If you are trying to order from here, have a back up plan and make sure you have time to deal with it. I didn't have time to find and order different meals, but my coworkers are great and were willing to go pick up bagged lunches to bring back instead. Still, embarrassing.
author: M B.

description:
Good food but the seating was horrible. 

First, we stood on line for 15 minutes to order and then waited for a table to open. Seating is limited - they only have a few tables with chairs and a few bar stools on the side.  

Our appetizer came out before we could get a table - we ended up holding our plates while we continued to wait for a seat. 

Finally, a table got up and offered their seats to us. Once seated, everything was else fine. Food was okay - nothing special - but my gluten free husband liked it,
author: Karen B.

description: Went back for another try. Something wasn't the same. Maybe the boss wasn't around to keep the profile high. People were nice so that hasn't changed. I hope it was just an off night.
author: Mike W.

description:
I took my fiancée here while we were on holiday in SF for a treat as she can't eat wheat.

 I ordered the Arepa Pernil (pulled pork inside a grilled corn flour flat bread) and a pint of Pacifico, the misses had Arepa Pepeada (chicken salad with avocado).

Let's start on food...it was the greasiest weirdest tasting thing. I loved pulled pork, but this stuff was just pure nasty. The flat bread was dripping with grease, possibly from the pork, but still. I felt ill after eating about 3 bites.

As for the beer, I ordered it with my meal, and it arrived 5 minutes after my food did. He said they were in the process of changing the gas. It was warm and completely flat. 

So disappointing. We were only in SF for 2 days and could have eaten in hundreds of other much nicer places. Shame we choose Pica Pica Maize Kitchen.
author: Gordon N.

description:
This restaurant was recommended by the Gluten-Free meetup group that I used to belong to. Located in the Mission District of San Francisco, it serves up delicious Venezuela-style sandwiches made with corn breads and yummy fillings and side dishes. This is a gluten-free kitchen, so it is safe for those with Celiacs, gluten-intolerence or gluten-sensitivitiy to dine here. Even if you are not among one of those, you can still go there to enjoy something a little different than usual.

Based on the Yelp reviews, this place can get busy and a seat could be hard to get, so I arrived there early. I guess due to it was weekend, actually there were plenty of spots available! I informed that we will have a group of about 15 people for lunch, so the young guy at the counter suggested that I just pull a couple tables together to reserve for the group.

For appetizers, I tried the yaca fries and sweet plantains.  Maybe it is just me, but I honestly think the yaca frieds taste much better than the regular potato fries! The sweet plantains look like bananas, but taste more like sweet potatoes, with a firmer texture and perhaps sweeter in taste. It is filling too so you definitely want to share with your dine partners.

I also ordered the "chicken salad with Guasacaca (creamy avocado) in a grilled sweet corn bread. The portion of this "Maize'wich" is so huge, I could only eat half of it at one sitting, and later ate the 2nd half for dinner! The corn bread tasted fresh and it actually holds up well to contian all the heavny stuffings inside!

For dessert, I got "Alfajor", which are light biscuits filled with "dulce de leche" and rolled in coconut flakes. I love anything coconut, so as soon as I saw the word "coconut", I picked up one bag of the goodies from the counter.

They also serve gluten-free beers. And another Maize'wich that is popular here is the Pelu'a Aprepa (shredded skirt stake with chedder cheese in a grilled corn flour flat bread). The portion is also huge and very filling.
author: Claire W.

description: I had the spicy chicken Arepa in the sweet corn. Mmmmmm so good. I would go back and eat the plantain fries everyone is talkin about. this is a great little spot in the mission.
author: Tatiana F.

description:
Arepas have caught on in SF, which makes me happy. I first tried them 8 or 9 years ago in Florida and searched for them on the West Coast, but ended up giving up. Now, years later places like Pica Pica are popping up. 

The arepas at Pica Pica aren't as amazing as I remember experiencing in South Florida, but that's just because SF is a far cry from hot and humid Miami.
author: Lee H.

description:
Had the vegetarian arepa twice now. Thoughts:

+I love that it's gluten free, vegan (I think?), and has avocado

-it's pretty damned bland. Maybe add a salsa? or salt? 
       The ingredients are polenta, black beans, avocado, tofu, and plantains - none of these are stand-out ingredients without some proper seasoning. Don't get me wrong, I love them all...but really...add some umph. 

Also, the first time I came they told my friend that they wouldn't serve the cole-slaw to go. Rude. The next time I came in I didn't even ask about the cole-slaw and it was cutely packaged in my to-go bag. My friend was really per-turbed by this inconsistency. I'm only writing on her behalf because she doesn't yelp.
author: Maggie F.

description: Delicious! I got the arepa with pulled pork and the Plato with spicy chicken. The plantains, black beans, coconut rice and side salad are delightful. I look forward to going back and trying more things:)
author: Loren C.

description: This is the first time i ate arepas. I thought it was ok.  The servings for individual are ok if you have a small appetite , but if you're hungy its not enough. I haven't ordered the platter meals so i wouldn't know how much it fills you up. I didn't think it was that special but its a good place if you are looking for a snack or light meal. .
author: Kenson K.

description: Excellent vegetarian friendly food! I love this place and don't know many other good Arepa places in town
author: Nikki M.

description: The food was good but not as great as everyone raves about.  I would not make an extra trip here unless you need to eat gluten free foods.  It's a cute little place with limited seating.
author: Paulette P.

description:
After seeing Pica Pica as the ROTD recently, I knew I had to check it out. I absolutely LOVE corn, so naturally I'd be super excited to try a self-proclaimed maize kitchen.  

However, after eating here last night, I was really disappointed. I came here with one of my favorites and we ended up ordering 4 things: a pabellon arepa, a pabellon maize'wich, garlic Yucca fries w/aioli, and tajadas (sweet plantains). 

The cool thing about this place is that it enables you to personalize your order a bit. You start with picking one maize bread (arepa, maize'wich, or cachapa) and then continue on to choose a filling (too many options to list). The one we both opted for, pabellon, consisted of shredded beef, sweet plantains, black beans, and queso fresco. Sounds awesome, ya? Well, it wasn't :( 

The primary culprit preventing them from attaining awesomeness? THE PLANTAINS. 

Where do I begin? The plantains were horrible. Both the tajadas and the ones tucked into our pabellon dishes. There aren't very many things I like to eat soft and mushy; however, plantains are one of the few. I like 'em soggy, wet, moist, and sweet. But the plantains here were dry, hard, and too oily. No amount of cheese, meat, or sauce could mask their nasty taste. Sadness! 

The one thing I truly enjoyed about our meal were the Yucca fries. These babies were delicious. Especially with the garlic smothered all over them. The aioli dipping sauce served on the side was pretty bomb too.  

If it weren't for the plantains, I think I would have enjoyed my meal a lot more. The maize bread was pretty good and the shredded beef was well seasoned. I'd say, this place has some potential. I like the concept of Pica Pica, and I hear the one in Napa is much better. I'm feeling generous tonight...3 stars!
author: Natasha H.

description: My wife and I love this place. Whether we walk in or order delivery, we just love the arepas. As gluten-free folks with pretty restrictive diets, it's sometimes hard to walk into a restaurant and order off the menu. Here everything is pretty much fine for us, and we can make tweaks like "sub avocado for the cheese" and they're happy to oblige. Friendly, fast service and delicious food. I miss 'em every time I travel!
author: Eric W.

description:
I FINALLY had an arepa! I wanted to try one ever since I saw Bobby Flay have an arepa throw down. What is an arepa? Think of a cross between a pita pocket and an English muffin made out of a corn tortilla filled with all kinds of savory goodness you can imagine. I tried the "Clasica" (ham and cheese) and the "La Shuli" (black beans and salsa served with side of guacamole). I also impulse ordered the beer sangria.

The arepas are fresh so they take a little bit to be ready. Good thing I had my beer sangria! It tasted peachy. I'm not sure what they put in there but the sign said "made to order" so I doubt it's something they have sitting around like real sangria. It's a refreshing drink. They also have fruit juices and lemonade that they make fresh.

My arepas were brought to my table and they were looking good. They came out hot off the grill or whatever cooking surface they use. 

I tried the La Shuli first. It was good but I was a little underwhelmed. The filling on this bad boy is really black beans and pico de gallo type salsa. The guacamole really saved it. This one was also a little difficult to handle and got messy quickly because the beans and salsa are kind of runny.

Next I tried the Clasica. This one was my favorite. The ham was called deviled ham, but it's not like devil's food or deviled eggs. It's just good. The cheese was melty just the way I like. It was so good and I didn't want it to end. 

These are pretty filling and I only ate about half of each. They are good for sharing.

There is so much more of the menu I want to try out. Next time I'll get the Pabellon (shredded beef, plantains, black beans and queso fresco). The lady sitting next to me ordered that one and it looked delicious. 

Mmmm......
author: Daisy S.

description: LOVEEE this place. Im pretty obsessed with plantains and love that they are inside the shredded beef arepa. SOO yummy. Also, the coconut lime drink is delicious too!
author: Sheila S.

description: Delish! Never tried this kind of food but it was fantastic, a little pricy for me but worth it. My main complaint was that the floors were filthy and things kept sticking to my shoes.
author: Sara P.

description:
I was in the mood for something different. I had my first arepa at Mr. Pollo and I instantly became a fan. So when I heard about this place, I was intrigued.

Pica Pica lets you customize your "corn-y" concoction any way you like it. First, you pick your outer "shell": arepa, maizewich or sweet corn. Each option is slightly sweeter than the previous one. Then, you pick from several filling combinations. 

My favorite is the maizewich #7, which comes with pulled pork, avocado and tomato. It's savory, just a little sweet and really filling. The #2 is my husband's favorite because it just has beef and cheese. I love their garlic yucca fries - the pika'chup sauce that comes with it is really good, like a spicy ketchup. They even serve sangrias here, which are surprisingly strong.

Their weekday (noon - 3pm) lunch special is a pretty good deal: for $7.99 you get a medium arepa with one side.

So far, I am still a fan. The food tastes healthy and they offer several combination options so you don't get bored.
author: Mariela D.

description: Maybe I am spoiled from having lived in Florida but I am used to bigger and cheaper ones, I tried the Shredded Beef Pabellón Arepas which was small for the money. Taste was good but nothing special, pretty dry, I tried the sauces that are at the table but they didn't help much.
author: Robby G.

description: Cheap, quick and easy. Everything is gluten free and freshly prepared. It's got a small dining room But people are considerate.
author: Katie E.

description: Portions look small but I was filled up after I ate it.  Service is alright.  The place fits not too many people but people eat pretty quickly.
author: Byron L.

description:
This place is closer to three stars, really, but I'm factoring in its gluten free status, which bumps up the score. How many dedicated gf restaurants are there? That was the draw for me. If you can eat whatever you like, you may not be overjoyed by this place, but for gf people, it's a solid bet.

So: the place. It's pretty quick and casual in vibe. You order at the counter and take a number to your table. Speaking of which, the tables in this place are gorgeous! They are the highlight, decor-wise. Service is quick, and prices are ok for this area. Looks like a minimum-wage joint with teen servers, so there is that. How's the food? Here's the lowdown: if you like soft corn cakes, avocado, plantains and aioli, you'll dig it. Their main offerings are arepas and cachapas, which are identical other than their shape (one looks like a taco, the other looks like a burger). There are some meat and veggie options, but there won't be many permutations here. The corn is sweet, the aioli is good, and the yuca fries are a highlight. They serve gluten free beer, and I highly recommend the coconut limeade. You'll quickly find the meal you like here and stick to it, or you'll go elsewhere.

It's simple, it's quick, it's Venezuelan, gluten free and pretty good. 3-4 stars.
author: Ninja B.

description: Went to Pica Pica for the first time the other night and the place was pretty busy. The signage is similar to Chipotle inside, albeit the kitchen prep area is set up differently. My friends and I were able to order rather quickly. I ordered the Pulled Pork Pernil platter. After ordering to eat there, we were getting rather worried because of the lack of seating in the restaurant. This is my one and only complaint. In this type of atmosphere, you really should eat and enjoy yourself but not dawdle at your table. However, many people were doing so. Luckily, an empty table freed up in the nick of time for us to sit and eat. The pulled pork and tostones (plantain chips) were my favorite. Venezuelan food is delicious!
author: Marcos H.

description: Great lunch place!!  Highly recommend the sweet corn vegetarian arepas, and the cheese empanadas are light like tempura batter!  Don't try to decide between the desserts - the coconut quesillo and the yuca beignets are so insanely good you must try both!!!
author: Ariela S.

description: Saw this on TV and had to come try it for ourselves. It was worth the trip and the small amount of time we had to enjoy our grilled chicken. Must try the yellow corn...it was bomb!
author: Tina S.

description:
This place shows up in all of the gluten-free searches (my mother is strongly allergic), however you don't have to be GF to enjoy Pica Pica! It's a non-issue here, as everything is made with corn anyway.

Both the chicken and pulled pork arepas were great, as were the white corn vs sweet yellow corn options. I think I prefer the sweet yellow corn over the traditional white, however. The yucca fries and sweet plaintain sides were tasty (the plantains come with Cotija cheese), but I don't think I'd order as much food next time if there are only two of us. An arepa plate (with the side of slaw) is a significant amount of food, and the yucca fries added a lot. We were really stuffed when we left. Maybe if I go with more people...

Also, if you order the yucca fries, let them cool down before you bit into them! They came out so piping hot that we burned our mouths on them!
author: Nick S.

description: Amazing amazing amazing arepas ! Try their vegetarian arepas with the sweet yellow bread ! They also have a bunch of tasty sauces , which is a must try ! Especially the pink sauce .
author: Pamela C.

description: This was my fav. Spot to eat but my sweet corn was undercooked and just was not pleasant to eat. So disappointed. 3 days ago.
author: Linda G.

description:
This place can be a little on the slow side if it's during their busy hours. A poster on their wall indicates all of the different food delivery companies they are partnered with, which is maybe why it's harder to get out with your food if you actually just stop by and wait in line. 

That said, the food is delicious! And despite usually trying to avoid anything gluten-free, I've actually gone out of my way to eat here a few times even while not trying to accommodate anyone else's gluten free diet. 

So there you have it -- Pica Pica Maize Kitchen -- great for eaters of any sort, both gluten-full and gluten-free!
author: Elaine S.

description: Cheap and delicious. I'm ridiculously fond of the vegetarian arepa with yellow corn, although I've tried a number of my other dishes. The nachos are divine, the yuca fries yummy. The pulled pork cachapa was actually -too- large, even for my typically enormous appetite, but so, so good. It's delightful to have a filling and appetizing gluten-free option.
author: Jeri J.

description: Saw this in diners drive ins and dives and had to try it out since I'm visiting the area. It was phenomenal! I would order more but I'm so stuffed from the good amount of food they served. Had the Pabellon and the beef and arepa were on point! Alongside with the coconut like juice, literally the cherry on top! It definitely has the Latin flavor down packed! Love this place! gracias por todo!
author: Claudette Y.

description: Watching it at food network makes me want to try this. Order yellow arepa with spicy chicken, seviche with taro chips, basket of taro chips. It just ok for me, my wife has to order another arepa with pork because she wants more protein. There's a lot of people, place is small, hard to find parking, too pricey for what you will get. I probably won't be back
author: Noel O.

description: Delicious! Lots of vegan options and all homemade awesomeness. I had the sweet corn arepa shuli, yucca fries, and taro chips. Their homemade sauces are wonderful, and I wish I had them at home to put on everything. They are as addicting as Sriracha. All the flavors balance perfectly.  The only bad thing about this place was the wait time and lack of seating--it's super popular and it's obvious why. Will go again for sure.
author: Mylie T.

description:
So glad this place is so close to my place if business. I could eat there every day. The food is SO good - tasty, well-priced, and (mostly) good for you.

Service is pretty fast (most of the time) and the counter staff is super friendly.
author: judah m.

description: First off, let me say that being gluten intolerant, being able to go get food without having to go through explaining it to staff and get worried about getting sick is AWESOME. And the food here REALLY tastes great. I love it. I drive from Half Moon Bay to eat here. HOWEVER, as others mentioned, it is quite overpriced. My biggest complaint is that it is primarily corn based but no option of organic or non-GMO. For the sake of health and our environment, I think that is a key aspect. I understand the price aspects, however most who eat gluten free ALSO choose non-gmo/organic for the same health and environmental concerns that they avoid gluten. If Pica Pica offered non-GMO/organic options, I'd be willing to pay more, I'd eat there way often, and I believe they would have much more business. Thank you Pica Pica for the great gf food, but please consider this option!!
author: Kristen L.

description: Hell. Yes. This place is the bomb. Amazing, fresh flavors. Blew me away and can't stop thinking about the next time I return. Highly recommend.
author: Ian S.

description: Yucca fries and naturally gluten free food, I didn't need any extra convincing to try this restaurant. And the food was just as good as I expected, I'll be back the next time I make my way to this area of the city, I may go just for this restaurant!
author: Kayla R.

description:
This was my first time at Pica Pica and I think I'm in love!

I went there for lunch yesterday (a Sunday) with 5 other people and it was pretty packed, but the line moved quickly. Luckily, we were able to grab a table  (it's first come first serve) and enjoy our delicious meals!

I had the Grilled Chicken Arepa and I want more!

Our food came out pretty quickly and everything was scrumptious!

I will definitely be going back.
author: Michelle P.

description:
My father is from Venezuela and I grew up there. The arepas at pica pica are amaizing, totally Luke the ones my abuela made. This is my new fav restaurant in SF.
Las arepas estan de madre. Vivi en venezuela mucho tiempo y la comida aqui es pero muy autentica
author: Gregory L.

description: Wonderful and delicious 100% gluten-free food, please go here! The staff is incredibly nice as well.
author: Dan S.

description:
(See pic)

More of 3.4 stars. #3 shredded beef with arepa bread (grilled corn flour) was heavy for lunch but was with strong flavors. It was so much food I had to finish it during the following 3 hours in intervals. 

The wait was about 10mins for takeout.
author: T L.

description: Came here after catching it on DDD. We had both the vegetarian arepas (tofu and black beans) and thought they were OK - neither good nor bad. One of them was too sweet because of the plantains. The tofu despite being shown as marinated for a good amount of time on the show didn't have much flavor. The arepa itself sort of got lost in the filling/topping. I would prefer regular pupusas to this.
author: Manjesh N.

description: Just had an arepa for lunch here. Venezuelan food is hard to come by so definitely wanted to check it out. While the food is interesting (though carb heavy), I didn't think the place was clean. The tables were greasy, and the cooks and servers were not wearing gloves. I noticed that the guy making the corn bread was rubbing his chin as he was cooking! Won't be going back there again.
author: puja s.

description: Wow. So underwhelmed. I guess I'm spoiled by San Diego taco shops where $5 gets u a delicious  monster burito that you can't finish. I housed a $10 Arepa and a $10 shrimp cevicha and am still really hungry. Both were lacking in the flavor department but it was prepared in about 35 seconds so I feel 1 star wouldn't b fair. I would totally order 2 more things and get full but I'll just have a second lunch somewhere else.
author: Kai D.

description:
I just started a job in the neighborhood and was told to try an Arepa at Pica Pica. 

I had the chicken, I literally had to close my office door so I could make yummy food sounds in peace. Holy hand baskets.  I want one now..I got the sweet corn and had avocado added. Mother of pearl! They even added sweet plantains. 

Try it. They have amazing vegetarian options..I'm actually weaning off chicken no longer eating beef or pork for a year now...I'm ashamed to say I may have one more as a finsl meat farewell...oh beautiful torture.
author: Kristy L.

description:
Pica Pica!

This place gets at least 3 stars from me for being gluten free... I just love it!  I have only had one arepa, but then another time went back for the GF beer.  I thought the food was great, and I really liked the spicy dipping sauce that came with the fries.

I would say, definitely give it a shot.
author: Laura P.

description:
I had never had Venezuelan food before this place, but once I saw that they had plantain and taro chips, I already knew I would like this place. 

The arepa was delicious. My shrimp ceviche with taro chips were also good. Plantain chips and regular cooked sweet plantains, both amazing as well. The huge plate of taro chip nachos that passed by looked so good that it made me wonder why I didn't order that. 

So why the 3 stars?
It was just 2pm on a Sunday and they were out of A LOT of stuff. No more yuca fries, no more agua frescas, what did they serve between then and closing time at 10pm?? They forgot to give me the taro chips that were supposed to come with the ceviche; I only got the side order of taro and plantain chips together. The place is small, so good luck getting a seat. 

I want to love you Pica Pica. I will be back, and I'll update after I get to try all the other things I wanted to try. But for now.. you are just A-OK.
author: C. Z.

description:
My friend is Venezuelan and approves of this place! closest thing she has had to home. 

Sauces are great! I enjoyed the Shredded beef Arepa. 

Should start making a ham and cheese one! that's his favorite kind. 

Its not the kind of food you eat everyday so be open minded.

Edited* 2/15/15
Went here to have someone try it, im taking away 2 stars unfortunately... I ordered the pulled pork sweet arepa it was good. However we ordered garlic yucca fries and empanadas and they were way too fried. You see the ones in the list of pictures here? well ours were five shades too brown. I put one on a napkin and it was drenched in oil. A little dissapointing, something like that should never leave the kitchen. They remade them for us and still came out over fried.
author: Maricris P.

description:
Chosen for gluten free: 100% gluten free place. 
The happy feeling an allergic person gets when realizing they can order anything in the place and be safe: indescribable!
Easy corner location; easy street parking pre-lunch rush. 
Great looking room; clean and bright space with great ethnic touches.
Easy seating.
Delicious food! They live up to their five star and four star ratings. 
Friendly, helpful, informative, clean and bright-eyed staff. 
We ordered the chupe chicken soup with corn. Just enough portion size, delicious broth and pulled chicken with fresh avocado wedge and dash of white cheese. Tasty and reminded me of the various Latina moms' kitchens I visited while growing up. YUM!
Next we had the arupe. The young lady was so helpful and told us her favorites were the white corn with pulled pork. Oh lawd was that great! It looks small but beware! Its filling!! 
Did not even think about desserts. Hope to another fine day. 

They have a restroom so you can wash up after that saucy meal. Its finger licking, lip smacking good. Hope you enjoy it!
author: F M.

description:
Salad with beef-ok
Ceviche-good
Arepas-No
author: Lauren V.

description:
I feel like dancing! This place is sooo good! I went in, ordered my food, and got my mind blown. When you order you get a number and they bring it to your table. I ordered with a friend so when they brought the big mound of nachos first, they took the number not knowing I had a second order coming. So my friend and I saw the server stumble around looking confused holding my arepa, then brought it back. I figured it was mine so I went and asked for it. She asked, "You didn't take your number?" I said, "I did! But the server took it back!" We laughed and she apologized and it was all good because I liked the way she smiled and because if it wasn't for her I wouldn't have had an orgasm in my mouth from the sweet corn arepa mixed with sweet plantains and savory shredded beef. Alternate by taking a bite of the arepa and then a bite of the salad on the taro chip to make the party even more wild! 
Oh! And the green creamy sauce on the nachos was awesome and they have it in a bottle on the table. So squirt some of that stuff on your food, too. If you like spicy, use that yellow mustard looking sauce. That stuff burns!
author: Stephen W.

description: Gluten-free paradise! Everything is GF, so no worrying about cross-contamination. Tons of vegan options as well. I had the sweet corn arepa with black beans- I loved it. Yummy, spicy and filling. My husband had the white corn arepa with shredded beef and he devoured it- the sweetness of the plantains made it perfection. But the yucca fries...holy moly- I could add these to my last meal and die a happy woman. Loved this place and want to try lots of different combos. Open a location in LA, pretty please!
author: L C.

description:
First time trying food from Venezuela. So we decided to come to Pica Pica because I happened to see it featured on the food network. Immediately I was intrigued by the "arepa". So when we walked into the restaurant it was very crowded. Luckily a table cleared up prettt quickly for us. The restaurant itself is very small but quite nice. The girl at the register wasn't very friendly. She looked flustered. I ordered the beef pabellon arepa. And as a starter we ordered the yucca fries. Our food took about 20 minutes to arrive. So, the yucca fries were very nice...crunchy and hot. They came with an ok guacamole. My arepa was quite flavorful and piping hot. It came with a tiny amount of coleslaw on the side. 

Bottom line: good food, not so friendly staff. And for $8.95, the arepa was just too small. I didn't actually feel full. I guess if you're really hungry this isn't the ideal restaurant. We left wishing the the portion size was just a bit larger.
author: Priscilla A.

description: So tasty. Get the yellow corn, not the white. My fav is that with the pork or beef. Beef if you want something a little sweeter b/c has fried plantains. Meal was $15 with a beer.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Love this place !! the yucca fries are delicious and they come with a dipping sauce. 
The arepas made with corn meal or plantains are delicious.  I recommend this place for a quick bit to eat for lunch or dinner.
author: Lscotty S.

description: Overpriced. Also the menu lists their sandwich at 9.50 and the lunch platter with rice and beans for 13.50. The lunch platter is only the rice and beans and does not include the sandwich. $25 if you want the whole lunch plate.
author: Aaron M.

description: I really don't like chains but this place was has some pretty good tasting food. The grilled chicken corn pocket was very good and was huge. I enjoyed the corn pocket very much because of the sweetness, I do recommend getting the beef instead of the chicken for more flavor. This place is perfectly located in the trendy part of SF with many restaurants to choose from. Would I come back? Yes.
author: Matthew L.

description: First time trying authentic Venezuelan food and it did not disappoint! I had the sweet corn arepa with spicy chicken & it was full of flavor and delicious! Also their nachos with grilled chicken and taro chips were too die for!! Definitely want to go back.
author: Adriana S.

description: Generous portions and great to try a different type of food! More of a fast food/takeaway outlet than restaurant but definitely a good place for dinner
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Cool place, good food. 

$9 gets you a VERY good fried corn pocket with some tasty filling, and a little slaw on the side. At the end of the day,  the filling might be pretty average but the corn pocket is worth a visit. 

If you have low heat tolerance, you may want to avoid the spicy chicken catira.
author: Kylie F.

description: Really yummy food. Sweet yellow corn pockets r amazing with Spicy Chicken Catira. I can't wait to come back & try more dishes!!  Service was amazing with very friendly staff
author: Jeffrey L.

description:
Came here since one of my friends suggested it.

The food is good. Had the nachos w/ shredded beef, the crispy chicken platter & the pork platter (which ended up being beef since they were out of pork). The food is very tasty! Nothing too special/interesting on our plates though. Pretty cool that it's all pretty much gluten free if you're allergic. 

The ambiance in the place isn't bad. Pretty clean seating area & relatively empty while we were there. Decent service, although, our cashier seemed to have some type of attitude. Don't know why. I might come back, it didn't appeal to me like I had imagined though.
author: Cat M.

description:
Well. Maybe the food's good. I have no idea. My food was supposed to be delivered within 40 minutes and it's been almost 2 hours. Something tells me it's going to be cold.

I'll assume that they were just busy, but it's obvious they can't handle delivery very well yet. Be warned.

Edit: Food got here. It's good, and cold/soggy as hell. Clearly been sitting a while. Yeah, don't get delivery here.
author: Munaf A.

description: One of my favorite lunches in San Francisco! Definitely get the yuca fries; they are incredible. Fast service and wonderful food!
author: Eliza L.

description: Price seems very off for quality / quantity. Came back here after a couple years away. Did something change or did my bar for arepas skyrocket? Not sure, but either way...I wasn't blown away. My chupe soup was apportioned somewhat stingily, while the crispy chicken arepa felt undeserving of its price tag. Service was pretty slow too. I'll come back some other time to re-verify but I think this place has gotten too comfortable riding on the endless supply of ppl off Valencia
author: Jay T.

description: Tried it for lunch while we were in San Francisco and loved it.  We tried the arepas and cachapas and both were excellent.
author: Hl B.

description: I've eaten here about three times now, and it's the most delicious, fresh, all-around great Salvadorian food I've had in the Mission.
author: Jim B.

description: One of my favorite fast casual places to eat. Yummy arepas with great fillings plus the sauces are perfect to pair! A healthy dose of guacamole inside the arepa to top it all off!
author: Carly K.

description: Definitely NOT Venezuelan food. Not traditional arepa at all. So if your looking for anything Colombian/Venezuelan don't come here. Other wise, the food may taste alright if you haven't had the pleasure of eating traditional Colombian/Venezuelan food.
author: Stephanie B.

description: Decent place. Sadly all the vegetarian stuff has the same contents - plantain, yuca and so if you go there order one. The nachos is good and made of plantain chips which are thick and not as crispy as corn chips. The cachapa is sweet and unless you can eat an entire pancake, it needs to be shared. The salad with the cachapa is yummy and has a slight sour dressing. Yuca garlic fries were good too. They are five thick pieces about 2 inches long and 1 inch thick.
author: Himanshu R.

description: This is a great place for a quick, delicious dinner in San Francisco.  I have intolerances to gluten, soy and dairy and I am never disappointed with the options and the great tasting food they serve.  I love the arepas and the yuca fries are off the hook!  Great quality and great tasting food!
author: Liz K.

description: I love this place. Arepas are great, fries are great, but I think I just love the simple authentic platos with fried plantains & coconut rice the best...soooo good! Plus everything is gluten free with no possibility of contamination so it's celiac friendly, YAY!
author: L K.

description: Friendly staff! Arepas were yummy but the chicken seemed to lack flavor and was perhaps undercooked :(
author: Chauanh D.

description: Tried the pulled pork sweet corn arepas, yuca fries and the yucca beignets. All tasted great and very flavorful. Service was good and food arrived quickly. Although I did arrive shortly after opening, so no lunch crowd yet. Would definitely be back to try other dishes and recommend.
author: J Y.

description:
Came here after a movie with a friend during a recent trip to SF.  She had originally found out about Pica Pica at a music festival where they set up a stall, and only recently learned of their brick and mortar store in the Mission.  Raving about the yellow corn "maize-wiches", I took her advice and ordered the shredded beef pabellon (with side of yuca fries).

It may not look like much, but these sandwiches are filling and delicious.  The yellow corn maize-wich especially since the insides of the corn patty are still gooey and warm.  The fillings all worked together too; a good balance of sweet and savory (contrast of the plantains and queso fresco).  I also really liked the slaw served alongside it, as well as the homemade spicy ketchup.  The fries were ok, but didn't really do much.

It's convenient, quick, easy, and relatively cheap.  I only wish we had something like this on the east coast.
author: Barrett L.

description: So disappointing and overpriced ! If you want real Arepas, go to your local Mexican store, get Harina PAN, a pound for less than $3.50 and make your own at home. Beef and platanos were good.
author: Ana S.

description: The sweet corn arepas are outstanding. Always fresh, not cheap but really worth every bite. And the sangria is flavorful and not overly sweet. Great service, yum.
author: Eve H.

description:
Being a new establishment, Pica Pica's still got that "so fresh & so clean (clean)" vibe. I don't know how well it fits in at 15th & Valencia; it almost seems more appropriate as a mall eatery.

So, the Lesbian Crew took me here for lunch yesterday. None of us had had Venezuelan fast food & I'd only eaten an arepa once (hardly making me the expert in the group.) 

Their menu is all about decisions, decisions. First pick your vessel: arepa, cachapa or maize'wich then you pick from ten different fillings. For those more visually inclined, there are examples of each maize bread & some fillings behind glass at the counter.

I chose an arepa ($7.99, grilled white corn flour cake) with the Perico filling (scrambled eggs, tomatoes, onions & cheese) which was a good sized sandwich. I liked the mix of ingredients & the fact that the arepa was a combination of crispy on the outside & softer on the other side. My only complaint is that the eggs were a bit overcooked. Our table shared plantains & yucca fries ($3.99 each, both of which were perfectly fried & therefore, a huge hit with our party.)

The bill for three came out to about $15 per person. I'd come back to try the cachapa & the maize'wich. It's an interesting concept--Venezuelan sandwiches in the land of Mexican tacos & Salvadorean pupusas.
author: Fancypants X.

description: Best cabbage salad ever! I had the sweet yellow Grilled chicken Arepa AND it was amazing!!! Definitely recommend it!
author: Pamela C.

description: Really good Venezuelan grub. Being from Miami its a bit expensive, but then again theres not much Venezuelan in SF. GET YOUR AREPA ON.
author: Leiani P.

description: Found this place on yelp and thought it'd be good due to the amount of reviews. I ordered the pulled pork arepa with the sweet yellow corn and a side of garlic yucca fries. First, I guess the guy who took my order mistakenly wrote down regular, which was fine. They were still good. However with the arepa, the bottom was totally soggy and it was super hard to eat since it was dripping and falling apart the whole time. The meat was pretty good, but chewy. I'm from Miami, so I've had a fair share of amazing arepas. Unfortunately, this was kind of a shame in comparison to what I've had in the past.
author: Mindy N.

description:
Pica pica is a small restaurant which is fast casual.  You order at the front then sit down.

[shredded beef pabellon arepa]
An arepa is a grilled corn pocket.  It's kind of like a grilled corn bread as a bun.

Inside was sweet plaintains, black bean spread, queso fresco and I choose the sweet yellow one.

Now I kind of thought the arepa shell was a little too sweet, but that might have been my fault as I chose the 'sweet yellow one'.  The ingredients inside are really good and fresh.

I think overall in my personal taste disposition, I kind of don't really like a gooey 'bread' (the arepa) because it feels like I am eating a corn bread sandwich.

[tres empanadas]
Basic empanadas freshly fried.

[plaintain & taro chips]
Thin and freshly frie.d

[overall]
I think if you like corn bread.. I mean REALLY like corn bread you will like Pica Pica.  If you can only eat corn bread in small portions, I probably recommend steering away from the Arepa.
author: Dan Q.

description: ok, How have I not been here before?  This place rocked!  Food was DELICIOUS.  I had the Vegetariana corn thing...can't remember how to spell it.  Coconut Lime juice, Yuca fries and tasted my friends pulled pork.  All of it was exquisite.  The lady that helped us was very knowledgable and helpful too...thank you!
author: Matt V.

description:
Just stopped in to grab lunch To go for three of us... The chicken arepa was okay by the boyfriends standards but my mom and I had the pulled pork arepa and yuck!!!!! I don't know if we just got a bad batch but it was terrible. The outer corn pocket was so soggy and sopping with terrible sauce and mustard. We each ate two bites and threw it away. 

We also got Yukon fries which tasted like they had been fried in rancid oil.... Ew

The only good part of it was the passion fruit drink.....

Maybe we hit an off day but it was NOT worth the hype
author: Mikaela K.

description: Yes my first time in SF. Flew in NYE and had nothing but laughs and good times the entire trip!
author: T K.

description: Yummy food but the location didn't seem such a nice area, especially at night time. Great naturally gluten free arepas.
author: Rachel B.

description: Such a great meal! I first saw this place on diners drive ins and dives and I'm so glad I was able to come here! Came in on a Monday night around 8 and it was busy! I had the shredded beef arepa, yucca fries and a sangria. My friend had the pulled pork plate and tarro and plantain chips. My dinner was amazing. Friends was tasty too, I especially liked her black beans. I liked the tarro chips better than plantain chips. Hope to come back and try other stuff.
author: Kelly C.

description:
This place is so incredibly awesome. Cannot believe I only found this on my last day here. 

From the music playing the background to the wide variety including the sauces.

Loves the yucca fries and classic chicken arepa!!  Just WOW!
author: Will S.

description: Update, I have changed my rating to 5 stars as I learned that the Beignets should be eaten fresh, and this is why they weren't perfect.  Everyone should eat here.
author: Elle S.

description:
First time eating here yesterday. What a treat! We had become addicted to Arepas years ago, but our local haunt closed down and we've been missing them ever since. 

PicaPica filled that space and more. The beef arepa with plantains was out of this world. I will definitely be going back when in the city!
author: David T.

description:
I'm reading some of the bad reviews for this place and I'm shocked!  Someone complained that the food came out too fast....umm.....I'll take it, thanks!

I thought the food was amazing, and I've sampled nearly everything on the menu.  Its different and delicious, and I love that you can add your own sauce.

Small place but easy enough to grab something to go.  Staff was friendly.

I loved this place and I highly recommend it.
author: Scarlett C.

description: I can't believe I've never heard of arepas before. I'm so glad I did. I have to say it's one of the best things I've ever eaten! It's so simple, too. I tried the pulled pork with the pica'pun sauce on the side. I also got the coconut lime drink which was so good. The service is fantastic and the prices are reasonable. I think I have a new addiction!
author: Catalina V.

description:
OK so this is probably an unfair review because I have been sick so I only got their coconut garlic rice but it was SOOO good! My friends, however, all enjoyed their meals too and each had something a bit different. 

I like that the menu had things I wasn't used to seeing around town. The service was great too. Small place, but what a way to go for gluten free peeps!
author: Kat M.

description: Not a huge fan. Had a cachapa which my bf who is Venezuelan warned me wasn't what we are used to. I was craving cachapa and didn't want to cook. I was disappointed. Server was rude and dismissed us at the register. Owner was not there which I found strange. I realized this might not be an authentic Venezuelan restaurant since no one from staff was Venezuelan. He had the pabellon which was ok. Serving size was perfect, not too big not too small. We weren't impressed. The garlic yucca fries are good, it's like potatoes though kinda hard to mess up. However I have had under cooked yucca which is bad. This was perfect and yummy. The salads looked good. I'm just wishing it was more authentic. I really miss Venezuelan goodies. I'll stick to making arepas and cachapas at home with my bfs Venezuelan grandmothers recipes.
author: Milly S.

description: My husband and I drive from San Mateo at least once a month to go here. The food is authentic and tasteful. We love it.
author: E B.

description: The food is AMAZING. The service...meh, but I will continue to go back for that food. The yuca fries and the arepas are absolutely sinful. Love its artsy layout, too. Definitely recommend.
author: Sierra H.

description:
Suffering from celiac disease or want to avoid gluten for other reasons?  Allergic to nuts? Pica Pica could be the place for you.  The main ingredient is corn.  Even their empanadas are made with corn flour.  They mentioned they don't use nuts either, but if you are allergic to nuts, please double check.  Don't take my word for it.

The three main types of corn/maize breads are the Venezuelan arepa (grilled corn flour cake), cachapa (sweet corn pancake) or maize'wich (corn bread cakes).  You choose the form (you can see what they look like at the counter - they're displayed in a plexiglass case) and then one of 10 fillings (like Chipotle).  They also have salads, soups, sides and a kid's menu.

* Cachapa with pepeada ($8.99): The corn pancake is thick, dense, chewy, a bit spongy and very sweet (maybe the sweet corn really is that sweet).  It seemed too sweet.  The pepeada filling is a creamy mixture of skinless chicken, avocado, red onions and herbs - imagine chicken mixed with a mild guacamole.  I wish it had a little crunch (more red onions?) and more fresh herbs.  It was bigger than I expected and generously stuffed with pepeada.  A smaller size option would be nice along with the option to mix and match the different maize breads.  
* Shrimp soup: nice, light, but full flavored, fish stock with medium sized shrimp, potato and corn.

The setting seems a bit too polished but the flavors are fresh and vibrant.
author: Lolia S.
Tina F.

description:
Both my boy friend and I saw this place on TV and it looked delish so we had to go try.   Its in the mission valencia area but the part around there seemed to have plenty of street parking around on a Monday lunch time...probably not so much during dinner.  When we walked in, it was smaller than I expected but I loved the big windows.

We ordered the nachos pica pica which was humongous!!  and the spicy chicken arepas which was I think a decent size for one on the white pocket.  It was so light and fluffy...I think next time I wanna try the yellow one though.  The arepas came with a nice little salad.  The nachos though I think were the star!!  It was so gooodddd!!  Taro chips crispy (though bottom layers were quite soaked with cheese and guac and beans), pulled pork plentiful and juicy, and the guac (i wished i had more)....mmmm....

Definitely a good place for fast friendly venezuelan food.
author: Nikkie P.

description: I saw this restaurant on Triple D.  When visiting family in San Francisco, I finally got the chance.  I had the grilled chicken on yellow corn pocket.  The taste was spot on, the flavor of each ingredient present but not spicy.  I feel in love with the food.  The other family members had the pork and enjoyed it equally.  I can't wait to go back
author: Marcy R.

description: I love this place. Gluten free, great veggie options and easily nightshade free which can be so hard to find! I get the veggie without aioli which makes it vegan but you don't even miss the dairy/cheese with so much other good stuff in there. One arepa is definitely enough for a meal, esp if you get a side (garlic yuca fries YUM). Highly recommend!
author: Gabrielle G.

description:
Delicious, filling, greasy-in-a-good-way, cheap, decadent food. I recommend the Maize'wich as your "bread"-- a good balance between the drier arepa and the sweet pancake. 

Try the Clasica, which is a ham and cheese sandwich, on the Maize'wich for ultimate cheesy-gooey glorious taste explosion.

So good! I went for lunch around noon on a Tuesday and there was no line whatsoever. 

Bring your gluten-free friends and they'll thank you for all time.
author: Christina M.

description: Good food. Good service. Liked arepa, which I had for the first time. We are thankful that it opened on July 4 and opened even when all else was closed in the neighborhood. We were traveling: So it was nice to have a place to eat and were pleased that our arepas were good tasting as well.
author: Ana T.

description: Definitely will not be disappointed with this place. We all tried something different.  The arepa pabellon was delicious but so was the cachapa with the pulled pork. Had to place an order to go.
author: Alejandro N.

description:
Walking down Valencia on a sunny afternoon, I passed by many fine establishments, and after walking 6 blocks, I made it to Pica Pica Maize Kitchen.  I was looking forward to the experience, but was left disappointed.

If I had to sum up Pica Pica's food in two words, it would be "one note".  There wasn't enough contrast in the perico maize'wich or empanadas to motivate me to finish my food.  Just a note, Pica Pica, a little acid goes a long way.  A crunch would have been nice as well, for texture.  Fresh onions would have done wonders for my maize'wich.  The grilled maize itself wasn't impressive enough to make me want to return for another.  

I know the maize is supposed to be the star and unifying theme at Pica Pica, but I would like to nominate the cooking oil.  Everything was greasy, like it was cooked at the wrong temperature, so the oil saturated the food instead of crisping it.  Although this place is gluten-free, the copious amount of oil in the food produce the same result, upset tummy, as if I were eating gluten laden food.
author: Sandy K.

description: We went to Pica Pica with lots of excitement and graving to eat arepas. We were super disappointed. This is not a Venezuelan place. The staff was from other Hispanic countries; nothing wrong with that if they knew how to cook Venezuelan food.  The arepas were not cooked well (raw) so the "masa" stuck to the roof of our mouths. The pabellón filling was bland and not even remotely like the Venezuelan pabellón flavor. The spicy chicken was okay, but it was not a Venezuelan dish. It also was super expensive for being a self service place. There is no way we will go back to this place.  I definitely recommend against going there. AND they do not have coffee-- definitely not a Venezuelan place.
author: Keka W.

description:
I think I've met my match. As a connoisseur of all that is oily and greasy, the question I've always asked myself was: "Would I ever come across something that was too oily and greasy for my liking?" I guess Pica Pica is Venuzuelan  for "the Answer."

It seemed that all the ingredients were in place for me to enjoy the cuisine, the yucca, the plantains, the fried flat breads, the Latin American flavors... But the whole was not greater than the sum of the parts. It was just a little too much grease and not enough freshness to balance it out.
author: Jeffrey J.

description:
I have been craving this type of food ever since we ate there last year. The corn was a perfect means to eat with the meat like a sandwhich. Really good for a gluten free option. 

That being said shortly after eating there, both members of our party got sick. Not sure if it was Pica Pica or something we had eaten prior. The timing was an hour or two after eating there.

Despite that. I REALLY liked the food.
author: AJ Q.

description: Bomb food, cool atmosphere. I'm ready to go back and explore the menu a little. If you're down to try something new or in the mood for something spicy I say swing in to pica pica. You won't be disappointed
author: Dave A.

description:
Maize'wich Pepeada - next will try as an arepa. Both the chicken salad & guacamole combo and the maize'wich are tasty but not as good together. I like sweet and savory so I thought I'd try. Although the maize was sweet and reminded me of a corn tamale cake, it was a little tough to slice and more doughy then I liked.

The Yucca Fries with garlic were delicious! How can you go wrong with something fried and covered with garlic? I forgot how hearty and rich yucca is. Tasty but could only eat a few.

Arepa Pabellon - exactly what i was looking for! Sweet and savory! The sweetness of the plantains flavorful seasoning of the skirt steak, saltiness of cheese and texture of the arepa was a winner! 

Bululu salad - colorful and attractive but passable. Not much in the way of flavor. Stick to the arepas and maize'wiches!
author: Anna R.

description: Nachos plate was very tasty, well priced, and the staff was very friendly.  I would come back here again. I did enjoy the environment and my pork arepa as well.
author: David L.

description: I really love the food at this place, I would give 5 stars if the service wasn't soo slow and so unfriendly...
author: Brett M.

description:
yesterday was my second visit to pica pica. I ordered the chicken arepa which was good. I saw that they had a giants world series themed arepa (orange arepa filled with cheese and beans), so I ordered it. it wasn't what I expected. they charged around $8 for the giants arepa which was somewhat pricy given that it is only filled with cheese and beans. 

on my previous visit, I ordered the ceviche. wouldn't order it again..something was missing.

i like chicken arepa and will definitely be back to try the other items on the menu.
author: H C.

description:
I picked up two arepas to go to take with me to D-Park to nibble on.  I ordered the grilled chicken and pulled pork pernil on savory arepas.  

The grilled chicken was the better of the two.  The chicken itself was grilled but very tender/juicy and seasoned well. The black bean spread, queso fresco, and guasacaca sauce were a nice addition creating a nice deep savory experience.  

The pork pernil was rather disappointing. The pork was very tender so I was pretty excited, but it was very bland.  I tried it on its own and got no flavor.  The garlic aioli and/or pica'pun (don't know what that is?) had a nice kick that I liked.  There was perhaps a bit too much aioli for my taste.  The avocado was fresh and creamy which was nice.

I haven't had too many arepas in my life, but I thought the actual arepa itself - corn cakes - were a bit tough and chewy.
