Overall, I like what they're doing and would want to come back to try a cachapa and their yucca fries, because I love me some yucca fries.

Also, one arepa is plenty for one person. I ate one for lunch and the second for dinner.  I reheated the dinner arepa in a pan slowly so it was fully heated through and maintained the crispy outside of the arepas.  I felt satisfied and full after eating each one.
author: Naoko M.

description:
Not bad at all, but I feel like they could really benefit from a more organized menu. The staff there knows what's up and they ask you the questions you need to get the perfect combo on, however, the line gets super long because there is an option for nearly every aspect of the dish. Thanks to smart staff this is made somewhat simpler but the menu is crazy confusing!

Step 1: Identify what meat you want. There are two chicken options but one is more of a chicken salad, which wasn't feeling too healthy to me. 

Step 2: Based on that they can tell you which type of Maize wrapper you'll want to get. I got the Cachapa which is pretty sweet but that's how i roll. There is also more of a flat bread type option which is less deep fried looking.

Step 3: choose a side like empanadas, and first select a salsa. Then they can tell you which meats go best with it since there are several filling options.

See what I am saying? There's an obvious flow to the menu that you don't get from reading it. Thanks for helping me staff members, the menu board was a hot mess! :)

Food wise I felt like everything tasted the same to me and my husband agreed. It had a very "house of same sauce" feel to it, but the good news is that it was tasty! If they had a fresh salsa bar or some kind of sauce to add to things to change it up that would rock, the empandas were really bland without the sauce and I think my main dish would have been better served with some kind of accoutrement. Still it's a nice affordable spot in a great location and definitely adds some variety into the typical burrito fare consumed nearby.

Bonus points for being wheat and gluten free!
author: Nikki M.

description:
This is the best Venezuelan arepa joint on the corner of 15th and Valencia that I have ever been to.

Seriously, though, the food is good and reasonably priced.
author: Cam M.

description:
I have been searching for a good arepa joint here on this side of the country ever since I had my first arepa experience in NYC a few years back. Boy, was I excited when I found out that Pica Pica was opening it's doors here in SF. They were supposed to have opened on 5/10 however there were some issues that delayed their grand opening and so that didn't end up happening for another 5 days. 

Being that it was their grand opening it was a bit surprising there were PLENTY of seats available and virtually NO LINE when we got there. We had been stalking their website so we kind of had it figured out what we were going to order. We were absolutely famished and wanted to try out almost everything off the menu but settled on ordering the following between the two of us:

-Pabellon - Arepa filled with shredded skirt steak, black beans, sweet plantains, cheese
-Perico - Arepa filled with scrambled eggs, onions, diced tomatoes and cheese (this would be perfect as breakfast)
-La Shuli - Arepa filled with black beans, tomatoes, onions, cilantro and a side of their version of guacamole "guasacaca"
-A Maize'wich
-Yucca Fries with garlic aioli dip (a must-order!)
-A bottle of pale ale

It did taste a bit "healthier" (less greasy, less starchy) than the arepas from Caracas in NYC (I miss my freshly blended banana shake with cinnamon sprinkled on top) as Pica Pica boasts their wheat and gluten free menu which makes me feel better as we stuffed our faces here. I think for our next visit, I'll settle down with just one arepa. With a side of the yucca fries, TWO arepas each per person was certainly pushing it.
author: Esther A.

description: A nice place to hop in and stop for a quick bite. Every bite you eat will be packed with a trip to flavor land. If you're walking around Valencia and have the evil hunger flowing through you, just direct yourself here.
author: Gladys M.

description: Was really excited to try Pica Pica, but unfortunately the service was awful.  The food looks delicious and since I was in he neighborhood I decided to stop in for lunch.  I stood at the counter waiting for someone to help me for a good 10 minutes.  The place was half full with diners and all the employees were just talking amongst each other and joking around.  I was being extremely patient waiting to place my order, but all the employees working would not  acknowledge me and continued on with their conversations.  I couldn't believe it and kept looking around wondering what was going on.  I thought I was perhaps in the wrong line....   Needless to say after waiting over 10 minutes in a half empty restaurant with no line and nobody willing to help,  I walked out.  Terrible.  Not coming back.
author: Brian Y.

description: I was in the area and I was hungry but I wasn't looking for an ordinary burrito - I wanted something different.  I was actually thinking about skipping the food altogether and hitting up CREAM but quickly decided against it for my body's sake.  I saw a pizza place but it was kinda crowded but then I stumbled upon this jewel!  OMG I had the Beef arupa with coconut lime juice for a beverage and my life has not been the same since!  The sweet plantains were everything and I just can't wait to go back!  Love it!
author: Crystal C.

description:
If you can't eat gluten, this is a great little spot to grab a sandwich or other maize delicacies. As someone who gets to enjoy wheat and other flour delicacies, this place didn't exactly blow me away, but it was nice to eat out with some of my more diet-restricted friends. 

Biggest pro? gluten free beer. I've never seen my celiac friend so excited!
author: Claire G.

description: 100% gluten free which is perfect since I have Celiac disease and the food is delicious! The empanadas and arepas are my favorite!
author: Sarah N.

description:
Can't pass up a free arepa, right? I found the food here to be totally fine, but pretty disappointing, because a lot of it SOUNDED good, but from a small sampling, I have my doubts that any of it would be exciting. Definitely not as exciting as it could be, anyway.

I had the pernil arepa. It had sizable chunks of avocado and slices of tomato, a mess of pork, and the garlic aioli on the side. The pork was too salty, which the avocado and tomato slightly, but insufficiently, balanced out. Overall the individual tastes were fine but the ingredients didn't particularly come together. This was even more evident in the pabellon - skirt steak, plantains, black beans and cheese makes a really nice plate of food, so you can see how it might make a nice sandwich - well, it doesn't. It's better to disassemble the whole thing and eat it separately although, as noted, the chili pepper on the menu more realistically designates only that it's been cooked with a pepper, as it's not spicy at all.

The yuca fries seemed to be entirely "friedness" with no evident vegetable. I mostly find that disturbing and repellant. Mostly. Overall it's too expensive, bland, and out of my way for me to go back.
author: Lisa K.

description:
I should have known that when you name your restaurant after a jelly fish (pica pica) the chances of enjoying it are much like being stung by a jelly fish...anger, resentment and the urge to pee on your leg to find some relief. 

The good things...they are gluten-free; their vegetables on salads and entrees were good quality and seemed very fresh.

The bad...everything tasted pretty bland. Even a little salt and pepper would have greatly improved the salad. The passion fruit vinegrette tasted like fake juice with no vinegar. My man got the "Special" tuna salad...I've had better in a diner...bland again. The special corn "Arepah" bread was a good concept, but again tasted like it needed salt.

In the land of good and plenty...I'll be going elsewhere next time.
author: Brooke F.

description: My boyfriend and I saw this place on Diners, Drive-ins, and Dives and decided to give it a shot. We were definitely not disappointed! We shared the nachos pica pica and white corn shredded beef arepa. Both were very tasty. We didn't realize the chips in the nachos were taro chips until we got them (our fault for not reading closer) but they were actually really good! The only thing I would have changed would be to have had some sour cream spread inside the arepa because it was a tad bit dry. Just personal preference, though. Otherwise, a great spot!
author: Nikki V.

description: First time trying this place out. Heard about it on DDD (diners, drive-ins& dives) so it's almost a must try if Guy says so. My guy had the arepa which he told me was bomb, definitely filling. I on the other hand had tthe plate with beans, coconut rice, plantains & tofu. DELICIOUS! We also grabbed a side of the yuca fries. We got the original since the cashier told us to try out their different sauces. 3 different sauces they varied in slickness & one looked like ketchup but def fooled me, it had a nice luck to it! I will for sure come back ! Only downside: pricey, but then again labor & freshness.... Idk maybe it evens out.
author: Brenda E.

description:
Well, obviously we have an arepist near Dolores Park!  Hide yo beans, hide yo cheese and hide yo plantains 'cuz they arepa'in errybody out here!  

Pretty awesome concept of offering 10+ filings served on 3 variations of corn-based breads.  This is the type of place where I ate like a cerdo and still feel like I didn't scratch the surface of the menu.  Some choices are much heartier than others so keep that in mind when considering budget or, like me, how to maximize the number of dishes you can try.

Pabellón: This filling rocks since it gives you an arepa sized sampling of the tender slow cooked beef, hearty black beans, sweet plantains and that squeaky white cheese.  The beef was full of slow cooked, stringy goodness!

Pepeada: I usually associate this as the signature Venezuelan arepa since it's at the top of the menu at every arepa joint I go to.  It's usually called "Reina Pepiada" and it's usually a lot better than here!  My least favorite item I tried, I found the avocado too mushy and the chicken too bland.

Clásica: I had to order this because of the same sick curiosity that makes me order Spam from menus.  If was definitely better than that Underwood brand with the tiny red devil mascot.  However, despite the deviling, I still felt it was pretty bland and a little heavy on the mayo.  Probably best to enjoy this between a firm maize'wich since the mushy texture wouldn't go well with a soft cachapa.

Arepa: I wasn't a fan of how they cut the arepa, pretty much in half so it acted like bread around a sandwich.  I prefer the technique of a small incision in the top and stuffing it like a pita.  Semantics aside, the arepas was good.  Grainy texture with nice griddle marks on the outside.  Freshly made for my order.

Maize'wich: These reminded of me those "mozzarepas" from street fairs.  It lies in firmness between the arepa and the cachapa.  The mixture of firm, yet chewy makes it perfect for any of the really pasty filings.

Cachapa: My favorite corn vessel!  Like a delicate corn pancake or corn omelette encasing your filling.  Absolutely love how there are fresh corn kernels mixed amongst the maize flour.

Tostones: Normally I get my fill of tostones at Cuban restaurants, but San Francisco is sorely lacking Cuban joints so I had to get them here.  Perfect!  Not too greasy.  Not too hard.  Not too salty.  Had an enjoyable creamy chipotle sauce to dip them in which added a unique Venezuelan flavor.  Though I do miss those Cuban minced garlic sauces...
author: Adam B.

description: Yum! Great pit stop for a quick bite & brew (especially if you're passing through on your bike). We snacked on a huge plate of veggie nachos made with thick, crispy taro root chips. The 3 squeeze bottles of sauce on the table (which I would guess were: horseradish cream, spicy ketchup, & savory creamy mystery sauce) allowed a bunch of flavor combos. I was like a kid, discovering flavors again.
author: Kristine M.

description: I'm gluten free and I was thrilled to find this place. Super impressed, the food is amazing. I would definitely recommend it.
author: Jayna A.

description:
Came here looking for arepas like we had in Miami. There are definitely good we left satisfied! 

The only thing lacking was all the different sauces that really take arepas to the next level especially the pineapple sauce! 

Ana at the counter was nice as well.
author: Mariam H.

description: They served at least 8 people that came in after me that i counted, maybe more. What the hell?! Screw this overpriced, badly managed place.
author: George M.

description:
Came here the other day and it was awesome! I had the shredded beef pabellon which I highly recommend. I really loved the plátanos in the arepa too, they added a nice kick. 

I would definitely recommend this place to my friends. Although I think this place is more of a pick up and go spot, there are  places for you to sit down. I would definitely want their food again and delivery sounds like my best bet. 

I am giving it four stars because it's not a 5 star restaurant ambiance wise, I would have wanted the arepa to be a tad bit larger (although I'm assuming that these arepas have a standard size), and because I've had the same flavors in my mouth before, just not in an arepa form. 

Overall, this place is awesome and a great introduction to Venezuelan/South America food if you have yet to try any.
author: Carina M.

description: Good for healthy and filling food. Just enough food for one. I tried the vegetariana on an arepa. The plantains and avocado were amazing but the rest of the ingredients lacked much flavor. I also felt $9.50 seemed a bit much for what you get. Good place for a quick lunch but the menu is rather limited. I liked it, but I probably won't be coming back.
author: Kim S.

description: I had the most wonderful food here! I would highly recommend it to anyone. I saw it on diners, drive ins, and dives and the restaurant held up to its reputation!
author: Laura L.

description: We arrived 1 hour before closing and were served cold food, the arepas were not crunchy on the outside as they claim. Almost seemed like they were pre assembled. The girl behind the counter was rude but RUDE and basically made us feel like SHE was doing US (the paying customer) the favor. Not a terrible place, just keep your expectations low
author: Roberta C.

description: The pulled pork arepa was delicious! Great flavours and such a great snack. Was on the small and expensive side. You won't be full off one.
author: Penny C.

description: Went here for a friend's birthday. Ordered the pulled pork. It was really delicious and super tasty for something so gluten free. I loved the corn and how it was put together. The sauce was also really light but was able to put everything together. I would definitely come back to this place if I ever go into the city!
author: Diana T.

description:
TIP #1: This food will fill you up! Try an arepa--I'm almost sure you've never had one before, and it'd hard to find a restaurant that serves them. 

TIP #2: There's happy hour here! Specials on beers and other drinks. Lunch specials too. 

If you're looking for a unique blend of flavors, interesting textures, and all-around delicious and satisfying food, look no further. This is an amazing place to try--even if it's only to take a break from the regular burritos-and-tacos fare of cheap dining in the Mission. 

I came here to reward myself after getting a tattoo (as if the tattoo wasn't already a present to myself!). I had also been itching to try an arepa ever since I missed the SF Street Food Festival last August, where the legendary/mythological Arepa Lady from NYC made an appearance. 

Basically, I had extremely high expectations. And Pica Pica Maize Kitchen delivered! My arepa with shredded beef, sweet plantains, black beans, and queso fresco came hot and steamy, just how I like it. Every bite was one to savor--every bite was a burst of flavor and it never got old. Their signature hot sauce was the perfect accompaniment, adding more complexity with just the right amount of heat and another layer of flavor. My boyfriend's arepa, chicken with their signature guiso base (a sweet meat and vegetable stew/sauce) and gouda cheese was a combination of sweet and salty that I had never tasted before. Both the beef and the chicken were extremely tender. Each arepa comes with a side salad. 

We also ordered empanadas, which were okay, but I would stick to the arepas. I hope you leave as satisfied and happy as I did!
author: A.L. H.

description: Phenomenal. The beef pabellon was ridiculous, the raw lemonade was one of the best things I've ever tasted and it absolutely loved up to its rep
author: Anthony D.

description: This is a great place for vegetarians! Their arepas are so flavorful, and the yucca fries with whatever sauces they have on the table are delicious. And the coconut-lime aqua fresca was amazing. I don't think I've ever said that a juice was amazing before, but this one was. Pica Pica is on the pricey side for a quick lunch or dinner, but I think it's worth it.
author: Kristy S.

description: It didn't meet my expectations of a Venezuelan arepa. Too juicy to eat like a normal arepa.
author: Cindy G.

description:
This is a great gluten free place, as everything is made from corn (unless you have a corn gluten allergy) 

We had the empanadas, the maizwich and some of my friends had the corn pancake. I'm a vegetarian, so it's always nice to find a place that does good vegetarian with a  GF option. My friends who ate meat also really enjoyed the place. My husband and friends liked their beer selection, but that obviously wasn't an option for me. However, they had other drink options that I could have tried, but as the driver, didn't. 

All in all a good experience and will definitely go here again.
author: Kacy P.

description: Some how ended up at this local restaurant while visiting San Fran from LA.  I haven't stopped thinking about it since.  I had a vegan arerapas.  So so so good.
author: Vicki V.

description:
I always remember the wonderful Arepas I had while living in Venezuela.  I was in Berkeley one morning looking for a place to have breakfast, a gluten free breakfast. I wasn't in the mood to tell everyone about Gluten Free, Celiac, cross contamination, etc.. and a quick search on my iPhone gave me answer. Drive to San Francisco: PICA PICA MAIZE KITCHEN... Wait, what? AREPAS? like the ones I had in Venezuela... not quite.

Looking for parking in the Mission in San Francisco can be as difficult as getting a quality service at Chile Lindo (a few blocks from Pica Pica), in other words, park and walk or simply take Bart. 

The place is small, simple and clean.( be aware of the waiting time doing a line to order and to get a table) The staff is friendly but want you to know what you want to order by the time you get to the counter. The menu is front of you, so take a moment and decide...   Want a recommendation? Try the Veggy Arepa, griddle seared Tofu strips, cheese ,fried plantain and avocado topped with a thick sour cream and chipotle sause to die for!.

This place was able to master the art of arepas, a popular street food in Venezuela, giving them a new fresh spin more on the gourmet side, these are definitely not your mamma's  arepas, these are bold fun and modern (not cheap but superb!)

One arepa will be enough to satisfy you, they are big and by the time you pay and finish eating you'll be content with the price/quantity ratio!
author: Mr. T.

description:
I went one day, OMG, BOMB!
I went the next day- what happened???
I went again today- it was so so!
I dont know if it's the cooks, the day, the food or what. 
It is different every time.
I also went another day before today, and they were out of what I wanted so I walked out.
Will I go back, probably. Will I be worried? Probably.

*the slaw was a bit dry, there was a gigantic piece of fat in my pork maize Arepa,
the beans were a bit off, and the portion of meat changes on the platter. One day its a nice size, another day it's really small!
This place is so good, I cant not go back, but I just never know what Im going to get!
.....APPREHENSIVE!
author: Domina V.

description:
Oh Pica Pica... You are fried happiness!  I spent $20 here for lunch because I wanted to try a few things.  I had enough food for 2.5 meals. 

-Empanadas: YUMMY! More of a lightly fried/crispy exterior than a flaky crust. For fillings, I liked them in this order (1) Morena (2) Tilapia (3) Guiso
-Cachapas with Pabellon: Cachapa is a sweeter corn pancake. I liked it but maybe too sweet for a savory type filling. Pabellon is tasty. Next time I will try the Maize'wich.
-Yuca Fries: Lightly fried, good sized wedge cuts. 
-Dipping sauces! YES! I had the salsa/ketchup and an aioli. Both are delicious for dipping anything!

Empanadas were my favorite. The empanadas are smaller but with 3 pieces, it can be filling. I want to try other sandwich combos. These sandwiches are a pretty hearty size. 

Pica Pica is on the corner of Valencia and 15th. It's small inside but feels airy with a high ceiling. There are a row of tables and then a side bar with stools.
author: Veronica H.

description: I've been to this one and the now closed Castro location.  The food is really delish, arepa soft, tasty and fillings yummy.  All the people working at both locations were super nice and helpful.  I would have given them four stars, but still annoyed that they had not yet listed the Castro location as closed on their website before I took my mom there.  We only realized it was closed as we were about to open the door.  Then I had to scramble to think of another restaurant open at 3pm in between two movies, in enough time as not to be late for the next movie.  With technology what it is today, they should have listed the closing much earlier than they did; as not to inconvenience people.
author: Delicious B.

description: It was my first time to try this type of meal ...Honestly I didn't like the food very much, I don't know maybe because of my taste... But there is something like thick french fries in their appetizer menu that was great ... and also plz try the dressing on the table
author: Reza T.

description: Being gluten free, I've walked by this place a few times and have wanted to go try it out.  I finally went to dinner here one night with my wife and we were not disappointed.  I really love that everything on their menu is gluten free, even the empenadas.  I can't tell you when was the last time I had empenadas because they're usually made with regular flour.  The ones here are made with corn.  We had a sampler with three different types and they were quite good.  We had a Pabellon and Palu Arepas and both were very good.  We also had the Yuca Fries which were a nice treat.  The only remotely negative thing I can say is the food isn't exactly cheap given that nothing is very big, but that's being kind of nit picky given how unique and good their food is here.  I'll have to go back and try a Maizewich some time.
author: Scott L.

description:
I've been coming here so much more now that my BF is on a temporary gluten free, dairy free, and soy free diet. 

The entire restaurant is gluten free which is awesome for a restrictive diet.  Their food is consistent and pretty yummy. I like the pabellon with black beans, beef and plantains.
author: Skye W.

description:
mango juice FTW! omg soo good!!

i had their spicy chicken arepa and great flavors. but i realized i'm not too crazy about the actual pocket. the texture was too......cornmeal-y. lol sorry, i can't think of a better term. this is just my own preference, so don't take it for literal haha

i just had to try it, and now i did it's off my life haha
author: Diana P.

description: I opted for the sweet corn arepas over the traditional white corn, hoping it would be a blend of my two favorites: Cachapas and arepas. Unfortunately the sweet corn piece of it just defeated the purpose of an arepa: it really lost its crisp and the "holdability" feel of it. Probably my fault for not getting the traditional, but I was disappointed. Still worthy of three stars as it has a cool vibe, awesome service, and serves a largely unfilled niche for Venezuelan in the Bay Area. I'll go back to try the standard white corn arepa.
author: Neal C.

description:
i cant believe i've lived all my life without having an arepa. these are heavenly and i crave them at least once a week!!!

go for the sweet corn arepa. it's seriously the most delicious thing i've had on valencia street while living in the mission.
author: C. L.

description: I'm allergic to gluten and dairy products so finding good spots that cater to me are hard to find. I LOVED this place. My husband and I went to San Francisco for the weekend and this was by far our favorite place we ate. It isn't fancy and you don't go there for the ambiance but the food is amazing. We had the grilled chicken arepe, the pulled pork plata and the yucca fries... Also the side of plantain and taro chips. We loved the yucca garlic fries but there weren't that many so next time we'll get the whole basket of fries or just stick with the taro and plantain chips. We went back a second time this trip and wish we had one in OC!
author: Emily G.

description: Don't sleep on this place!  You might miss it hidden on the corner with small signage.  I love this place.  Only problem is when I leave here I am headed back to work and I am full and satisfied and pissed that a nap is not possible.  I planned to try something different each visit, but why? The chicken arepa with the sweet corn is all I need.
author: sumaya g.

description: The shredded beef arepa is great! The arepa itself was a bit too dry but the stuffing was delicious so I let that slide...however, my meal was ruined by the disgusting yuca beignets with dulce de leche...bleh! The yuca balls were like baked potato balls rather than fluffy doughnuts. And the dulce de leche...who the heck makes that crap? Tasted like old coconut cream and not silky caramel. I can understand if you were trying to be unique with the beignets but please don't try to pass off nasty things as tasty treats just for the sake of it.
author: Karina V.

description:
Fantastic , even if not gluten free.  

Everything is gluten free except the beer on tap.  They have GF beer as well

Had the pulled pork sandwich on sweet yellow corn "bun".  Superb.  Absolutely will go back.


Best gluten free restaurant I have ever been to.  So good , went back the same night for seconds.

Update:  went back had grilled chicken on white corn...pretty bland. Which , granted, is that I wanted. Go big. Yellow corn And well spiced meat. Otherwise you're not doing the taste justice.
author: Jacob S.

description: Not great, they were unknowledgeable and inaccurate about products ingredients,  unorganized with delivery of food items, food not impressive upon arrival. Not horrible,  but not really good either.
author: Jessica R.

description: Often GF options are bland and simple at restaurants, but Pica Pica has a wide variety of tasty and different options. Their corn pockets had a good texture, and were tasty and different to anything I've ever tried. Only recommendation is that if you don't like spicy food beware. I've tried 3 different dishes here, and I've found them all to be a little more on the spicy side.
author: M M.

description: The most amazing arepas I ever had. Great sauces. Great atmosphere. Try it. Really good $$
author: Toby V.

description:
This is the second time I have eaten here. THis time I had the Pulled Pork Pernil
with sliced tomatoes, avocado, pica'pun, garlic aioli in a yellow corn pocket. It came with a side of slaw. it was very good except it had some kind of mustard on it that had such a distinctive flavor that it took away from the overall flavor.
My 11 year old had the Nachos PICA PICA
(pulled pork, taro chips, black beans, cheese, tomato, Guasacaca sauce) which was large and very tasty.
We also had a side of yucca fries that were good as well.
The menu is gluten-free.
author: Tracy M.

description:
This place is pretty fantastic.  I've been about three or four times now, and the food's been consistently delicious.  

The first few times I went, the maizewich and the cachapa were mysteriously not being sold.  I had to "settle" for an arepa, which wasn't so difficult.    

What really surprised me were the yucca fries.  I'm not one to get a hard-on for yucca, but these are amazing; golden crispy on the outside, and so fluffy on the inside.  The sauces they offer are all great, but I always go with the spicy ketchup and the spicy cream.

Anyway, check this place out.  The people are friendly, the food is delicious, and it's not terribly difficult to get to.
author: joe p.

description: Delicious!  And the entire restaurant is gluten-free so my boyfriend didn't have to worry about his order.  The black bean and plantain empanadas were delicious!
author: Laura L.

description: The food is good, but the service leaves much to be desired. And don't even bother trying to order to-go via the phone. I can't tell you how many times we have been placed on perma-hold (this last time I waited 10 minutes). I should have wised up and hung up sooner. We'll quit wasting our time and take our business elsewhere.
author: Annie G.

description:
Preceding Pica Pica Maize Kitchen is its reputation, which is as substantial as Guy Friere's appetite. Unfortunately, value and portion size don't quite match its outsized reputation; too much for the light eater in our small party and too little for those of us with a healthy appetite. Nevertheless, Pica Pica certainly deserves a visit at least once for the arepas, which are their unique grilled flatbread sandwiches stuffed with slow-cooked meats, and for vegetarians, tofu. Particularly notable is the perfectly complementary textures of the arepas- crispy and flavorfully char-grilled on the outside and soft, starchy and salty cornmeal cooked just right inside. The fresh oregano, garlic aioli, and copious helpings of artfully sliced avocado make them nearly worth $8.95, although the curtido is shamefully plain as a side dish. One suggestion to the cooks would be to let the curtido marinate longer, as well as add more fresh herbs and vinegar to kick up the flavor a notch. The drinks were expensive but fresh, with a taste reminiscent of fruity melted popsicles (the Sangria was tasty but don't order it if you want to feel happier - I had to ask if it had alcohol, there was so little in it). For dessert, be sure to try the flan which is bathed in thick and buttery caramel, although there being no spoons anywhere in the vicinity meant no one could take pleasure in the confectionary soup so delicious one might skinny dip into a pool of its fatty-lusciousness. 

     The atmosphere was quite nice, as the the mission street atmosphere overflowed in through the widely partitioned window, giving us the feeling of being both inside and outside, while allowing us to share in the scent of pizza from a restaurant next door. The music was too clubby for our tastes and certainly too much old-school Nelly Furtado for one sitting. Less pop music and more cultural musical treasures from Latina America, please.

     All in all, I would give it three and a half starts until they start giving the  sides more attention and culinary thought, and either drop the price of the drinks or up the alcohol content. The atmosphere neither hurt nor helped although the customer service was just fine, no complaints as the food was brought in a timely and friendly manner. Will we be going back? Maybe, but only after trying our hand at some home-cooked arepas first.
author: Peter F.

description: Pica Pica CHU! Can't help but think of that little fur ball. But really though, these arepas are electrifying! They zing your tastebuds with a delicious array of flavors; definitely worth a visit.
author: Mark S.

description:
For god's sake, eat a maize-wich!  

My wife is gluten free, so I'm left to wander the earth eating godawful interpretations of bread and lying to my wife insisting "no no, this TOTALLY tastes like normal bread."   Pica Pica is the savior of the gluten-free proletariat.  The yucca fries are spectacular and they serve carafes of sangria.  

Okay, see you out there.
author: Kaare W.

description: So first off my fiance ate everything but on a real note love the atmosphere the colors and music are very welcoming the location is pretty convenient but parking isn't the best there isn't any way around that they have booth eating and barstool seating is well but not recommended for large groups I loved the size of the menu there's a lot of things to choose from and from what he described everything is really fresh we ordered three things they only serve one type of soup so we have the soup the shredded beef Arepa and a chicken salad no complaints about the salad large portions of avocado which is great everything in the salad was really fresh. The arepa is what the restaurant is known for they served with bananas inside of it which I really don't understand but I guess it's a cultural thing but they didn't taste bad I just don't understand why they were in there the soup was really confusing it seemed more like a Mexican stew rather than a soup because the chicken was kind of shredded almost and there was like a sliver of a corn on the cob in there which didn't make sense to me either it have great taste but it almost seemed like once they put the stock in they added a lot of salt it would have been a great soup without the added salt it was overall a decent experience but not amazing but definitely worth at least one try I guess.
author: Elisha W.

description: I ordered take-out. The food was ready within 15 mins. It is good but it's not the food I am used not ~ do not quiet like the taste.
author: Tracy D.

description:
Shame on me for sleeping on this restaurant! I've been meaning to try it for over two years and just... never did? I don't know how these things happen. I think it has something to do with the fact that I obsess over certain things and then get tunnel vision. And now I've set my sights on Pica Pica. 

Grabbed a bite for lunch and I am in love. I ate the maze-wich (sweet corn bread) with pepeada (chicken salad with creamed avocado) and plantains. My friend and I also split the jardinara salad. I gobbled down everything and when my BF gets home from work I'm gonna see if I can sway him to go back for dinner so I can order the exact same thing. See? Tunnel vision.
author: Rebecca P.

description:
I'm fairly sure everything else that could be said about this slick and stylish place has been said.. but just in case...
YUCCA FRIES. 
OMFG.
yess!
garlicky! crispy! delicious! A MUST HAVE.
Great with some beer! :D
author: Christopher L.

description: Delicious food, easy to get takeout. The fried plantains are my favorite, I grew up eating plantains ripened to perfection and then fried sweet and crispy and these do not disappoint!
author: Ayo R.

description:
As a disclaimer my first arepa experience was with Mr. Pollo and I immediately fell in love with this dish. So as we drove around looking for parking, I was really looking forward to this restaurant that specialized in this grilled corn goodness. We ordered the grilled chicken and pulled pork arepa, yuca fries, and the shrimp ceviche. Bummer. We paid about $35 for everything and did not eat even half of our meal's worth. The corn pockets could best be described as soggy, mushed corn patties. Not as crispy as I last remembered or as advertised. It just seemed overwhelmingly greasy that it made the tummy angry. The other half had a sudden onset of N/V, D (nausea/vomiting, diarrhea). The sweetness to all the dishes was a bit extra. The delicious balance between savory and sweetness was nonexistent. The shrimp ceviche tasted similar to Costco's version. I enjoyed the taro chips. Yuca fries were so-so. 

It's an order at the counter, then find your table type of joint with random rushes of high foot traffic. Service was average. Sorry Pica Pica. Not a fan, but to each their own.
author: Denise N.

description:
I ate lunch here on recommendation from a local foodie and was happily fed.

PROS:
1. Good food. I had a small cup of shrimp soup and the salad (with bell peppers, jicama, pineapple, passion fruit dressing, etc.). The cup of soup was, indeed small, so don't expect a ton for $3. But, with the salad, it was really filling. 

2. Charming cashier, fluent in both English and Spanish (and maybe more).

CONS:
1. Crowded. It is apparently a popular place, so seating may be a challenge.

2. Not the fastest service.
author: Victoria C.

description:
My friend has celiacs and requested we eat at a totally gluten-free kitchen. I was a little hesitant about going somewhere gluten-free since the central parts of my diet consist of lots and lots of gluten. But my friend was in town, trekking in from Chicago, the least I could do was give it a chance. I felt more comfortable reading the good Yelp reviews it had, as Yelpers in SF rarely lead me astray.

It was an all-out grub-fest. I guess my friend rarely ever comes into a gluten-free kitchen, so we decided to share and go all out.. We ordered the Pabellon Arepa which is steak, plaintains, beans and cheese and Pernil Cachapas which was a sweet corn tortilla with a pulled pork filling with an aioli on the side. I like the Cachapa outside, but definitely preferred the Pabellon filling. And out of all their sauces, their spicy cream was my favorite.

Next came the empenadas, there was a chorizo corn special on the filling, so we ordered that, a queso fresco and a queso and black beans. My favorite out of those was the queso fresco, deep fried cheese and you can't go wrong. The empanadas were light, not a thick crust so it definitely fill me up to the point of being uncomfortabe.

We ordered some yuca fries and fried green plaintains, both were good if you eat them right away, but definitely not things you can let sit otherwise they become a weird texture.

I have to say, I really did enjoy my meal. There were times I felt it could be saltier, but I was very satisfied with what I ate and celiacs or no celiacs, I highly recommend Pica Pica.
author: Analisa S.

description: I was spoiled by having a fluffy chachapa in Florida that was amazing & still the best I've ever ate. At the Pica Pica Arepa Kitchen, the arepa was decent. The chachapa was a bit over cooked and pancake thin. The hot sauce in the tall bottle was the great. The fresh fruit drinks were ok. We ended up mixing 2 of the drinks to take away the bitterness and then it became a great drink.
author: Michelle T.

description: You havn't tried arepas before?! Well come on down! The arepas will have you salivating at first site! Do not be afraid to try some of the sauces!
author: Jónatan P.

description:
mmmmm check out the Garlic fries, the pepeada maize'wich which is a chicken salad smashed between a sliced arepa and creamy guac. grab a bunch of salsas and you're a happy camper! 

If you have dietary restrictions this place is wheat and gluten free. Well priced food with an authentic flair done quickly and right!
author: Jade W.

description:
I love, love, love Pica Pica's food, being gluten-intolerant and a lover of all Latin American cuisine. It was my first time trying Venezuelan food and I'm definitely hooked! Some friends and I tried this place on a whim after wandering around Valencia and looking for a place to have lunch. We had settled on another restaurant and while we were walking over, I brought up wanting to try Pica Pica. My sister made up a word for me and my habit of bringing up other places when we've already decided on a place to eat, so when I brought up Pica Pica she accused me of 'clamberponding' but when we reached our chosen destination, we found out they were closed.

So we went to Pica Pica instead and for once, she was glad I had suggested it earlier. My clamberponding proved fruitful this time. When we got there there was no line and our food was brought out quickly. It's a walk-in restaurant and you pay first. The menu had so many wonderful options. We each got the chicken arepas and they were delicious. There's not much to say that the other reviewers haven't already said. Portions are generous and everything tasted fresh. Their sauces are wonderful. The only complaint I have is about their Castro location.... Don't order delivery from them. I ordered delivery from the Castro joint after the wonderful experience on Valencia but our arepas were practically empty (we got veggie) they could have definitely given us more beans. And the portion was so small it was pathetic! I had to scour my fridge for something else to eat. They also gave us no sauces.
author: L. L.

description:
Only five choices on the menu, which has the most confusing design possible.  I ordered an item and was told that they were out of it.  I order a second item and was told that they don't offer it anymore (devilled ham).  I ordered a third item and was told that the gouda cheese had been replaced by cheddar cheese (which is much cheaper).  This was hella annoying.  Fix your freakin' menu already.

Once I got the food, it was OK but nothing great.  The woman behind the counter was very pleasant.
author: Bay G.

description:
Tasty. Cute place. Sweet corn. Yum!

I'll definitely go back. We tried a number of things and all were tasty.
author: brandi g.

description:
Not the best arepas I've ever had but not bad either. My husband and I got some take out from here on election night. The arepas look expensive for what you get but they're actually really filling so that worked out OK. 

We got  the salad verde (nothing special), a beef arepa (pretty good though too much creamy mayo like stuff for me), and a cachapa. My husband didn't care for the cachapa because it was pretty sweet but I thought it was good.

All in all I wouldn't be itching to go back here but if we were in the area, I'd be open to trying some of the arepas with other fillings.
author: Sydney L.

description: This place was super delicious but when it was bussing my dish, several other dirty dishes that were stacked too high fell out of the tub above the trash and hit me on the head. The staff did nothing. This is a dangerous set-up. I hope it's rearranged in the future so dishes can't fall on customers.
author: Hillary M.

description:
This place is a very hip and not for anyone looking for a lot of food. It's basically like snack food. You order, get a number and food is brought to you. Nothing crazy.

The food is good and the most memorable thing I had there was the sangria. I've been here a couple of times and while there isn't anything I can really complain about, I'm not big on maize being the focus of the meal, granted this is a maize kitchen. 

I like it but I feel like they don't add enough to it to make it other than a mouthful of corn.For me, it's more of a place to go and have once in a while when I want a quick bite. The menu is very limited.

Plus, the food there is mostly corny, fried, or accompanied by thick sauces. The yuca fries and empanadas are yummy but when I leave there I don't feel satisfied or that I ate anything truly healthy.

I would not be opposed to going back, but I wouldn't make it one of my first choices.
author: Kathryn B.

description: This place was featured on DDD with Guy Fieri. Since the arepas looked delicious on TV, we wanted to check this place out. Unfortunately, we were disappointed. I wanted to try the spicy chicken, but it was unavailable. I ended up with the regular chicken arepa and my husband ordered the pulled pork. Both weren't bad, they just weren't great. We've had better and more authentic arepas.
author: Erna F.

description: Ate here about 11:30 a.m. for the first time today and enjoyed the spicy chicken arepa.  Very good. The cole slaw was good, but a little too vinegary for me (came in a small plastic cup, not on the plate as shown on two of the pictures below).  The staff were very pleasant and patient as we looked over the menu.  My mark-down on the score is because we felt the price is a little high for what you get.  That said, we will possibly return when we are in San Francisco again.
author: Beachwalker B.

description: The food wasn't all the great. Everything looked the same. Ok....spicy sauce was good I guess, I put it on everything.
author: Tiff W.

description: Good food.  Casual place.  Get the pork arepa on corn.  Tasty.  I could eat is all day long.  Too bad this place gets crowded.  there was a little wait for a table.   Tight seating,  not much seating or decor.   But I come here for the food.
author: Richard G.

description: So the fiance has been talking about this place for years and I think I was being stubborn because "gluten free" always sounds like "taste free" to me. Wrong. Amazing and delicious. Two arepas are pretty filling with a side of yucca chips. And I'm going to hope it's not bad for you...
author: Emilia S.

description:
Great tasting fresh flavors but seating is limited.

# 6 - Catiria - Chicken & Cheese. $9.00
# 2 - Pelu'a - Steak & Cheese. $8.00
Empanadas - $4.00
Beer - $5.00
Coke - $1.75


Total - $30.35



The dishes here are sweet, filling and worth the wait and the prices are fair considering the high quality. I will be back but only once the buzz wears off and I can get a table in a short amount of time.

Come here, it's great!
author: Justin S.

description: Not bad food but NOT what I would ever want someone to associate as typical Venezuelan food. The arepas didn't have enough salt and were limp, the plantains were great - sweet and cooked to a burnt crisp (I'm not joking - that is a great thing). Empanadas were ok but not what is typical. Would I eat here again? Yes but I wouldn't go out of my way - I hit up places that say Venezuelan food because I want a meal that reminds of meals with my family.
author: Linda H.

description: Not impressed. This will never catch on. The taste is not truly representative of Venezuela street food.
author: Harry V.

description:
I WANTED TO LOVE IT HERE!!!!!!!!! 


It was freezing inside, and the door was OPEN?! 
The food was : ROOM TEMPERATURE, TEPID GREASE BOMB. 
All the sauces came in these TEENSY servings, and extra was extra........Nothing was spicy enough, and there was mayonnaise ........

The staff was: so cavalier, and did not remotely care if anyone liked it or not. 


The yucca fries, however, were another story entirely. 
I may never eat regular french fries ever again. 

SO.
GOOD.

Will get fries to go often. 
Eat in? 
Never again.
author: A. H.

description: Pretty pricey for one small arepa but satisfying snack
author: Carleen C.

description: I had stopped by Pica Pica to kill some time while waiting for a friend to dine at another restaurant. The place looked inviting and staff greeted me well. I had noticed some cups of filled juices in front at the counter, its was of mango, orange and coconut lime fresca. One of the staff recommended i try the mango or the coconut drink. When I did, to my surprise it was really good. If I am in the neighborhood I will definitely try it again.
author: noel s.

description: Yay!  Found another amazing place with gluten free options.  The arepas are wonderful... never had one before but I discovered they go well with anything.  A great place to grab a bite.
author: David B.

description: Over the many times I've been there, I have never had a bad meal! May not be cheapest around but the fact that most dishes are gluten free - def a bonus!
author: AJ R.

description:
Id give this place 3 stars if it werent so expensive! $8.50 for an arepa in the mission? Caracas in NYC has really high quality arepas for $5.

The arepa was also nothing to sing about. The flavor very bland, somewhat soggy. Pass.
author: Ash S.

description:
This was my first experience having Latin American food and it was pretty darn great. I had the pernil arepa, which is basically grilled flour corn bread stuffed with pulled pork, tomato, and avocado. While the meal itself was pretty simple, the ingredients were just on-point and the arepa overall was delicious. It's also a perfect portion for a meal since I was left feeling contentedly full but not stuffed afterwards.

Stop by this place if you want to experience a quick, affordable, and fresh taste of Latin American cuisine.
author: Jasmine A.

description: I highly recommend the beef asado area. The taste is authentic Venezuelan black beef stew. You will love it!
author: Janis C.

description: OK yes - the food is good but... but there are a few buts. BUT it seems super expensive for what it is and doesn't come with sides or anything. BUT you have to awkwardly stand next to people hoping to crowd them out so you can have a seat. BUT there are better places around this area for similar food so going here seems moot-ish.
author: Rashmi J.

description: Delicious fast gluten-free option when wandering the mission. Can easily be made dairy-free by just having them omit any dairy based sauces,  which gets you pretty close to paleo/primal (depending on how you look at corn).
author: Sam B.

description:
I usually either love or hate a place but for the first time I have mixed feelings about this place.

The arepa was good but the empanadas and the yucca were drenched in oil. 

My friend found a hair in her arepa. 

Now a whole segment just for the cachapa: The cachapa was horrible. Plasticky, rubbery, tasteless in other words I think the person that makes the cachapas has never stepped foot in Venezuela. Not a place I would come again!
author: Viken B.

description: Delicious, colorful foods in the most colorful part of the city - The Mission!  I had the best sangria to accompany the yucca fries, plantains, and angus beef.  I love the huge open window that slides open on a hot day.  It may take awhile before the food is served, only because it's made fresh & hot.  I'd like to stop here for brunch sometime, great experience!
author: Christine R.

description: I really enjoy the food here. I would give it 5 stars if the staff was a little nicer to the customers. Sometimes the person taking your order won't even make eye contact with you. Still, the food is pretty tasty. Who knows, maybe you hate eye contact and would love to have your order taken here. Parking can be annoying though. Give it a try.
author: Chris C.

description: Their Tofu Arepas and Fried Plantains are Vegan and the $hit! I'd recommend getting there early on a weekend evening before they run out of plantains.
author: Scott C.

description: The arepas vegetarianas were fabulous. So soft and fluffy and enough for two meals. I will return next time I'm in SF!
author: Erin S.

description: Very tasty arepas with good sauce.  I tried the vegetarian; the sweet corn option with the plaintains is a bit too sweet for me but the avocado was generous and the corn crepe had good texture, holding together well.  Next time I'll try the regular corn.  The food is reasonably priced for the neighborhood.  I will return!
author: Disa L.

description: Wow what a great treat. Flavor explosion. All gluten-free with a bread that's soft and delicious. Ordered enough for two meals, intended to reheat some back at the hotel the next day, nope, ate it all.
author: Brett S.

description:
Stopped by their tent at Off the Grid Fort Mason on Friday and ordered a side of the yucca fries and some of the coconut cookies.

The fries were great, it was generous portion for a side and they were nice and hot served with a side of ketchup. (Only bummer is that I wish they had come with more ketchup.)

The cookies were not my favorite, they didn't taste bad, but they had a weird texture. I would not order these again.

PIca Pica's menu looks really good, I can't wait to go back and try some more of their items.
author: Stephanie T.

description: This was the longest line at the Maker Faire this year but I had wanted to try it for awhile so we all got different arepas. Gluten free seems to be the new craze. The pulled pork arepa was quite tasty. We were amazed that the filling didn't fall out of the sandwich. Mine was filled to the brim so it took me awhile to finish it. I sampled a bite of my friend's chicken salad one which was good too. I'll definitely have to go to the actual restaurant next time now that I know what it's about. The prices at the Maker Faire were a bit high but it's what you'd expect right? I was happy to finally try it.
author: Amy J.

description: Finally got to try this spot for a late lunch and it lived up to the hype! Got the shredded beef arepa which had some plantains in it. Very good! Husband had the pulled pork arepa. We also shared the Pica Pica Nachos which were a HUGE serving of taro chips with a delicious avocado like sauce, black beans, cheese, and pulled pork. It was a LOT of food but we were hungry and we left HAPPY. It's a small place so the tables get full but you can order to-go if you want so be prepared.  And might I mention, that I LOVE that everything here is GLUTEN-FREE!  Next time I want some carbo comfort food, I'll be back :)
author: Rosie S.

description:
I have to make my trek back over there for their yucca garlic fries.

Ordered:
- Garlic yucca fries - I love them. 
- Maize'wich - This was good too.
- Sangria - I didn't like their sangria though, it was so sweet, I only drank 1/2 of the glass. Even then I was sipping water in between.
author: Anisha G.

description: Amazing amazing!!!! Get the sweat corn pancake with the #3!! Sooo worth the drive across the bay!
author: Kylie O.

description: This place is a great find! We specifically went here when we went into the city and are glad we did. We both got an arepa and split nachos. We were stuffed, but knowing everything was healthier than your average restaurant was great. And for being on the healthier side, EVERYTHING was delicious including all the sauces set on the table. We will be coming back!
author: Sydney O.

description: Yay for a safe gluten free kitchen...even have gluten free beer! Thank you for a safe restaurant with great food! Seating can get crowded, I like going when it's not busy
author: Anonymous A.

description: I really wanted to like this place! My husband and I found out about Pica Pica Arepa Kitchen from an episode of DDD, and given we were home for the holidays, we wanted to check it out for ourselves. I ordered the Shredded Beef Pabellón because it looked super scrum shish on TV. But sadly, I was a bit disappointed. The beans had no taste, the shredded beef fell short on flavor/spice, and I was expecting more of a sweeter taste from the plantain. :( To me, everything was just bland and saturated in oil. I had to constantly overuse their sauces to compensate the flavor my areap was lacking. (The sauces were pretty darn good). My husband had the Spicy Chicken Catira- in which fell short to his expectations as well - lack of flavor/greasy. I expected a lot more from this place granted all the amazing reviews it received. I don't have much to compare to since I don't have much experience with Venezuelan food - particularly arepas. Overall, the service was great. The ladies at the counter were polite and cheerful, but MY food was mediocre. Would I return? Probably not.
author: Vanessa G.

description: Forget the hype. We tried this place after hearing rave reviews on Yelp and on TV and were sorely disappointed. Soggy, flavorless, chewy arepas and a sack of corn maize with a single piece of meat inside being masqueraded as an empanada. Severely over priced for the quality.
author: Nico A.

description:
One more totally gluten free restaurant in San Francisco! This is awesome. People sensitive to gluten don't have many choices if it comes to eating out. If a restaurant is totally gluten free one does not have to worry about cross contamination. This is a big PLUS!

Other than that I didn't have Venezuelan food before so I can not compare but I also won't complain. 
I had the Cachapas La Vegeteriana which is a corn pancake filled with grilled tofu, avocado and plantain. I didn't like the tofu to much in this particular combination but the rest was good. I would rate this with 3 stars. Next time I'm gonna try the other vegetarian version they offer. 

I also tried the yuca fries which were okay. I'm not a big fan though. I would rate them with 3 stars also.

Empanadas- corn flour pockets- which I tried with a tilapia filling and a queso fresco filling I would rate with 4 stars.

Staff is very friendly and helpful in explaining their food. They deserve 5 stars.

Other than that the place is cozy and very busy. It's a small place but I like the atmosphere. Will be back and looking forward to trying out some more dishes :-)
author: Daniela Y.

description:
Having lots of experience eating Venezuelan food left me absolutely disappointed with this place.  First thing I noticed when I asked for my fried yucca was that the "guasacaca", a traditional staple of sauces used in Venezuelan food was indeed guacamole and they had this awful mix of BBQ with ketchup.  

The arepa "masa" or dough used tasted very poor and had no flavor. 

Perhaps this place might be good for people who have absolutely no experience with Venezuelan-Colombian cuisine.  But if you know what a arepa is supposed to taste like don't come here.  Best of luck either way guys.
author: Carlos S.

description:
A little pricey but then again, it's not like there are areperas on every corner.

They take some liberty with some of the dishes, but maybe that makes them more palatable to more folks?

The passion fruit juice which is served out of a slush puppy like machine (but all natural) is quite tasty. I highly recommend it.

The arepas are pretty good, although I wish they gave you more Guasacaca and / or the other sauce when you ask for it.

The yuca is fine.

They present the guasacaca as more of an aguacate dish.. (avocado) and as such, I could see how they have to charge per serving... traditionally you will see a bottle of guasacaca on every table, which you use at will.. and pay for aguacate, which you add when you order your arepa.

I would give it 4 stars but the owner was not friendly to me. He was too busy hanging out with his 'compay'.  Believe me, I tried to make contact.

The staff themselves were very nice and attentive, but this is the first Venezuelan restaurant that I have been to where the owner was too 'I'm the owner" or "too cool" to talk to, or even briefly say hello, to a fellow Venezuelan.  Carajo!

No worries though, there are enough hipsters there to keep him in business.  I just missed the 'cariño' that you normally get from one of these establishments.

I know they have an original establishment in Napa Valley and I was hoping for them to make their way down here, which they did.  I do wish the owners, father, daughter and husband a long stay and hope they prosper.  

Maybe next time I go I will get that missing condiment, =).
author: Gustave P.

description:
After my boyfriend found this place by accident and had been raving about it, we finally had the chance to try PicaPica.  I ordered a maize'wich #7 (pulled pork, tomatoes, avocado).  All I could keep saying as I ate it was "Omigod.  Oh my GOD."

The sweetness of the corn, the savory salty flavor of the pulled pork, the heat of maize and meat balanced with cool, smooth avocado and juicy tomato...I had to stop myself from licking the paper that my maize'wich came wrapped in.  The yuca fries were nice and garlic-y, but probably too starchy for me to handle.  Didn't matter though; one of the most satisfying lunches ever.

We were there at lunchtime on a Saturday, but I imagine this place gets crowded for dinner.  Parking is a pain to find, but the neighborhood is so full of hipsters and interesting things and it's not all that bad to park a few blocks down and window-shop or people watch as you walk to a damn good meal.
author: Addi M.

description:
I came to Pica Pica a couple months ago, so I don't remember exactly what I had (whoops!), but I do remember that it was quite delicious. I got an arepa with some sort of meat inside and it was flavorful and delicious. I'm in love with plantains, so I also also got a side of plantains, which were quite generous in portions. 

Beware, however, that prices here are not as low as they may seem because the sandwiches are quite small. I ended up full after the arepa and the plantains, but if you're looking for quantity over quality, then this is not your place.
author: Talia G.

description: I had really high hopes for this restaurant since it was featured on diners, drive-ins, and dives and it sure met my expectations! The yucca fries were really light so it didn't make me feel stuffed like regular french fries do. There's also a variety of sauces on the table to dip them in. I got the cachapa and also had a bite of my friend's arepa. I liked the texture of the arepa more but they were both delicious!
author: Monica W.

description: Saw this place of diner, drive ins, and dives and I was not disappointed. The pica pica nachos are good and the large portion makes it good to share with a group. The Arepas were good and you really can't go wrong here. My personal favorites were the shredded beef pabellon and the pulled pork pernil.
author: Miguel M.

description: Absolutely LOVE this place and go here often for lunch. I usually get the shredded beef pabellon sweet corn arepa. I am weird and chop it all up together with the side of slaw and then squirt of bunch of their white sauce (don't know what it is but SO good) all over it. It's a party for my mouth! I've also gotten their yucca fries a couple times and when dipped in their spicy ketchup are so yummy. Service is always friendly.
author: Tara M.

description:
I went here with a friend after buying the Gilt deal. The atmosphere was WAYYYY different than I expected- small, clean place with a quick meal kind of vibe. The Gilt deal really wasn't worth it as we got far too much food for two people, more than we would ever normally order, while overall not even saving that much money. However, the food was pretty good. My favorite was the Beef Pabellon Cachapas. The thick corn crepe was both savory and sweet while the sweet plantains and beef complemented each other nicely. The Pulled Pork Pernil Platter on the other hand wasn't anything special. The pulled pork was pretty tasteless and the sides didn't do much to bring in any flavor. The Sangria was super different than anything I'd ever tried before- lots of different fruits blended together including passion fruit! Mmmm....BUT it was so sweet that drinking more than a glass made me feel like I was going to get a sugar hangover! 

The BEST part of this whole experience was the Yuca Beignets. Usually when you bite into a beignet it's like biting into a soft, airy cloud. These, however, were super dense and sweet- amazing texture and absolutely delicious! You definitely don't need to eat more than one though. 

Overall, I'd say order the Beef Pabellon Cachapas and get he beignets for dessert. This place is definitely worth trying once.
author: Nicole G.

description:
This was my first time ever having any maize type sandwich and I LOVED it.  I had the La Vegetariana with the Cachapas, the sweet corn pancake.  I was unsure which bread to choose so I asked the woman taking my order and I'm glad I did.
The flavors went together perfectly.  I wasn't sure what I would think about the plantains because I do not like bananas, but they added just the right amount of sweetness to balance out the savory flavor of the tofu and beans.  Now I need to go back and try out the rest of the menu.
author: Nam Kirn D.

description:
My first trip to Pica Pica, brought on by the hype surrounding this restaurant and the delicious-looking photos outside, turned out to be a disappointment. Not a bitter, spit-it-out, what-have-I-done disappointment. But a disappointment nonetheless.
The place itself is cute. Small but we went there mid-afternoon and it wasn't crowded. The service was friendly but I do take note that my friend ordered a side salad with his arepa and got served the arepa and the dessert but the salad came only once we were almost done (we did get reimbursed for that).
The main disappointment for me was the food. When the small coleslaw-type salad (with cilantro, onion carrots and such) on the side is the highlight you know it wasn't a great meal. I had a beef pabellon arepa and I didn't care for it. Hear me out, I don't know what it is supposed to be like so maybe they did it perfectly authentic and I just don't like arepas. But the textures were all wrong. Everything was mushy. The plantains, the arepa shell, the beans and that shredded beef that I really didn't like. It needed some texture to be enjoyable to eat. The mush turned out to be off-putting after a few bites. And the flavor were unremarkable. I tasted mostly the beans. Which wasn't bad but ... Meh.
And don't get me started on the yuca fries. Now again maybe that's what they are supposed to be but the gross hardened part I found in one of them completely turned me off and the fry itself was too thick and dry to be enjoyable. It wasn't a fry, it was mostly yuca flesh.
My friend didn't care too much for his similar order but gave thumbs up to his coconut flan for what it is worth.
I also ordered a coconut-lime fresca which was a very interesting and original flavor so points for that. But as a drink, the "originality" got old pretty fast and I had to resort to water by the end of the meal.
So I give it three stars. Not four or five because I didn't like it and won't be back. But not two or one because disappointing as it was, nothing was bad or shocking about the meal or the restaurant. I just don't get the hype. Well, at least, we didn't pay the Castro Pica Pica prices that are almost all $1.50 to $2 higher than the ones at this location.
author: Dorian S.

description: Get the yuca fries and the beignets. Throw a pork arepa in between with that slaw they serve with it and: make sure they're serving you what you ordered. ;) you won't be disappointed. Gluten free never tasted so good. Those beignets are KILLER!
author: Karin F.

description: My g/f is gluten free but I am definitely a man that loves carbs. This place made her happy but was still absolutely delicious for me. Highly highly recommended! (Arepas are where it's at btw)
author: Ryan S.

description:
This place has gone completely downhill. I dont know if they switched ownership or what but they are awful now and not sanitary to say the least. They have even changed their menu. I would NOT recommend this place anymore at all.

I went in yesterday and was treated horribly. I was the only one in the place at 4:30pm and it took them 30 minutes to make me 2 pork arepas to go. What a joke. It was only until a man (who must have been the owner) walked in that the cook finally started making my arepas and the woman in front actually put gloves on to help him. I watched them make them and he dropped his knife in the garbage once and took it back out and kept using it without washing it. Gross. The two of them were giggling the whole time like they thought it was funny to make me wait and use dirty utensils. It was so bizarre. I wish I hadn't tipped them before all of this happened. I was appalled to say the least. The food was GREASY. Like heart attack greasy. It was inedible. I now know what my friends were saying when they said they dont come here anymore.
author: E A.

description: I have tried their arepa's and chicken salad, both were absolutely delicious. highly recommend for a quick spot to eat or grab take out
author: Andrew W.

description:
After a horrible waiting experience at another establishment, the dude, his cousin, and I came to Pica Pica because we were STARVING!

The guy at the register was really cool and helped us order.  We order 3 sandwiches and sangria beer. Service was awesome. 

We sat down, and the food came out within minutes. The shredded beef was so good and flavorful.  The dude have shredded pork and his cousin had the deviled ham.  Everything was great.  

The sauces are definitely something you have to try.  Hot, spicy, and garlic-y! LOL... I was very impressed bc I have only seen Arepas in New York.  Now I know where to go in SF for an Arepa! Thanks Pica Pica!
author: Cel A.

description: Oh la la a-MAIZE-ing yummies here. One of those Mission spots that I have walked by a million times but only went into when with a friend who suggested it. I loved my grilled chicken Cachapa so much I actually ordered a second one to bring home to my roommate.  The food tastes fresh, healthy and delicious. Recommended!
author: Serena Q.

description:
I can't believe I haven't reviewed this place yet! 

Pica Pica Maize Kitchen is one of my go-to places when I'm looking for a fast, delicious & nutritious, and of course, gluten-free meal in the Mission. I usually go with the Vegitariana Arepa, but I've also had the Pabellon, which is fantastic. Ditto on their beef empanadas. All of their dishes are gluten-free, most are dairy-free. 

The service is very friendly here, as well as relatively quick with getting your order ready. The place is nice and clean, and you can pretty much always grab a seat. 

Highly recommended!
author: Deirdre P.

description:
Arepa is what took me to this place albeit on a cold evening.
So we took over twenty minutes finding a parking spot I would attribute one percent of my rating to this because a location is a location, once parked I had to walk ten minutes to the restaurant.
Maybe it was too late, beyond 9 PM on a long weekend, but there was a blank expression on the person taking order more like, "dude, make it fast and stop thinking." This contributes nine percent to the rating.
Then there was a delay, a painful one - I could see my plate on the stand but it was time for the server to go munch. It was like bait for a fish.
Whence the desired dish was on my plate I magnanimously forgot the paens and started munching through but Lo and behold, I saw something different. Sitting in one corner of my plate was a piece of meat. Okay being a congenital vegetarian I could have raised a hue and cry but I usually let it be and this is one of the places where I was made a fool of. There was no apology, another delay and then the arepa.
That's the ninety per cent for the rating.
The arepa tasted normal nothing epic.

Well if you aren't a vegetarian and don't care about service, this place is good!
author: KC L.

description: Others have accurately described this place, so this is just for my own future reference.  Totally Gluten-free!  So awesome.  I had Taro Nachos that were really good, though next time I need to ask for no onions on top.  They had so many delicious looking things I want to try next time.  I'd be happy to try this place again.
author: Kate Marie G.

description: Excited it is gluten free and the drinks were good and the meat on my arepa had good flavor but waaaaay too much corn masa going on. My friend and I both felt sick about 20 minutes after eating, not a food poisoning sick, just a ouch my stomach is full of masa will I ever go to the bathroom again kinda of feel. Sorry, really wanted to give it 5 stars!
author: Lisa S.

description: I was visiting SF and went there for lunch with a friend. Being a vegetarian, I had at least 4 different options to choose from and that is pretty decent considering it is a Venezuelan place. The food is made fresh, and the portion sizes are pretty good. I loved the vegetarian arepa and I got mine with yellow corn. This is my first time having arepas and I would definitely have them again if arepas i get back home will taste like this. Not too crowded and we were able to find a seat quiet easily. The place cleared out by 1.45 pm and was almost empty when we left.
author: Arch T.

description:
Flavorful food, quick service, and smack dab in the Mission. I hate cliches but it's an absolute gem of a place. I was a bit surprised at it being a counter-order kind of restaurant, but I don't mind. The seating is really nice inside and pretty roomy despite appearances. I had no idea what kind of food to expect actually, it was sort of a random lunch decision for me and my friend and thank goodness it paid off! We both got arepas - she got the vegetariana and I the pulled pork and they were both VERY different but IMO equally delicious! The pulled pork meshes with the garlic aioli and arepa in an incredible way - it ALMOST (almost almost... not quite) makes the chunky avocado superfluous. My friend's vegetariana was also amazing but with really different flavors, naturally, since hers had tofu and grilled plantains. I thought it was superb as well, but not comparable to the pulled pork if you're really looking for a huge kick of flavor. Ooh, and the yucca fries!! This is a can't miss. It was pretty similar to the one's I had at Limon but the sauces are bit more standard - garlic aioli, spicy/tangy mustard, and a barbeque (which are found on the table, so they don't exactly come with the yucca fries... they're for anything, really).

All in all, we left with super stuffed and super happy bellies. It was a perfect date!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Delicious shredded beef Maize-wich.

Greasy empanadas.

Guava and passionfruit drinks available.

Pleasant service.

Clean bathroom.
author: Inigo M.

description: Terrific and pretty healthy arepas. The only wish was that the arepas were a bit less salty and slightly thinner/or cooked more. The meat was flavorful. The avocado was fresh and the side salad was very acidic and delicious. Reminded me a bit of an vietnamese slaw.
author: Steve N.

description: Great find! The arepas were so delicious I didn't want to share! Great value for the serving sizes and quality. Friendly staff, local feel. Highly recommended
author: Kerri T.

description: OMG!  As a gluten free person, I stopped by on my way through SF.  I had the Arepa and as we were eating we saw this incredible dessert go by the YUCCA Beignets.  We had one and they are dipped in dulce de leche.  The decor is like a chain fast food, but the food is outstanding.
author: Pat M.

description:
I've eaten here twice and the food has been pretty good but on this last (the 2nd) experience the service was no bueno.

We waited 30-40 minutes to get a couple of the sweet corn sammiches. Now i realize that on a saturday night, sometimes you need to wait....but it just seemed that they didn't really have their 'stuff' together. The yuca fries and drink we ordered weren't brought out, with the drink being rectified quickly. The fries were on their way we were told. We ate, we chilled, we talked, and after another half hour (and another inquiry into the whereabouts of the fries) we still had no yuca fries. This annoyed me as we saw other folks whom had ordered well after us being served their meals with their fries. Hmmmmm.....

When I explained to the counterperson that we'd prefer a refund seeing as how we had already finished our food sans fries, I received an annoyed look and a request for our receipt so that we could get our money back. No apology, explanation, or even patience.

Lame.
author: Nate R.

description:
An a-maize-ing maize-wich.
Pick your bread, pick your filling.
Add a side:
yucca fries, garlic yucca fries
plantains, 
fried green plantains. All will be
delicious.
Free of gluten, free of heavy spending.
Free of long waits, long lines, leaving unfulfilled.
Bring a friend.
Bring a napkin. 
Bring an appetite.
author: Jared S.

description:
Pica Pica is awesome. I don't know by what miracle this place was created, but I'm awfully glad it exists. Sure, their main ingredient is corn, but I love that they have gone the extra step to run their kitchen gluten-free. This means that I can eat everything on the menu, a rare and wonderful feeling.

They specialize in sandwiches made on your choice of gluten-free corn bread--you can opt for cachapa (a sweetcorn crepe of sorts), arepa (made from a ground corn dough), or the maize'wich, situated somewhere between the previous two as a sweetcorn bread. 

It doesn't really matter what you get, because it's all very tasty. You have an array of hearty fillings to choose from, with solid meat, veggie and vegan offerings. Basically, pretty much anyone can eat here--though I did once manage to dine there with a friend who's allergic to chili. She enjoyed it, but as you might guess in a joint that does Venezuelan grub, we had to be pretty careful.

On the spectrum of San Francisco dining, Pica Pica definitely counts as cheap and cheerful. They have plenty of gluten-free drinks (with alcohol and without), and you can also grab soup, empanadas and delicious yuca fries. 

Any considerations of price must take into account the fact that you will not be hungry for another day or two after eating there--it's incredibly filling fare, replete with plantains, beans and avocado. I often ambitiously set out to complete La Vegetariana with yuca fries and succeed only when I have backup.
author: Kimberly M.

description:
Black beans and plantains were born to hang out and Pica Pica knows it!  Order the Pabellon and thank me later!   

Right now it is raining outside and I am about to walk a mile just to sit in their lush Latin atmosphere and chow down on an arugula salad and Pabellon arepa.
author: Emily O.

description:
I really dig this place. First off, their sweet corn bread is to DIE for! I would gladly order that alone and be satisfied, however, I would only be cheating myself. Try out the maize'which and get the pulled pork. Also, I fell in love with their spicy salsa, Pica'pun, so make sure to try that out as well!

Do yourself a favor and order a side of yucca fries, because that is an addition that sets the meal above and beyond!
author: Teresa C.

description:
Fantastic!
We had lunch catered for work ~ 20 people.  They delivered all the way to Palo Alto!  It was right on time.  We will definitely order this again!
author: Jenni H.

description: Love the place, small and they give a nice palate of food, get the arepas and yuca fries.
author: Bryan T.

description: Great Venezuelan food in Miami and friends from Venezuela spoiled me so this place was a HUGE disappointment. They have gotten lazy after receiving foodie awards and having the luxury of feeding easily amused palates. There is potential for rebirth of this restaurant, but not until they realize their food is lacking and boring.
author: Danielle O.

description: YUMMY. I was away for a month travelling and eating out every night and this was one of the most memorable meals. This was my first time eating such cuisine but I would liken it a bit to Mexican except with a bit more flavour. We ordered a few sides to share - the yuca fries are just delicious and each ordered an arepa which is similar to a sandwich/burger. I got the pork one and my goodness it was just so good. The service was friendly and the meals were very reasonably priced. They do takeaway here too. One word of warning - the bottled beer is gluten free but they do have normal beer on tap.
