I would definitely recommend going here. Writing this review makes me sad there is no Pica Pica where I live!!
author: Olivia C.

description:
Everything I had eaten was mind blowing.
The food does seem a bit oily but I am not sure you could find a better gluten free Latin American cuisine!

From first taste, you can tell the corn is beautifully ground and fresh. You can not replicate such a remarkable taste without having good ingredients.
The corn salad-ish thing was also sweet and each kernel tender to the taste. The black beans were fresh and perfectly soft.

I had an absolutely great time, though I think they are a little pricey. Portions are relatively small too. Can they add back in the gluten and give me a $1 discount on each item? ;)
author: Winè C.

description: Hi Adriana.  We tried the yuca frita and that was good.   The first time I tried a chicken arepa and second time a beef arepa.   I think it's ok to have lots of liquid when the chicken and beef are cooking but when the chef builds the arepa it does not need that much juice.  Both times my arepa totally fell apart on the bottom side.    Thanks for listening to our feedback.
author: Don S.

description:
Great food!
Good place to have some Venezuelan food, wich is not comon in the Bay Area.
author: Isa J.

description: I needed a last minute contribution to lunch at a friend's -- ordered online and picked up some delicious empanadas and taro chip nachos in 15 minutes and on my way!  And delicious!  I'll be back
author: Aki N.

description:
I really liked this place! Went for lunch one day and thought it was a cute little spot.

I opted for a arepa (almost a pancake like sandwich). I got the pernil with pulled pork, avocado, tomato, and your choice of aioli on the side. I thought it was really tasty... loved all the savory flavors wrapped in the sweet arepa. Also loved the yucca fries and your choice of all those different sauces! They have a spicy sour cream sauce, spicy ketchup, signature hot sauce. All things I love!

Really affordable too.
author: Sarah A.

description:
So this place was an interesting experience.  I wasn't very disappointed since there are options to replace what I ordered . . .  let me explain:

This restaurant has 3 types of "breads" to choose from, all corn based.  There's a corn bread, a dough corn flat bread, and a corn pancake.  I ordered the pork w/ avocado and tomato on the corn pancake.  The sandwich had potential, but I think the sweetness of the pancake (which was advertised, so I was warned) threw me off.   I heard the corn bread is THE best, but of course they were out of it.  So sad.  So if I were to return, I probably wouldn't choose the corn pancake.

The sides they offer are yucca fries, fried green plantains, and fried sweet plantains.  We had the fried sweet plantains which were served with a spicy dipping sauce and garnished with what I think may be queso fresco.

Towards the end of my meal I felt like some hot chocolate, but of course they were out of that too.  Actually, we were informed that the machine was broken.

Finally as to service.  Not the friendliest of service.  She was kind of just going throw the motions of assisting the guests.  The beers we ordered, several times, were poured for us about 5-10 minutes after the fact, yet we saw her pour beer for other patrons on the spot as they ordered.  So, don't know what's up with that.
author: Marty L.

description:
Went to this location twice in recent months the first time was great had the arepas two diffrent fillings and took it to go it was good and something diffrent for me.

This past Saturday was with a friend over at monroe motors and wanted to grab a bite I reccomended we go here we order the yuca which had garlic over it and we ordered arepas as well and tried their lemonade. The lemonade was super sweet I had to pour half of it out and add water as it was toooo sweet The arepas were ok the filling of pork seemed to be cold like it had been sitting around, The yuca was the worst it was very oily and the garlic was straight out of a jar long story somewhat short ended up tasting this damn yuca all night long wont be back to pica.
author: Michael W.

description: I love this place. I am gluten free and am always looking for great gluten free restaurants. This place is 100% gf.  The Arepas are my favorite partically the beef, the plantain adds the perfect amount of sweetness. Also the Arepas are so filling you only need the one, if I am extra hungry I'll order a side of the yuca fries but only if someone will share with me. My favorite is the sweet yellow corn pocket, it is a little softer than the white. I also love that this is an order over the counter then sit, we usually get it to go and then have a picnic at Dolores.
author: Jessica C.

description: Never had them before. Had the Chicken and Beef. I thought the Beef was the better of the two with the yellow masa. Made the mistake of ordering a gluten free beer (didn't read the label close enough) No Bueno!  I would definitely go back. Made
author: MARCUS L.

description: Cool concept, but despite several tries I just couldn't get into it.  The food is okay, but not anything that leaves me craving another visit.  It's a shame because the people that work there are so nice.
author: Meow S.

description:
This place was such a 5 for me- at first. Until the service really began to decline. This last visit put me over the edge... LOVE their food but I won't send people there anymore. I was running late for an event at the theatre two blocks over and thought ahead enough to call a take out order in. The girl answered and then put me on hold -- for the entire 12 minutes it took me to drive across town-- I literally walked into the restaurant listening to her chatting with someone else through my phone. Spoke to a guy (who turned out to be the manager) about my situation, and could he make something while I wait in line to pay? He was absolutely unapologetic, tried to talk me into ordering something I didn't want that was easier to make, and then sent me to stand in line. As I was finally arriving to the front of the line the same cashier that had put me on hold (and not once in this time looked at the phone to see I was no longer on hold) she just walked away to take care of someone else. I would have appreciated her at least saying, "sorry, I'll be right with you." Finally got my food, and all the manager had to say about it all is "we're busy." In summary, good food if you can handle the lack of customer service. And for them, give someone a heads up if you are going to put them on hold for almost 15 minutes so they can choose whether or not to call somewhere else.

*On a food note, a agree with many other vegetarian posters that the tofu arepa is a bit bland. If you add a few of the sauces it does help, but they could definitely stand to add a few more spices.
author: Paula H.

description:
Of the options in the gluten free range; this is a good one. 
Everything here is gluten free, and is quite good! 
They still have beer on tap (but they do offer a delicious cider!)
author: Charlie D.

description:
This place is perfect for people who need to eat gluten-free, as all their breads meet that requirement, AND they're delicious! Basically you just pick a type of corn-based bread, add a filling, and then get any sides or drinks you want to go with it, so there are a LOT of possibilities for different things to have.

I had the Cachapas bread with the Pernil filling, and it was pretty amazing. The corn pancake was crispy but fluffy, the pork filling was tender and flavorful, and the aioli sauce that came with it complimented it extremely well. My girlfriend got the Arepas bread with the Pabellon filling. She was a little concerned about the sweetness of the plantains in the sandwich, but they ended up going very nicely with the bread and beef flavors. We got a side of Yuca fries, which were simply amazing. They were thick-cut wedges of Yuca potatoes, lightly fried so they were crispy on the outside and fluffy all the way through - I HIGHLY recommend giving them a try. I also had a glass of the passion fruit Sangria, and while I'm no expert on sangria, I found it to be extremely refreshing and original.

The only drawback we could find about this place is that it's very small -- there's probably only seating for about 20 people -- but since the ordering process is walk-up rather than sit-down we saw past this pretty quickly. The service was great and the woman at the register was great at helping us decide what to order. 

Overall we were EXTREMELY pleased with this place, and will definitely be going back when we can make it over to the mission again. This place is now one of my favorites in San Francisco and I can't wait to go again! Do yourself a favor and give it a try!
author: Mike M.

description: This place is really good. I had a big glass of sangria which is well worth the cost. It tasted like it's based with passion fruit juice. Delicious! For dinner I had the sweet corn arepa with fried chicken. Add the sauce that's there on the tables and you got it made! The side slaw was too tangy or pickled for me. 5 stars for the sweet corn arepa and sauces and 4 stars for the chicken and slaw.
author: Haley M.

description:
**I am strictly gluten-free, so my review is from the perspective of someone with this need.**

PROS: I have been eating at Pica Pica since they opened their Valencia Street location.  If you're GF, you know how difficult it can be to find fast finger food that is reliably GF.  Well, here it is -- and it's REALLY, REALLY TASTY.  They also have Bard's Beer and GF desserts available.  My favorite thing is to grab some and take it to nearby Dolores Park for a great GF picnic.

Friends with no food restrictions and my veggie friends also love it here, though veggie options are more limited.

CONS: Minimal.  Sometimes it's difficult to find a seat in this small restaurant, and staff can be grouchy at times; however, this describes most of Valencia Street.
author: A. L.

description:
This is a solid lunch place which I may find myself going to more often!

The biggest issue I have with the food here, which prevents it from being a 5 star hit, is the oiliness of the food. I feel like if you get a basic arepa and a side of garlic yucca fries or empanadas, the oil from the side dish makes you full (not in a nice way) before you finish your arepa!

As for the arepas themselves, I suggest starting with an arepa the first time you go, so you can find out what the standard is, and then experiment with the other two options (I prefer the maizewhich).

My advice: Go with a friend, and each get one arepa and share a side to prevent the side from getting too heavy. As for the fillings, go for the Pernil if you're into something a shade lighter, but I agree with my friend Cristofer P (who is the one that brought me there), that the Pabellon is great as well (though much heartier!)
author: David H.

description:
**Warning: I am not an expert on Venezuelan food. I've never had Venezuelan food. Is Pica Pica Maize Kitchen authentic? I have no idea. Do I care? Absolutely not.**

Yum the Pabellon arepe was soooo good that I had it twice in 1 day!! And then I had it the next day too :) The arepe is a maize dough that's cooked to be crispy on the outside and a bit chewy/wet on the inside. The shredded beef in the Pabellon arepe was extremely flavorful and tender. The beef mixed with the black beans, a little bit of the plantain, queso, and salsa made for a hell of a bite. I am so happy to have tried Pica Pica at the Sunset Celebration Weekend and I will definitely make the trek up to SF to visit Pica Pica again. 'Cause damn, that was good.
author: Chelsea T.

description: So good. I've had the beef and pork arepas. They were bomb. Keep doing what you're doing Pica Pica.  The coleslaw was supbar but I'm fine with that due to the delicious corn arepa and tender meat.
author: Marie R.

description: This is my first Yelp review. I'm not going to try and be witty or sound like I'm writing a dissertation for my doctorate in Foodoligy. I'm gonna keep it simple...wow, incredible, amazing, superb! Everything I ate and drank was marvelous. The Pabellón Arepa, Tajadas, Yuca Fries and Passion Fruit sangria were outstanding. My partner and I will become fixtures here for sure!
author: Kelly B.

description: In Portland we lack spots that serve Venezuelan food. My lady is from Venezuela and hasn't been impressed with the arepas at home. Seeing her face after trying the arepas here was priceless. She loved them, as did I.
author: Michael H.

description: A solid joint.  A bit pricey, but well worth every lint-laced Andrew Jackson.  The food is simply delicious.  The young people taking your order don't necessarily know what they're doing, so just be mindful of that.  They tried to give my order to someone else because they gave him the same number as me.  But the food is good enough and the decor is nice enough that ultimately that aspect isn't really a make-or-break issue.  The yucca fries are to die for!  Quantity-wise it looks like you're getting a little bit of food for a lot of blingage, but I was absolutely stuffed afterwards.  It's also worth noting that it's not a luxuriously spacious dine-in experience, it can be a bit cramped in there for sure--just a caveat.  It's got a relaxed atmosphere, despite being busy when we went.  The coconut lime juice is wondrous, too!  Viva la comida venezolana, pero SIC SEMPER TYRANNIS to their government!
author: Christoph C.

description:
I brought a good friend of mine & my boyfriend to Pica Pica on Valencia today.  Oh boy! What a disappointment. This is not the first time I was there but certainly the last. The girl at the counter was short, snippy and rude. She also was unable to run my card manually. Leaving no choice but to go to the closest ATM. Roooode!

Our food topped it off. Smaller than normal servings, under prepared vegie arepa, puny emanadads and ceviche made with frozen NOT fresh shrimp...

Adios Pica Pica.
author: Holly S.

description: As a Venezuelan, there are two obvious reasons I loved this place: arepas and cachapas! But, as if that were not enough, I was happy to learn that they offer a 10% discount for Venezuelans... so, Venezolanos visiting the Bay Area: next time you are in town, swing by Pica Pica for some good ole arepas at a not-so-steep price.
author: Manny H.

description:
Mexican food for yuppies and squeezing gentrification down from 16th street into a dicey sro / public housing area
Some of the most unique flavored food you could eat, anywhere
Good people watching from the large corner window, with a view of the streetcretins mulling about
Left with a full belly, and burning mouth
author: G K.

description: Bad experience. Slow service. Messed up multiple parts of my order. Low quality ingredients. Food (ordered a steak salad with some sides) was bland. Better off at Chipotle.
author: Lauren D.

description: What is when Guy F. visits a joint the price of the food goes up and QUALITY goes down..I would  have a pupusa.  The doughs were all undercooked and the experience of the food should of better..DISAPOINTED
author: Linda R.

description:
Came for lunch with a very picky mother-in-law. She hated it before we even got in the door because and only because it is gluten free. Her opinion did not really count in my review, only the way she was treated by the employee. 
I am totally gluten free and was so excited to find this place while on vacation. 
The food was great and I didn't worry about getting sick, very nice. I decided on the pulled pork arepas and my husband had the shredded beef. Both were wonderful and my gluten loving husband also liked his meal. 
Mother-in-law hated everything EXCEPT for the Yucca Beignets which she thought were donuts. Nobody told her about the Yucca :)
The girl behind the counter was very kind and very patient. She offered her samples of everything and never seemed irritated. My hats off to them!
If only they had a store here in Phoenix I would be there for lunch every day!
author: Kristina W.

description:
3 star - overall average 

Bottom line: Great tasting food but high price for the portions. 

Very tasty food. I have had the maize'wich with pernil an a maize'wich with clasica. I really love the sweet corn flavor of the bread. It is worth a try but if you have a big appetite you might want to go somewhere else.
author: Matthew T.

description: YUM! I got the nachos and the pork was excellent! The cashier was also very sweet.
author: Leilani W.

description:
The food was great the first time we ate at Pica Pica Arepa Kitchen so I returned with my brother when he was in town from Seattle.  We drove from Alamo to San Francisco to eat at the restaurant.  The outer corn shell was supposed to be cripsy; however, it was soggy.  We could barely eat the Arepas because it was falling apart.  I mentioned this to the staff and they just blew us off.  I contacted the owner to express my concern.  She said that this happens sometimes if the batter isn't prepared properly or if the Arepas sits too long.  She apologized and offer to send me coupons to return and try it again.  There are 3 issues:
1) I could have taken my brother to many great restaurants.  I'm a foodie and have dined at food trucks along with all the 3 Michelin restaurants in SF, Chicago and New York.
2) I wasted gas by driving to SF.  There are great restaurants in the East Bay,
3) The owner said she would send coupons and never did.  I called to remind her and she still didn't send the coupons.
This restaurant isn't managed properly.  The owner lacks customer service skills. I won't return to this restaurant and will tell all my foodie friends not to dine at Pica Pica.
author: Ruth S.

description: A bit on the slow side, and super crowded on this day. . . BUT the manager said they were featured on DDD the day before we arrived.. .  Hence, the crowd. We grabbed a spot along the wall and they brought us our arepas. These were fun and different to eat. Kind of like a chalupa made from a less durable cornmeal mixture. We had the beef with plantains and the pork arepas. Really tasty!  It was fun, and loud, and very casual. Everyone was really nice to chat with as we ate. Just an overall good vibe here.
author: Greg S.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE. After seeing it on Triple D on the Food Network, we had to give it a try. I got the pulled pork arepa and my dad got the chicken arepa. Both were fantastic. The corn pockets are so soft and different than a typical burger-style bun. The sauces that accompany the arepas are delicious as well - there are spicy sauces, medium, and mild. We also got a side of the yucca fries, which everyone should get. Highly recommend this place for lunch if you are in the area!
author: Julia M.

description: It took some time before they got our order down. I ate here first in Napa and realized they have an SF location.  Their Arepas and Maize (corn) taco thing is amazing. They use fresh ingredients and it tastes amazing. The chicken is good, but their steak is the bomb!  Def recommend!
author: Abra S.

description: Amazing all gluten-free food. Highly recommend the Yuca fries. Plantain chips are good but not amazing.
author: John M.

description:
Ever since I saw the episode of Throwdown with Bobby Flay featuring Arepas, I was on a quest to try some out. 
Well, fast-forward to a Food Truck Fest @ Fort Mason. The hubs and I visited the Pica Pica stand and were very pleasantly surprised by the selection. We ended up trying the Pabellon & the Pernil Arepas. The flavors of both were fully present. Pabellon-Shredded Beef & Plantains with a little cheese; sweet & savory- definitely a must try. The Pernil was created with pork carnitas; this is an absolute try! 
Our next vist to San Francisco, I will definitely be looking out for either the truck or stop by the store front location.
author: Just Me P.

description: So disappointed in Pica Pica! Wanting to try something new and different and left wishing I'd never even bothered! They were out of chicken and pork at 2pm and when I ordered the cachapas that was supposed to be with a tasty sounding salad on the side...it instead came with flavorless cabbage possibly trying to pass as coleslaw without ever mentioning I would not be getting the product described. Sangria was way too sweet and all over a bad experience! Highly recommend you go somewhere else!!!
author: Keri W.

description: Stopped by here because I love Latin American food and my friend was gluten intolerant. Paid 17 dollars for a plate of food which I waited 20 minutes for and was then mistakenly made into a plate half the price. Then I waited another 20 minutes for my original order to not come to me because they ran out of the main ingredient. This whole time the service was curt and ridiculously rude. Never coming back here again.
author: Isaac K.

description: To the server who I spoke to 20mins ago said the drink was sealed... My bag and my newly washed clothes are wet!!! I asked for a tape. You should've said you don't have rather than telling me it's close/sealed!!!
author: Ties O.

description:
Cute spot in the middle of Valencia 'district'.  Nice signage/menu guides you to fairly easy ordering.  Eat in to enjoy the scene.  I had the pulled pork/avacado arepa...we were there at high noon and they were out of the Maize'Wich which sounded good.

Made to order and when delivered to your table, it is piping hot.  Mine was tasty, but not over the top great.  Had the yucca fries with garlic and one or two sticks was enough for me.

If in the area, try it for something different if you've not eaten Venezuelan food lately.
author: Randall F.

description: I had their arepas once and it was pretty good. But today I had the yucca fries and empanadas.  The yucca fries didn't have much flavor (though the ketchup was good.)  The empanadas just weren't tasty at all. They literally had no flavor and tasted like they were straight from the freezer.  I actually couldn't finish my empanadas because they were pretty sub-par.  Also the price point for everything seems too high.  That being said,the service was nice and friendly!
author: Maryanna Q.

description: Excellent taste. We had the Arepas with pulled pork. Will definitely come back to this place soon.
author: Nikolaus M.

description: Food was good, although I did not like the cashier at all, I asked one question about the food and the way she answer was quite rude... Other than that, food was ok, although the yellow arepa was more like a cachapa and I did not like that either... That's why I give it a 3
author: Maria C.

description:
I'm glad I had a deal coupon for a free arepa from this place, or else I might have been disappointed. For $8 you choose between 3 different types of sandwiches & a handful of fillings. For $6 you get a tall skinny glass of sangria - which, to their credit, was 1 of the better sangrias I've had...not overly sweet. For an additional $3.25 (w/ purchase of sandwich) you can add a salad, soup or fries.

I had the arepa with carita - chicken in their sofrito with cheddar cheese. The sofrito (mix of veges in sauce) had no flavor, didn't show up in the arepa at all except as a few diced onions & red sauce. The chicken was ok, the arepa was at least grilled very well. The cheddar cheese??? They threw shredded cheddar cheese (like the kind you buy in Safeway) on top of the chicken/sofrito mix right before serving me...so I had raw shredded cheddar cheese on top of bland chicken in sauce stuffed into an arepa. For $8.00. 

I also ordered - since I was getting a free arepa with purchase of sangria - a salad to go w/ my meal...bululu (? don't remember how to spell). Sounded delish on the menu board & the counter guy said it was pretty big. Since I wanted it for later, I asked for it To-Go. They brought me a rather tiny salad that was missing 2 ingredients! Glad I checked before leaving! I asked for the 2 ingredients - and really wanted to ask to beef up the salad overall, but didn't. The cook found the missing roasted corn but they apparently didn't have daikon sprouts...in fact, they didn't even know it went in the salad! The counter guy & cook looked in a fridge, apologized & said they must have run out. Right...or you never had it to begin with & don't know your menu too well. 

Not a place I'd go back consistently. Interior was ok, it did get busy but everyone around me did mention that the price wasn't very consistent with the portion. But - what do you expect from owners that started this business in Napa?
author: Marissa H.

description:
Do you LOVE honest, good food? Does the sound of grilled maize stuffed with pulled pork, or tender steak make your mouth water? Are you all about being gluten free? If so, this is the place for you.

I've been familiar with Pica Pica for the past few years when I had a chance to try it at a street fair. It was love at first bite...plantains...cheese...steak...black beans...yum. I always wanted to make a trip to Napa to go to the restaurant, but never had the chance..and then POOF they opened up a Pica Pica here in the city--hooray!

Even better? I had a TownHog.com deal...came on a Monday when it wasn't busy, and had some great food. We ordered 2 arepas (#3 and #7), a maizeiwch, yucca fries (hey aioli!), fish empanadas (yes!), and the "panda" sangria (SO REFRESHING!). 

Be careful about the hot "sauce" on the table--it's SPICY!

I heart you Pica Pica.
author: Misha F.

description:
The good:

The arepas are good, i have had them many times and it's just good.

Empanadas are also very nice. I personally like the cheese ones.

Passion Fruit Juice is also good. A bit too strong for my taste, i blend it with some water to get it a perfect state of being.

The Bad:

Cachapas, i did gave them two tries to make sure it wasn't a bad batch or something.
I did NOT like the cachapas, too dry the first time, too salty both times. Far far away from what a cachapa should taste like.
author: Jorge B.

description:
I stopped in here awhile back for a quick early dinner. Got there around 6:30, had somewhere to be at 7:30. Ordered one beef arepa. Waited. Maybe 15-20 minutes passed - much longer than this place usually takes. People who'd come in after me got their food and I was still waiting. Went to see what was up. Oh, they forgot mine - they'll have it out in 10 minutes. Fine. Oh, oops - 5 minutes later, here comes the guy from the back to tell me that actually, they ran out of beef 20 minutes ago. Okaaay... but you told me five minutes ago you'd have it out... ugh, never mind. You'll make something else, you promise, it'll only be 5 minutes? No. No it won't. I don't have time. I left almost 40 minutes after I arrived, running late and without any dinner.

I'm still giving them three stars, because prior to this I'd stopped in several times and the food was always good. But they don't really seem to have it together.
author: K S.

description:
Cute little restaurant.  Friendly staff.

Had the cachapa pepeada and loved it.  I have always been a fan of cachapas.
Tried the arepa pabellón and it was very good.  Also tried the arepa de pernil and didn't really like it.  It wasn't as tasty as other arepas de pernil i've had.
Tried the yucas and... no, did not like them.  They seemed old and too garlicky.

I was bummed that they didn't have a greater selection of venezuelan cheeses (queso de mano, guayanés, etc) like in other venezuelan restaurants.

Overall, it was a good experience.  I liked Pica Pica and would totally go back for more cachapas and arepas and would love to try other stuff.  But it  only gets 3 stars because some of the stuff i tried i did not like.

Go check it out though.
author: Rita F.

description: The sit down location  is now closed, but the Valencia St location is as good as ever.  The new crispy chicken Arepa is Yum.
author: Banana G.

description: A friend showed me this little gem in the Mission.  It is a great place with fresh South American gluten-free food.  There is rumor they are opening up another location in the Castro.
author: Matt S.

description: Ordered one of everything ! Love it all but our favorite is the pull-pork... either the Arupas or the Cachapas. Absolutely loved the plantain & Taro chips. Yummy beignet - 4 per order... smaller than the ones that one might see at the ferry building ... but 4 is more than plenty. The Cachapas a good size for the ladies unless you're a big eater. Great for the guys. Loved the beef empanada... not greasy... 3 per order. Go off hour (i.e.) no lines and plenty of seats. Nice guys!
author: Jay S.

description:
Super-yummy and unique gluten-free food for not that much money? Awesome. We got it delivered at work, and it came on time and was really tasty. We'll definitely be ordering again.

If you're not sure what to get, try the Arepa + Pork/Avocado, and the yucca fries. The fried plantains were dry and underwhelming.
author: Bryan K.

description:
Okay this place is a bit overpriced but their maize bread options are just so good, I can forgive them for the premium price they charge for their sandwich selections. There are 3 kinds of maize breads: arepa, cachapa, and maize'wich.  I've heard that the arepa is a bit bland and dull so we went with their cachapa with catira filling and maize'wich with pabellon filling.  The pabellon was a perfect blend of tender shredded beef with sweet intermixed plantains.  I can imagine it would go well with any one of their bread options, but the maize'wich was definitely my high preference over the cachapa.  The maize'wich had a sweet taste with an outside crunch compared to the capacha which had a similar sweet taste but without the same kind of crunch on the outer layer.  I especially liked the fact that there were sweet kernals of corn in the breads; adding to the authenticity of what Pica Pica brings to its menu.

I've heard some good things about their yuca fries so I'll definitely be back again for that and another maize'wich.  My girlfriend said they also sell their bread options separately so if you want to bring a cachapa or arepa home, feel free.
author: Albie F.

description:
The lunch order: two la vegetariana arepas, the special garlic yucca fries, a beer, and a glass of white sangria. (We did the "buy a beer, get a free arepa" offer.)

The positives: the yucca fries were very good. The arepas were nicely sized. All said, we walked out full. The decor is also bright and comfortable. The beer selection is interesting. 

The not-so-positives: not impressed by the arepas. There was a definite lack of flavor in the tofu, they could have used more black beans, and the plantains were almost to that sickeningly sweet over-ripe stage. The arepa itself was much thicker and less tasty than ones I've had in NYC. Maybe the spicy sour cream would've helped things, but I'm not doing dairy right now, so we'll never know. The white sangria tasted like syrupy passionfruit or papaya. 

The verdict: I'd rather have a far smaller arepa that packs a much better flavor punch. And the search goes on...
author: Robyn M.

description:
AMAZING AMAZING AMAZING AMAZING AMAZING.

This place is going to make me sooooo fat! LOL

The passionfruit sangria with white wine was super tasty (I preferred it to the red wine version).  Gluten Free heaven!
Yuca Fries were good, but there are so many other goodies, that I can't see filling up on the fries.
The Pabellon (sp?) Arepa is to die for!!!!  The beef is super tasty and tender, the plantains, beans, and cheese were just perfect!
Empanadas were good, feels like a little bit of a luxury for the gluten free in me. 
And oh...the pork and avocado and tomato filling in the Cachapa was killer as well!  That sweet corn paired with the pork was awesome!

I can't wait to go back and try the chicken filling as I hear that's pretty darn good too!

Nothing was greasy, everything tasted of good quality, well seasoned, spices were spicy and not just high heat on the tongue.

It still amazes me that it too so long to get my butt in the door here!
author: Q L.

description: Being Venezuelan and finding a place that sales food from my country in San Francisco was quite challenging until one of my Colombian friends told me about pica pica ! I went there today and the arepas are exactly like the ones made in Venezuela ! very delicious, kinda pricy but it's worth it if you have a 20 minute lunch. the service was fast. A Lot of American customers that love arepas as much as I do but I think what would make the place a lot better would be if the waitresses could speak Spanish ! other than that everything was spot on.
author: Kevin L.

description:
I've only had two experiences with this establishment and probably wont have another.  The first experience was a couple of days ago and just over the phone.  I called in to place an order for delivery and was told they no longer deliver.  Okay.  
Second experience was today.  The cashier was very nice and helpful, but the wait time was too long.  I waited over 20 minutes for my order... only to find out that on top of waiting so long, I received an incomplete order.  The manager(?) (not the cashier who rang me up) had such an apathetic attitude.  She could see me sitting there with an inquisitive look on my face wondering, "why did those three people who arrived after me get their meals and I'm still waiting?"  She checks on an order (turns out it was mine) and then gives an employee some money to go buy something.  Two more patrons arrived and placed an order with the manager, at which time I finally got up and made my way to the counter.  The patrons pay and make their way to their seats.  I get to the counter and, simultaneously, the phone rings.  The chick actually picks up the phone and starts talking on it while looking me dead in my face.  Really?!!  I butt in to her phone convo to ask about my order.  She doesn't put the person on hold, she instead just whispers confirmation of my name so she can grab the order.  She hands it to me.  I ordered the grilled chicken cachapa (comes with a side salad), yuca beignets, and a coconut lime drink.  The side salad was missing.  The cachapa was good and the beignets were good...but I bet they would have been even better with the dulce de leche sauce they were supposed to come with (and, no doubt, what the employee was sent out to buy).  The coconut lime drink was really good.  While waiting I had ample time to check the place out...including a sign that says they deliver.
author: Jennifer T.

description: Delicious! Good food good staff. I eat here when I feel like letting go and pigging out during my time in the city and... for those with Celiac... It's 100% gluten-free which warms my heart. I think I've tried just about everything here with every sauce offered. Okay okay maybe one complaint, last time I went in they ran out of gluten free beer, but oh well. I'm craving some yuca fries right about now and I'm honestly thinking of driving an hour or two from Sacramento at this very moment to get some. 5 stars and beyond!
author: Ej S.

description: This place is the bomb. The arepas are definitely what you should get - grilled chicken is my favorite. The coconut drink so out of this world too, so good. Annnd it has the best salads ever too, love the passion fruit dressing. So delish!
author: Hello G.

description: It is worth ALL the hype! Had the yucca beignets and the pulled pork arepa with sweet yellow corn. The sweet corn had a stickier consistency than the white corn, which was more savory so it was a nice contrast with the fillings. If we weren't walking around the city afterwards, we would've taken home another serving of the yucca beignets, they were THAT good!  Also, make sure to try ALL their sauces, they're all different but tasty!
author: Tamara A.

description: Very good, but a little pricey for what it is. I got the crepe like dish and it filled me up which nicely blended the tastes of avacado, plantains, cheese, and tofu together nicely.  I'll probably go back again some time in the near future.
author: Isaac R.

description:
Came here over the weekend on my first real trip exploring SF. Our friends asked if we wanted OK food but a little more local to where we our location was or if we wanted Great food but a little drive too. Of course we chose the latter.....who would ever want to waste a meal on just OK food? Certainly not me!

I wasnt sure what to expect since I had no idea what Venezualen food consisted of. The bf had the Cachapa with shredded beef and plantains. It was pretty darn good but I LOVED my Maize'wich with pulled pork, avocado and aioli sauce. Mmmm....I have never had anything like it. The sweet and the salty works so well together. The next time I get to go back up to SF I will def come here again. 

I hope they consider opening a store out here in OC or LA area!
author: Thao N.

description:
I am liking this new style of eating. Similar to Kasa in its execution, Pica Pica offers Venezuelan food made quickly, with fresh ingredients, and for an extremely reasonable price.

The atmosphere is clean, friendly and efficient, with counter seating and a few communal tables.  You order at the counter, take a number and they bring you your food when it's ready.  Ordering is far less daunting when you look at the clear case below the register to see the difference between a Maize'Wich, an Arepa, and Cachapas.  

We tried a few things, starting with the Empanadas with Queso Fresco.  These are smaller than empanadas that you may have had before, and more crisp and textured.  You get 3 per order, so this is a great starter to share.

The main dishes are as Don H. said, about the size of a medium burrito, and filled to overflowing, so for $7.99 they are quite a bargain. We tried 3 Arepas:  Pepeada (chicken salad with creamy avocado), Pabellon (shredded skirt steak with plantains), and Catira (sauteed chicken).  My favorite by far was the Catira - the chicken had great flavor.  We also tried one Maize'wich, which is basically like eating a sandwich using cornmeal pancakes instead of bread - yum - the Pernil (pulled pork).  This one was the best by far, with moist meat with tons of flavor.

The sangria is $6 a glass, and for a big glass with tiny chopped apples in it - very refreshing.

You can eat well here for about $10-15, and I appreciate that a lot in these tight times. Plus everything on the menu is wheat and gluten-free, and there aren't too many places that can boast that.  This is not the place for your vegetarian or vegan friends if they want a lot of variety - only the cheese empanadas, the yucca fries, and the salad are not meat-based.  However, if you are a carnivore and looking for a tasty, well-priced meal, stop by and enjoy some tasty Venezuelan fare that will leave you full and with plenty of leftover drinking money!
author: Liz S.

description:
Darn you Pica Pica! You were pretty good your first week open. Fresh, different, hit the right spots. 
Second time around I couldn't finish even one dish. Sad. :(

The plantains were hard, and charred and kinda tarish and stuck to my teeth. 
The bread was undercooked and hard. 
There was no cohesion in the dish, just odd pieces seemingly piled together and served like I was in a soup kitchen. 
No sir, I dont want some more. 

Great location, not a bad place to eat. I think they're going to try for a chain by the people who were doing tastings the first week they opened, and maybe that's what it should be, a cheap chain at the local food court selling to people who dont know or care about the what that food really could have been.
author: Tasha A.

description:
The food here is super FRESH and delicious!  The very charming and affable young man at the counter advised me well. Tres empanadas (I chose 1 cheese, 2 beef)--yum. Very generous guacamole on the plate too. Then a classic white corn grilled chicken arepas, and sharing the plate was a simple salad made special with added cilantro. Yum!  A Pacifica on tap didn't hurt!

Next time, I'll mix it up with a sweet corn pulled pork arepas with the darker beer and some yuca fries. Can't wait!
author: A. J.

description: This place is ok. I got the shredded beef sweet yellow corn arepa platter and the portion was really big. It also came with a side salad, but I didn't really care for it. I think I wasn't into the dressing.. it was too tangy and had a strange taste to it. The shredded beef arepa was good at first but then after a few bites, the mushy texture just becomes off putting. Maybe I made the mistake of ordering the sweet yellow corn pocket because in addition to the plantains inside, it became too sweet. I was starving though after running around the mission and dolores park so I ate most of it, but I think if my stomach wasn't trying to eat itself, I probably would've stopped after a couple of bites. Large chalkboard near the door was cool though, it was cute when a little kid eating in the restaurant went to doodle on it with his dad.
author: Maggie T.

description: Warning: I have a toddler. I'm a total mom. I plan where we eat based on online menus to see if there's kids stuff or small plates available. My little one is not going to get a $9 plate but he isn't going to eat a side of fries either, you know? Pica Pica has two different menus available on their website (regular flash and mobile version) with two different kids options. In the restaurant there is no kids menu. Food is tasty and all but this is Bait and Switch. Simple as that.
author: bianca francesca o.

description:
I've been gluten free for a few months now, and this is one of my favorite restaurants in the city for a quick gluten free bite. 

They offer 3 kinds of maize bread for sandwiches with a choice of fillings - my favorite is the paballon (shredded beef, sweet plantains, black beans & queso). The sides are great too, especially the yucca fries.
author: Emily C.

description:
If you're looking for something different, then this is worth stopping in for arepas.  The food is well seasoned and reasonably priced.  I have an issue with the yucca fries; however, as they are overloaded with raw garlic.  The taste will remain in your mouth for hours.  Simple and fast.
Venezuelan cuisine hasn't exactly taken over in the USA.
author: John K.

description:
I stopped into Pica Pica this Tuesday, when it was raining and I wanted a warm location to read a book and enjoy a hearty lunch. In contrast to the dark, gloomy sky, the interior of Pica Pica was cheerful with orange, brown, green and red color scheme. Their menu is pretty standard, offering three starch options and choices of filling. Thankfully, they also offer a glossary of words and a plexiglass cabinet so you can see what each of the items are. I'd never had Venezuelan food before that afternoon, so the vocabulary as well as the mix of sweet and savory was completely new to me.

I ordered the #3 Arepas, a thick corn flour cake sandwiching skirt steak, black beans, plantains and cheese. The mix of sweet and savory was fantastic, though I was hoping it would be a bit more spicy than it ended up being. According to the glossary, this mix of black beans, plantains and steak is the national dish of Venezuela. Interesting...

The menu also said you could order a side of yuca, a soup or a salad for an extra $3 with your entree. The arepas looked small, so I underestimated how filling that would be and ordered a side salad to go along with it.

The sandwich was extremely filling because of the dense starchy nature of the corn cake. Side note: this place is completely gluten free, and you don't find many cornbreads that are 100% corn. Because of this dense corn, however, this place will fill you up despite their tiny looking portions. Even so, I am still so glad I bought the side salad because it was possibly one of the best, most interesting side salads I've ever had.

It looked standard at first: mixed baby greens, bell peppers, pineapple and jicama. But as I dug down I saw  some sweet roasted corn and some quinoa. The dressing was the bright yellow of Frenchs mustard, but it was a fabulous passion fruit vinaigrette. It was sweet, savory and best of all, different!

The service was friendly, the bathrooms were clean, and I was able to sit for an hour and a half with my leisurely lunch while reading The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao. I will be back for some more delicious steak and plantains, and I will try the yuca in the futurel
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Not bad - three types of breads (sweet corn, corn/flour mix and another type).  Then you pick the filling - they have examples in the glass which you think would be gross but it is fine.  
Order at the counter
I had their sandwiches at their food cart and actually though they were better - smaller and cheaper so you can have 2 (more variety) 

Mostly fried sides so while gluten free, wouldn't say this is the healthiest place.
author: Sarah G.

description:
I haven't eaten at the restaurant, but have had Pica Pica's food two years in a row at MakerFaire. It was worth waiting in the long line.

I've had an arepa and a cachapa. The cachapa is a gordita-thick sweet whole corn pancake that's used to wrap the insides taco-style. It's delicious. I like the sweetness against the fillings, which was pulled pork. The arepa is pita-like, but made out of corn. It's white and they grill them, so they're super hot and crispy, keeping your steak, beans, plaintains and cheese warm (this filling is called "pabellon").

And the yucca fries! Oh the yucca fries. Fried to perfection. Really crispy brown outside, fluffy inside, comes with spicy ketchup. So filling, yet as your belly struggles you'll look at your plate sadly, thinking it would be such a waste not to finish them. I recommend sharing an order. Or sharing the sandwich-thingies with a friend and getting an order each of the fries.

I'll have to come to the restaurant sometime when I'm not starving in a long fair line so I can try the chicken salad or the vegetarian options, which all looked really good.
author: Amy N.

description:
My mister started things off with, "it looks like Dolores Park came in here for dinner," which is a good summary of the crowd. And crowded it was around dinnertime, on the same day it was posted on Mission Mission.

But then, the food. The food!

This felt like Venezuelan Chipotle, in the same way that Kasa place in the Castro is Indian Chipotle. There's a standardized menu of options. Pick an entree: the arepa, a soft, corn-based pocket stuffed with savory yums, is a good choice. Pick from a set list of fillers. Pick a side, if you want. The end.

Pulled-pork and steak/plantains/black beans arepas were delicious, messy, and unlike anything I've tasted. The yucca fries with dipping sauce (the spicy aioli one that was my favorite). We had a frozen coconut rum drink, which was tasty, but not rummy. There's sangria, regular wine, and beer, too.

Can't wait to eat here again, napkins and all. Maybe at an off time, though.
author: Tara R.

description:
Do you want to try something different than your typical quick hole-in-the-wall viet sandwich, burrito, schwerma, slize of pizza for dinner...

Hop to Pica Pica for a unique sweet and savory mixture of taste in every bite.  Choose your bread and meat filling.  Display samples by the counter for your viewing pleasure.  

SO opted for the maize'wich with steak, black beans and plaintains.  I gobbled the cachapa (pancake) with the most tender chicken and melted cheese.  Ordered some yucca fries too (choice of sauce).  Both were very yummy.  If you're looking for a light meal, don't come here.  These things will FILL you up.  Each sammich sets you back $7-8.

The decor was very nice and it was obvious that the owner took pride and pleasure in designing this eatery.  Service was stupendous.  We came in right before they closed and though we were the last patrons, they NEVER once rushed us, only dropped by the table to make sure we enjoyed our food.
author: Jennifer H.

description: I was on my way to Little Star and saw Pica Pica across the street! I told my friends how amazing it taste and we ended up running across the street and split the yuca fries and one beef, plantains, beans arepa between 3 of us. They LOVED it!
author: Karen T.

description:
It is totally awesome to be able to eat at a restaurant that is totally GF and to have absolutely no worries about contamination.  Service is friendly and helpful too.  My favorite is the pabellon arepa, which is a corn cake filled with shredded steak, black beans, queso fresco, and plantains.  The yucca fries are also crispy and delicious, with a nice aioli sauce.  The tajadas (sweet plantains) can be a bit greasy.  I also enjoy the coconut-lime drink.

Overall, as a GF diner, I have really enjoyed this restaurant.  The only negative is that it is a small space and there can be a wait for seating, especially if you have several people in your party.  Some non-GF people I have taken here have not been huge fans of the cuisine, finding it too bland.  It definitely depends on your tastes, but if you are GF it is worth the trip to check it out.
author: L C.

description: Quick, clean, unique and delicious. Slightly more than I'd expect to pay for a glorified torta but it is a truly glorious torta.
author: Mario T.

description: Looking for great cheap food, look no further. The yuca fries are awesome, come with really tasty guac. The "arepas" were great, and I tried the pulled-pork platter also. Very satisfied. I've never had Venezuelan food before, and I think I'll have to keep an eye out from now on. before, but i'm a huge fan now. The food was fast, fresh, and delicious. I guess it's similar to mexican food, but tasted a lot less greasy, which was nice. Didn't taste like fast food at all!
author: Laurent L.

description:
Yes, yes, y'all.

I sometimes wonder when the more-obscure, off-the-beaten-path-type world cuisine will hit SF, further justifying my decision to relocate here 10 years ago. Pica Pica, which serves Venezuelan-style maize delights, is just such a place.

Don't get me wrong: The place itself is nothing like Caracas. For one, it's pretty damn clean. Also, the arepas are much larger than what I had down south.

Still, the two that my lady and I got were nothing short of stunningly delicious. We mixed the spicy sauce with the aioli, smeared it all on our skirt steak and pulled pork arepas, respectively, and went to town. The yuca fries were cooked to perfection, and are delicious and heartwarming even if you're not hungover.

The coconut-lemon-rum slushy drink thing was good, though neither of us tasted rum in it.

Oh, and the place was packed. On a Tuesday. Slightly annoyingly so. Maybe that's just by virtue of being new, and having been mentioned in Mission Mission earlier that day.

Still, at $8 a pop, and a mere five blocks away, I can see myself going back time and again. Hell, it beats flying back to Chavezlandia.
author: Jeff H.

description:
I loved the food here. The chorizo arepa was bomb. 

Their house wine (the one that was made specifically for them) is good. It was $32 a bottle, not bad for a bottle of decent red. 

My only grip is there is no where to sit... I felt like I had to stalk the other patrons dining in order to score a table. 

Definitely worth checking out!
author: Sofia H.

description:
I love the fact that there is an arepa place I can go to now and then, but the couple of times I have been, I feel that the arepa alone is not enough and the price is a bit too much for what it is. I ordered an arepa and yuca fries for a little over 12 bucks (no drink.... bad economy and I work in a non-profit=broke!).  

In regards to the food, the pulled pork is the more tastier of the dishes. I decided to try a pabellon the other day and was disappointed, as was my friend who ordered the same. It needed sauce or something. It also was listed as being spicy by the use of a chile pepper next to its name and if that is spicy, well, spicy went on vacation.

I once ordered a drink got charged 3 bucks... I know that said drink has a suggested retail price of $1.29-$1.49. 

For a restaurant that you have to get your own utensils, expected to clear your table, and go to a counter to place your order, you should really walk away feeling like you just had a great meal at a great value, not guilty and telling yourself "I think I over paid". 

I love of arepas and support a So. American joint around here anytime (because I just get super tired of Mex food!), but lets be realistic... for this neighborhood... it is too pricey for what you get. 

Suggestions: 
- Make your spicy foods spicy when listed as spicy
- Consider adding a little something to the plates, even 2 slivers of  plantains with a piece of yuca (this way you get more people that are unfamiliar with yuca to try them out!)
- Have some sort of combo deal that actually presents a savings and this will most definitely encourage people to come back. I know you guys are in NAPA, and perhaps there is an expectation of a high price for things while you are in wine country and this formula has worked for you at that local, but this is a completely different area.

I say all this because I really want to see this place stick around and am extremely happy to have you guys in the neighborhood. It is just constructive criticism. Con todo el respeto que se merecen. La mejor de la suerte a uds.
author: Amelia M.

description:
This place is awesome. The food is delicious and so unique! The staff is great and always cheery!

My favorite is the pulled pork! Today they were out of it, I was sad but it made me choose something different. I chose quickly because I thought I needed to hurry due to the large line. There was one girl working so she was running around and as she passed me I asked her if I could change my order to something different. It was no problem and she handled it right away. 

This place is wonderful and I will keep coming back!!

Appreciate the service and don't forget to tip!!
author: Justine B.

description: Waited 10 min to order and then 40 min for food.  Wait is disguised because line is short but there are about 10 times as many phone/internet orders.  Definitely not worth the wait though the food is good.
author: Amy F.

description:
Cheap, quick, filling, and DAMN tasty!

We popped in Saturday evening for a quick bite.  It's an order-at-the-counter sort of place, so just walk right up.  The menu is simpler than it appears - Choose your wrapping, then choose your filling.  Done.

The Arepas is sort of like a corn version of a thick pita - it's got the texture, flavor & consistency much like lightly fried polenta, with an almost crispyness to the edge.  Very good.  I went with the Pabellon filling, which is shredded skirt steak that was seriously as tender as perfect pulled pork.  Fantastic!  Also nice chunks of fried plantain, black beans, and cheese.  This was pretty much awesome, and way more filling than I expected.  Pretty comparable to a medium-sized burrito.

I also tried the empanadas, which arrive as a set of 3, and are of the thin, deep fried variety.  Be warned - they come HOT!  I got the black bean & cheese option, and they were tasty, but on the greasy side.  They're also pretty small.

Everything comes with a dipping sauce (there are a few different options, mostly based on spiciness I think), which all seem to be mayo blended with various things.  Reasonably tasty, but thick & mayo-y.

They have a few beers and wines available, as well as a standard selection of sodas & such.

Pica Pica is definitely a fast-food sort of place - it's small, ain't fancy, but is clean and well designed for quick turnover.  They're open until 10, and the food is tasty, and totally filling for $8, which is only a bit more expensive than a burrito, so in my book, that's a win.
author: Don H.

description:
I would have eaten the maize by itself -- it was THAT scrumptious!

Lucky me, I caught these guys 15 minutes before closing at Off the Grid last Friday. Their ham and cheese picture looked amazing, however, they were only serving arepas for the evening. Let me tell you, there was nothing unfortunate about that! I ordered the one with skirt steak and cheese -- first of all, it was ready in an instant. I had just finished putting my change in my wallet when I looked up and saw the gentlemen handing me my order.

I took a bite -- HOT! Good sign that it's fresh. The cheese was slowly melting on top of the hot, savory and very juicy pieces of steak. Everything combined tasted wonderful. The maize itself had a nice crunch to it and tasted lovely. My pallet was VERY pleased. The seasoning on the steak had so much flavor. If only I had more time, I would have ordered another! So happy I finally got to try one of these San Francisco vendors. I can only hope I find them again soon.
author: Jonny A.

description: This place is great. Don't have a gluten allergy and was a little iffy about going to a place that was gluten free, but was pleasantly surprised! Had the taro chip nachos and arepas and both were fantastic. I'm officially addicted to taro chips now!
author: Kristina B.

description:
I first had Pica Pica at a Oxbow Public Market in Napa and thought it was tasty. The vibe here in the Mission is definitely different - there's a seating area (instead of just a window counter) and I like the bamboo/wood decor. I went with a bigger group so we were able to sample a lot - here's what it came down to:

- Sangria: Meh. My friend really liked it, but don't expect Cha Cha Cha's style sangria. It's thicker and darker, and more tart. You won't find any fruit floating around in your cup either!

- Pasapalos (side dishes): Yucca fries are amazing. Light, crunchy, and thick. They were super hot and came with a garlic aioli dipping sauce...my favorite! The plantains are just okay. They were kind of burnt and I'm not the biggest fan of how sweet they were.

- Empanadas: Here's where Pica Pica could earn an extra star. The empanadas left MUCH to be desired. They were undercooked almost, kind of doughy, and really flat. Skip these!

- Chupe: The only time I've ever seen soup come with half a corn on the cob! I didn't taste this dish, but it looked good. A soup with shredded cheese...mmm!

And now for the main dishes....I'm just going to throw it out there and say that I prefer the maize'wich over everything else. The arepas taste like they could just be a plain pita, and the cachapas are messy. Go for the gold and get the corn maize'wich.

- Pepeada: Basically just like chicken salad with some creamed avocado. Meh. I liked the fact that it didn't fall apart when you took a bite of it, but it wasn't anything special or that flavorful even.

- Pabellon: Delicious skirt steak, with plantains, black beans and cheese. I didn't like the sweetness of the plantains. The black beans made it really watery and messy, so I had to eat it with a fork and knife. The menu claims this dish is spicy... it wasn't at all.

- Pernil: Saved the best for last. Everyone's favorite. Shredded pork, tomato, avocado, and what else? Aioli. I liked to add extra.

I'll definitely be back to try some of the other combinations that looked interesting (like the only breakfast option - perico, the Venezuelan-style scrambled eggs stuffed into an arepa or maize'wich). 

Spice up your empanadas, get on top of your sangria, and you'll earn 5 stars, Pica Pica!
author: Hannah L.

description:
100% Gluten Free. Vegetarian options. 
Melts in my mouth.
Friendly and helpful if you need some help deciding between an arapa and Chapata.
Sometimes they give free yucca fries when asked or ordering for a large group.
author: Tigre T.

description: For those of you who are challenged by gluten, this is your place! My favorite arepa is the pork one. But you can't go wrong with the chicken. Its a casual atmosphere, low key and friendly. The cashiers are very accommodating and knowledgeable. This place does get busy on the weekends and during the evenings. Bring change and patience for street parking.
author: Joel Z.

description:
I'm conflicted about the three star rating. First let me say that I have never been to Venezuela or any other Latin country for that matter, so my point of reference is skewed and I am aware of that. 
I also hate eating at restaurants that feel like cold, fast food chains and Pica Pica is definitely like that but...
Their Pabellon is so fantastically delicious. I've eaten there three times in a week and a half for that one thing on their menu.
author: Hilde L.

description:
Excellent food. I had the vegetariana arepa, which with a side salad. The side salad itself was awesome. The steps arepa was equally awesome too. 

This is a tiny place with very little seating but if you are like me and are bored with your current food options, give this place a try. You will not be disappointed.
author: A G.

description: Saw this restaurant on Food Network and had to try it. The shredded beef arepa is the one I saw being cooked on TV and I tried it with a beer. It was everything I hoped it would be. Don't miss it next time you visit San Fransisco.
author: Susan S.

description:
This place is cute, and located in a great area of the city, but my main beef (pun intended) is that they got my empanada order wrong....

I am a pescatarian, so I ordered the Moreno (black bean), Queso, and Tilapia empanadas--(The $5 deal comes with three, you choose from a list of 5 flavors).  However, instead of getting the black bean empanada, they gave me a MEAT FILLED ONE!  

I had never been here before, and was not sure if what I was eating was what I ordered (I should have listened to my intuition) until I saw my friend eat her black bean empanada--the filling completely different than what I had just eaten.  

My friend alluded to the fact that the cook always gets her order wrong, and that the waiter even said to them "Sorry, my chef is incompetent".

Then find one that isn't!
author: Fire S.

description: Their arepas are good! Also I would recommend the fresh squeezed mango juice and the plantain chips
author: Sara G.

description: Unless you have food allergies/sensitivities you can't begin to imagine that thrill I experienced upon discovering this place. Every item they serve just is gluten-free. They don't alter the recipes or substitute anything. I was literally able to order anything. That alone would have made me ecstatic. Then, I tasted the food. First off, the sangria is some of the best I have ever had. The perfect balance of wine and fruit! I dined with a few people, so we sent my brother-in-law up with instructions to order a good variety and we'd share. He ordered carnitas, a spicy chicken arepa, a vegetarian arepa, a beef arepa, and one of their Venezuelan crepes stuffed with beef. I don't usually like pork. It tends to be dry. Their carnitas were out of this world. Everything was fantastic. The coleslaw was a little too vinegary for me, but it wasn't bad by any stretch. Just a personal preference. The rice had a lovely garlic flavor to it. After we finished our buffet of awesome, we wrapped up the meal with the taro beignets and dulce de leche sauce. I was in heaven. Seriously to die for.
author: Olivia F.

description:
Healthy and crave-ably delicious!  I first tried Pica Pica at the Oxbow location in Napa, and I was delighted to see that they had one in SF, I spent the week after I realized this looking for an excuse to go in to the city for an arepa!

I get the vegetarian on a cachapa, and I recommend eating with a fork and knife as the cachapa will get stuck all over your teeth if you're biting into it.  The arepas are excellent too, but I didn't care for the maizewich.

I didn't try to sangria or water at this location, but the one in Napa had good sangria and amazing cucumber lemon water (the water was free even though it was better than just tap water!).
author: N S.

description: Ordered ahead and food took forever. Stood there for over 45 mins waiting. When I got home all the sauces were missing. Yucca fries are not so good without the sauce. Staff was also unfriendly. Never going back.
author: pb ..

description: Its small but a popular place. Loved the cachapas with chicken filling
author: Vrushali P.

description:
Delicious food! Nice out-door seating area. Mmmm plantains.

A little pricey, especially for the amount of food you get.

Also- they're at off-the-grid at Fort Mason on Friday nights with all the food trucks.
author: Kali L.

description:
Um so yeah, gluten-free glutton heaven right here. 

All arepas are gluten-free and you can choose your arepa of choice, and then fill it with nuggets of heaven from their menu.  

Adrienne and staff are incredibly helpful and accommodating.  The aerpas are so fresh and delicious.  The hardest decision you have to make is whether to get one or two arepas!
author: GlutenFree G.

description:
I am really digging this place and that is based off of just two things: La Vegetariana Arepa & Yuca fries!

The arepa is amazing. Almost like conventional bread but with a nomz corn taste and softness. The flavors all work wonderfully together especially with the tamarindo sauce (some of the other sauces/condiments are not vegan but the staff is fully aware of the options if you ask about vegan).
The Yuca fries are like big crunchy fried potatoes. Can't go wrong with that (other than wishing for a bigger serving).

I do have to note that the dining area is super small and this is not a sit down and order joint. I would prefer more space but I haven't been unable to find a seat yet.
author: shane s.

description:
A wonderful, healthy fresh sweet and savory corn sandwichy joint, at reasonable price.  In case you don't know Venezuelan food -- and who does here in San Francisco? -- these are stew-like meat and vegetable fillings inside corn wraps that have a shape, texture, and taste somewhere between a tortilla, a papusa, and a corn pancake.  The outside is solid but the inside has a springy moist texture.  It's mind-blowing.  Another completely different comfort food.

There's (almost?) no wheat here yet lots of tastiness.  The yucca fries are memorable.  After trying them I wonder why we're still eating potatoes here in North America - they have all the qualities of the best french fries, plus a lot more starchy root flavor.
author: Gil S.

description:
Nice atmosphere, amazing food, & it's menu is gluten & wheat free.  I feel awesome after eating here.

I highly suggest the pull pork.  Delicious!
author: Augie S.

description:
I was a bit skeptical before heading to Pica Pica because $8 was more than I wanted to pay for a dinky Venezuelan sandwich. I was wrong - the arepas are larger than I expected and definitely filling. 

I tried the arepa pernil and was very satisfied! The white corn flour bread had a great texture with a satisfying grilled flavor. The pork could have been a little more flavorful, but the aioli provided needed extra. The yuca fries (cute triangular sticks) were delicious and the pica'pun salsa is addictive! The space is cute and they also have wine and beer on tap.
author: Vicente G.

description:
This is the perfect place for me (vegetarian) and my partner (meat eating and gluten free). We went here three times within a week and a half. The sauces are spicy and amazing. The salad, empanadas, and yucca fries are delightful.
We plan to make this a regular spot for a casual lunch or dinner. Their Napa wine is yummy too, what a plus!
author: max k.

description:
I know that the restaurant hails from the oxbow market up in Napa, where the natives might get a little ... skerred ... if the food had too much oomph, but you're in the Mission now.  Everything we ordered could have used a *lot* more flavor.  For example,The "hot" sauce (advertised on the menu with two chili peppers) was merely flavorful.  

All the food was like that: you could tell that calories were entering the mouth but flavor-wise: just a big monochromatic blob - I wouldn't go so far as to call it bland, but there wasn't a single bite where my mouth went: "wow."

The interior decor looks like it came out of "restaurant construction kit" - Wood and Earthtones everywhere.  Note to interior designers:  You're boring us.

Btw, no alcohol here (yet).  The Yellow application sign is in the window for Beer & Wine.
author: Stephan W.

description:
In LOVE with Venezuelan food.  Never had Venezuelan food and wasn't sure what to expect.  Having gluten allergy my cousin picked this place out for me during my visit to the city.  Amazed with all my options and the flavors.  
The place is very tiny and hard to find a place to sit and a little pricey else a great experience.
author: Bhavi L.

description: My family and I were intrigued by this quaint restaurant. We had pretty high hopes as my husband had lived in Venezuela for a few years. But unfortunately we were a bit disappointed. The food had ok flavor, but they weren't terribly distinct (we got grilled chicken, and asada, just sort of there. But that's not the main problem. But their service was a bit lacking. They didn't explain that the arepa menu meant you get one. There's a choice between original and yellow sweet corn. We were under the impression that each order had two, so when we were asked which kind we wanted we ordered one of each to try out. Little did we know we got charged for FOUR arepas instead of two orders. We kept the order because by the time we sat down and figured it out there was a long line waiting to order and didn't want deal with it. Then the food came, only one of the arepas never came. When we finally were able to ask for it, they brought the wrong one. The prices are a bit high for the individual orders, and especially for the yuca fries, while they were tasty, I've had better ones at other places. I can see how this place could serve the late night, beer filled bellies though.
author: cg w.

description:
The food is not bad but the service was horrible. I waited 30 minutes for my food...30 MINUTES! This is not a fancy sit-down restaurant - this is food that should come out in less than 10. 

When my food finally came (after 2 attempts to talk to the girl at the front desk), there was no attempt to even apologize for the wait. There are so many good places to eat in the mission, I'd rather go to one with good service. Wouldn't you? :)
author: Grace T.

description:
Heard people raving about this place so I decided to check it out.  You basically choose your maize bread and then a filling.  This is probably where I went wrong.  

I ordered a pernil arepa (pulled pork in a grilled corn flour cake), and the chupe (chicken, potatoes, corn, cheese in a broth).  I have to say that the food was really bland.  The pulled pork had the flavor pulled right out of it, the soup was gross.  Not sure what kind of cheese they put in there but it wasn't working.

Perhaps I ordered the wrong things off the menu or perhaps this is how Venezuelan cuisine is supposed to taste, either way it was really disappointing and way overpriced.
author: Prav P.

description:
Went to this place based on a recommendation from a coworker and her mom.  If it's mom approved, then why not?

It's a very convenient BART ride from Union Square.

The place is quite small and I can imagine it being hard getting table during a busy point.

Their arepas were fantastic!  Ordered their pulled pork pernil and shredded beef pabellon.  Both were out of this world.  Also a big fan of their tajadas (sweet plantains), which I normally eat plain, but the cheese they add is great.  My husband also enjoyed all the table sauces they provided.  

I didn't get to try their frescas, but they seemed popular?

I'll def. return!
author: Sherryl P.

description: Pica Pica was not what I expected at all. I expected a larger maybe with waiters, type restaurant. Pica Pica is a small place. You order your food at the register and they bring it to you. I got the shredded beef arepa. SO WORTH IT! It was delicious. It had sweet plantains, black beans, queso fresco and served on a thick almost tortilla, used as a bun. I got the savory one. I'll definitely be returning here! I hear their sangria is awesome too!
author: Star M.

description: My wife and I came here on a Friday evening for a quick and casual dinner; we are vegetarians and ordered the vegetarian (tofu, avocado, plantains) and shuli (black beans, avocado, cilantro) arepas as well as the garlic yucca fries. My wife preferred the white corn arepa to the yellow corn (I liked the yellow one more) but we agreed that both were quite good. We both enjoyed the vegetarian arepa to the shuli since it basically had the same ingredients but included a tasty tofu and plantains so we would probably just order that one next time. The arepa concept is cool, kind of like a pita taco with a soft, corn shell which they have clearly mastered. We could see ourselves coming back, maybe on a colder day as the food was comforting. Price is standard for SF ($10 per arepa) which is on the higher end when you realize it is basically street food, but it's about the same price as a king of falafel lavash sandwich or wise-son's deli mushroom reuben.
author: T K.

description:
Hmmm! I am ever-so-excited that there is a gluten-free restaurant that even offers GF beer. That said, this business still has a way to go.

I've been for both lunch and dinner now, and can say that lunch is a much calmer experience. Dinner on Wednesday night was so busy that finding a seat was challenging. I'd recommend being flexible as to dining in or taking out for dinner; if it's slammed, it may be best to take things to go.

Food is pretty delicious, and definitely filling, but some dishes are completely forgettable. My shrimp soup looked like it had come from a can. 3 soggy shrimp floating in a sea of nondescript veggies is not a $4 soup, sorry. I'd be embarrassed to serve this soup to people. Yuca fries are delicious but I would recommend sharing them - I cannot finish an order myself. Plantains are spot-on. I've had an arepa (con paraballon) and a cachapa (con pernil). Both are filling and lovely. 

I still need to try the empanadas and the exciting salad with quinoa and other tasty goodies. I also plan to explore the wine list - it looks promising,

Previous posts about food being greasy and/or heavy are a consideration. It wasn't too greasy/heavy for me at the times I've gone, but I've been ravenous and in the mood for something substantial. I wouldn't come here if I wanted a light nibble.

Tab each time I have come for one main dish plus one side has been about $14. God, why did I quit my job and go back to school? This now qualifies as fancy food for me, so I won't be coming back unless it's on someone else's tab. Poverty sucks. 

So, an OK place. I'm grateful it's all GF, I cannot recommend the shrimp soup, and these are rather filling meals that I can no longer afford. Quel irony.
author: Polly Enmity P.

description:
My first experience with arepas didn't disappoint.  They're kinda like a cornbread pita pocket, stuffed with all manner of delectable goodies.  I had the pulled pork with avocado and tomato and my friend had the chicken salad with creamy guacamole sauce.  We shared the yucca fries.  Everything was light, fresh, and very tasty.  A good grease-fix without being too overwhelmingly greasy--we actually felt good after eating there, not weighed down!

The ambiance was bright and cheery, and the place was packed to standing room at 7 o'clock on a Tuesday - we were lucky to get a spot at the bar along the wall!

The gluten-free aspect is a major plus, as I have a family member with Celiac disease. She's coming to visit in a month and I'll be sure to take her here.  But I think I'll be back before then to try more of their menu options!

I think the only negative was that I wasn't expecting to pay $5 for a bottle of beer.  I mean I guess it's not that bad, but when I order what's essentially a sandwich and a beer and it's $14, it makes me scratch my head for a minute.

Still, quality wise, all of the food was absolutely worth the price (I just might stick to water next time...)
author: Kevin H.

description:
This place serves super tasty South America inspired dishes that don't break the bank! I have been here twice this week and I hope to go more. They offer a variety of dishes ranging from corn-flatbread sandwiches (arepas) and filled corn pancakes, to salads and soups. And don't forget the empanadas! For lunch you can do a "choose two" thing where you get two of the medium arepa, soup, salad, or side. I've tried the arepa sandwich with beef and platanos and it was pretty tasty. I couldn't help myself and got some platanos as a side too. For 8 bucks, I was pretty happy.

What really is good here, though, is the empanadas (4.50 for 3 plus a sauce). You get them super fresh and crispy with the right amount of filling with one of their delicious sauces (try the aoli!!!!!) One bite of the queso fresco empanada with the crispy outside and gooey inside and I was hooked. My friend that I shared the empanadas with has family from Ecuador, and she exclaimed that these were the best empanadas she's had besides the ones her grandma makes in Ecuador. That pretty much sums their awesomeness right there! Had 3 for lunch today and I'm satisfied. 

I'd heard of this place because of it's gluten-free friendliness. As a celiac, I am super stoked when I see a place that's 100% gluten free because that means I'll be 100% worry free in going there. Love it!
author: Karisa P.

description: LOVED all their gluten free options. Not usually a fan of foods outside of being american, asian, or a fusion of both those with the occasional mexican, lol. This place was awesome. Made me really appreciate Latin American foods. My girlfriend, who has gluten allergies was in heaven knowing that everything was gluten-free (except like 2 beers) and that the cooking environment was also gluten-free. Wish there was one in San Diego. Oh yeah, the girls behind counter were super nice to us. We love good customer service.
author: Giang H.

description:
I'd just heard so much hype about this place, and the couple of times I'd peeked in, the place was mobbed... PLUS, I really love corn (the theme here). So I went in expecting greatness. I went in expecting to find one of my new go-to restaurants in town.

Sorry to say... I found it just blah. We shared a few things... none of which I significantly enjoyed. I thought that the overall theme of the food was heavy/dense. I don't know what ingredients go into their items, but I would guess that lard/Crisco is involved too much. There just wasn't a lot of flavor either... and the food wasn't served very warm. And it was so crowded, with the tables so close to each other... it really was like we were having lunch WITH the two women at the adjacent (almost adjoining) table. 

Gotta say, hugely disappointed. Mostly because I wanted it to be great. Maybe if I'd have not had such high expectations I wouldn't have been so disappointed. I really do like the idea of a corn-theme restaurant. And the interior design and menu graphics were quite pleasant... (trying to not completely give them a sucky review...)
author: Zoe H.

description:
A new favorite of mine for sure. Brought tropical sunshine to my SF sunny/foggy/windy spring day!

What to get: The cachapas (a soft yellow corn pancake) filled with Perico con Chorizo (eggs, onions, tomatoes, chorizo).
