The flavor of the Pabellon (skirt steak, plantains, black beans, cheese) and Pernil (pulled pork) were both succulent and tasty, but the best corn wrapping is the cachapas, by far. Loved the refreshing coconut y limon granita, especially with blue agave liquor.
author: Winter R.

description:
I went in to this Venuzuelan sandwich shop on a quest to  try the arepa The arepa is a cross between corn bread and a corn pancake. Something akin to the salvadorian pupusa but made with less refined flour. They have several selections of bread including a sweet corn bread (maize'which), crepe like corn bread (cachapa), and the arepa(savoy corn bread). 

I had La Vegetariana on the arepa bread: black beans, avocado, sweet plantains, and tofu. This was served with aioli on the side. The black beans were amazing. Somewhat spicy, and full of flavor. They were pureed into a spread. I was disappointed in the tofu.  I think this sandwich would be best without the tofu or with a marinated and baked tofu. Simply using more of the delicious black bean spread would have made the sandwich perfect, no tofu needed. Sadly, this is a tragic fault of many vegetarian dishes.
 
But, I would be willing to repeat the experience for the tasty bread. 
 They had quick and friendly service. The price was right (7.99 for an arepa). Next time I think I would like to try the empenadas. The soup, which my friend had, also looked amazing, however, not vegetarian.
author: Lindy J.

description:
If you cant handle the 45 minute wait at Lil* pizza (or even if you can) cross over to Pica Pica. Its quick and the food is really very good. 

The mango slushy, the soup, the plantains, and the pulled pork sandwich were all just as good as the other. Packed with flavor, and pretty damn tasty. Also next door to 4 barrel if you feel like coffee after your meal.
author: Vivek N.

description:
Fresh and different Venezuelan street food.  Chewy maize wrappings for the arepas and empanadas.  More mushy corn kernel-filled sweet cachapas.

Nice vegetarian & vegan choices too.

Airy, casual space. Order at the counter.
author: Melanie C.

description:
Totally gluten-free. Delicious food. Very affordable. You just can't beat that! My sister in law, who has Celiac disease, was visiting and we found this awesome little place where she had more on the menu to choose from than salad and didn't have to pay an arm and a leg for it! We tried three different breads with different meat fillings and several different empanadas, as well as the yuca fries.... and boy were we impressed! Everything tasted wonderful and this will probably be a place we come to eat with or without the SIL. 

The place is pretty small and we had to wait about 15 minutes or so for a table on a Friday night. It was a little annoying as several of the parties that were seated had been done eating from the time we walked in and were just chit chatting, they seemed oblivious to the other starving patrons, even though we weren't the only ones waiting for a table.
author: Jen B.

description: Saw this place in DDD and we had the Cachapa with shredded beef and avocado. Very good Venezuelan Food!  The Arepa's also look yummy and huge!!
author: Gil F.

description: Very good.  Tasty.  Different.  However, the price is a lot for a little sandwich made of corn - a very abundant ingredient.  $8 and I can eat at least 2-3 of these, that is a huge price for lunch.
author: Jordan S.

description: Went with the Chicken Cachapa and it was very flavorful. Nothing otherworldly but delicious if you are looking for something pretty quick and out of the norm. Plus you can grab a beer or wine there as a perfect compliment. It's a really small place though so it fills up very quickly. I could definitely see people getting pretty annoyed with how crowded it can get.
author: Brendan F.

description: I walked in not knowing what to expect and I was pleasantly surprised. It's a cute little spot with good food. I got the grilled chicken arepas and it was excellent!
author: Callie T.

description: My husband  and I went to this place In a weekend . The place was small. We were seated next to the entrance door and the cold breeze keeps coming in to our face ... We heard about this place in the show . After we ate , food was good but we got sick after hours . My husband called and was just told they will talk to the owner . 3 weeks not heard anything ...disappointing first time visit .
author: Xylena R.

description:
A friend of a friend recommended this place, and at first I was hesitant to go because I'm not a huge fan of empanadas and other fried, bready foods.

BUT this place is amazing and I will definitely go back. Their pabellon arepa and tilapia empanadas were really tasty and lovely. Like I said, I will definitely go back. Highly recommend!
author: Sheirin G.

description:
Mi Lindo Yucatan, RIP. But Pica Pica, Yum!

Pica Pica is basically Venezualan fast food for the hipster crowd. You order at the counter, get a number, they bring your food --if you're lucky enough to score a spot at the narrow counter or one of the tiny tables. 

You're instructed to choose from one of 3 "bases" --arepa, "maize-wich" or cachapa. Then you pick a filling --pulled pork, chicken, eggs, beans, etc. 

I got the arepa, which is like a really fat, white corn tortilla. My husband got the maize-wich, which was much smaller but even thicker, moister, made with sweet yellow corn. Both were delicious just on their own.

My arepa I had filled with catira, which was chicken and cheddar cheese with sofrito sauce. While this was pretty good, I would have preferred a little more spice and flavor. My husband got the pernil, pulled pork, which was REALLY great. Lots of porkiness, great sauce and avocado to boot. 

We also got the side salad, which had quinoa, pineapple, lettuce, peppers and jicama --but in spite of all that, was sort of unremarkable. Came with a passionfruit vinaigrette, even. Good, fresh, healthy, but somehow a little boring. 

My main issue was that even with a salad, it wasn't quite enough food. It's about the equivalent of a small sandwich. For the price, they could give you about 15% more and that would be just enough. As it is, you're going to probably want sides --fried yucca or plaintains --neither of which is a light choice for those of us who are trying to avoid becoming an obesity statistic. 

But the food did taste good, and we didn't have any problems with service (but it was definitely crowded). We will be back to try the empanadas, the hot chocolate, and cachapas.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Maybe it's because I was totally spoiled by having a Colombian roommate who made the most delicious arepas I've ever had in my life (read: the only arepas I've ever had in my life until now), but the arepa I had at Pica Pica was just not good.  I get that Pica Pica is a Venezuelan place, so I wasn't expecting the same arepas that my dear roommate used to cook, but what I ordered, the arepa filled with cheddar cheese and shredded skirt steak, was such a letdown.  I mean, seriously, who wants to eat a sandwich-y thing that comes to the table drowning in a pool of grease?  If I wanted greasy, I'd order Pizza Pino -- and be a million times more satisfied.  

The yuca fries that my friend ordered were kind of okay.  Meaning I would rather walk a block to McDonald's and chomp some of their fries, but since I'm lazy and the yuca fries were there, I ate them.
At least they have Racer 5.  That helped dull the sting of profound disappointment.
author: Christy J.

description:
I'm of two minds about this place:

  I really liked the sandwich-type things (the regular corn flavored ones were okay, but the sweet corn was really delicious.  With the beef or the pork?  Yum!) but I feel like the ordering system they have doesn't work well.

This place is fancier than a taqueria, so I don't think that the order-at-the-counter then find a seat thing works.  They don't need to do table service, but I think that they ought to be the ones to tell you where to sit because, otherwise, douchebag customers waiting behind you try and "save" tables for themselves.  I saw one jerk grab a table for himself even though he was in the back of the line, and the guy in front of me (on crutches!) had to stand there in the middle of the restaurant and wait for another table.  Yes, the guy who cut in line was an ass, but the system that the restaurant has invites that kind of mis-behavior.

So maybe the best thing would be to order to-go.
author: Jocelyn K.

description:
The food here is tasty, but a bit on the pricey side for what you get.

I ordered a Pabellon Maize'wich, which is a shredded skirt steak, fried plantain, black bean and cheese sandwich.  It was tasty, but didn't have a lot of meat.  The dominant flavor was the sweetness of the plantain and the sweetness of the cornbread (used as the bread of the sandwich).  If you don't like a sweet sandwich this item is not for you.

I also had a cup of Chupe soup: chicken, potato, corn, and cheese.  Thumbs up.

Total damage: $12.30 (incl. tax but before tip).  Good?  Yes, but not great.  Good value?  Borderline.  Good service?  Yes (at least at the register; table service is limited to bringing your food).
author: Marcus W.

description: Arepas!!! Takes me back to my childhood! Nice to know there's a cozy Venezuelan food joint in The Mission. I've always been a fan of Colombian arepas, but to my surprise these were very flavorful. There was no line on a Wednesday night, not a long wait, and there is also the option of ordering online if you don't want to eat there. Given the arepa was $9, the arepas could be a tad bigger or should come with something else besides the cabbage, maybe sweet plantains. I recommend the rose sangria, maize'wiches, yuca fries, cachapa, and the shredded beef pabellon arepa (add avocado & sliced tomatoes). You can't go wrong with tasty arepas, plus these are gluten free! We need more Pica Pica's in the city!
author: Stephanie M.

description:
I had a groupon for this place and decided to give it a shot.  We ordered all 3 breads they make with different combinations.  This is place is CLEAN, full of gorgeous girl (we were the only guys there) which caught my attention!!!

Some of the the combinations we put didn't work out as good as others, but those Yucca fries had a good crisp to them and were tasty.
Portions are just right and prices are decent.  A cute place to grab a quick bite.
author: momo m.

description:
On the second time around I got some perspective on the complaints people have mentioned about the food not being hot.  This time was a busy Friday night, as opposed to mid Sunday afternoon.  It was busy, and pretty clear that this place isn't so good at scaling up for the crowds.  On my first trip the cachapa was so hot that I had to wait a few minutes to dig in, while this time the cachapa was luke warm, the meat was hot, but the cheese was cold and not melted.  

That said....the food is too delicious to give anything less than 4.  Lesson learned: avoid going at peak times to ensure the quality and avoid having to go through the crappy situation of scavenging for seats.
author: Danny G.

description: I've been to Venezuela and these arepas do not compare. Little flavor and mixes of sweet and salty that should not be blended together. Over crowded and over hyped. Sadly disappointed as I love  Venezuelan food and this is not it.
author: Elizabeth V.

description:
Hello hello, first of all I want to point out that I'm Venezuelan. On International Arepa Day I wanted to take my friends to experienced Venezuelan food and maybe more, hoping to be more than an event in that special day. When we got there they already ran out of Reina Pepeada which is emblematic. Looking to the menu I saw that almost everything was spicy, even considering that most of the people here in SF mostly like spicy food, it's not normal in Venezuela to eat spicy, we just have different sauces and you choose how spicy do you want it. The arepas were completely burned which make no sense because they just made arepas and a few other stuffs. I tried also the empanadas and surprisingly they were spicy as well. Sincerely as a "Venezuela place" is just awful because there was not even one dish exactly as is prepared in Venezuela and they are not hard to do at all. During this International Arepa Day I was hoping to hear at least Venezuelan music and not even that happened, they were playing just latin american music which is ok in a normal basis but not good at all in the day they have to promote Venezuela.
Really sorry to say this, but if you want real Venezuelan food this is not the place at all. My friends like a bit the flavorings but is not  traditional at all.
author: Andreina R.

description:
I live a block away from this restaurant, and over the past few months I've persistently reminded myself to check this place out, but didn't do so until my friend suggested that we try it last week.  So World Cup futbol matches were at a standstill (break) so both of us could take a lil breather from TV to venture out and check out this gluten free Venezuelan restaurante.  I've heard a lot about Venezuela from a coworker who hails from that land, and was excited to try out the food.

As we ventured into the place and up to the counter, I had no idea what anything (read: ingredients) was or meant in any of the plates.  We had a lengthy q and a session with the owner, who was very patient and explained what everything was in mucho detalle. My friend ordered the arepa "La vegetariana" (which he seemed to enjoy) and I ordered the same thing but with the cachepa maize bread. I was truly amaized by the poppin flavors and it had the *perfect* amount of spiciness that I could take.  The sandwiches also came with an interesting guacamole, which had a lil bit of a flavored mayo taste to it (it was good but I have no idea what was in it, so I could just be making the ingredients up).

Great new place with some interesting menu items. I want to check out their empanadas next time!
author: Megha S.

description:
This is for my review of the Pica Pica at Off The Grid, Fort Mason.  

I love it when I discover new foods and I had never heard of arepas before.  Turns out they're basically grilled corn flour cakes that they stuff with your choice of filling.  Popular snack in Venezuela (and similar to the pupusas from Central America).

The Pabellon version with skirt steak, black beans, plantains and cheese were surprisingly filling and a great start to my first OTG experience.  Can't wait to try some other version next time (the pulled pork with avocado sounds great)!

I think closer to 3.5 starts but I've bumped it up for the delicious side of crispy yuca fries that come out piping hot and creamy in the inside.  Yum!
author: F. P.

description:
Stumbled on Pica Pica a bit tipsy on a late Sunday afternoon. We were aching for something flavorful but not too filling. I had recently had arepas at Arepa Cafe in Toronto a week prior and was dying to have the bf try them. We ordered two- one chicken and one shredded steak and shared over them over a bottle of Racer 5. We devoured them quicker than I thought possible and were surprisingly full because they seem quite small. There are some great hot sauces to add to them as well.. Only downside is that they were a bit expensive for what they were, otherwise I would have given 5 stars!

Definitely will be back for a quick dinner.. not a great place to sit down for a proper dinner but definitely a good place to hit before mission bars..
author: Seema M.

description:
Calling all gluten-free peeps- Venezuela might just be the answer to your prayers! 

Any sandwich connoisseur knows that the secret to a great sandwich is exceptional bread. I was a bit skeptical when I noticed that they only serve gluten-free fare, aka sans traditional wheat flour. I was surprisingly pleased by their corn bread, which I discovered is actually a delicious treat. It adds a sweet twist to a pulled pork sandwich. 

Let's just say- this is a great 'bang for your buck' kinda place. They offer good grub, made to order. Last piece of advice: be sure to bring your appetite because they don't skimp on their portions!
author: Lauren T.

description: Very good food, and out of the ordinary. Sangria is so so. Must order: Yuca Fries
author: Bobby B.

description: 100% gluten free menu. The food has so much flavor! The cachapa with the crispy chicken is my recommendation! The sweet corn pancake with crispy chicken tenders is a combination made in heaven! The prices are hard to beat, too! Yummm! I wish we had this place where I live! If I ever come back to SF, I will return!
author: Rachel G.

description: Visited Venezuela and tried variety of arepas there and here in the US. $8.95 for soggy, burned and tasteless arepa is just not right! Nothing authentic about the food and does not really represent what a Venezuelan arepa is like. At 2 pm no yuca fries, what?
author: Albina G.

description: ah! I am Venezuelan. The truth to me is, si eres Venezolano, tendrás expectativas que probablemente no cubrirás. La cachapa esta pre hecha y la sacan de una nevera, al igual que las arepas y las yucas. Me explico, una cachapa o una arepa pre cocida y refrigerada o congelada? sabes de que hablo?. La hallaca no sabia a lo que normalmente saben las hallacas y era marron. The service, nothing great, if you are hoping to see a Venezuelan, well good luck, nobody was it when I went there, and the cashier does not know explain our dishes when people ask. It's not bad, but is not what a Venezuelans is hoping to see, taste.
author: Carmen D.

description:
Good Food.. The place was really busy on that sunday evening.. We were lucky enough to get a small table in the corner.. Its basically fast food. Order at the counter and they give you a number.

La Vegeteriana Arepa - OK, lacking a little flavor. Comes with their aioli which was too garlicky. could definitely have used a little flavor.

La Shuli Cachapa - Really good. Beans were nicely spiced and went really well with the rest of the ingredients

Morena Empanada - Good, but we ordrered the smoky tomato sauce with it.. We didn't like the sauce as much

Fried Plantains - Good, We got the tamarind sauce with it.. Very nice.. Tamarind sauce was just like the indian tamarind chutney.

Sangria - Small glass, $6.00 - a little expensive, but, they screwed up our order, so, got another glass on the house. Can't complain about that one. 

Parking - this was not fun.. Had to circle the block a few times. 

Might go there again..
author: Tanvi D.

description:
Yum! I'm so excited about this place. I'm always on the lookout for new and interesting food places, with reasonable prices and little hassle. AND everything is gluten free! Being GF, it's so rare to get the opportunity to totally pig out on any sort of bread product...I don't get to eat sandwiches, bread put on tables, oh how I miss it. But this place - the sweet corn bread sandwich with the chicken filling was so so so yummy! 

The yucca fries were alright, although a bit on the dry side. The sauces were really yummy, especially the spicy ketchup. The only thing that was sub-par was the empanadas, nothing special. 

I can't wait to come back and try the salads and soups too - the flavors look awesome. 

I highly recommend this place!
author: Lauren F.

description:
Oh, my God, I love Venezuelan food.

We went here Saturday night for a cheap dinner and I was sort of expecting good, but not great, food, given how this is the hot new place.  I tend to discount those types of places since they often don't live up to the hype, but I'm trying an experiment with being open-minded about hype.  Anyway.

Damn, was I wrong.  The food is superb (and I don't always bust out the 'superb').  We had a few different things - the arepa with the pepeada is unbelievable (and mayo-free!  I am ideologically opposed to mayo).  The yucca fries should only be eaten one way - with the black bean sauce.  We had three of the empanadas - the fish, queso fresco and black bean and they were all delicious.  I seriously could not stop eating.   

It does get crowded, and there's not always somewhere to sit so get there early. The service is great - I love, love love the fact that the guy at the counter was so patient with us as we clumsily tried to figure out what we wanted (husband and I were not on the same wavelength that night or something) for about five minutes.  

All in all, a nice change of pace from the Mission  burrito scene.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
Tasty, unique food. As other reviewers have mentioned, choose your bread wisely.  I had the salad as well, which was tasty and provided a nice contrast to the main dish.

Oh, avoid the mango or passion fruit special drink they make...I was expecting juice and it's basically a slurpe.
author: Corey C.

description: What a fun concept. We need more flavorful fast food like this and fewer tasteless Peruvian restaurants monopolizing the Latin American cuisine scene! I first got turned onto Pica Pica in Napa so was pleasantly surprised to run across one in the Mission. All 3 maize bread options pretty sweet, so hot sauce a must (luckily, the Mission branch, unlike the Napa one, is acquainted with chiles).
author: Faith A.

description:
I like this place because it is joyless and simple.  You can be in and out of here in 15 minutes, stuffed as a filipino box spring hog.

The menu is brief enough to mitigate your girlfriend's 20-minute decision ritual, but it boasts inarticulate Venezuelan titles, so she still feels special.

There is so much grease and fat in this food, I'm able to briefly forget that life is a miserable grind with infrequent cessations in pain, and instead focus on hating myself properly for over-eating.

I've had all the shredded beef and pork.  They'll treat you right.  I've tried all 3 types of bread.  They are technically different, but who cares?  The important part is the prevalence of delicious, rendered lard.

It has the typical SF inadequacies. What little seating there is has the line parading through it, and they expect you to bus your own table.  But overall, this is a very convenient heart attack.
author: JJJJJ M.

description:
I had the Pernil Arepa (pulled pork, avocado, tomatoes and aioli inside grilled corn flour cake) and it was tasty. Very simple, but good textures of corn and flavors.

I'm looking forward to future visit to try the rest of the menu.
author: Clifford P.

description:
we had a wonderful dinner tonight at Pica Pica.  The food was excellent, the staff adorable.  
It is true, though, that we don't know the origin of the maize.
author: yvette c.

description:
The food was tasty and not too filling.  I had the sampler plate of 3 flavors on corn pancakes (can't recall the name and it wasn't on the regular menu) - the pernil is VERY tasty, as was the sauce it came with.

It gets 3 instead of 4 stars because of the brusque service of the manager.  We had mistakenly thought they opened at 11 (since the Napa location opens at 11) and showed up at 11:45.  He let us wait inside since it was a rainy day - which was nice of him - but his demeanor throughout was very curt - almost like he resented our being there.

All of the other people behind the counter were fine, though.  And the passionfruit sangria was yummy.
author: B. Y.

description:
This place has become one of my favorites as of late. Walking into a restaurant knowing that all the food is gluten free can be hard to come by. Everything I have tried has been excellent from the arepa's to their empanada's and even their soup. 
They do offer sangria which is a nice gluten free alcohol choice.
The only suggestion I would make is to bake the yucca fries instead of fry. They have been a little greasy, and I would prefer them to be lighter. But I am no expert as to how this could effect the texture.
author: Jen R.

description:
Viva Pica Pica!  Haven't had an arepa since 1999 in Caracus, Venezuela, so to trip across a place in S.F. that serves up great ones was a dream come true.  Though the cachapa-style (sweet corn) were nice, I am a sucker for the classic white corn ones.  Amazing!

Can't wait to go back.
author: Janice B.

description:
Be corny.

Great tagline. Three ways to do it: 

- Arepa: grilled corn flour bread
- Cachapa: sweet corn pancake
- Maize'wich: sweet corn bread

Choose your bread then choose a filling.

My bread was arepa. My filling was vegetarian. Grilled tofu, avocado, plantains, black  beans, spicy cream. Very good but expensive at $8 - $9 depending on your choice. A side dish away from being four stars.

Friend had the maize'wich. Caution: Very sweet.

The empanadas sampler was a four star dish. Choose three for less than five bucks. The guiso (three meat stew), tilapia and morena (black beans and cheese) were shared and loved.

Applaud their purpose and giving this part of the Mission some love.
author: Jason B.

description: Yummy! Very good.  Everything is 100% gluten-free.  Although, there wasn't much for my kid to eat, but then again my kid was being picky that day.  I had 2 servings of food.  Very yummy!
author: Jinny K.

description: I was very disappointed with the food. The food was grease and the restaurant was very dirty,all the sauce bottled were crusty and grease the tables were sticky, and very over priced and extremely slow service for the type of food that it was.
author: M G.

description: Love it! My only request is that they get some organic or GMO-free ingredients on the menu. The empanadas and the platanos are amazing!
author: Shauna B.

description:
If there is another place serving Chachapas in San Francisco, please let me know!

These were no where near comparison to my beloved NYC chachapas.  But, they were still tasty.  We got the Yuca fries with spiced ketchup, which was pretty good too.

I will go back.  I would love to try the arepas and maize-wiches.  

Basically, no complaints.  I knew I wouldn't be able to find the perfect chachapa on this coast, but it'll do until I can get back to Washington Heights in NYC :)
author: Lauren R.

description: Omg! Slowest service ever! Took over 10 minutes to order and waited close to 10 more just to get chips and rice! The restaurant wasn't even busy - I think they have some serious efficiency issues!
author: Samantha T.

description:
Though I am not personally GLUTARDED, I have friends that are.  This place is a Godsend for them.  And me.  

I like the casual walk-up ordering but it's often hard to get a table.  

The corny vehicles for the multiple savory fillings are excellent- depends what mood you're in: crunchy, pancake-y, or fluffy.  I had the beef/plantain filling, which was juicy and spicy.  

The addition of beer (even gluten-free!) and wine adds something extra to this place.
author: Eric S.

description:
If this was based entirely on the food alone - I would give it 4 stars. But the service and treatment has been bad enough to knock off 2 stars.

The various types of corned based bread and their filling have always been very good, very fresh and really hits the spot (though the cachapas are a bit to sweet for me).  I especially enjoy the pulled pork and shredded steak dishes, as well as the shrimp soup. 

The problem for me has been awful service. Because it is often crowded and I live around the corner, I typically get it to go. When I get it to go, I have had nothing but bad experiences. 

The first time, the food was put on plates, and then when I asked where my order was - I saw them quickly shuffle it into to-go boxes as they realized it was to-go. Hence to say, hardly even warm food. 

The second time, my order was completely wrong. As in not one thing correct. I called, complained, the guy on the phone was really rude and wasn't willing to correct the mistake. 

Today, though, was the final straw. I got there at 3:30. It was empty, no lines, nothing. I ordered to-go and though the food was hot and fresh, part of my order was still wrong again. And the same thing happened on the phone.

Hence to say, unless I have  wheat free company, it will probably be a VERY long time before I go here again.
author: Benjamin P.

description:
If I lived nearby, I'd be here once a week. Anything that starts with "cornbread" and ends with "pulled pork" has a special place in my stomach! Throw in some avocado and how could you not love it? The prices of sandwiches are hard to beat, so why not throw in some Yucca fries to complement a greasy sandwich?

Great for the stomach. Not for your health. But that's okay on occasion.
author: Adam D.

description: Wow! Mind blowing food! You have to get the beef pabellon cachapa. Great portions too!
author: Zahra N.

description:
Not for me - but then again I've never been big on corn tortillas nor do I have to deal with the Crohn's.

Impressions: oily, from the chachapas to the shrimp soup.  The pulled pork, even with the huge chunks of avocado, was nothing to talk about, and the chorizo and beef had peculiar flavors.  I did enjoy their special hot sauce though, and although I wasn't blown away by Pica PIca,  I didn't have to pay to much to experience it.
author: Irene C.

description: My first time trying Venezuelan food and I like it!  I got the cachapa with chicken (#6).  Yummy and filling!
author: Michelle P.

description:
My dad is allergic to glutton, so I took him here with my siblings for Father's Day when they came up to visit from the South Bay. I had the La Vegetariana Arepa - which was delicious! I think it had tofu, plantains and some other good stuff inside. We also split some yucca fries and queso and moreno empanadas. I like the way they prepare their empanadas - they were crispier than I've usually had and pretty small (they come in a set of 3) so it's a nice dish to share as an appetizer. I'd recommend the spicy cream sauce with it!

The only downside was that there was limited seating, but then again it was Father's Day, and also they messed up our empanada order and gave us an extra meat empanada instead of a black bean one (I'm vegetarian, but my family is not)  - it wasn't a big deal so I didn't hassle with saying anything.

If you are looking for a good glutton-free place definitely check it out!
author: Daniel M.

description:
Pica Pica Pooooo I choose you.  But not really.  Well ok, I chose to eat at you today to celebrate my 50th Yelp review with everyone's favorite J S (and her posse).      

Anyhow, all the reviews I read about this place are mostly wrong.  It's neither too greasy, too crowded,  great, OR gross.  It's just kind of ok.  I had the Pelu'a without cheese in the Arepas sandwich thing.  The pulled pork itself was well made and juicy, complementing the dry Arepas.  Quite tasty.  Unfortunately, that was pretty much it for tastiness. The Yuca fries should have just been called Yuky fries cause they were dry and flavorless.  I should also mention that the price was $10, for something that left me hungry, which is kind of iffy in my book!  But still, since the one main thing was yum, the place gets a Triple Pica Pica Star!
author: Leon K.

description: Tasty arepas...if you haven't tried these yet, a very flavorful creation...subtle heat and complexity in each bite...
author: Richard D.

description:
Clearly my friend Stephan's skirt steak maizeathon was far more aMAIZEing than my MAIZEwellhavebeencrap vegetariano tour de maize. Ok, enough corny Maize plays on words (see what I did: CORNY??). 

I digress...just say no unless you really like empty flavorless calories served up in a very Ferry-Building-esque outlet with decent service, clean bathrooms, and not another damn redeeming quality. Everything is overpriced and nothing tastes as good as it sounds. Why? Because this is a CONCEPT restaurant, folks. Not at real, solid cultural or technique-based joint. It's a shame, too, because it might be the sleekest, closest yuppie-friendly lunch spot in my new work neighborhood. The empanadas are particularly disappointing.

Excuse me while I take a bottle of laxatives to try and eradicate these useless calories from the temple that is my body.
author: Autumn K.

description:
I have never had Venezuelan food so I can't compare it but there were quite a few Venezuelans in there sporting the flag.  

The yucca fries were delish, the empanadas were almost empty inside - the meat mix flavor is one I wouldn't order again & the beans were good but it needed about 3x as much as a filling.  

We also ordered the bean cachapa & beef arepa.  Both were very good.
author: N A.

description:
The fact that this place doesn't have 5 stars is amazing to me!

As someone who has strictly followed a gluten/dairy-free diet for the past 6 years, I can safely say, this is one of my favorite places... ever. Not only is everything %100 GF (gluten-free), it's also ridiculously delicious. This is heaven for a person like myself.... not to mention they serve my favorite kind of GF beer, Bard's.

Even if you are able to eat gluten & dairy, I would highly recommend this place. 

PS. Get the Yuca Fries!!
author: Taylor F.

description: Love the maizewich with pork, tomato and avo! I love places where you order at the counter, and this is one. They are quick, have beers on tap, and I never spend more than 10 dollars. HOLE IN ONE!
author: Julia D.

description:
I had a Maize'wich a bit over a year ago at the Glen Park street fair stand that Pica Pica set up.  I was completely blown away and I couldn't wait to get home and look them up on the internet.  But I was only disappointed to find out the only one they had was in Napa, so it was kinda a bit far for me to go there just for a maize'wich/cachapa.  With that said, I was super excited when my gf told me that they are opening one up in the city.  After waiting around for months, it finally opens, and we couldn't wait to get there.

So we took a couple of friends with us and headed up to the city for dinner on a Monday night.  We got there around 8pm and the place was still pretty packed.  The place is definitely leaning towards the small size, I could imagine a group of 5 or more would have problem getting a table to sit together.  

So my gf and I both got a different cachapa and both were great.  She had the pabellon and I had the pernil.  We also ordered 2 glasses of sangria and an order of enpanadas (3).  The sangria came in a rather small glass and quite frankly a bit over priced.  The enpandas were a bit bland, we would probably skip them next time.  

But the cachapas were amazing.  The size was decent even though I've read reviews that some felt they could be bigger.  The meat were tender and the ingridents were fresh.  I really like the sweet corn flour that they used.  I think it might not be a sizable dinner for people who has a bigger appetite, a maize'wich to me would make a perfect lunch for both size and price.

We also ordered the yucca fries and they were really good.  We had the aioli sauce, highly recommended.

The day we went they were also having some problem with their POS, and some orders didn't print out for the kitchen staff, so we were waiting around for a while only to having to tell the server what we ordered.  But I'll let that slide since they pretty much just opened and I understand they still need time to iron out some stuff.  Also the staff seems to be a bit overwhelmed that day, maybe due to the POS failure, and didn't really get around busing the empty tables till a while later.  Even so, the staff were really friendly and really helpful.

I will definitely give it another try maybe in a month or so and see if they have their stuff together a bit better.

But overall, based on the fact that it's a new store and how yummy the food was, I think they deserve a 4 star review on my first visit.
author: Anthonio C.

description: My girl and I were craving Venezuelan food so we decided to come to Pica pica. I order an arepa with pork and she got the chicken cachapa. I also order the fried yucca with guasacaca. The food look great but it lack in flavor. The Arepa was too thick and I could only taste corn so where did the pork flavor go? I guess there was no love in this arepa. Her cachapa was cold and not seasoned. The fried yucca wasn't crunchy as it should be  and their guasacaca tasted more like a cheap version of guacamole without the tomato, onions, cilantro and lime! Really?!! This place doesn't make food with love!  Not coming again
author: Christian P.

description:
I haven't been to their restaurant, but they had a food booth at the Millbrae Arts and Wine Festival (stop laughing!  It was actually pretty fun!).  I've never had Venezuelan food, but this makes me want to try more!

A-maize-ing.

I got the chicken/avocado salad maizewich and yucca fries.  The chicken-avo salad wasn't greasy, and the chicken was perfectly done.  I should have skipped the fries because I was barely able to finish the sandwich, but they were great.  Sweeter and about twice as dense as potatoes, served with a spicy ketchup.  The lunch was a bit of a gut bomb, despite having skipped breakfast and walking around for a few hours, so I bet it would be the perfect dinner to start a night of pub crawls.  I will definitely be checking out their Valencia Street location!
author: Jen D.

description:
The manager at Skunk Funk led my travel partner and me to Pica Pica Maize Kitchen when we asked her for a dinner recommendation. I'm glad we trusted her opinion, as this Mission gem served me a unique, filling and gluten-free meal. The main options comprise cornbread-filled treats: the Arepa, a grilled corn flatbread; the Maize'wich, a grilled sweet cornbread; and the Cachapa, a sweet corn pancake. I pointed longingly at one of the sample items in the display case--the Pabellón. Stuffed with shredded skirt steak, sweet plantains, black beans and cheese, this quesadilla-like Arepa variation confused and delighted my bored palate. My companion raved about his chicken salad Maize'wich; pieces of corn jutted out of the bread, while the chicken salad sat creamy and smooth with mushed-up avocado. 

I found the bathroom situation interesting, as the key hung on a shelf outside the door. Why even have a key if it's so accessible? I liked the hook fastened to the inside of the powder room door: a brown distressed hand.

I wish a Pica Pica would come to Atlanta, not only because I've never eaten anything like the Pabellón but also because the city sorely lacks gluten-free eating from what I've heard.
author: Bobbin W.

description:
Pica Pica is a Venezuelan maize sandwich place. I suppose they're actually more like tortas. You get to choose from 3 different corn patties for your little sandwich, but we had the "Arepas" on all of them since it seemed to be the least bulky. We then realized that with their prices, the coupon I had was actually going to get us a ton of food. We ended up getting four of the sandwiches (two pork, tomato, and avocado; one skirt steak with plantains and black beans, one chicken and cheese) and a few empanadas (pork/chicken/beef, black beans, and tilapia).

The sandwiches were all really good, but the maize bread was very thick. I would have preferred if it was thinner like a tortilla so it didn't over power the filling so much. The pork/chicken/beef empanada was also amazing. The tilapia one smelled a little fishy (no pun intended..) so we didn't finish that one. My friend was also a big fan of the signature hot sauce on both the sandwiches and the empanadas.

Overall the place was really good and worth checking out.
author: Nicole L.

description:
The entire place (minus most of the beers) are gluten free! What a fantastic thing for a celiac like me!

Pros:
1. Lots of choices. Even for veggies.
2. The food is always warm and fresh and seasoned to perfection.
3. It's a fun thing to introduce more people to.
4. The plantains are fantastic!

Cons:
1. It can be extremely hard to find a table at times.
2. It's hard to go with a group because of the table situation.
3. It is a bit more cost wise than a tacqeria, for example.
4. A can of diet coke is $1.75! :(
5. They close at 10. I wish they stayed open later.

My foodie buddy gets the #3, I get the #6. They are good and safe choices. I like the arepa and the cachapa, the other half enjoys the maize'wich and the cachapa.  I ordered the salad, she ordered the plantains and we each had a diet coke. The total was 30 dollars, which for lunch is kinda expensive in my book.
author: Carla S.

description: Delectable arepas for a really fair price. Love this place! plus theyre open pretty late, and are a good after-work-after-happy-hour bite when no one wants to cook, but eating junk food is just not in the cards
author: Carolina S.

description: The Most Fuego Food your ever going to put in your mouth ! If your near or by Velencia you have to go to this place and order a Arepa  you won't regret it ! Get it before or after you go to Delores Park ! I can't praise this place enough lol my girlfriend got me hooked !
author: Khris T.

description:
I know this review will sound a bit biased coming from a Venezuelan native, but see the bright side:  I can authenticate the food! After 2 years craving my hometown food, I became another Pica Pica's lover who desperately waited for its opening in the City. 

Although it's not 100% the classical Caracas' arepera, the menu is very diverse and representative of the Venezuelan cuisine. Compared to the typical spicy flavor that most of you are looking in Latin American food, the traditional Venezuelan cuisine combines sweet and savory flavors. 

I like the whole menu, but my favorite and recommended flavor for arepas and cachapas is pabellón (our national plate, by the way). Also, I highly recommend the plantains and yuca frita.

The location is great and convenient, and the staff is as we say in Venezuela: "demasiado panas".

I'd love it even more if they served more batidos de frutas (fruit smoothies), cocada, and cerveza or malta Polar, but the hot chocolate is a blast! Very traditional taste. Viva Venezuela!!
author: Silvia Y.

description:
My meal was cold and the bread wasn't nice and fluffy like it was the week Pica Pica opened.

Also, there was some miscommunication of the wrap type I wanted between the order taker and I.
author: John A.

description: Delicious food, quick and friendly service! I had the Vegetarian Maize'wich. Ah-maize-ing :)
author: K P.

description: This place is delish.  I had never tried an arepa before.  It was great.  I am a vegetarian so naturally I got the vegetarian option.  It's a big, warm, yummy pocket of goodness filled with tofu, black beans, plantains.  Kind of messy to eat- hard to pick up.  But once you get it down to a manageable size it's great.  Love the side of slaw they give you as well.
author: Sarah G.

description: The maize-wich is a-maize-ing! (aren't you frustrated that you can't downvote yelp reviews?)
author: Jeremy S.

description: This is the kind of place you want to bring your out of town friends to demonstrate what a cool foodie you are.  Relatively low cost for a unique meal.  I had the arepa with skirt steak, plantains and beans, pretty delish-- albeit a little greasy--but hey, I don't mind a little grease!   The sangria was $6 for a small but delish glass.  And I didn't mind the tall, sweet, cute guy behind the counter either!
author: Amy W.

description:
I'm thrilled to have a new food option right around the corner from my house, but after my third experience here, my feelings for it are only lukewarm. 

1st time: Awesome! Had a cold beer and the Pernil cachapa - subbed spicy sauce for the aioli, and it was all quite pleasant. The pork is super tasty! The salad was a little too sweet, but pretty good/fresh. Dug the empanadas, too.
2nd time: Gross. I was pumped to try their vegetarian option, but it was absolutely dreadful. Did anyone try this before putting it on the menu? 
3rd time: Meh. Got takeout and tried my first arepa. It was dry and dull and made me sad.

Pica Pica I don't love you, but I like you! I think.
author: Stephanie P.

description:
Greasy or juicy?

Interesting, Yelpers.  I wouldn't really call the food here greasy.  I'd more go with "juicy" as a descriptive term.  Either way, I can let that go and give you that these little arepas are a little hard to eat.  I was expecting something more street-foody, but it was nearly impossible to eat my black bean arepa without a knife and fork.  Since that's the case, I feel like we could do without the paper wrapping.. that gets a little gross.

There were a couple good veggie options on the menu, which was great for me.  I also tried some yummy yucca fries as others have mentioned.  Apart from the hard-to-pick-up part, the other downside is coming here with a group.  None of your food comes out at the same time, so it's hard to enjoy the meal together.  It also takes a while for them to make the tasty little sandwiches.

All that said, I'll still be back.  This is a great stop for a quick, cheap, interesting meal in the Mission if your expectations are set accordingly.
author: Gretchen S.

description: First time here and I had the #5, La Shuli with Cachapa bread. It was yummy and my mother-in-law's pulled pork, the Pernil (#7), was great too. The only thing I'd do differently next time would be to pair the sandwiches with the Arepa bread instead of the Cachapa as it was a little too much sweetness overall. The Yuca Fries were soft with a little crisp to them... Perfection! I don't love Pica Pica yet but I could see that happening in the future. Can't wait to try this place again.
author: Jasmin L.

description:
I really wanted to like this place, I was excited about finally trying the food  and oh was I disappointed. Everything seemed to have the potential of being amazing and just didn't do it. 
I ordered the Pabellon chachapa and the filling was delicious but the corn pancake was too oily. I will say they make some great fried plantain! Their bululu salad is also a winner and a must have. I also had some special of the night which was stuffed yuca and not worth trying. Their yuca fries with dipping sauce has potential but that's about it. I tried the garlic yuca fries with the pica pun, great combo (beware too oily) but I was yuca'ed out by the time I was done eating. 
The service was not that good. The guy behind the counter rushed us even though the restaurant was empty. 
Would have been 3 stars if the service was no soo blah.
author: Marie-Claire R.

description:
I came here for lunch today.  The restaurant is very clean and there are a ton of corny puns lining the wall (ahaha pun intended).  Overall I really liked this place. 

Had no idea what to order. Everything sounded great.  They had some samples out, so I pretty much just pointed at the one that looked the best.  Yes, that might be lame when they've got such a straightforward menu to order from, but I guess I'm just a lame person. 

What I ended up with was the Cachapas with Pabellon.  Now, I ordered it take out, so I didn't actually get to eat it for another 30 minutes.  I think that the food might have been a little better fresh, but my oh my was it delicious.  The cachapas were super sweet and delicious.The meat was great and oh those plantains.  The plantains were the best part.  So good.  

The portions for the cachapas are pretty huge.  At some point, I just ended up eating everything on the inside.  Was just so full.  

I also tried the yucca fries.  Delicious.  Definitely worth a try.  What I wasn't so impressed with were the empanadas.  I was SO excited when I found out that they had empanadas, but all I could taste was oil. It wasn't pleasant.  

Prices were reasonable.  It made for an expensivish lunch, but would have been a delicious, delightful and cheap dinner.
author: Alea G.

description:
This place just didn't do it for me.  I was really hoping to find a new joint to add to my workday lunch rounds, but ehh....don't think that's gonna happen.

And I really wanted to love The Pabellon (shredded skirt steak, sweet plaintains, black beans and cheese) but the meat was kinda dry. The plaintains helped with the dry factor though. Those were yummy.

Pepeada (chicken salad with Guasacaca, which is their creamy avocado) wasn't too bad. Thank goodness for the creamy avocado to moisten it up some.

The arepas itself were a bit on the dry side and the fillings didn't have enough flavor. 

And initially, I didn't really care for the yucca fries, but I think it was the best thing yet. It came with their signature hot sauce "Pica'Pun" I mean, who doesn't love anything they can dip their food into?!

Thumbs up: Yucca fries and dips
Thumbs down: dry arepas
author: Heidi L.

description:
Decent lunch place. Think of a Subway set up but with gluten free bread and burrito type fillings. Smallish sized portions and the food was warm but not hot. Though gluten free and somewhat healthy, the fillings didn't seem fresh. However, the side of plantains was a delightful treat. 

There are tables but I would recommend to-go. If you are hungry and in the area, its worth a shot.
author: Halley B.

description:
I will make this quick...I have been here three different times. Two to go, One sit down. I really like what they are offering on the food side of things...the sides, three diff corn wraps and flavors rock. I am always filled and happy ONCE I get the food. 
The service is strange, no one in the rest. and it takes 20 min for one sandwich order. Again, the skirt stake and plantanes are worth the wait if you get it hot and fresh, the service is not.
I would hate to see the place packed and to experience the service then.
Okay, I bumped it from two to three stars because the product is great. One suggestion, order by phone for pick up!
The other thing, almost $9-$10 per main 'wich is about $2-$3 high on the price point, I am just saying.
Good luck, try communicating with each other for faster service and happy corn to you!
author: Joe Bob J.

description:
Very pleased with Pica Pica would be an understatement. Finally, a decent walkable lunch option! Their ingredients play along the fine line between sweet and savory, often combining fall off the bone meats with the slightly tangy taste of plantains. 

Their empanadas were soli although a bit oily.. They looked delicious, but I found them a bit too much for a lunch, and I ended up spending the rest of the afternoon fighting a food-coma.

Their maizewhich, with the natural sugars of the corn, was hands down my favorite. 

The Pabellon (skirt steak, plantains, black beans, cheese), and Pernil (pulled pork, tomatoes, avocado, aioli) were probably my favorite fillings.

Tip: if you like things a little spicy, make sure you get the Pica Pun sauce with whatever you eat. That firers little sauce takes every dish and elevates it to another level.

The space is a bit tight, but it's clean and cute.
author: Cristofer P.

description: Agree with the other yelpers - this place is GREASY. The arepas are dripping with grease. It's gross. The kitchen they are cooking in is NOT clean at all and the woman in front taking orders could care less about the customers. She is more interested in chatting it up with the chef. The arepas are sloppily made with their so-called aioli glopped on one little piece of one of the sides of the arepa. It took 20 minutes to get one sandwich and the place was practically empty. I should have known when I walked in by the lack of customers that this place wasn't worth it. I think I will have indigestion for the next 3 days. Ugh. Grease-fest!!!
author: H M.

description:
This place is great! Eat here before everyone knows about it and it's insanely busy! 

I got the maize'wich with ham and cheese, and my friends and I shared assorted empenadas and yucca fries. The hot sauce / salsa is awesome. I felt the prices were reasonable as well. The portions seemed a little small but in the end this was fine because the food is very heavy and filling. 

Will definitely be eating here a lot more.
author: Beth D.

description: 4:30 on a Saturday. Walk in with friend who is ravenous. Order food. There is no other order in front of us. Watch as the three people in the kitchen do EVERYTHING but prepare friend's sandwich. 25 minutes later food arrives. Tastes good and is gluten free (bonus star). Kick myself for not learning the last time I was in.
author: Ed F.

description: The Maize'Wich with #3! Eat. Love will occur. Then you should get a frequent dining card. I love free stuff.
author: Chris Y.

description:
Terrible. Second time I went there. The first time was around when it opened, so it wasn't as bad. This time around, the food was cold, the "pita" was kind of hard. The plantains were soggy and sorry looking. Think dark brown wet sock. Nasty.

The display items in the glass had flies all over them. I picked out cutlery for our table, half the items were dirty and had dried hard food remains on them.

Will never go there again. There is nothing redeeming about this place. Warm garbage.
author: Anish B.

description:
Was in town to shop for a new Ducati across the street at Monroe Motors and decided to try Pica Pica out.  My husband ordered the chicken yellow corn wrap which he loved and was reluctant to share with me (whatever). He also had a veggie yellow corn Arepas which he said was his favorite.  I went with the white corn Arepas, grilled chicken and a steak.  Mine were good but I would definitely go back for the yellow corn version of both.  The passion fruit and mango juices we tried were both too tart but the fried Yucca was very tasty. 
Parking on Valencia is beyond challenging but walking to and from our car gave us the chance to find this and other neighborhood gems.  We will be back with family and friends.
author: K V.

description: The food is very good and the price is great. MIssion in one of my are place in San Francisco, so you have to try Pica Pica!
author: Fabio D.

description:
The food is great! The staff is nice. The ambiance is ok. I can see why other reviewers mention that the atmosphere kinda feels like a franchise.

Onto the food! The chachapa is to die for with the pebellon, chicken salad, or the chicken sofrito filling. Their white sangria is also yum yum. The side salad is very unique and tasty, but a little on the sweet side, and the yucca fries are delish. For vegetarians, LOTS of options :)

They're new and obviously still working out some kinks. I've been twice and both times they have forgotten to give me the drinks I ordered, but that's ok. Once they get into the swing of things, maybe it'll be a 5 star review.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
As an arepa LOVER, I decided to try Pica Pica today for the first time. The menu looked fantastic.

Overall, 3 stars. I ordered the Bululu salad and the #4 La Vegetariana Arepa.
The counter service and food service was great, very friendly.
The salad was fresh and tasty. Good combination of ingredients and I like that they give you the dressing on the side so you can decide how much you want (it was really really good dressing).
The arepa was good, but greasier and more charred than most that I've had. The sweet plantains inside were DELICIOUS. Next time I'll order a side of just plantains. Yum. I wish they would've had a more salsa-esque salsa rather than fancy ketchup. Some spicy pico de gallo and at least one fresh ingredient would've made the dish much better.
author: crystel s.

description: This review is a little late, but I was there 2 months ago, my wife had seen it on DDD and thought I'd love it...well I did! I was born and raised in Venezuela and this is as close as you can get to real Venezuelan food, the other good place I know of is in Vegas, so anyway I say as close as you can get to Real Venezuelan food because as someone who makes his own empanadas, arepas and cachapas at home you find yourself making due with items that will work close enough because you just cant get it in the US, you can't get Queso Guayanes or you gotta use crappy California Avocados in lieu of the tastier more flavorful South American Avocados,  that said  the food was great and it was a great experience that brought me close to a home I have not been to in over 20 years, the only reason I didn't give 5 stars is because the one other thing I REALLY wanted was the fried Yuca and they were out. I visit the city from time to time so I'll be back and try again. thanks for the good food, the friendly service and the fresh taste of home.
author: Bryan L.

description: They changed their menu! I would NOT recommend this place anymore at all. It was 4 stars easily before and now... I am just torn that this wonderful restaurant has become a shithole. It's food used to be delicious and for a great price. And now, it is on a good day vaguely mediocre.
author: Emily M.

description:
Heard rave reviews from a coworker as well as online so thought I would check it out. Went for dinner with a friend though the 'wait in line, order and we'll bring it to your table' seems to be better for a quick lunch thing. I prefer full service at dinner. 

The 100% corn pancake was super tasty. I had mine with the pulled pork. The pork was a bit bland and not as tender as I hoped. I was just hoping for more flavor. 

The empanadas we ordered were OK. They definitely had more flavor inside but they were quite greasy. 

The yuca fries were amazing.. by far the best thing we ate. But the dipping sauces were definitely uninspired - ketchup, chipotle aoili, tartar sauce, boring, boring. 

For a quick lunch, I might go back. Hopefully there is more 'flavor' next time.
author: Philip D.

description: Love the food here. It's a little pricey for counter service, but is fresh and delicious.
author: Cody H.

description:
Decent arepas at a reasonable price. Good atmosphere. 

The cachapa was a major disappointment, though. It was doughy and not brown enough. The cheese was not the kind used in Venezuela; the flavor much too strong, and only half of it was melted. 

If the chef is reading this, I think you could use more salt everywhere.
author: Halle L.

description:
Central American/Venezuelan food that has been yuppified. I was going to say healthy but given that many things are fried, it's not exactly light cuisine. 

The online menu doesn't reflect the current prices or offerings (note: on the mobile version of yelp/website). Prices are more expensive (empanadas are now $4.50, there is no side offering with the entrees for $3.25 anymore--just the full priced sides). Their granitas are just juice (a granita in my world is a akin to an upscale slushy--ground or shaved ice--these granitas were your standard juice with ice cubes--at $4, it's a rip off). 


I had higher expectations for this place. The food was good but for a lunch tab totaling nearly $40, it just didn't live up. Next time I'm craving central american/venezuelan food, I'll probably check out a mom and pop dive for a fraction of the price. (oh yeah, and I think that a lot of this cuisine is already gluten free because it's corn based so that's just a marketing gimmick!).

I wanted to be a-maize-d but this was just ok.
author: J L.

description: Very unique place. Just make sure you inquire about the type of arepa you're having. I ended up having one which was extremely spicy (at least for me). Otherwise, staff is great, service is fast and location isn't bad either.
author: James H.

description: Man it was gooood. I ordered maize bread with "6. Catira: chicken with our signature guiso base, gouda cheese" as a filling boy it was tasty. it looks kinda small but its not  and it's very filling. My niece had pulled pork and it was just as tasty, We also had yuca fries and i really like the dip i'm guessing it was habanero? and definitely would recommend for lunch, dinner, quick bite. !!
author: Gonzalo O.

description: Very tasty! For someone that is eating vegan and gluten-free right now, this place hits the spot; although, it involves me make some alterations. I had the Vege Maize`wich sans creamy sauce.
author: Brian S.

description: Very tasty food and very different style of food. Location is a bit off the beaten path which means it's not too crowded which is great. Also veg and gluten free options which makes lots of friends happy.
author: Nicole S.

description: I've been to Pica Pica twice now, and I always get the Maize'wich.  Its pretty hard for me to stray from that crispy sweet crunch stuffed with the savory and juicy beef, fried plantains, beans and gooey cheese (pabellon). The other filling I've had is the pulled pork with tomato and avocado.  Although I'm not a big fan of fried things, you just can't go wrong with the garlic yuca fries or the fried sweet plaintains covered in queso fresca.  Next time my friend Katelyn gets one, I'll probably have to steal a bite.  I just can't resist.
author: D. K.

description:
Yummy.  I've never had Venezuelan food before so I can't attest to how authentic the food is.  However, it was delicious.  I had the Cachapa which remind me of a thick corn pancake.  It's sweet and savory all at once.  I liked the yucca fries, however, I've had far better before.  The empanadas (sorry can't spell) were okay.  Once again I've had better.

As for the service.  It's one of those places where you order and pay at the register and they bring the food out.  It was busy while we were there so they ended up bringing out the wrong order which wasn't too great, but understandable.  

I have to end with my favorite part of the meal- the lime coconut slushie.....SO AWESOME!!!!  You must get the slushie!!!  I've been craving it ever since Ive had it!
author: Rose T.

description:
Two words: NOM. NOM.

After an afternoon of exploring the Mission with a friend, we were starving. My friend had been introduced to arepas in NYC, and was eager to find a place in California that measured up to what she was used to. We both ordered the Pabellon arepa - beef, cheese, black beans, and plantains (!!) - basically everything I want in a meal. All the flavors worked so well together; it was delish and filling. Also got the side of plantains (because you can never have too many plantains, let's be honest) which was great. They were soft, but not gooey, sweet, but not cavity-inducing. But my favorite thing (which is saying a lot) was the white wine passion fruit sangria. Definitely hit the spot on a hot day and was the perfect complement to the rest of the meal. One thing to note...this place is super tiny - just 4 or 5 tables and a counter area with barstools. When we came it wasn't super crowded, but I imagine it could be a problem when the place is poppin'. Service was basic, but quick.

My friend even said she liked this place better than her usual arepa spots back in NY. Will definitely be back when I get the chance (hopefully sooner than later, because looking at their menu just now has got me craaaaving).
author: Jessica A.

description: The Pasta Princess has gone gluten free (the body insisted!) and I am so grateful to Yelp for the gluten free in San Francisco listings. I tried Pica Pica yesterday and my first impression was 5-star. Had the Pulled Pork sandwich on one of their delicious and exotic corn flour breads (NO DAIRY, EITHER!) and was just in heaven. Lovely guava juice accompanied, great service, fun and clean environment, and hey, next time i might try the Sangria, too! THANK YOU SO MUCH, PICA PICA! Also walking distance to one of my favorite music venues, Martuni's, so you KNOW i'll be back!
author: Lua H.

description:
Awesome yucca friends and just good overall unique menu.  Seating and noise in the restaurant is a crazy turn off...terrible place to have a conversation and is always full but people are in and out quickly enough.  

Have to say, in the last 2 months of being open they have raised their prices twice already so I hope their success doesn't go to their head
author: hatti l.

description:
We stopped in here for dinner this past weekend and it was great!  The beans were amazing and the coconut rice was really good.  A friend had the corn sandwich with beef inside and it was really flavorful with just the right amount of sweet and salty.  We all loved the cole slaw because it is made with vinegar (not mayonaise) and had a good cilantro taste.

The mojo sauce that they have on the tables is amazing!

Excellent food for the price, too.
author: Karen H.

description: Great customer service. Food was just ok. Had shredded beef arepa, spicy chicken arepa, and yuca fries. Beverages were very tasty (mango fresca, passion fruit fresca, sangria, passion fruit sangria). I personally would not return. Was not impressed by the food.
author: Mandy H.

description:
My husband and I drive to the Oxbow Market in Napa just to eat Pica Pica.  We were extremely happy to find out they were opening a location in San Francisco, not too far from our house.  We went to the new location this weekend, and were not disappointed.  I had the Pabellon Arepa w/ Yucca fries... AMAZING!! 

We look forward to many great Venezuelan meals in San Francisco!!
author: Zoe J.

description:
Tonight was my first visit to Pica Pica.  I went with a friend who suggested it because she needs gluten-free options.

Not haven eaten much Venezuelan food, the menu items were all new to me, but there are helpful explanations on their menu board.  You do sort of assemble your order from multiple columns, however, so consider giving yourself a minute to make your selections before you get to the front of the line.

I had the arepas (cornmeal patty) with pelu'a (shredded skirt steak with cheese) and a salad.  Everything was very tasty!  I didn't find the pelu'a especially spicy despite it being marked as such, but it was very flavorful regardless.  The salad was also very good (with nice dressing), but be warned that it's almost a full dish unto itself.

Seating is somewhat limited, but we luckily grabbed a table before it filled to capacity.  Because of the table layout, I wouldn't recommend trying to go with more than four people during their busy hours.  Couples shouldn't have a problem.
author: Jon P.

description: Pica Pica is one of my favorite quick places to eat in San Francisco.  Plus its nice that their menu is Gluten Free which definitely allows me to eat with one of my best friends, Lauren S.  The food here is pretty delicious...everything is cooked to order and the flavors are rich and savory.  My favorite thing to order is the Arrepa with the shredded beef and cheddar cheese.  Of course you have to add the plantains and avocado to complete the sandwich!  I also order a salad to complete the meal...the passion fruit dressing rocks!  All of this food for less than $15.00 is quite a bargain in this city!  Other worthwhile mentions are the empanadas (you get three), the plantains and the yucca fries (the dipping sauces are pretty amazing as well).  Definitely grab a bite to eat, especially if you don't see a line...this place gets pretty packed!
author: Joel C.

description:
I discovered Pica Pica the night I found out that Ramblas had closed... yes, that is very sad. But anyways, walking down the street in dejection, we chanced upon this cute little place and decided to give it a try. I've never had Venezuelan fast food before, but if the food here is anything to go by, I think I'd like it :) I had the Vegetariana maize'wich (I can't pass up sweet corn bread...) - it was pretty amazing. I love what they did with the tofu - good marinade. Also tried the empanadas which were great - and the spicy cream salsa was delicious.
One complaint - the sangria was pretty bad. Don't bother with it unless the owners read this and make changes. 

All in all, I'll be adding this to my list of "quick food" places. Somewhat pricy for a sandwich-type meal, but good food!
author: What's in a nam e.

description:
Sunday was an exceptionally beautiful day...after a few days of rain.  The heart of the mission was packed and we couldn't find a parking space anywhere...so we ended up at Pica Pica at the edge of restaurant row.  

I've always wanted to try this place...and parking was plentiful.  I ordered a maize'wich with pepeada, and a side of pasapalos with morena.  Wow...outrageously delicious.  Everything was fresh and flavorful.  In plain English, I ordered a sweet corn bread sandwich filled with chicken salad mixed with creamy avocado, in addition to (fresh) garlic yucca fries with a black bean paste.   

Oh yeah, I'll definitely be back to try the rest of their menu.
author: L. L.

description:
Super delicious. The yucca fries are unreal, and the sweetness of the corn pancakes is addictive.

Instantly one of the best places in an area already crammed  with great food options.
author: Andrew L.

description:
A-Ok experience. If you are looking for decent and good variety of Arepas Venezolanas, perhaps this is the only place in the city that has them. Good to have something new around. 

At the same time, the place was a little over priced in my opinion. Offering vs Cost, we were 2 people, we had 2 arepas, 1 cocktail a beer rounding up to 30 bucks.

30 bucks is an average for a Thai food restaurant or Sushi place and there is no comparison between an arepa and what you could get at the others.

i would come back only if I want to take someone that has never try arepas before.
author: Juan Camilo R.

description: OMG! YUMMMMMMM! I had just seen the Triple D episode last week and had to visit. The ALL GLUTEN FREE menu was a super bonus for me! I had the vegetariana Cachapa. I ordered ahead of time for Pick-Up through Yelp, not knowing what the line would be like. I tried adding the Yuca beignets, but they were out of them. Good sign and I will definitely going back to try them! The Cachapa was soooooo incredibly good, especially with the garlic aioli (and they give you extra to take with you). I will definitely try them again and again. I only gave them 4 stars because of the service being a tad slow. I'm glad I ordered for pickup because they didn't have a line when I got there, but had one going out the door by the time I left. It appears Triple D did such a good job, they may need to hire more people. 3 people doing everything seemed a bit much, but they were happy and did everything with a smile on their faces :)
author: Sara H.

description: Good food but terrible service. Cashier didn't know what a "wine cocktail" was which is on the menu, and rudely told our party that there were no specials when the board again specified that there was a special of the day. She also failed to inform us that they had ran out of an ingredient in the meal we ordered; simply placed it in front of me and walked away.. I would recommend knowing your menu better and keeping customers informed of any Changes. Unfortunately would not recommend this place..
author: Veronica G.

description:
The food here is pretty good, and deceptively filling. The ingredients are all very fresh and tasty. The plantains are outstanding.

When it's crowded, the place feels a bit overwhelmed.
author: George S.

description: My introduction to Pica Pica Maize Kitchen came via the Maker Faire.  Though the line as well as the wait was long, it was definitely worth it!  I had the arepa (a flat, round, unleavened patty made of cornmeal which can be grilled, baked, or fried) and stuffed with pernil (pulled pork, sliced tomatoes, and avocado).  Everything was so delicious from the freshly grilled, hot, crispy, arepa to the juicy pulled pork and avocado.  Now I wished I had also ordered the yucca fries!  Can't wait to visit the actual restaurant in the near future!
author: Lupe M.

description: The food was really good and tasty, but overpriced, I felt. Two arepas in Venezuela probably set you back $3. Here, I paid $26 for two meals and one soda for lunch. I would go back, but I just think it's overpriced.
author: Amanda D.

description: It has been less than a year since i realized that some of the crappy stuff going on in my body has to do with a gluten sensitivity and so I'm still finding my way around 'gluten free'.  Went here because I knew I could order anything on the menu and had cachapas pepeada and the meat empanadas.  The empanadas were a special treat because I thought pastry stuffed with yummy things and then fried was out forever because of the gluten - no samosas, no empanadas, no pot stickers, do dumplings........Surprise - these empanadas were really tasty and it's where I'll go next time I want fried, filled savoury pastries.  Both dishes were delicious and I hope to be back soon to sample some more of the cachapas fillings.  On the other hand.....not too soon....it's still the kind of food that makes you a little soft and roly poly but that doesn't mean it isn't very yum.  I liked it very much.
author: Kamaljit B.

description: Im Colombian, and I had been looking for a place where I could eat my dear Arepas and the Arepas here are amazing but they're Venezuelan. I recommend the beef and plantains Arepa, it's just delicious! The service was also great! Love it!
author: Natalia Q.

description:
I've been to both the Napa and SF Mission locations several times. I love the combination of the flavors in their sandwiches...but the maizewich with beef and plantains is truly exceptional. 

It's definitely worth spending a few cents more for the food given the quality ingredients they use. Plus it's a great change from the standard Mexican food that's available all over the Mission.
author: melissa c.

description: Amazing place!  So happy this is by our office so we can go for lunch whenever we want!  Everyone is in love - sandwiches are yummy, potatoes (OMG!) and the service is great!  New favorite!
author: Michelle H.

description: Ok. The entire restaurant is gluten free. For that reason they had me at hello. But the food was good too. I am not exactly familiar with South American food and it ook us a while to finalize our order, there were so many options we just couldn't decide. Everything was good. In particular the veggie arepa.   I was a little put off by the presence of hoboes roaming around the restaurant, panhandling  but I guess tolerance is a good property and the owners have some compassion for those less fortunate. if you are gluten free, or a fan of Venezualan cuisine, or both, it is well worth a trip.
author: hunter j.

description:
I went here yesterday and had the Bululu Salad and Coconut Lime drink and have to say I enjoyed it.  My Daughter didn't seem to have enjoyed her's to much, I'm sure you'll hear from her.  Now their Tajadas, I didn't care for at all.

Oh!  When you finish with your meal you need to bus your own dishes.
author: Naomi H.

description: The food was really good. I left feeling full but not gross, which is often custom after eating Mexican cuisine.  It was my first time eating Venezuelan food so i did have some questions.  The person who took my order was not super happy to answer my questions but all and all a good experience.  I will definitely go back.
author: Malia M.

description:
It's all about branding and marketing folks.

What I love about Pica Pica is that they have been able to skillfully re-brand Venezuelan staple dishes to the bay area crowd. It fits and it fits very well. It's the best internationalization attempt of arepas and cachapas. Pica Pica's appeal attracts a blend of people- and that my friend is called success. 

I'm sure they will figure out customer service kinks like any other restaurant as time progresses.

Look forward to seeing the restaurant flourish.
author: Robersi A.

description: I haven't tried this place and never will. They are calling themselves ambassadors of Venezuelan cuisine. Charging $8-10.75 for an arepa or cachapa is like charging the same for a hot dog. Arepas are street food for the common person. What's worse is that they're adding to the gentrification of the Mission. I used to be able to afford to live there before it became hip. I wonder what percentage of their clientele is Latin-American. I wouldn't be so annoyed if they said they were ambassadors of the Venezuelan bourgeoisie or the petite-yanquis. This is not a restaurant for working-class blokes, like myself.
author: Ivan N.

description:
Pica Pica's a bit far from my office for lunch, but I had to go pick up some Four Barrel coffee beans to send down to friends in LA. Honestly, I wish I would have tried it earlier! I was a bit worried about the menu including chunks of broken lightbulbs, hair, and dirt from the name, but thankfully, not a sign of anything inappropriate on the menu or in the food....  http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pica_%28disorder%29
They've got a really pleasant corner space in the Mission, which isn't very big, but they have tables outside for nice days. For my first lunch outing, I had the arepa, filled with pulled pork, and a side of yuca fries. They brought back memories of growing up in Miami - the arepa was nice, moist, sweet corn patties with lots of whole corn kernel, and the pulled pork was very (perhaps a bit too) juicy, and flavorful, with just a bit of spice and heat. It came with some green salad on the side, dressed with just a bit of citrus dressing, and awesome, crusty, crunchy, starchy yuca fries. If you haven't had yuca before, it's kind of like a really starchy, dense potato. It came with a garlicky white herb dressing, and I also ordered their spicy ketchup, which was excellent. The portions, IMO, were just perfect - some might call them a bit small, but this food is a bit on the heavy side. However, everything went down perfectly with a pint of ice-cold IPA.
author: Kevin P.

description:
I've eaten almost everything on the menu and I haven't had a bad experience yet nor do I expect one.

Love this place! Food is sooo good, fills the belly and for the quality and freshness of the ingredients the price isn't THAT bad.

Parking close by kind of sucks, since I am coming from Burlingame but it's definitely worth the drive!
author: Nyle J.

description: We ate at a ton of places in SF during a city venture, but this was the most stand out grub of the 7x7. Tucked away in the Mission area and just blocks away from Bi-Rite. Highly recommended. Cachapa's are ridiculously tasty on the sweet side. The Maize's were also tasty as hell.
author: James N.

description:
Made a few new friends yesterday and after we hit a bar (Elbo Room - clever name and really cheap beer during happy hours. But that's another review), one of them reminded us that we hadn't had dinner yet. It wasn't very late really, but hey, 'm always in for food. So, we gave her the responsibility of taking us to a good place (which, trust me, should put a lot of pressure on your shoulders). After walking around a bit in the Mission/Valencia area it was like she suddenly had a vision (or whatever) to go to Pica Pica - she'd been there before and had loved it. One of the best epiphanies I've seen in others, ever. (okay that might be a bit of an exaggeration).

Pica Pica serves something unique, at least to me. I haven't had/seen that anywhere else before. It is like a not-so-fluffy pancake (the one I had was made of Maize - the semi-sweetness was lovely!) cut horizontally through the center and opened up like Pacman, whose mouth's filled with sheer awesomeness. The awesomeness in my case was mostly shredded beef and friend ripe-plantains. Fried Plantains! I tell ya, I miss that thing a LOT. The maize-wich (as they call it) was overall really good and apparently is gluten-free (which doesn't really make any difference to me, but hey 'm just throwing it out there in case it helps).
