The only problem I had was that the quantity you get, especially for the price you pay, is pretty limited. I could've easily eaten two of them maize-wiches (and I wasn't even really hungry, ha). Also, not something they could control, but we had to sit outside coz all tables inside were taken, and it was really cold!

Definitely a must eat place. Unique and delicious.
As an added bonus, they have funny names for some food items. If you don't think 'Bululu' is funny, you're wrong.


PS: The good food experience means I might have made a friend for life ha.
author: Pravin P.

description: Loved this place!!.. i live in a town where theres not alot of gluten free resturants so when i came here i was in heaven and ordered almost everything off the menu! everything so good and fresh!!! the only disapointment was they didnt have gluten free beer anymore.  but if your gluten free and want really good food this is the place i cant wait to go back!  dont be scared by the menu if your not used to it just order and you will not be disapointed.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Yea! Pica is I believe the first and only cooked food/truly Gluten-free restaurant in the Bay Area. No gluten products are used in any of the dishes or beverages-so there is no issue with cross contamination. Being a celiac, this is now one of only two truly safe/truly gluten-free restaurants I can dine at.

The space is a great location-warm decor. Note: there is a line out the door during "peak" lunch and dinner hours. I can't wait to bring in a large group of friends so we can order everything on the menu-literally, to share. Love the chx maizewich with Yuca fries and the coconut/lemonade granita-all to die for. 

The staff was so helpful in answering all my questions-warm and super friendly.

The cute guy in line behind me admitted he eats lunch there everyday!

Prices reasonable considering it is organic and gluten-free

Hope they add some GF appetizers and desserts?

Three of my friends had dinner, the day after I had lunch and they all raved.

Great all around-cant wait till I am back    Cheers!
author: Michal W.

description: oh yeah! are you kidding me?! everything is gluten free and delish. the Cachapa with beef,plantains, black beans and cheese is bomb diggitttyy. the sweet corn was great. didn't care for the empanadas at all. everything was made to order but they tasted frozen. wouldn't get those. their fresh juices are so good!! I loved the coconut lime drink with ice...reminded me of Thailand. enjoy this south American gluten free gem!
author: Amanda L.

description: GREAT latin food. I had never tried arepas or Venezuelan food in general before coming here but after the trip here for lunch, I was sold! I tried the beef pabellon arepa with the yellow corn masa and it did not disappoint. The combination of the sweet plantains, black beans, perfectly marinated beef, and queso fresco was perfect. The arepa was a pretty decent size. Except I would go with the cachapa if you are more hungry and want something more filling. But overall, the food could not have been better. Super happy I drove out to SF to try this place.
author: Adriana V.

description: Had the fried yuca root fries at the Friday night outdoor food market at the  Marina. Wow. Gluten-free yummy'ness. Next time I want to try the Pabellon shredded skirt steak, yams and the tostones (green banana).
author: Wilson T.

description: If you like arepas, this is the place to go !! Great stuffed venezuelan arepas....
author: Marcela O.

description: The food was phenomenal. I ate every bite, and I was stuffed half-way through. This is a gluten-free establishment, all of their food is made with corn flour. Very easy to get dairy-free food as well. Service was fast, food amazing. Their yucca fries are a must!!
author: Stacy P.

description: Love it! If you like comfort food, Latin food and meat all at the same time, try it.
author: Claudia R.

description:
Another Culinary adventure with Thomas and his mum. And one, i must say that failed to disappoint. 
Whilst planning an afternoon with T-rex and his mum it happened upon me to find a place for us to consume sustenance prior to our viewing of Les Papleues de Cherbourg at the Castro theater. Of course I utilized YELP! to assist me with the task of finding food in the Mission (a part of town T-man and I do not spend a great deal of time in- admittedly) before strolling to the Castro. And I happened upon this place.
Many Yelp reviews will attest to the food being somewhat bland (my menu selection included plantains and ailoi which assisted greatly) as well as being greasy (which it was) However, the food was incredibly filling.
As a person who has celiac disease I was pleased to find this gem of a restaurant with undeniably charming outside seating in front of one of the mission's incredible murals AND in full view of an incredible mural. I ordered the pulled pork Ah-Mazing with plantains and both T.B. and his mum ordered the chicken with Avocado Maize sandwich. 
I struggled to finish the last 1/3 of the sandwich which proved to be tasty (as was the aioli) and rich with flavors that each burst forth through my process of mastication: Avocado, tomato, pulled pork, fried maize, plantains and (when topically applied) ailoi. It was truly a party in my mouth. 
I liked it very much and will return again without fail to try other menu options.
author: Sarah S.

description: If you can get over the TV hype, the corn arepa with pork and avocado is worth trying.  The flavors and texture are unique, but probably not going to send you into food show host heaven.  The corn arepa gets soggy fairly quickly, but doesn't ruin the experience.
author: Martin C.

description: Stopped in here for a snack after a not so filling dinner at Weird Fish. Friend got the cheese empanada and we were both extremely disappointed. Yeah, I know it's gluten free so it's not going to be the same as a regular empanada, but that doesn't mean it has to be crazy greased out and flavorless! Maybe the cheese empanada was not the best flavor choice, but I have a hard time believing that any other empanada would be less greasy. Meh, indeed.
author: Karena Q.

description: Gluten free heaven. Such delicious options, and the guy that helped us was really great.
author: Ali A.

description: What can I say, I love Pica Pica. I first discovered this place when I visited a friend in Napa and it probably was some of the least expensive food in the area. I drove by it when I was visiting San Francisco months later and told my SF friend's about it. We all went for dinner and all of us were in love. I love the sandwiches, this time I tried the pulled pork which is amazing and the garlic yucca fries. Oh why can't more places have garlic yucca fries. In a city that has lots of pho, falafel, and burrito places Pica Pica is refreshing to have some unique ethnic food. Love it and I just wish they would expand down to Los Angeles please.
author: Katherine J.

description: Amazing salads and arepas. Can get pretty busy at lunch time but usually quiet for dinner. Think it's a good value for the money and always delicious.
author: Emily L.

description: Using Caviar, I ordered a variety of Pica Pica Maize Kitchen's dishes.  The shrimp ceviche, beef empanadas, yuca fries (light and crisp) , pulled pork perni were excellent.  I hate coconut as a general rule, but the coconut rice was sooooooo good.  The yuca is not a big portion, but considering that it is an exotic vegetable and that whoever cooked it really knows how to fry to perfection, I savored slowly as I chomped through the crispiness.  (The take-out containers can ruin that, but everything that should be crisp was crisp.) The empanadas are fried also.  They were light enough with a lovely spiced pastry.  One or two of them is like a good sandwich that, with a salad, could be a meal.  There were three.  Too good!  The plan was to have leftovers, but, even though I ate slowly and there was a lot of food, I had a long big dinner and no leftovers.
author: Chris E.

description:
I was HUNGRY and my mouth craved a flavour party and my stomach shouted FEED ME NOW!  I'd been to the Venezuelan inspired Pica Pica Maize Kitchen the week before and had enjoyed it but I wasn't DESPERATE to go back again, it was tasty but not WOW and the tofu in my vegan arepa was too soft and bland.   Nevertheless, I found myself walking back through the doors on Mission Street.  This time I decided to make the menu my own. I smiled with all the sweetness I could muster, as I asked the helpful, but dour, manager for the grilled corn flour cake, the No.5 La Shuli to be stuffed with plantain in addition to the tomatoes, black beans and herbs.  I also caved into my yearnings and  ordered the smashed, crispy plantain cake and the yucca fries, oh and a small side of avocado.

I don't know what happened since the previous week,  but Oh my good GOD!  The food was amazing.  AMAZING.  The arepa was transformed and made a thing of utter bloody perfection by the omission of boring mushy tofu and the take-over by the sweet plantain. A genius move by me (thank you me).  The slightly sweet plantain, the earthy black beans and the finely chopped, herbed tomatoes were a perfect marriage, and their take on guacamole that I smeared with abandon on the roof of the cornbread nearly had me in tears.  My eyes tolled reverentially to the heavens.  I was undone with joy.  Oh Jesus..... and the fries.....oh, bloody hell they were salty, garlicky, crispy and left a yummy film of oiliness on my lips.  Oh feck.  I was in LOVE.  Right in the middle of it; if love was a spinning of flavours and textures and gorgeousness then I was at its CORE.  Ha, ha.  I could of laughed at the joy of it all.  I was so happy I could of danced on the tables and done star jumps all the way to the counter before planting a huge smacker on the chef's fissog and bursting out onto the street to tell the WORLD of the scrumminess I'd discovered!  But...I didn't.  I quietly told the chef he was fabulous and walked out with a smile like you get when you've just had great sex.

GO THERE NOW!
author: Leigh With A Veganobsession X.

description: Sooooo good! Number 3 with the plantains and steak is to die for. Highly recommend.
author: Hanan H.

description:
To be honest, I don't even know how to pronounce half the things on the menu. And I'm not gonna even bother trying- I just point to the display and order. Regardless of what I end up getting- its good.

 I went here for the first time a couple weeks ago- and the yelp reviews here were on point! The sandwiches were so ymmy!  I don't even know what I ordered- but I'm guessing it was the Cachapas with beef and plantain filling. It was amazing! Their empanadas +aoili sauce was another plus! Topped off with a pitcher of passion sangria= wonderful lunch.

 And gluten free? awesome!
author: Cindy L.

description:
as far as i am concerned, this place has a pretty unique thing going on! the food is absolutely fantastic, they were quite quick about serving me, and of course i wish it was cheaper but i am more than happy to pay the price for what i had. 

i had their sandwich on that amazing homemade corn style pita pocket with black beans and chipotle cream sauce, grilled tofu and plantains, and avocado.  BOMB!

also they were willing to let me sample their yucca fries for free and they were delicious!
author: Jasmine F.

description: Ordered the veggie arepa- filled with avocado, tofu and plaintains and some spicy goodness! Worth my weekly bart rid to the mission.
author: Sofie Z.

description:
pretty yummy

the food is different and pretty unique. we tried the different maizes and had yuca fries.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Really really delicious food.  I wanted better dessert choices, but all in all it was fabulous for "fast" food.  Plantains were sweet gooey and savory at the same time.  I wish they had a place in the East Bay... namely.. Berkeley... what are you waiting for?  I made a joke to the young woman at the counter about whether this was a place where male models tended to congregate... she stared at me dumbly.  Maybe it was a dumb comment, but I was just being playful... oh well..  I don't get out enough I guess.  Full of eye candy it was, but maybe that's just the Mission... I dunno... like I said, I don't get out much.
author: Richard P.

description:
arepas! 
what more do you need?
Why aren't they more available in the BAY?
let's bring them down in the peninsula.
i had one recently (pabellon) and it was great, the relleno and meat really fresh and tasty.
Just like something you would get in the streets of CARACAS!
 and the Yuca Fries, OMG i see a trend starting....
Now all we got to do is bring the prices down to socialist levels and we're good! j/k but some more locations would be ideal.
-peter
author: Peter F.

description: Good, tasty food and helpful service....even helpful customers!  Our first taste of Venezuelan food. Selection was made with the help of other Venezuelan customers and employees! Yummy!
author: April G.

description: I saw this place on Yelp and the idea of a maize-wich got me pretty excited... I brought my girlfriend here 2 days later and WOW.  I was expecting it to be more of a sit down style restaurant (you place your order at the counter and then fight everyone else for a table).  The food was incredible! We each got a maize-wich.  I got the Catira and it blew my socks off with flavor, I could eat this everyday- no joke.  I'd give it a 5 but the Sangria didn't do its job (did I get fooled into non alc sangria?) and there were some pretty shovey customers trying to claim a table we were waiting for (they hadn't even ordered yet, jerks!)  Oh yea! the Empenadas are AWESOME!  order those too! :)
author: Bobby P.

description: Good flavorful food that is unique. I went here because I needed a gluten free place and was not disappointed. I wish they had one in Sacramento.
author: Julie C.

description: Hit or miss. I've been here twice and both times I left with the same impression - which is that some things were good and some were blah. both times loved the arepa with pulled pork, sliced avocado and tomato and side of aoili (#7 on the menu).  last night i was disappointed with the shredded beef/black bean/plaintain/queso combo because of the quality of the beef.
author: Yevi A.

description: Can't wait to go back for delicious Venezuelan cuisine! Fast service and good food. Can't go wrong.
author: Kai J.

description: If you want gluten free and tasty stuff , you should checkout this place. Their grilled chicken CACHAPA is fantastic.
author: Prudhvi D.

description:
I have been to Venezuela so I was very excited to try this restaurant, but my excitement did not last long!!
I had the arepa with shredded beef pabellon, the corn bread had the texture of cardboard because it was cold. The salad that came with the order was flavorless. I had a side of ripe plantains, they were also cold not ripe and not sweet. I thought the coconut drink was just ok!
After eating I went to the restroom and was surprised with a poster supporting Leopoldo Lopez.
Leopoldo Lopez is in jail for inciting violence In Venezuela. He is one of the opposition leaders trying to achieve through violence and propaganda what they have failed to achieve through the ballot box in free and fair elections.
Leopoldo Lopez and the opposition protesters are trying to destabilize the country in order to achieve the unconstitutional overthrow of the country's democratically-elected government.
Not only is the food bad but Pica Pica Maize Kitchen should be ashamed for supporting Leopoldo Lopez. I will not spend another dime in this restaurant.
author: Monica N.

description: The entire place is gluten free. Everything I've had is consistently amazing.
author: Ariel L.

description: Fantastic. How many places can a Gluten-free eater go, and order anything on the menu? It's rare. What's more rare, is that everyone loves the food, whether they're GF or not. Sweet corn Arepas with Pork filling are amazing. The Yuca Beignets are awesome too. It's a 40 mile drive for us, and it's still worth it. Nothing fancy. Just awesome flavors and textures. Delicious.
author: S L.

description:
I love the concept of having a South American fast food place in the city. I was satisfied with my arepa sandwich with yucca fries and fried plantains, but it lacked the wow factor. Liked the variety of dipping sauces, but I'm a condiment girl and the sauce portions were on the smaller side. 

The Coconut-Lime granita was really good.
author: kirti p.

description: I will first say that I have only been to their booths - but their food is so delicious. If you get the combo, it is a bit on the heavy side with food which was denser than i expected. Feel free to ask them about the different breads since there have different types.
author: Jason B.

description:
We visited Pica Pica last Thursday and we all loved it (husband and my 2 young daughters).  One of my daughters has Celiac Disease and has to eat gluten free.  Everything at Pica Pica is gluten free and delicious.

We loved the garlic yuca fries, we shared 2 orders.  We had 3 different verions of the Maize'wich and one Arepa.  Yummy....if we lived in SF we'd be there often.  FYI - the Arepas are different than the kind I used to get when I lived in Miami.
author: Helenmarie S.

description: I LOVE this place.  I first had Pica Pica at the Bernal Street fair and was in love.  I went on line and they only had a restaurant in Marin.  I was thrilled to find they had opened in SF and have been a loyal customer ever since.  You can not go wrong with any item on the menu.
author: lori c.

description:
Warning: Pica Pica's Maize'wiches are more addictive than In-N-Out when you're sh*tfaced at 2am. Hell, those Maize'wiches are more addictive than heroin. Screw that dirty cheesesteak place on Divis, Pica Pica really should have that sign hanging out front warning that "eating here can be habit forming".

The wife and I first had the pleasure of eating these overstuffed morsels of heaven at this year's Fillmore Jazz Festival (the BEST Fillmore Fest yet, BTW). On that glorious Saturday afternoon, I ordered the Pernil Maize'wich with a side of Yuca Fries, while the wife went with the Pabellon Maize'wich. I don't think I've ever inhaled food that quickly in my life (well, at least not while sober). That Maize'wich was the most delicious thing I've ever eaten, super sweet cornbread stuffed with a heaping mound of juicy, perfectly seasoned pork and creamy avocado. My wife downed hers so fast I didn't even get a bite of the Pabellon. This was an obvious miscarriage of justice, so naturally this wrong had to be made right the next time we were in La Mission.

Blessedly, we found ourselves at that newly-sainted corner of Valencia & 15th this past Friday evening. The restaurant was only half full at around 6:30, so I went up to order while wifey sat down at one of the few tables that Pica Pica managed to shoehorn into their dining room. We did the old switcheroo this time around, with me ordering the Pabellon Maize'wich while the boss went with the Pernil, both with a side of those amazing Yuca Fries. Those Maize'wiches were even better the 2nd time around! The steak was perfectly cooked and impossibly moist, and the fried plantains added yet another layer of sweetness to the heavenly cornbread. The old lady LOVED her Pernil, taking down her Maize'wich in "Joey Chestnut ain't got sh*t on me!" time. The Yuca Fries are absolutely divine, and the Napa Smith Ale on tap washed it all down perfectly. Total tab: $27, thanks to the free Arepa coupons they were giving out at the festival. Damn, I wish I had taken a few more of those...

Pica Pica has since become my 2nd most unhealthy addiction and is a fantastic addition to an already amazing neighborhood restaurant scene. We finished our crack habit dinner, headed to The Phoenix for some pints of my 1st most unhealthy addiction, and watched the Giants kick the D-Bags' asses. Another day in paradise.
author: Michael T.

description: I really enjoyed eating here! Soy colombiana and I needed some arepas. Los pericos were delicious!
author: Ingrid O.

description:
Gluten free, interesting, fresh, delicious, reasonable.
Get the jenga-style tower of yucca fries, arepa,s and salad great. Will go back often.
author: Ali C.

description: Everything I tried here was really good! My sister has to eat gluten and dairy free and it was easy for her to order almost anything she wanted. The maize "fries" (not sure what exactly they're called) are really yummy - crispy on the outside and fluffy in the middle. I wish they had more vegetarian options that aren't spicy. I will definitely go back for lunch if I'm in the area.
author: Gina C.

description: This place  sure does provides allergen free food with some style. Unfortunately all dishes are not equally savory and the interior is poorly designed. Place gets quickly crowded, noisy and chaotic. It is a pity that that the overall experience turns out worse than Mac, because the exquisite menu has great potential.
author: Al L.

description: Well, after hearing so much about this place I went down there for an expensive disappointment.  We went for lunch because you have to negotiate a sketchy neighborhood to get there ... so it's not so encouraging at night.  We looked at the samples in the showcase and ordered according to our hunger.  First disappointment.  The samples were much bigger (and fresher) than the actual food when it arrived.  Next disappointment was that when I mentioned this fact to the waitress she told the manager. He looked at the sample, looked at our plates, walked away and never even spoke to us.  Hmmmmm.   So, for one CACHAPA and a diet coke and another soda it was $15.05 !  Not worth the trip.  The cachapa was mildly bland and listless.  Ehh.  Skip it, even if you could find parking.  I didn't like that when I was asked "how is everything?" and I politely shared my disappointment they didn't even address it.
author: James G.

description:
My BF and I wanted to try some thing different. So I checked out some Yelp reviews and settled on this place.
 It was around 2pm, so there wasn't a long line and tables were available. I ordered the cachapas filled with pulled pork, sliced avocados, and tomatoes. My other half ordered the maize'wich which was filled with onions, eggs, diced tomatoes, and cheese. It reminded him of an omelet except it was wrapped with maize bread. Both our plates came with a garlic infused, mayo based dip. 
We enjoyed our meals and found that the maize bread wrappings were sweet. I noticed the maize bread had a nice, crispy outer texture with bits of corn attached to it. 
We also had a side of thick cut yuca fries with spicy ketchup dip. The sweet taste and slightly firm texture of the yuca were accented nicely when fried to a golden crisp.
Four stars for gluten free food, unpretentious service, and for being in my favorite sunny neighborhood. Knocked off one star for hard to find parking spaces. I will definitely come back to try the bululu salad and will give you an update when I do.
author: Win L.

description:
who cares if everything is gluten free, this place is just delicious. 

the pabellon arepa.. damn tasty!
author: Jesus B.

description: Was so disappointed... Saturday was my father in-laws birthday and thought we would take him out to this place since he grew up in Venezuela and there are almost no venezuelan restaurants around  thought he would love coming and having some arepas. Saw this place on triple D thinking it would be great and worth the drive from the east bay and worth the toll. So get there finally find parking get down with a 3 month old a 2 year old go in and look to order and they tell us they were out of the white corn arepas and only have the sweet one? It was 11:30 in the morning they had just barely opened and they could of made a store run and bought some arena p.a.n. So disappointing how are you going to call your self an arepa kitchen and not even have the ingredients to make an arepa???!! Needless to say since it was my father in-laws bday we took the trip to Palo Alto to another venezuelan resturant and got our arepa fix. So disappointed and was embarrassed since this was my idea.
author: Espinoza E.

description: Pica Pica is really, really good! Adding to my list of Mission faves, Pica Pica does offer the "opportunity to explore lesser-known flavors of Latin cuisine" and in this case, we're talking about Venezuelan! With just me and my fam, we ordered Pelu'a Arepas (shredded steak w/ cheese), Clasica Maize'wich (ham & cheese), Chupe (chicken soup), and Yucca fries. We enjoyed it as much as the kids... and I'm sure Yelper parents know that the kids are the real critics. Flavors are rich and not really spicy (as some dishes may note). Corn is the center of all these dishes and they're gluten and wheat-free. I'm looking forward to the next visit. First timers, be aware sitting is limited.
author: Leroid D.

description: Decent. I figure this is pretty good gluten free food.
author: Grant M.

description:
Arepas....I'm pretty new to them but I think I savored great dishes both in NY (Caracas) and SF (Mr Pollo).
Now, why should I lower my standards here?
Food came out fast, too fast, ant the place was full.
Why? Because they just assembled it, in perfect "fast food" style.
Now, go to Mr Pollo and wait 10-15 minutes for your arepa and then tell me...
The arepa itself here was mediocre, so stiff and chewy, and the filling had major flaws.
The cheese was completely boring, still in clumps (like those Sargento bags at Safeway) and the meat was uber dry. They tried to mask it by soaking it in its own cooking juices but you can't hide when meat has gone overboard. In fact, we ended up chewing dry stuff with a fountain of dripping juices. Plantain were soggy and the yucca fries were just, eh, OK. But $4? In the Mission?
Kudos for the spicy crema but you can easily recreate that with sour cream and chipotle adobo.
Too bad, I was eager to be excited tonight... :(
author: Dario B.

description: Pica Pica is ok. The sweet plantains are quite good, the service is friendly, and they always give you plenty of perfectly ripe avocado. The wait can be a bit long and every now and its a little greasy, but overall it is worth going!
author: Kate M.

description: I love the food!! There is one in Napa with Live music. The combination of food and music is a great environment to relax and enjoy!
author: Jade H.

description: I ate there a while ago so I don't really remember it that well.  however I do remember it was interesting looking inside and the food was interesting too.  I liked the service and the price was reasonable.  However I didn't really like the sides.
author: Seth W.

description:
We were so excited for this place to open we went and checked a couple times to see if they were opened before the actual opening weekend. My husband is venezuelan and we have been hoping to find some empanadas or arepas in the city since we moved here. 
Needless to say, this is the real thing. All of the ingredients taste exactly how they are supposed to....very authentic and delicious. I also really like how everything tastes fresh and not too greasy.
The empanadas disappointed me a bit, they are miniature! They only had cheese ones when we went and I like a big empanada full of meat and all that jazz. We had to have the pabellon arepa... Very good. Cachapa-delicious. 
My biggest complaint is the prices. It should not cost 30$ to eat arepas! They are good quality and in bit of a hipster area I understand, but I don't think the prices are reasonable for what they serve. We would come here every week if it was more affordable.
For a great, unique, and truly Venezuelan meal this place is great! But on a budget... I won't be coming as often as I'd like to.
author: Kristen D.

description: Art & I had lunch here on Thursday.  The service was very friendly.  I had the tofu maizewich, but they mistakenly gave me the cachapa.  The cachapa was yummy, but the insides were bland and tasteless.
author: Kevin M.

description:
this place had been on my radar for awhile, though I had never had an arepa before, and I was pleased with my dinner. 

Initially my pulled pork maize-wich looked a little on the small side, but when I was full at the end of the meal, I realized they'd gotten the portion right afterall.  I really enjoyed it.  Now the empanadas were a little lack-luster, if only because their wrapping is not what I'm used to, and they accidentally gave us the tilapia instead of the beef.  But I like the multiple salsa options, and the yuca fries were decent.

It was a corn-centric meal, which is something I love, and because of that some of the items felt a little heavy, so I guess it does fill you up.  I'd come back for sure to try some of the different fillings, wrappings, and dippings.
author: Anne Marie B.

description: Amazing food!!!! Don't let the gluten free fool you to not try it!!! It's amazing.  Not to mention I personally know the owner and she's just as amazing!!! But whether I know her or not this is one of my favorite spots!!!! It's a small place and you need to order your food at counter then sit. I loved the shredded beef arepas with sweet corn wrap... Melts in my mouth. yummmmm!!!! I have brought friends here and they were all well pleased! They even gone back without me :-/
author: Trina M.

description:
I thought the food was mediocre. 

Yes it's Venezuelan which I had never tried but not much different from just bread, beans, lettuce and guacamole (just in a different form). 

Regardless I'm sure there is food that can be more tasteful but Pica Pica fails to do anything. 

Can you eat it? yes, its good enough to eat if you're hungry but nothing WOW. 

Ate there because I was really hungry but would not go back.
author: Geena T.

description: Not the best (or cheapest) arepas I've ever had, but pretty good.  The bread was really hard and tough, and the sauce was good but could have used a little more zing.  The place was fast and clean and the yuca fries were pretty tasty.
author: Linda L.

description: Had a cachapa pepeada with garlic yucca fries. It was like a corn crepe filled with chicken avocado salad, though I doubt that's a truly accurate description. Tasty and filling, as it should be since it set me back almost $15. Yep, pricey.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Wonderful little spot to eat at!! Great customer service and fast service. There food was very fresh and great taste and affordable. The chicken soup was the highlight. Gluten-free menu and wide selection of g-free beer. For those like me with Celiac disease it is a great little gem.
author: Cora H.

description: I love the food at Pica Pica, but every time I go there is always some kind of flow problem -- either the cash register person is taking forever, and the cooks are standing around, or the order goes smoothly but the food comes out in a crazy staggered fashion (like getting my side of pasapalos long after I've finished my sandwich, or once not at all.) Last night I couldn't wash my hands because one of the cooks was in the bathroom for the entire duration of my visit. And the girl ringing up orders was also responsible for delivering the food -- so when there was a queue of people ordering the food sat there, getting cold... and it's not cheap. Hopefully they'll work out the kinks!
author: Emily B.

description: I LOVE Maize Kitchen! I first had sandwich from them at a festival in San Francisco. I had NO idea that they had an actual restaurant until I stumbled past it one Sunday afternoon. The service is fast, the food is fresh and delicious, its inexpensive, AND its all gluten free. I'm in love with this place-everyone should try it.
author: Shalana M.

description:
Where to begin?

When I first heard about this place I was intrigued and, as always, excited to try new food. The interior was nice, if small. It had that kitschy SF foodie spot feel to the place, which is always pleasant. But don't judge a book by it's cover. 

First off-the food. It was terrible. I had empanadas, plantains, and a maize-wich. The empanadas were greasy, thick, and the included sauce had a strange taste to it. It would have been nice if the stuffing wasn't quite so bland as well. The plantains were alright, sweet and good for sharing (although I personally did not like the cheese sprinkled on top). The maize-wich was the WORST. The pancake itself was very greasy and it seemed unevenly cooked or warmed-up. One side was really hot and dark colored, while the other side was luke warm and of a more natural color.  The filing was a mixture of various ingredients pureed with avocados, so it had an off green texture that did not look appetizing (kind of like toothpaste with particles of food stuck in it). The filing was also COLD, and I personally don't like cold and hot foods to mix. That was an extreme downer for me, considering the wait time couldn't they at least have warmed up the filling a little? I mean I'm talking about straight out of a cold freezer. I also had a drink with my meal and was charged $3. Any other place on mission would charge 1-1.75 reasonably. For the amount I paid, I would expect more and of a higher quality. Of course, part of why I am upset, I went here for dinner thinking I could get a complete and filing meal. Needless to say I left disgusted and utterly unsatisfied. 

I went with a Venezuelan friend and even he said that this was not typical Venezuelan cuisine. Everything was too greasy, too thick, and some ingredients seemed much more from Mexico. I think a lot of fellow San Franciscans are being fooled into coming here for the idea of eating Venezuelan food and feeling "cosmopolitan" and cultured. Unfortunately, they are being duped like sheep into paying for overpriced stodge from a hole in the wall operation.
BOTTOM LINE:
THERE ARE MANY OTHER FINE CULINARY EXPERIENCES ALONG MISSION AND VALENCIA MORE WORTHY OF YOUR TASTEBUDS AND PRECIOUS DOLLARS. When I left here unsatisfied, I went to seek out those higher quality establishments.
author: J E.

description:
Tasty! I had never had Venezuelan style grub prior to trying PIca Pica, but what a savory introduction. First trip i had the Pabellon Arepa, which was stellar. The second time, we got an assortment of everything and shared. Both times, I came away satisfied with my meal. They also offer a small selection of beer on tap and wines which is a nice addition to the yummy food.

The place is nicely painted in bright colors which are more restaurant feeling than the otherwise cafeteria style order, seat yourself, pick up your own food and beers kinda service.

The only real downside for me with this place is that it is definitely NOT fast food. Getting lunch and getting back to work within a 1/2 hour would be an impressive feat, even though I work on the same block. But that doesn't matter too much to me. The food is NOM, decently priced, filling, and it's damn close to my work. It's an experience I will likely repeat and have recommended to friends. Check it out!
author: Rocky H.

description: menu is pretty confusing to order from , especially when you order online , arepas and empanadas have amazing dough but just wish they filled them more
author: NAEL K.

description: I got the pulled permil arepa and it's great. I especially like the pica chup sauce, which kinda tastes like sweet barbecue. The pica pun sauce is quite spicy, but very bearable. The mojo sauce is like a combo vinegar and mustard barbecue and moderately spicy.
author: Alex P.

description: The other day the lunch delivery place here was delivering from pica pica so I tried it. I've seen this place when I've gone to get my Little Star pizza, but I've never gone in because, well, I'd rather have Little Star. But even though this is no Little Star, it's still yummy! I had La Vegetariana Maize'wich, which is a sandwich made with instead of bread, corn cakes. Those corn cakes were really good, and you could see the little pieces of corn. They're not light and fluffy like bread, more like corn fritters that my mom makes. Inside was tofu, avocado and plaintains, and it came with two sauces. One was too sweet, the other was a little spicy, it was supposed to be their signature spicy sauce. That spicy sauce was good, but if you're not into spicy things, don't worry, because it's not that spicy at all. Or not to me. Overall, yummy flavor combo, and something unique I haven't seen anywhere else. I'd come back for this, or maybe the pork one sounds yummy too. Or the arepas I keep reading about. I can't vouch for the insides of the place, or the waiters, etc. since I didn't get mine delivered from them. But go eat there!
author: Merredith L.

description:
I had the CACHAPA (sweet corn pancake) with CATIRA filling (chicken, cheese) and it was soooo yummy!  

The fried green plantains were meh...

All in all - I highly recommend checking out this place - I really don't know where else one get the same kind of food.
author: Cindy C.

description:
Corn corn corn corn corn...
Pulled pork nothing special but
Yucca fries delish!
author: Adam F.

description: This place is pretty good.  The employees seem to always be a little bit unorganized.  The sandwhiches are mechanically off, but taste good.  I don't come here often, but sometimes it is nice to get some different food.
author: Jonathan U.

description:
I went here because I got an internet coupon for a free arepa and the place seemed interesting. Even after reading the pretty mixed yelp reviews, I was quite disappointed!

Service: 
The register guy was completely friendly and fine. I don't know if they were understaffed or what, but the place is pretty small, and tehre was a table that sat with dirty dishes on it for like 10 minutes. This is not something that should happen during the lunch rush. 

Food:
Not good. Maybe if you don't eat gluten, this kind of thing seems delicious because it so closely resembles normal food. I had the pabellon arepa (steak, plantains, black beans, cheese), which sounded like pretty much my ideal latin sandwich. The corn bread thing itself was inoffensive but I don't really ever need to eat another one. The filling didn't work AT ALL. The meat was fine in terms of seasoning, but the giant chunks of plantain completely dominated the sandwich and made everything way too sweet. They needed to be much smaller and better distributed. The bites without plantain in them were definitely the best. I also found that the black beans got completely lost in there. Also, this thing is marked on the menu as spicy, which I think must be code for "contains flavor," because there was no heat whatsoever. I also ordered the yuca fries. The fries themselves were pretty tasty, but I was surprised when I wasn't asked which dipping sauce I wanted, since there are 5 or 6 options listed on the menu. I liked the sour cream-chipotle thing they came with, though. The one issue was that the fries were not well enough drained and there was a sizable pool of oil that dripped out of the cone thing they came in and onto the table. Gross! All in all, the food was totally forgettable and i will never ever crave it. 

Atmosphere:
Totally fine work-lunch crowd. Not very "missiony." It might work better in a mall or something. The bright colors are nice, but the fancy signs and whatnot just make me feel like I'm overpaying.
author: Julia G.

description: Pretty good for what it is. I love corny things and the corn based goodness did live up to all the praise my friend was giving it. It is very good and delicious. However, the filling I had wasn't as great. I had the parnil pork and it was just too salty and not the heavenly deliciousness I envisioned in my head. But it was decent and the yucca fries were nice. I don't really feel the need to go back unless I'm having a terrible craving for yucca fries and I happen to be by it.
author: Lisa K.

description: Wow.  Sounded so promising from the other reviews.  Too bad the food is flavorless.  Yucca fries aren't bad but their pulled pork sucks.  My wife had the tofu sandwich and thought it was basically flavorless as well.  Definitely avoid this joint.
author: R C.

description: YES!  They finally opened.  My partner and I would always stop by the oxbow market in napa when out there for a weekend.  the folks in SF have a bit of work to do, but the taste is the same.  i would recommend not getting takeout, as the arepas get pretty messy in the boxes.  yucca fries are to die for.  the chicken salad arepa with guacacasa (homemade guacamole) is my favorite.
author: Timothy S.

description: My first taste of Venezuelan cuisine was successful!  I had arepa with pulled pork, avocado, tomato and aioli and  yuca fries.  The pulled pork was very tasty and plentiful, especially with the arepa, which balanced the saltiness of it.  I really enjoyed the yuca fries because they had a perfect crunch to them.  Nice, casual spot with many selections to choose from.  I would like to return to try the other menu items and for more fries!
author: Linda P.

description: A cute modern twist to Venezuelan food.  I love how the menu has a lot of great vegetarian options.  I had a pabellon maize'wich and the flavors of the meat, plantains, black beans, and cheese melded together really well although it was a bit messy to eat.  The sweet and fluffy cornbread adds a real kick to the other mostly salty ingredients.  The cheese empanadas were really fresh and the yucca fries were great albeit SUPER greasy after awhile.  Service can get kind of chaotic since the space is small and the menu can be confusing for first-timers.  Great on the go option, though.
author: Christina L.

description: I dashed out to get some emergency food tonight when dinner plans fell through.  Pica Pica happened to be open and within a 2 block walk of where I was staying.  I haven't had cachapa in a long time, so I ordered that, with the Pabellon filling, the medium spicy hot sauce, and an extra side of plantains just because I love plantains.  Everything was just a tad bit fast-foody compared to a more "home-style" Venezuelan restaurant that I used to go to back in the day, but heck, since I can't even get Venezuelan food where I live now, I was hardly going to complain.   Everything was fresh, well-made and tasty, and everything being gluten free is a nice bonus.  Pica Pica can open a branch in Charlotte any time.
author: Cynthia G.

description: The arepas were tasty but overall it was just OK. The pulled pork was not at all delectable on its own. It kinda had that "dirty" pork flavor, if you know what I mean. The yucca fries had a decent fried texture but were no improvement on regular fries. Wish I'd waited for that table at Little Star across the street.
author: Marco L.

description: vegetarians beware! this restaurant might be a hit with meat lovers ut as a vegetarian i thought the food was just tolerable. i really liked their sandwiches but being a vegetarian kinda limits your choice. Neverthless, a definite must-try.
author: Shal S.

description:
Locating a gluten free sandwich anywhere outside of the confines of your kitchen is next to impossible. At Pica Pica on Valencia Street, you can stop in for a "Maizewich" just like the good old days. Everything on their menu is gluten free. If you've never tried an Arepa, Maizewich or Cachapa, they are variations on a delicious Venezuelan corn bread which looks something like a cross between a pancake and pita bread. Choose your specific corn pocket and have it stuffed with a variety of fillings, like tofu, plantains, black beans and a zesty spread or juicy pulled pork with shredded cheese- they even have a chicken salad filling. Two specific vegan options are available, and for the dairy sensitive carnivores- just ask them to leave off the cheese. The Pernil (shredded seasoned beef with plantains and black beans) with or without cheese is delicious- among many others. Don't ignore the tasty sides offered like yucca fries and sweet plantains. 

For photos and more gluten free friendly restaurants in San Francisco: www.GFinSF.com
author: lauren v.

description: I could go on and on about Pica Pica, but it would take too much time. I was introduced to this place a few months ago and I was blown away. Everything is great, and the prices are semi-reasonable. You will be adding Arepa to your food vocabulary after you venture in here. I love how this place is gluten free--how often do you find completely gluten free establishments these days? PP is a VERY small cafe so seating is not always guaranteed.
author: J S.

description: Delicious, unpretentious, reasonably priced and two blocks away from me. Great taste experience on first visit.
author: stuart l.

description: Since being diagnosed with Celiacs 18 months ago I've been VERY careful about where I eat out and I love that I can get great tasting food without worrying about gluten.  I've been here a few times and gotten an arepa every time.  I love the sweet corn bread and am always full afterwards.  I also really enjoy both of the sangrias.  I will definitely be coming back.  My only complaint would be that the wait staff tends to forget to bring me my sangria.
author: Marie B.

description: Service was amazing. Food was not. I spent $9.75 for the chicken salad sandwich n was SUPER disappointed.
author: Peter T.

description: I've gone to Pica Pica no less than three times since being introduced to it by Laura-D, I've had three different arepas and i've left happy three times.  So far I've had the pulled pork, the chicken with avocado and the chorizo, all three pretty good.  I've also had the empanadas which were spot on as well (though a little greasy, since they are deep fired).  The arepas are a little more pricey that your average Mission burrito, but they are filling and TOTALLY worth the extra few bucks (but burritos are my enemy, so I might be biased).  The arepa corn bread is always crisp and tasty and chock full of yummy fillings.  This place has becoe one of my go to places for a quick, cheap meal.  I want to try the yucca fries, but have known i'd be satisfied with the arepa, so thus far they have been unnecessary....  The dipping sauces look good too.
author: Adrian L.

description: pica pica is really good. i'm vegan and gluten-free and love their veggie arepa (no aioli). it comes with either white or yellow (sweet) corn, sweet plantains, black beans, tofu and avocado. the yellow sauce is spicy and freaking delicious. i also adore their yucca fries. i eat here a few times a month, and often go out of my way to grab food here en route home after work...
author: joey e.

description: I ate their  food at summerthing- the people were super friendly and patient and the pulled pork in a sweet corn pancake was DELICIOUS!!! can't wait to go to the restaurant.
author: Moira N.

description: This place is yummy--a haven for even the non-gluten-free folk. Yes, lots of stuff is fried, but I can't kick that out of bed. The tastes are hearty and solidly delicious. Comfort food. The prices seemed reasonable compared to what they could charge--three empanadas with a delicious aioli for $4.50. Can't beat that. Try the lime and coconut drink.
author: S. R.

description: I was so excited for new gluten free eatery option, but boy did they let me down. I could only down two bites of whatever it was I ordered and I felt so sick - almost worse than I would have felt if I had devoured a large glutenous roll. Such a shame.
author: M S.

description:
i was just introduced to the fabulous-ness of arepas last year, and finally was able to visit pica pica last night with a couple of friends.  of course, we started off with a happy hour drink...$3 beer, wine, and sangria!

i had the arepa with the shredded skirt steak, black beans, plantains, and cheese (aka "pabellon")...muy delicioso!  the cash register guy also gave us a drizzle to try - chiles in vinegar...he said it was spicy...i didn't get so much "spicy", but it was vinegar-y, and went well with the arepa.  we also shared an order of yuca fries (w/morena sauce - black beans) and sweet plantains (w/spicy cream) ...oh, both are definite musts!  lastly, we shared something sweet...little cookies that sandwich'ed dulce de leche and coconut in the middle...yum, yum, yum!

i'm already looking forward to my next visit!!  i plan on trying their empanadas, as well as changing the sandwich up by getting the cachapa or maize'wich...*sigh*...so many good things to try!!
author: Kelly T.

description: The arepas, empanadas and yucca fries are tasty enough and the decor is bright and relaxing.  This place goes with the all other trendy overpriced modern latin joints popping up all over the mission. I don't think the mom and pop and neighborhood restaurants have anything to worry about. I'd go back but with so many other better options in the neighborhood, it might be awhile.
author: Miz J.

description: Love this place!  Yummy arepas & cachapas are not to be missed.  Quick, affordable and tasty.  Plus it's convenient.
author: Sandy L.

description: wow, we just tried a pica pica treat today for the first time at the millbrae art and wine festival.  needless to say, the food was delicious and we will seek them out in San Francisco to try even more treats.  Ed and I ate a pita like break made out sweet maize dough....it was thick,  creamy and crispy on the outside.  The maize ''pita' was filled with an amazing chicken and avocado mixture.  the avocado was in place of mayo and the big chunks of chicken were so tender and moist......it was absolutely one of the best things we have ever eaten at a street festival; and we can't wait to try another treat with black beans, plantain and queso next time...or who knows:)
author: Erin S.

description: A gentrified pupusaria, but you can find some more interesting parings than the cheap Salvadorian joints.  I had a Pabellon Arepa, which has skirt steak, beans, cheese, and plantains.  It was pretty tasty, though not spicy as indicated on the menu.
author: Ann K.

description: I loved this place!!!  it has amazing food. Venezuelan food is delicious.  I suggest you try the Pabellon on a sweet arepa or the cachapa con queso.  My family and I have agreed to go to this place once a week.  its clean, not expensive, trendy, great food and great service.   But be ware -you will need to be patient- because there is always a line ;)
author: Chana D.

description: Of all my friends, I am the only non-fan.  The food was fine.  I had a planteens with bbq pork wrapped in a corn pancake, a flavorful combo if I made it at home, but not enough to bring me back, essentially, to a deli where I stand in line to order my food.  I want to give this a two-star rating, but for anyone who wants a taqueria type experience Pica Pica is fine, if unremarkable.  The place smells like corn oil too, so be prepared for that if you're sensitive to that kind of thing.
author: Patrick B.

description: Fabulous food! A Vegan's dream come true! Tasty! Not your grandmother's corn bread! Well worth the trek into SF Mission. Follow the Food Truck (OfftheGrid.com) for the same delicious food. Flavorful. Local organic. Reasonable prices. Eat in or take out! Check it out!
author: KJ P.

description:
first of all...to those with gluten allergies, so sorry.  i can't think of a curse worse than thought.  anyway, here is your restaurant.

the food was really good.  the yucca fries were good...nice and crispy.  the salad i got was really tasty...it had this passionfruit vinaigrette, pineapples (not much), corn (not enough), and some other stuff.  it was really good and light.  it's sweet though, so you have to be in the mood for that.  it was kinda weird that it came in a plastic container ON TOP of a plate...let's skip the middle man and just give it to me on the plate.  i'd prefer not to have to think of landfills while i'm chowing down on some gluten-free fare.

the maize-wich was really tasty too...and the name is cute, i guess.

the workers are cool, and they have some really rad t-shirts, but they don't sell them, which is LAME...gimme me one of those t-shirts!
author: Miss P.

description: We usually don't review another outpost of the same eatery but for Pica Pica We are making an exception (see our earlier review for the Napa location). We love pica pica. I grew up on arepas and even though theirs can't beat mom's they are delicious! We love their little space and are so happy to have them nearby.
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description: Went here this past weekend and was pretty impressed with the food.  My wife is completely gluten free, so this place was a must try for the two of us.  The food was actually really good (unlike most gluten free food!) and the portions were pretty large as well.  Do yourself a favor and don't over order.  The pictures of the food online looked much smaller that what was actually served.  I wasn't the biggest fan of the way the place was laid out, it was fairly small and very reminiscent of a cafeteria.  However, if you are gluten free, or enjoy food from south of the border, Pica Pica is the place for you.
author: aaron h.

description:
yes! yes! yes!
i looked up "gluten-free" restaurants in the mission, and pica pica came up as the first option. tried it out with two friends, and we all left as fans. the sweet cachapas is delicious, the food comes out so fast, and the yucca fries are perfectly crispy.

i personally like my food a bit saltier, so i thought the vegetarian arepa i ordered could use a bit more flavor/pizazz/kick. but, the aioli for the yucca fries totally made up for it.  

this spot is definitely worth trying, especially for you gluten-free folks.
author: Liz S.

description: Had lunch here today and the food was good!!The place looks great and the staff was incredibly friendly. The food had it all. Nice, friendly, great place to grab a bite in the Mission.
author: Art A.

description: Mmm, corny goodness. The sweet yellow corn arepa and tasty fillings are consistently delicious. Bf prefers white corn arepa, but mom, dad, and I prefer yellow. The portions are small for the price, but it's so darn tasty I keep coming back.
author: Presto G.

description: La Shuli Maize Wich add Pica Pun...WOW, refreshing.  Exactly what I needed and then craziness happened to my tongue!  You know when you sleep on your arm too long and it falls asleep??  It felt like I slept on my face too long w/ my tongue out.  Jesus that's spicy and I love spicy...tears, I want more!  Don't forget to have the yuca fries...I know bad, but you gotta do it.  It'll help revive your tongue!
author: D C.

description:
Melanie brought me here on the fly last month. Whenever we go out to eat, we never really know where we're going, which is kind of the fun part. She asked if I've ever eaten Venezuelan food and I said, "Nope." So off to Pica Pica we go. We get there and the place is really nice. The decor is simple yet elegant, small and quaint. We got there in the late afternoon so the sun was shining all up in the place. As I've mentioned, I've never had Venezuelan food at all so since the menu was on the wall and pretty self-explanatory, I had a go at it. I ordered a, lemme make sure I get this right, Pepeada Arepa. An arepa is a grilled corn flour cake and pepeada is a delicious chicken salad with guanacaca (creamy avocado). WOW. I was savoring every bite. I also ordered a side which is called a pasapalo. I had some fried plantains with some aioli dipping sauce while Melanie ordered some yucca fries. Both equally delicious. After a while the place started filling up so I'm assuming this is "the spot"! The folks running the joint were really friendly especially for folks like me who've never eaten there before. The bathrooms are clean and really cool. 

I will definitely come back!
author: Ivan F.

description: Stopped in during the week to pick up a late lunch to-go. Tried the Cachapa w/Pabellon (skirt steak, plaintains, black beans) since I saw it display and looked mouthwatering. Sounds cheesy but I like that they have some sample food on display since some of the menu items are relatively unfamiliar to diners. My food tasted awesome, can't wait to go back and try more things, but definitely during an off time.
author: Carin R.

description: Great place to take friends who don't eat wheat! Flavors are good, but the food is a little greasy and also really messy to eat. The food is over priced for the portions, but like i said, if you have friends with dietary restrictions this can satisfy both your needs for a relaxing lunch date.
author: Milo D.

description: Delicious!  I read that this place had recently opened and loved the idea.  Went with a friend and was totally blown away.  We got the salad,  maize-which and one of the other options with a variety of meats (can't remember now, it's been a while).  The combos were great, could have easily gotten seconds.  Can't wait to go back.
author: Dina B.

description:
I'm rating this place a solid 3.5 stars.  This was my first introduction to Venezuelan food, and I went here last night with my friend who studied abroad in Venezuela in college.  

I ordered the vegetarian on arepa.  (You get three choices of corn material to envelop your meal.  It's hard to describe.)  It had avocado, black beans and plantains.  All the ingredients were fresh and perfectly cooked, however, some seasonings would have been nice.  We also got the yucca fries, which were easily the best I've ever tasted, and I have traveled in South America.  (So maybe not authentic, but tasty to a California palate.)  

Food is reasonably priced.  The locale is small, but we squeezed in.  Overall, I think it's an interesting addition that shows much promise.
author: Martine D.

description: loved! new to the city staff was great and offered suggestions. would definitely recommend for gathering with friends!
author: Anita C.

description:
I've recently been having an arepa fiending.
A friend told me about Pica Pica so I checked out their arepa scene for lunch.

The $9 lunch special served up a small, vegetarian arepa and a side order of bunk-ass yucca fries - I'm sure they weren't 100% yucca.  Probably some pre-packaged yucca/potato blend.  Please!  0% for authenticity.

The arepa was decent and didn't come with all that was advertised.  Frankly I don't think tofu and arepas should go together.

The meal was so close to underwhelming that I had to write immediately and give this meal 2 stars.  I don't know about the other meals.  The service was friendly and I generally liked the feel of store.

I will only go back if I am close to Pica Pica and very hungry or if I experience a re-emergent arepa craving.
author: Micah T.

description: I crave their hot sauce. I could probably use an entire bottle of it for my little corn/meat sandwich combo. The plantains are yummy too! Eat here now!
author: Rachel T.

description:
Seriously delectable. We strolled in at 3pm on a Sunday afternoon, starving. Ordered the #2  Palu'a and #3 Pabellon and were so psyched - pretty much the most savory sandwiches I've had in the mission ever. You get your choice of bread - and that might be what makes the sandwiches. I got mine on sweet corn bread - not filling, just a tad sweet that complemented the savory skirt steak - cooked for hours - in the palu'a. 

Unique in this area and not expensive - a total highlight when you're hungry for good food.
author: jeff g.

description:
delicious!

this is a true story about luck and fate and destiny and things that go rawr in the night. for the last one, its mainly my stomach at 9pm when ive just cleaned my kitchen and dont particularly want to cook anything. im talking to my friend on the phone who just happens to be driving through my hood and hasnt eaten, either, thus happenth the impromptu dinner in the mission (luck). 

she finds parking and we are walking down my street trying to decide where to go when she mentions pica pica. i google it on my phone and we happen to be just 2 blocks away! (fate! destiny!...okay, ill stop) after that, though, its all just delicious.

i order the pabellon maize'wich, which is amazing. shredded steak (like more tender carnitas), plantains, black beans all stuffed between corn maize pancakes. we also ordered empanadas to share. the dough is an interesting texture, i was more a fan of my sandwich than the empanadas, but they were good to try. 

reasonably priced, delicious food and laid back environment, close to my apt - whats not to like?
author: Diane L.

description:
pica'pun = SPICY AS HELL

my first time ordering, did it online, was not expecting the spice. 

I like the concept, but I cant stomach the taste.

You have been advised!
author: Lux P.

description: This place is really delicious, with good ingredients and fast.  My only requests are these: more patience with substitutions (as someone with dietary restrictions, there is only one sandwich I can eat, and I wish they'd let folks mix and match meats with other fillings to keep it interesting and I'd probably eat here more often).  Some specials/combos, especially for lunchtime would be awesome.  It gets a little steep for a stop-in (as a taqueria stop alternative) if you start adding on, but the maize-whiches are great.
author: Gabby G.

description: This is place is delicious, tried the arepa with pabellon along with yuca fries and empanadas. The establishment is very nice but sized rather small so if it's packed inside might not bother. But none the less worth trying, I was impressed!
author: Frank R.

description: Tasty, something different. A little oily and a little expensive but overall a a good deal and gluten-free options make it a good spot in the area.
author: Mike S.

description: I have no idea if this is "authentic" Venezuelan, but it is mighty tasty.  I love everything I've tried at Pica Pica. Only reason I'm docking them a star is because I'm pretty sure they made their sandwiches smaller recently, without altering the price. Which is sad.  But their food is so delicious I'm still probably going back.  The gluten-free thing is great, too. It can get a little noisy and the staff is sort of reserved but not actively unfriendly.
author: Beth W.

description: My Venezuelan friends love this.place! Great arepas - the best in SF, but they still leave me longing for arepitas in Caracas.
author: Denis L.

description: This place is over-priced. Am I paying for the new decor?!  The yuca fries are almost $4 bucks and the serving size is about 1 potato's worth of yuca.  I lived in Miami and you get a lot more yuca fries for a lot less money.  The dipping sauce doesn't seem like it went with the flavor of the yuca.  There are a couple of sauces to choose from, in hind sight I realized that and they just gave me some random redish orange colored one.  The arepa was pretty bland.  I got the cheese and ham and unfortunately the cheese was not melted.  I will give it another chance to get the sweet corn maize and the other yuca fries dipping sauce.
author: H G.

description:
I'm really sad to have to give a bad review, but I've now been to Pica Pica three times and twice have been given the wrong items. Both times I was given the wrong item, I only ordered one thing: Cheese empanadas. Both times I got empanadas with some kind of meat in them. It was particularly disappointing because I had bought them for my daughter, 3, who loved the cheese empanadas the first time we went there, but she wouldn't touch them once she saw they had meat. So far, I have not received a response from Pica Pica after both a phone call and an email. 

To be fair, the first visit I did enjoy my arepa. It wasn't amazing, but it was good. The flavors are unique and it tastes fresh, but all in all, I wouldn't have gone back that often if not for the cheese empanadas my daughter loved. Unfortunately, I haven't actually been able to get those cheese empanadas, so I'm pretty sure I'm done. It seems they need to have a better organizational system so the empanadas don't get mixed up. Seems pretty simple to me. 

I wanted to like your restaurant, but I can't endorse a business that can't get a simple order correct. I'm hoping to get a response soon, so I can update this review.
author: Julie K.

description:
I can't wait to go back.

The space was open and had a high ceiling. We got there around 5:30pm on Tuesday and left a bit after 7pm when it was just starting to get more crowded. I'd definitely recommend going here on the earlier side if you want a table. The waiters/staff were nice and friendly and the place was clean and easy to identify from the outside. 

Their sangria was sooo good, white and red. And I loved that they had a still, dry rose!

Food: YUMMY! rich flavors, well thought out combinations. Although I think they could drop the price a bit (perhaps $1/dish) the food was scrumptious. I got a la shuli maize'wich b/c I wasn't too hungry. So good. I didn't think the Guasacaca was that creamy, but it was good and fresh. It was a bit spicy, just the way I like it. It had a lot of beans, but didn't skimp on the tomatoes or onions.

My friend got a Pabellon arepa and a side of Yuka fries with their homemade spicy ketchup. The arepa was great, and the fries were good, although greasy when I bit into them. The ketchup was surprisingly good b/c I usually only like Heinz. The corn, maize, bread wasn't quite as good as Caracas' in NYC, but this is a place I will be going back to and recommending often.
author: Sarah K.

description: A fun little place to try a different take on south-of-the-border cuisine. The sandwiches are quite big, so you might even be able to share.
author: Charles B.

description:
Loved the Yucatan place at this location before but Pica Pica is also great!  Relatively cheap and YUMMY! I call in advance so no wait. They have beer too!
The clincher is it's perfect for peeps with bread issues cuz the tortas are wraped in 3 selections of corn.
author: Scott S.

description: Having celiacs and always being on the run, I often find myself stuffing my mouth with rice cakes.  I was told about a gluten-free restaurant near my office and decided to try it.....and DAMN....this restaurant was AWESOME.....Having the peace of mind of being able to order whatever the hell I wanted and not have to worry about getting sick was a plus but once I tried the food, I almost didnt care if it was gluten-free or not...I had the Cachapa with shredded meat, sweet plantains, beans, and cheese.   It was euphoric!!!  I ordered to go and ate when I got back to the office, I almost wanted to go back and get another one....This is now officially one of my favorite spots in the Mission and I have recommended it to many folks!!!
author: G B.

description: My family is Venezuelan, and I have been looking for a venezuelan restaurant to try out.  This place transports me to my Tia and Abuelo's kitchen.  It is a very accurate representation of these Venezuelan dishes, and I probably would eat here way too often if I lived in the Mission.  The only downside is that their menu is small and simply changes fillings for types of bread.  There are a couple other foods that I would love them to add.  If you want know what Venezuelan food is like, then you should try this place out.  If you don't like it, then you don't like venezuelan food.
author: Alaric F.

description: not a Bad spot . this place is located in the spot where a Yucatec Mayan restaurant had once been . i was passing by it and decided to stop in and try a Arepa .i had a Arepa stuffed with Shreded beef and Beans and Platanos it was really good i believe it was called Arepa Pabellon . I also had some Chicken Empanadas they where really good . i will definatley check this place out again .
author: Jose C.

description: In a town saturated with tacos, Pica Pica's maize'wiches are a welcome diversion. Sweet, chewy cornbeard with a well simmered bean and tomato filling really hit the spot. The kid ate a whole half a sandwich, which means it must be good. Yucca fries look yummy. Will try on my next visit, which will be soon and with the wife.
author: Mark F.

description:
I have a couple of friends who are allergic to gluten, and so I had heard  their rave reviews about this place before I went. I had been meaning to check it out and hadn't gotten around to it, when suddenly all of my tennis buddies agreed to meet there after a match and I went along. 
     I loved every single thing about Pica Pica from the minute I walked in...great location, great atmosphere, wonderful large windows that open on sunny days so you feel like you're sitting outside, friendly, helpful service, reasonable prices...
    And then there's the food! There is something awesome and amazing about eating regular everyday stuff like sandwiches with the twist that they're made with unique and delicious maize puffy things instead of bread. I had the chicken salad sandwich, a delightful take on a classic with avocado in the mix. The yuca fries were a huge hit at our table, and a team of formerly ravenous tennis players went home feeling satisfied in a happy and healthy way that we just don't get from our usual burgers after the match. I'm going back as soon as I can!
author: kaila m.

description: Add this one to the list of the Mission's tasty + affordable spots.  Had the Maize'wich Pabellon and Maize'wich Chorizo with my wife and we found ourselves trading 'em back and forth for the perfect combo of savory and sweet.  Their use of corn in the maize bread is pretty darn exceptional -- adding extra dimensions of flavor and texture.  The place has a modern and warm feel to it with nods of seemingly re-purposed furniture/fixtures all around.
author: Edric I.

description: So I agree it is tasty, but portions are really small for the price. Like tapas style. It was a disappointing experience overall. For the price 2 sandwiches, fries, one drink and a glass of wine $35, and really service? I had to ask for the wine to be served because they forgot and they really were not really warm and friendly. Not rude either but I just had higher hopes. It's cafeteria style, and you expect to be tipped? Oy maybe that was my mistake for tipping. For the price it wasn't worth it. It's so hip and trendy that there was a air of pretension.
author: Eldar B.

description: YEAH! YEAH FOR GLUTEN FREE! YEAH FOR VENEZUELAN! Everything here is 100% gluten free, according to the sign, so yes, eat here for a gluten-free and possibly dairy free and EVEN meat-free experience, if you're up for that (if you love meat, come here for that too). There are also yuca fries that must be gluten free, because I'm not sick yet. Note: the beer is not GF, but they do have sangria for those of us who drink wine! For vegetarians--the blackbean and tofu combo with fried plantains and avocado!! Good food here. The cornbread really rocks.
author: Hey Y.

description: I found Pica Pica at the wonderful Napa Oxbow artisanal market (vendors carry food, wine, fresh spices, product, ice cream, etc.) and am so excited to find they are in San Francisco!  Their Vegetariana (tofu, avocado, sweet plantain, black beans) comes with the most wonderful spicy orange sauce that tastes like a chipotle in adobo.  I think I order the arepa - the grilled round corn bread that splits in half like pita bread.  They have other fillings that sound delicious, but I can't seem to branch out from what I already love.  I have not been to their place in San Francisco, but their little Napa outpost is fabulous: www.oxbowpublicmarket.com
author: Karen L.

description: A very nice clean small place, a friendly staff, and the only arepas in SF I think.  We have been there 3x and twice did take out for the park ... it was perfect.  this may not be haute cuisine but the food is imaginative, well priced, and very tasty IMO
author: M P.

description: Ummm...yes please!  This is gluten free paradise.  EVERYTHING is delicious and everything is reasonably priced.  If I lived closer, I would be a regular.
author: Chrys F.

description: Just order the other day for my staff. Everyone was loved their food. It was fresh and tasty..
author: Beverly E.

description: Had the chicken salad and empanadas... Super good, large portions!  They need larger water glasses...  Other than that you must check it out...
author: michael c.

description: hard to find food like this elsewhere. i love the arepas + my partner likes the maizewich. i usually order an extra arepa on the side because they're full of such carby goodness. this space is small, so be prepared to wait if you come at peak eating times. they have soup + dessert cookies too (alfajores, i think), but i never have room for that after i'm done w/my arepa.
author: Zoe L.

description: Pica Pica is AMAZING! I used to live in Napa where their first location opened up and am absolutely in love with the place! Great concept, delicious food! My fav is the cheese cachapa with a side of yucca fries (with the melao sauce)! I definitely suggest Pica Pica!!
author: Maya S.

description: My Wife and I first tryed them at carnival 2009 and then again at the 2009 milbrea art and wine fest. I was happy to see that they have opened up shop in the Mission. Its a small corner eatery, very clean and the menu is pretty easy because they have sample dishes you can point at when ordering. We started with a glass of Sangria for the wifeypoo and a tall beer for myself. Then came the food ,Yucca Frita,  Emplanada's filled with Black Beans and Cheese and my Wife had the Maize-wich "Sweet Corn Cake" with shredded pork, tomatoes, Avacado slices and shredded cheese. I myself had the Maize-wich with shredded skirt steak, fried Plaintains, black beans and shredded cheese. I rated Pica Pica a 4 out 5 stars only because of the seating. All in all the 2 of us will be going back to enjoy the food.
author: Christopher V.

description: Love this place!  Would strongly recommend to anyone with Celiac or anyone on a strict gluten-free diet since this place is entirely gluten-free!  (Even have gluten-free beer)!  I've tried a few of their items and everything has been wonderful!  Especially love their yuca fries and sangria!
author: Valerie H.

description: I love this place; however I find it a little bit pricey.  The food is really good including their juices.  It is also a little bit small.
author: Angie R.

description: already out of the meat empanadas, and no cachapas.  argh.  tried a maize-wich (pernil).  the sweet corn cake was grilled nicely and pretty good.  best i've had is in miami, and decent ones in nyc also.  i remember them being at oxbow, and i like the arepas here better than coupa cafe.  since they don't really have any competition, it's a good experience to come here.
author: Rob C.

description: Really excellent addition to the roster of places that deliver to our pad in the Mission!  I've lived here more than 10 years and am bored as hell of the same old pizza, Cambodian, Chinese, and Vietnamese options. And as 2 working parents, takeout is key to our sanity. I understand this is a gluten free resto, and we do love us some gluten, so that wasn't a selling point. But as vegetarians (OK, I'm a pescatarian) we had several options on the Pica Pica menu. When the food came we were wowed by the sauces - though we weren't sure what was supposed to go on what, it just didn't matter. The creamy spicy one, the mustardy spicy one, and the fruity sweet one: all yummy. Wished we'd gotten 2 or 3 orders of the empanadas - tasty little deep fried treats. The Cachapa corn crepe option elevated the sandwich from, well, a sandwich to *dinner."  The website ordering was easy, apart from not being able to find the salsa explanations.  Oh, and our dinner was delivered by bike (love this!) and arrived hot. No question, we will definitely be ordering from Pica Pica again.
author: Shannon D.

description: went here when I visited San Fran over a year ago, stumbled on it today and had to stop and say BEST CAPACHA PEBELLON EVER!!!! his place was perfect..quintessential SF vibe, friendly and prompt staff..oh and last but not least the yuca fries...perfection!
author: Mae s.

description: Absolutely love this place. The food is delicious and could eat the yuca fries all day long! Thank you for being gluten-free!
author: Michele M.

description: i was so disappointed that i didn't get a chance to get arepas in nyc, so i was really happy to find out that an arepas place just opened up in sf.  we came here on sat night around 845, and we ordered and got seats right away.  i got the vegetarian arepa w/ tofu, avocado, plantains, black beans and spicy sauce.  my husband got a maizewich w/ venezuelan scrambled eggs, and then we shared a salad.  everything was delicious, and all the sauces were good.  i loved their signature hot sauce, as well as the passion fruit vinaigrette for the salad and the tamarind sauce.  the arepa was really tasty and the maizewich was just delicious.  the arepa is definitely healthier tasting.  i also want to try the cachapa next time which is like a pancake/omelet w/ your choice of filling inside.
author: Helen T.

description:
Just returned from dinner here.  I went because a vegan blog source mentioned there are vegan options and I'm always looking for great places to go with my omnivore friends.  The food is tasty and it's easy on the brain when it comes to deciding what to order since the menu is tiny (and when you're vegan it's even more limited.)

Both my friend and I had the chachapas, mine was the La Vegetariana and my friend had the La Shuli.  We also had a side order of the Bululu and Sweet Plantains.  The plantains are awesome though probably highly caloric.  My chachapa was ok/good, tofu was nice and tender.  The salad was ok, the dressing was the most interesting part of it - definitely full of passion fruit flavor. 

Why only 3 stars?  I guess I expected (rightly or wrongly) that they would better understand how to "serve" a vegan given the review I had read.  
1) The first statement out of my mouth when I ordered was that I was vegan.  I double checked if the La Vegetariana was vegan and was told yes.  When it arrived - turns out the sauce it comes with is anything but vegan, so though the sandwich was still tasty I felt I was missing something.
2) When the sweet plantains arrived they were covered in cheese.  When I brought this to their attention I was told "it comes with cheese" but when I pointed out that it does not state that on the menu he took it back and made a new batch for us.
3) He had recommended the Aioli sauce to go with the Plantains and since the menu said it was made with "garlic and olive oil" I went with his recommendation.  But when it came out it clearly had some sort of dairy base to it.  Upon questioning it, the waiter was kind enough to go check with the cook and came back with the verdict that it was made with garlic, olive oil, cilantro, pepper.  I sincerely don't believe it, maybe I'm wrong, but I'd bet money there is dairy in the sauce.

So all to say, as a vegan I would have appreciated more accurate assistance in navigating the menu.  To all vegans, be very very clear when ordering, ask specific questions, don't trust that the ingredients listed on the menu are the only ingredients in each dish.  (I personally also dislike cilantro, and nowhere does it say there is cilantro in the aioli.)  Good luck!
author: Q E.
