description: Holy of Holies. Went here a week or so ago and loved it so much. I had an arepa, my honey had a maize 'wich. I had the shredded beef and she had the grilled tofu. Such wonderful flavors, really lively. We also got empanadas - tilapia, bean and cheese, and mixed meat. Splendid. Next time I'll try a lunch special or maybe soup. I'm wheat-free and this placed rocked my world.
author: Esther L.

description: Quite a variety of delicious Venezuelan food. Just like my Venezuelan mom makes it (Devil Ham & Cheese) yum!
author: Chris S.

description: Tasty tasty tasty are 3 words that come to mind for Pica Pica. The space is modern, clean and welcoming. I ordered a white sangria, plantains with aioli and the vegetarian arepa. Their white sangria is the best I've ever had! While it was not strong, it was deliciously flavored with peach juice and had lots of crispy fresh chunks of apple floating at the top. The plantains with aioli were really good, the soft sweet morsels of dense deliciousness paired well with the creamy aioli and salty bits of a feta-like cheese. The veggie arepa was satisfying with grilled tofu, black beans, slices of avocado, more plantains and a spicy cream. The tofu was firm and smokey, and cream was perfectly spicy and moisten'd up the corn exterior. My bf tried the other veggie option which was mostly spiced black beans as a maize'wich, he said it was tasty but it was very very messy. Be warned- the food is deceivingly filling! Cute place for a unique lunch, our total was $30 something.
author: Cori W.

description:
My girlfriend (who is Venezuelan) and I used to frequent this restaurant but when we moved out of the city our visits became less regular. At first we would happily make the drive to eat at one of our favorite spots but we started to notice a decline in the quality of the food. Everything started to taste as if it were frozen, the presentation fell off completely and the food was just not good in general. Ergo, we gave up and assumed this was just another great eatery that fell victim to complacency. On Sunday, we happened to be in the Mission and decided, if for nothing other than nostalgia, we would stop by and grab a bite. And just when I thought the food couldn't be any worse...they totally redeemed themselves!!! I mean the arepas were cooked properly and full of flavor, the empanadas were crispy and fresh, the yucca fries were just plain awesome!!! You even get a small salad with your food (which is supper delicious btw). Not to mention all of the new fresh juices they offer!!! Oh and dessert??? Forget about it...soooo good!

We had a moment to talk to one of the new partners and asked him about the changes. He let us know that they now have fresher ingredients, a new chef, new items, and have revamped the presentations. Thank the food gods!!! One of the best restaurants in SF is back like a vertebrae and dishing up better food that it has ever served before. 

Hands down the best Venezuelan restaurant  in SF. A++++++    Welcome back.
author: Christopher W.

description: Pica Pica is great for the gluten free crowd which now includes part of my family.  They don't have a very diverse menu but what they do have is very good and everything is gluten free.  You don't have to worry about cross contamination or any of that awkward conversing that happens when you start talking to wait staff about gluten.   We have tried just about everything on the menu and were not disappointed with anything.  The space is small but clean.  I'm sure we will be back many times.
author: Josh L.

description: Love it! As an individual with Celiac Disease, I can't tell you how rare it is for me to be able to eat in a restaurant and feel totally safe. Thank you Pica Pica!
author: Jessika W.

description: I think today is the first day of PicaPica SF being open. It's located in what used to be Mi Lindo Yucatan, but has had a facelift. It's clean, but the narrow space makes it very crowded. I had the Maize-wich with the Chicken filling and my bf had the pancakey one with the chicken/avocado filling. They were both very tasty. The service is still getting polished. For example we waited quite a long time, and the wrong cheese was on my order, and there were no utensils or napkins given. It came to over $25 for those two dishes, which were pretty small, and two sodas. I think that is overly expensive for a Latin-American style lunch in the Mish. Anyway, I would go back and try some other things because it certainly was tasty. And looking forward to the hot chocolate as well. It was totally overrun by hipsters of course, but that makes me ask myself, "am I not a hipster?" . I was wearing an organic cotton Prairie Underground hoodie. Ouch.
author: Darcy V.

description: This place was awesome.  The place was clean, the staff was nice and the food was delicious!  When we ordered we asked about one of their drinks and the man went to check that the ingredients were vegan, and he was very patient with my terrible pronunciation of the food.  The vegan sandwich is soooo good.  I was a little disappointed that there were no yuca fries, but we had a side of plantains.  And their coconut milk lemonade is additive.  I left feeling happy and satisfied.  I will be back!
author: S B.

description: This is supposed to be a vezuelan food place? Well it feels a lot more like a Mexican joint that serves ok arepas and really bad empanadas. I lived in Venezuela for most of my life and the empanadas there were alway hot, crispy and they were thin too. The empanadas here were all soggy tiny and really thick. Does the chef need cooking lesson? If so call me. The cachapa was filled like a taco, and it was extremely oily. In Venezuela cachapas are made thinner, with queso fresco, I've never seen a cachapa with avocado and rice, etc. They are trying too hard to make each dish into a full meal. Most the dishes they serve there are meant to be snacky foods, so just charge less and stick to original recipies.  The arepa wasn't all that good either. The masa was correct, but otherwise we don't really use avocados in Venezuela for arepas. What happened to hot dogs with salsa rosada or carne mechada or simple hamon y queso. Hay Dios este no un lugar venezolano. Stay away and wait for the real stuff or buy a ticket to Miami and get some real food
author: R Y.

description: I can't believe it's not gluten.  How do they make arepas so doughy and delicious without wheat gluten?  It is a mystery to me, but I will keep going and recommend the restaurant to all my gluten-free friends.
author: John F.

description: Exactly what I imagined, savory sweet plaintains in a corn masa with a few mix-ins.  Super cheap and filling.  Fries are awesome too with their dipping sauces.  They're at Off the Grid too.
author: Danielle B.

description: Pica Pica has dissapointed me. At first, I  was very excited to hear that there was going to be a Venezuelan restaurant in San Francisco. The first 5 times I went there I really enjoyed their quality food. Even though I thought it was kind of expensive, I didn't hesitate to pay for the super tasty chachapas, pabellon arepas, passion fruit juice, platains or yuca. It became one of my fav restaurants in the mission, but then they changed cooks and the food lowered its quality completely . I am Venezuelan and I can tell anyone how tasty  pabellon and reina pepiada arepas are. Pica Pica aperas and cachapas are now way too far to taste as good as the real Venezuelan food. After a while away from Pica Pica, I decided to go back last Sunday, and sadly I have to say that it has gotten even worse. I ordered a pork arepa and a side of yuca with guasacaca. The pork wasn't fresh, the yuca was just ok, but the guasacaca was plain guacamole, so thinking that I got the wrong order, I asked the waitress to changed it for guasacaca, and she said that what I got was guasacaca. I felt dissapointed because there is a big different between guasacaca and guacamole. The only thing nice here is the staff. They are friendly, but other than that there is noting else nice about this place. I hope the owner decides to do something about it.
author: Caro R.

description: the salad dressing was too fruity, too sweet and too thick. i had the palbellon and was expecting the flavors to be something magical in my mouth but i wasn't impressed at all. the meat was bland. the empanadas looked super small. i think you're paying way too much for what you get here.
author: elsie k.

description: The only reason I'm not giving Pica Pica 5 stars is because the portion size is a little small and it does get a little pricey for counter food. I totally appreciate the gluten free factor - THANK YOU! The owners are lovely and I want to support them 100%. I actually found the food slightly better at the Napa location. Looking forward to Pica Pica opening in the Castro!
author: Des R.

description: Found this place while wandering down Valencia street and was not disappointed.  Its is bit on the pricy side for what it is IMO but they have great fresh ingredients and the salads are a good sized portion.  The second time I was there I had the spicy potato soup and that was great as well.
author: Sun Y.

description: This place is good, I've been there twice and had two similar experiences. The food took a little longer than I would have liked to come. Flavors are fun and unique. As others have noted my biggest complaint is that there seems to be excess oil on the food. But the yucca fries are awesome, and it's fun to be able to pick a dipping sauce!
author: Holly S.

description: This is my very first Yelp review and it is a sad one!  2 beers, 3 "sandwiches", side salad-$44. Very doughy, meat no flavor, sauces were boring, not fresh and didn't taste good. I am shocked to see people in San Francisco like this place with all the amazing places to eat! I felt gross after I left...as if I had eaten bad fast food.
author: Sasha L.

description:
My first experience with arepas, a Venezuelan corn cake,  and I will be going back for more.
Toasty/chewy on the outside, something like Salvadoran pupusas, but very light and fluffy inside. Pica Pica splits and fills them with a variety of meats and veggies - I tried the shredded beef with plantain, black beans and quesa fresco. I wasn't even sure I was going to be able to handle it without a knife and fork, but although it was overflowing with filling the arepa is sturdy - the perfect street food! 
The beef was tender with a nice kick of spice, very little heat and the sweetness of the plantains was a great compliment. 
Also had the Yuca fries, very good, much better than any fried yuca I've had and served with their own spicy ketchup.
Washed it down with a Cock & Bull ginger beer, one of my favorites. 
I'll definitely be going back when I'm in the neighborhood, (or in Napa) and consider this an invitation to open a place in the east bay!
author: David D.

description:
-service is well meaning but slow.. they opened their doors @ 12.:08 about, begrudgingly it seemed altho the door said open @ noon. gotta be precise @ lunchtime!
-salad was just plain bad. didn't really make sense, pineapple chunks are ill advised w/ greens, dressing way too sweet.
-shrimp empanadas are good & greasy.
-arepas stuffed w/ meat options, are, well, meaty.
not as spicy as i thought it would be, even those little pitchers of peppers & garlic didn't pack as much of a punch as it should.
-shoulda ordered yucca fries - they're gorgeous stacked & smelled divine. 
might go again if the kids insist.
author: Kim Y.

description:
love pica pica, we found them at the maker's faire last year and went back for them this year!  and then i found out they have a restuarant in the city!  will definitely be going there for decadent food - definitely not healthy food.

i liked the pulled pork better than the steak beef ones. ;)
author: tc h.

description: My girlfriend and I were in The Mission and I decided to try Pica Pica since I had heard good things and my GF is gluten-free. I had the pabellon arepa and it was amazing. I'm Central American, so the ingredients sounded amazing. Black beens, skirt state, plantains, and cheese. I wasn't so sure about the cheese, but everything else sounded delicious. I was not disappointed. This was delicious. Being San Francisco in summer, it was a little cold outside. This warm sandwich was perfect for the weather. It filled me up without over doing it. My GF and I shared an order of yuca fries, which are as good as you've heard. I didn't find any negatives at this place and plan to go back often.
author: N B.

description: One word: YUM! Came here to grab a quick bite after having a few mimosas at Andalu and was NOT disappointed. Menu is super easy - you just order what bread you want and what goes inside and there's your (venezuelan?) gluten-free sandwich! I ordered the arepa which is sort of like a spongy dough-y pancake but not really sweet, with the filling of pabellon - shredded beef, fried plantains, beans. They have sauces for you to use at the tables, and I chose the sour cream+chile one - uber delicious, went perfectly with the sandwich and had a nice kick to it. Even the little salad on the side was fantastic with that flavorful passion fruit dressing. My friend ordered yucca fries and I've got to say I've had those from a Peruvian food truck before and these definitely topped the list. Absolutely yummy and go perfectly with any of those sauces on the table. I basically scarfed down the sandwich and will definitely be back for more! Location is pretty close all the other great stuff Mission has to offer, definitely noisy and cramped inside but food is so worth it.
author: Olga S.

description: did not know this place existed two blocks from my house. had the pabellon arepa and garlic yuca fries, AMAZING!!!
author: Star C.

description: Yes, this place is gluten-free and I am gluten intolerant, so I admit that this review may be tainted by my overwhelming joy that a gluten free restaurant opened 4 blocks from where I live. But I think their food is stellar regardless of its glutenity (I just made that word up). The arepas are the next best think to real middle eastern pitas, and let's face it, who doesn't like fried plantains in their pita?? Also, I was really not a fan of yucca fries before this place, since they are usually a stringy chewy oily mess. But pica's fries are deliciously crispy and soft at the same time. Awesome.
author: Y T.

description: Finally tried Pica Pica Maize after reading the reviews.  Tried the arepa with creamy chicken salad.  Does not compare to Caracas, Arepa Bar in the East Village of Manhattan.  That was the first time I ever had an arepa and have been looking for some here in SF ever since.  Next time you're in NYC, stop by Caracas, 93 East Seventh St. and see for yourself.
author: Mabel C.

description: A friend spent a year in Venezuela and came back complaining about the heavy, similar, underspiced food--and now I understand why Venezuelan food isn't sweeping the nation.  I don't need gluten free, and I found the corn wrapper to be overly dense and hard to cut into, let alone palate.  The plantains and the empanadas were saturated in oil and otherwise pretty flavorless.  I also found the menu and decor sort of corporate, Chipotle-esque.
author: Malena W.

description:
After waiting for some of the comparative newness to wear off, I went to Pica Pica yesterday. It's small, sparse and clean. I walked in a few minutes before it got busier, around 2:30. 
I ordered a vegetarian maize-wich, pasapalos de yuca and a drink, and the total was a little over $15. The cashier was totally icy. 
I scored one of the of the small tables before a large group walked in. Somebody plonked down my order and vanished. The sandwich was barely warm and quite honestly, it was boring. It contained one wedge of avocado, one square tofu patty, two 1/3 slices of platano maduro, and approximately two tablespoons of frijoles negros, which were absolutely bland. 
I'm from San Juan, and I've tasted plenty of cachapas and arepas in Caracas. The only thing that I can think is that the vegetarian presentation is more of an after-thought. I also noticed that the meat sandwiches are considerably larger than what I was served. I'm not a food glutton, but I couldn't help but notice the discrepancy.
Yuca is a common feature in my part of the world, and while I've never been a fan of it - I prefer yautia (taro), I will say that the yuca was good because it was crunchy, almost as though it had been twice-fried like a European-style french fry. The sauce that accompanied it was bland.
Over all; I found the un-engaging service and the blandness a losing combination. Pica Pica was way too "come y vete" for my taste.
author: Ramón B.

description: Fresh and flavorful!  We tried all three corn breads-the thicker, corn bread style Maize'wich was my favorite.  The corn was sweet and the bread was fluffy.  The vegetarian filling had slices of avo, tofu and lightly carmelized plantains.  Mmmm.  The Yuca fries were crispy on the outside, soft on the inside and perfect for dipping in the thick garlic aoli or smoky black bean paste.  We'll be back.  Alot.
author: Marisssa M.

description: If you have celiac disease, run, do not walk to Pica Pica Maize Kitchen, and give them your support.  Here is a place where for the first time in the 1.5 years since my diagnosis, I was able to fully relax and enjoy a restaurant meal without worrying about getting sick.  That state of mind might have colored my appreciation for the food, but everything was  delicious - interesting and novel combinations of flavors and ingredients that were very satisfying.   This place is now my default destination - make it yours to insure their success!   Thank you Pica Pica!
author: Bob C.

description: If you wish to pay $8.50 for $1.50 of ingredients, and have bland, uninteresting food in TINY portions, this is the place for you.  My wife and I had the Arepa with #2 filling ($8.50 with tax), the $9.00 sweet corn pancake with vegetarian filling, the #1 salad, and the Yucca fries.  The amount and quality of the filling in the Arepa was laughable.  In general, the portions were so small and the food was so bland, it made me feel disrespected as a consumer.  The only OK part of the meal were the Yucca fries, which were pretty good.  That doesn't excuse the rest of the meal or the outrageous prices.  If your eating choices are limited on account of being gluten-intolerant you and have money to burn, you might consider eating here.  I appreciate that people requiring this special type of diet need a place to go, but I don't believe that this, on its own, should be the basis for a four or five star review.  Anyone looking for a good meal at a fair price look elsewhere.  There is a dozen better choices in the Mission, in terms of both taste and value.
author: Alex V.

description: love this place. great food, great prices, nice and casual try the yucca fries or arepa with beef filling==yum yum
